Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 07:26PM leaf wrote: I've never had a cyst, or breast pain (except during/after breast procedures).  It is good that you are getting this checked out.  However, a) The most common symptom of breast cancer is a painLESS lump.  Now breast cancer can have a variety of symptoms, including breast pain and lump.   b) While its good that you are getting this checked out, most breast lumps, particularly in women your age, are benign.  Breast pain is actually fairly common, and often its hard to find the cause of the pain.  www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea...  Breast lumps can end up being cysts (which are usually picked up by ultrasound), or a solid but benign growth called a fibroadenoma.  Cysts and fibroadenomas are almost always benign.   But its good that you are getting this checked out.  There are some people here who have had a wide variety of symptoms before their breast cancer was detected, or no symptoms at all.   The breast surgeon will decide whether or not this is suspicious enough to biopsy or have further imaging.  Remember, particularly in younger women, about 80% of biopsies in the USA turn out to be benign.  If you are convinced there is something wrong, then insist on a  biopsy.  If your lump is palpable, they can probably do a needle biopsy at your office visit.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 03:09AM leaf wrote: I had my first biopsy 12-05, which triggered an excision 1-06 (for LCIS and nothing worse.  This is not common, so don't expect that.)  I certainly felt hard areas of my breast for several months afterwards.  I made an appointment with the nurse practitioner in 3-06 because I wasn't sure how to do a BSE after surgery. Instead, she did an exam and said there was a slight change in nipple direction, so ordered a sono.  I had my 6 mo sono (which had grown) and mammo.  At 7 months I started tamoxifen. At my 12 month sono (it had shrank) and mammo, they said I needed 2 biopsies, one in the  sono area they were concerned about, and the other of new calcifications.  Both ended up being benign, the sono one was 'consistent with' scar tissue. Later I had a 2nd opinion at a major institution and they said I had too much scar tissue to consider having an MRI. The 'bumps'/hardness slowly resolved, so BSEs are about what they were before my first biopsy.  (I have smooth breasts.) It took about 9 months for everything to get back to normal.  (I had  some bleeding during the 2nd biopsy and they had to compress me for 2 hours.)

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2017 04:05PM leaf wrote: I have classic LCIS, which is farther down the path as ALH. (I also have ALH.) Both ALH and LCIS are sometimes/often classified together as 'lobular neoplasm'. But, just about everything concerning LCIS, thus probably ALH, is controversial. So don't be shocked if you get different opinions from different doctors. I am not sure whether or not you have had the spot surgically excised. If you haven't you may want to strongly consider that. (Up to Date, a reference, said its a 'standard of care' for ALH found on a biopsy to have it excised.) But, this too is probably controversial. The reason why they often like to excise is not to remove the ALH, or 'all the ALH', because its likely there are multiple spots of ALH in your breast or breasts, but to make sure there isn't something more concerning going on, like DCIS or invasive breast cancer, which is treated differently. Roughly 10-20% of the time these things are upgraded on surgical excision. If you don't want to take tamoxifen, there are other anti-estrogen medications that can be used if you are postmenopausal. They have a somewhat different adverse effect profile. Also, I wouldn't take the number of posts in a forum as indicating how frequently a particular adverse effect happens. It is well known that people who have an adverse effect post MUCH more than people who don't have an adverse effect. Studies are a much more reliable source for suggesting how often a particular adverse effect happens. There is also the option of simply watchful waiting. If you are at higher risk, then some women opt for prophylactic bilateral mastectomies. You may want to consider getting genetically evaluated - to see if you/your insurance will pay for genetic testing, if you're interested in that. If you have a significant genetic defect, this may affect your treatment decisions. 'High' risk is relative. I have seen papers that claim that LCIS women are not at high risk, and LCIS is more advanced than ALH. Probably LCIS women (and nothing else) have less than a 50% chance of getting breast cancer in their lifetime. It is normally thought that ALH women have a lower breast cancer risk than LCIS women. If you have more risk factors that does NOT NECESSARILY mean that you are at higher risk. (BRCA mutations may be an exception.) Lots is unknown regarding lobular neoplasia. Breast risk calculators are not necessarily accurate for an individual; all of the ones I know of say that they 'should not be used to make clinical decisions' because, while they may be accurate for a population (for example, they might be able to accurately say that, say, about 300 women in a population of 100,000 (I'm making these numbers up - so they're probably drastically wrong) will get breast cancer, they do NOT say which individual particular women will get breast cancer - that Janine, Nina, Abigail, Tamika, Emma and 295 other women will get breast cancer in their lifetime (making up women's names.)

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2017 03:49AM - edited Dec 1, 2017 03:52AM by leaf I had a large hematoma from my excision. It took something like 6 months to go away, and turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal colors (black, purple, green, yellow.) It takes time for the body to re-absorb heme and iron. But it only looked horrible; it wasn't painful. Since the hematoma is coagulated blood, thus contains iron, a heavy metal, it shows up on mammograms. They may not be able to clearly see your 2nd cluster of microcalcs in mammograms if your hematoma covers that area. It sure would be nice if they explained their reasoning or plan to you. Yes, I have a 2nd breast excision scheduled for mid-Jan. 2018. I doubt they would put me back on an antihormonal, unless they find something worse like DCIS or invasive breast cancer. (I had 5 years of tamoxifen.) I did have benign cervical polyps every 18 months or so when on tamoxifen. LCIS is almost always multifocal, so there are probably other spots of ALH and LCIS in my breasts. Strange that they should want an oncologists' opinion. They (the oncologist) aren't the ones that would be doing the surgery. Maybe it was reviewed by a person who didn't know much about breast cancer. (I have heard that sometimes/often they have RNs reviewing claims.) Once I went to a conference about infectious diseases, and the infectious disease head (of course an MD) wanted to use very expensive antibiotic X. The insurance company wrote back and wanted him to use cheap, inexpensive antibiotic Y. The MD wrote back to the insurance company that the cultured bacteria was resistant to antibiotic Y, which was why he wanted to use antibiotic X because it was the only antibiotic that the bacteria was sensitive to.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2017 05:57AM leaf wrote: You're right - there isn't much info about LCIS and ALH. They are unusual conditions, though they cannot estimate how many women in the general population have them because you need a breast biopsy to diagnose them. Many women have never had a breast biopsy. Many studies have less than 100 patients, and they often combine ALH with ADH with LCIS to get groups large enough to study. As far as alternatives, for example, in this study of about 1000 women, exemestane in this study did NOT have an increased incidence of thromboembolism but did have an increased risk of joint stiffness, arthralgia and osteoporosis. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22855103 (There are other antihormonals too.) I certainly hope you can get your insurance to cover an oncology visit, and get this handled to your satisfaction. I'm having my breast excision done by a general surgeon (I imagine they're less expensive than a breast surgeon, but what do I know?) Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 10:50PM - edited Oct 21, 2009 10:52PM by leaf We all know how awful it is to go through this diagnostic process.  Its very hard to deal with the unknown.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead. Your mammogram report is very factually stating what they say on your mammogram.  So if it was a photo of your face, they would be describing your skeletal structure, the shape and color of your eyes, nose, mouth, your complexion, the presence of any moles or freckles, etc.  The more 'negative' imaging you have, the better.  Looking at a mammogram is like looking at a clear balloon that has writing on it, from the opposite side of the balloon.  If the writing is on the edge of the balloon, it can be hard to read. They are asking for the MRI because they don't feel the mammogram and ultrasound were conclusive. MRIs are usually quite sensitive.  That means they usually pick up cancer, but they can also pick up a lot of benign stuff, like inflammation. It takes skill to interpret MRIs. Many women feel distraction helps.  I couldn't do things I enjoyed,but I could do things I hated.  Some people feel going out with friends, or seeing a light comedy helps.   If things are really awful, some people go to their doctor (typically their General Practitioner) to get a prescription for an anti-anxiety medication. Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2010 05:28AM leaf wrote: After my excision, I had strange sensation (usually electrical-like sensations) for months afterwards.  I had hard areas near the incision for months afterwards. I had a hematoma, so my breast turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal shades like black, purple, green and yellow for several weeks/months afterwards.  After about 9-12 months, it all went away and faded into a slightly pink scar.  Occasionally, I had some sharp, shooting pains, which gradually decreased with time.  Its now been 5 years, and I can't remember any shooting pains at all for the last 3 years or so. I was crying at home and at work periodically throughout this diagnosis process.   Its perfectly normal to be scared of a potentially serious diagnosis.  We all want to be ready for whatever is on our path ahead of us. Take a deep breath.  For me, intense exercise helped.  Other people find other distractions useful. We will be here, no matter what the outcome.  Feel free to vent or ask questions.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 11:28AM - edited Sep 27, 2008 11:30AM by leaf The most common symptom of breast cancer is a painLESS lump.  But unfortunately, breast cancer doesn't read our textbooks, and the symptoms of breast cancer do vary.  No one on this big green earth can diagnose a person with breast cancer before looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. Some women have a lump, painless or painful, some have a thickening, some have an inverted nipple, some have changes in their mammogram or ultrasound, some have a dimpled area or change in breast shape, some have a breast discharge. Wishing you just a brief stay here at this site.  In this study, the number of women who had breast cancer with a negative mammogram and a unilateral bloody or serous discharge was about 3%    http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18005783 I'm sure different studies differ. Good for you for following through and getting it checked out!  Let us know how it goes, OK? Wishing you boringly normal results. If you're going through hell, keep going-Winston Churchill

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 01:50AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:34PM by leaf Well, I don't think there are any breast surgeons or radiologists that openly post here.  So we certainly can't diagnose you. The radiology report just is plainly stating what they see on the imaging.  For example, if they had a photo of your face, they'd be describing the shape of your face, and the color and texture of your hair, and eye color, etc.  They are describing in very precise terms (though we can't understand them :-)) what your imaging looks like: where there are dark spots and where there are light spots. The words that have 'echoic' in them are describing whether or not sound waves (from the ultrasound) were bouncing off of the lesion.  They are NOT saying that you have breast cancer in Greek or Latin. Cysts are almost always benign. BIRADS is a system that rates breast imaging.  Here's a link to BIRADS scores.  A chart is in yellow about half way down the website on the left.  Its probably more than you ever wanted to know. http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4349108442109#a43db92b2e8101 If you want to go to a 2nd opinion, you certainly can.  I think 2nd opinions are always helpful: even if you disagree with them,you are always getting more information. But I don't think there is any rush in doing so, especially if this will cost you several hundred dollars extra.  (When I had a 2nd opinion, it took about 2 months and they still messed up co-ordinating things.  But you are in a different situation.) If you were NOT anxious, then I'd be wondering if you were in DeNile.  Of course you are anxious. Anybody in their right mind would be anxious. Unfortunately, there is little in breast cancer (or for that matter, cancer in general) that is 100% sure.   But your radiologist did rate your imaging as 'probably benign'.  That is good. If you are going to get a 2nd opinion, though, I think it would be best to go to a breast surgeon, who is the expert at diagnosing things, or a radiologist who specializes in breast conditions.  A general surgeon is an expert at doing surgery all over one's body, so usually won't be an expert on breasts.  Even ****IF**** your radiologist is completely wrong, and you do have breast cancer, know that most breast cancers are fairly slow growing.  Most breast cancers have been growing for some 4-10 years (not a typo) before its big enough to be detected by ANY means (including feel, mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.)   So while you may be a psych patient by the time you feel you get confident of your diagnosis, it probably won't matter as far as your medical condition goes. Some people feel distraction helps with the anxiety.  (There are a variety of distractions that help different people, including exercise, housework, retail therapy, meditation, religion - if you are into that, a favority hobby, etc.) If that isn't sufficient, then some people choose to go to their GP and get some anti-anxiety meds. We're here for you!  Feel free to vent or ask questions.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 04:05AM - edited Dec 27, 2008 11:34AM by leaf My problem was that I couldn't find any guestimates about my risk for LCIS - having a weak family history, LCIS, ALH and nothing worse.  (This occured before the LCIS forum, below, was created.) The main gist of the thread was that I found out how poorly we can predict breast cancer - we really do not know what causes it.   We can fairly accurately predict how many women in a town in the United States or Florence, Italy may get breast cancer, but we have very little idea WHICH of these women will get breast cancer.    In the meantime, bc.org updated their estimates of risk for LCIS - to about  30-40% lifetime risk by one estimate, or, in another estimate, increases the breast cancer risk to 21% over the next 15 years. www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...  .  (Most LCIS is diagnosed in the 40-50 year old age group.) They also updated the LCIS  treatment options. http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/types/lcis/treatment.jsp Has anyone participated in clinical trials for LCIS and nothing worse? The ones I can find are: Soy Protein Supplement In Treating Hot Flashes in Postmenopausal Women Receiving Tamoxifen for Breast Disease Exemestane in Treating Postmenopausal Women at High Risk for Invasive Breast Cancer Letrozole in Preventing Breast Cancer in Postmenopausal Women Possibly for LCIS women who have had surgery  Infliximab in Treating Cancer-Related Fatigue in Postmenopausal Women Who Have Undergone Treatment for Stage 0, Stage I, or Stage II Breast Cancer Atorvastatin in Preventing Breast Cancer in Women at Increased Risk for Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2010 09:59AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:26AM by leaf Well, if only your great grandma had bc, and assuming no one  had ovarian cancer, then you wouldn't meet the USPTF guidelines for BRCA testing.   Calcifications are extremely common.  Most calcifications are NOT worrisome, but some patterns are. These sites may be helpful:http://www.uspreventiveservicestaskforce.org/uspstf05/brcagen/brcagenrs.htm#clinical http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 If you do ask for an MRI, I would check to see if it will be covered by insurance.  There are women with LCIS (which definitely puts them at higher risk), and dense breasts, and their insurance would not cover.  It can cost over $1K.  Since it was not covered, they have to pay out of pocket.  I just don't want you to have unexpected expenses. I get the impression that breast density means what your breast looks like under a mammogram, and not how it feels.  I have very soft breasts, I have never had a lump, and I was told by the radiologist I have 'dense, but not extremely dense' breasts. Of course, having lumpy, ropey breasts makes them a lot harder to examine.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 03:36AM leaf wrote: Of course you are nervous.  Anyone would be nervous. I am glad you are getting them biopsied so they can check you out. Lymph nodes can be a sign of breast cancer, but they can be a sign of other things.  You have prominent lymph nodes when you have an infection of some kind, for example. It is thought that breast biopsies (unlike some other cancers) do NOT spread cancer, or if they do, it is a VERY small incidence.  Cancerous cells CAN be spread to other tissues along the needle track, but it is thought they either a) die on their own -breast cancer cell growth is thought to be influenced by its neighbors.  A single breast cancer cell often does not grow, where a group of breast cancer cells might grow. b) are killed with radiation or removed by mastectomy and/or c) killed by chemotherapy.   IF you do have breast cancer, get whatever the standard therapy is. Many women here think distraction helps with the anxiety.  I think all of us were very anxious when they were getting diagnosed.  If it gets too bad, then you may consider asking for anti-anxiety meds.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 04:41PM - edited Feb 9, 2009 04:42PM by leaf The most common symptom of breast cancer is a painless lump.  However, some people do get a painful lump. Some women have no lumps.  Some have a 'thickening'.  Some have an inverted nipple, or a change in nipple direction.  Some have a breast that looks inflammed, and can look like a dimpled orange peel. Some have a nipple discharge.  Some have lumps in the armpit or around their clavicle. Some have no symptoms at all. Many of these same symptoms can be from benign things.  Good for you for getting any breast changes checked out! Its natural to be scared when there is the SLIGHTEST possibility of breast cancer.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead.  Feel free to ask question or vent.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 04:23PM leaf wrote: I would say it depends on your personality, and the personality of the people you tell.  If I were able to do it again, I certainly would not tell anyone at work, even though I was crying at work.  But that's just me.   I got my breast excision at the place I work, at a hospital.  The night before my excision, essentially a male stranger told me he recommended that I have bilateral mastectomies.  I had a difficult time with a part of the breast excision procedure.  The next morning, when I shared this with some co-workers, they replied they wouldn't have made the decision I made.  They never had gone through it themselves, but a neighbor had breast cancer.  So they thought they knew all about it.   For that, and for my other various subsequent diagnoses, I now have an alias for my medical care at work.  When another co-worker had a baby, one co-worker asked if she had a vaginal or C-section delivery.  I told him I didn't know, but both mother and baby were well.  That's all I needed to know. He replies, "Well, don't you want to know?<whether she had a vaginal or C-section>"  I said, "No, not unless she tells me herself."  Do you think that changed his attitude?  I don't think so. The co-workers I have told at work, I have told them I will personally 'boil them in oil' if they reveal my medical information to others. There was one poster here whose breast surgeon told her boss that when she was having a mastectomy that she got suicidal.  After recovery from the surgery, her boss would not hire her back.  Thus she lost her health insurance; she was single.  I know this was a breach of confidentiality, but after she lost her job she had no income so couldn't bring charges. So, unless you have very thick skin, and only tell very reliable people, I would think more than once who and when you tell them.  You can't 'undo' telling people.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2010 05:11AM leaf wrote: Of course, we all want to be safe, so its natural to be scared.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead. If you want some numbers, in this study, invasive breast cancer was diagnosed in 5% of the patients whose chief complaint was a nipple discharge. Three-hundred and thirteen patients presented with nipple discharge as their primary complaint. Invasive breast carcinoma was diagnosed by Triple Assessment <(clinical, radiological and cytological evaluation)>in 5% of patients. 24% of patients presenting with nipple discharge underwent nipple aspiration and cytological analysis. Duct cytology was diagnostic of the underlying breast carcinoma in 50% of triple assessment diagnosed carcinoma. Four risk factors were identified as having a significant association with breast carcinoma, these included (a) age >50 years (p < 0.0001), (b) bloody nipple discharge (p < 0.008), (c) presence of a breast lump (p < 0.0001) and (d) single duct discharge (p < 0.006).http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20709281 I know numbers don't always help because your mind in the middle of the night goes, "Well, what if I'm one of the 5%?  What if I'm one of the 1 in xx?"  Its a very understandable thought.  We all go there when it is possible to have a serious illness, no matter how small the risk. Holding out my hand to you.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 02:14PM leaf wrote: Hi there.  I assume your numbers mean your creatinine clearance.  To very accurately measure your creatinine clearance, they would need to do a 24 hour collection of your urine.  This is rarely done.  They normally use an equation to estimate your creatinine clearance.   It is a function of age, so as you age your clearance goes down. Many medications can cause kidney insults, including SOME chemotherapy.  Do you have hypertension or diabetes? I knew one young women who had kidney failure at age 22, and had hypertension.. During major physical stress, like in the intensive care unit, probably the 2 organs that are the most sensitive are the lungs and the kidneys.   The person who knows the most about kidneys and how to preserve as much kidney function as possible is the nephrologist.?Maybe you would like a specilialist review your diseases/medications to see if there is anything that could be improved? Here's more about chronic kidney failure from the Mayo. www.mayoclinic.com/health/kidn...

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2013 06:11AM leaf wrote: ALH is atypical lobular hyperplasia, and ADH is atypical ductal hyperplasia.  Lobules are where the milk is produced.  Ducts carry the milk from the lobules to the nipple.  Here is a rough analogy.  Lobules are like dead end streets.  Ducts are the streets that connect the dead end streets to the freeway (nipple).  A certain type of cell (epithelial cells) line the streets-both dead end streets and regular streets.  Unlike a usual city, it is thought that the streets (ducts)  intertwine, but they don't intersect. (We don't know if the lobules intersect.) These epithelial cells are like cars that line the street.  The sidewalks are like the basement membrane that separate the epithelial cells from the rest of the breast tissue.  When you have totally normal ducts and lobules, there is only one single layer of cars that line the streets.  There is no double parking.  If you have lots of double parking, then this is like hyperplasia.  If the cars look beat up, then that makes them 'atypical'.  None of the cars (atypical cells) are crossing the sidewalk (the basement membrane) to get into the driveways or garages.  If the cars drove through the sidewalks, then that would be 'invasive breast cancer'.   But in ALH and ADH, you have several layers of beat up cars that line the streets.  In LCIS - lobular carcinoma in situ-  (which is thought to be a more advanced case of ALH) the beat up cars fill up the dead-end streets, but they don't cross the sidewalk.  In DCIS  - ductal carcinoma in situ - (which is thought to be a more advanced case of ADH), these atypical cells also fill up the ducts.  There are many more types of DCIS  than LCIS.   (These 'subtypes' of DCIS and LCIS are thought to have different 'personalities' - some are fairly mild and would never progress to anything worse, and others more aggressive.) They are doing an excision of the area to help make sure there isn't anything worse in the area.   For ALH, ADH, and LCIS, if you have atypical cells at the margin of where the surgeon cuts, they usually don't re-excise and try to get it all out.  If you have DCIS or anything worse (in other words invasive breast cancer), they usually re-excise to remove most/all of the abnormal cells.  They don't try to excise all the LCIS because there are normally many spots of LCIS in a breast, and they would have no way of knowing where they are in a breast without doing a mastectomy.  If you are BRCA positive, then that would be much more of a risk factor than would the condition of ALH, ADH, LCIS, or at least most if not all cases of DCIS would confer.  (I don't know that much about DCIS since I don't have it.)  These are the guidelines that the US preventative task force have come out with for BRCA testing. www.uspreventiveservicestaskfo...   If you have an unusual family pattern, such as one of your parents were an only child, or your father's mother had breast cancer but she only had sons, then you may need evaluation by a geneticist.  Only about 2% of the general population meet the USPTF guidelines.  Those that do not have a low probability of having a deleterious BRCA mutation. To give you some idea, I have classic LCIS, the most benign type, with a low risk family history.  (I have 1 paternal grandmother who had breast cancer, 2 maternal aunts who had breast cancer, all these were post-menopausal - after the age of 50.  No ovarian cancer.)  My lifetime risk of breast cancer (which would include an additional diagnosis of DCIS or invasive breast cancer) is about 30%.  There is a lot of uncertainty about this number - one 2nd opinion said my risk was somewhere between 10% and 60% but it was probably much closer to 10% than 60%.  Every paper I've read says that ALH and/or ADH confer less risk for breast cancer than LCIS.   Remember that about 12% of the general population of women in the USA are predicted to get breast cancer sometime in their lifetime.  Women with a deleterious BRCA gene are thought to have a 35-84% lifetime chance of getting breast cancer.  Note these numbers are not the women that *die* of breast cancer; its the number that get breast cancer.  Overall, most (the majority) of women who do get breast cancer end up dying of something OTHER THAN breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2008 11:37AM leaf wrote: Yes, cysts could be the entire cause of your pain.  The ultrasound shows several cysts.  Cysts, particularly simple cysts (simple cysts are like small sacs of fluid), are almost always benign and do not put you at higher risk for breast cancer.  Many women opt to get them aspirated (drained), particularly if large, not because they might be cancer, but because draining them relieves pressure (which may be causing the pain). Also when you drain a cysts, then you can feel behind the cyst to make sure there isn't something behind the cyst. I've never had cysts, but there are some experts here, like Bessie, who know a lot about cysts.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 02:27AM leaf wrote: Its totally understandable that you are scared.  Anybody would be scared in your position. If I were you, I'd ask for a copy of your pathology report.  I know you are scared because your mom died of breast cancer, but since she was postmenopausal at diagnosis, that makes it less likely any breast condition you *might* have would be due to a single inherited gene  (most commonly BRCA1 or BRCA2).  Depending on your family history, you may not even qualify for BRCA testing. Remember, only about 15% of breast cancers are thought to be due to single gene inheritable conditions. If you have 'slightly atypical cells', then to me that suggests you do not even have ADH or ALH (which would normally be at least described as atypical, not slightly atypical.)  They won't be able to tell you *your* risk of breast cancer, but they may be able to describe the risk of breast cancer for many people who are like you.  If they will commit to a number like this, it will be a very inexact number, because its very hard to predict the risk of breast cancer for one particular person. They are doing the surgical biopsy to see if there is anything worse in the area.  Different studies differ, but for example, if you have FEA, then this study found about a 10% chance of it being upgraded to something worse.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22...  That means that 90% of these patients did NOT have anything worse.  Those aren't bad odds. I know this won't stop you from worrying, but your odds are good that there will be nothing worse going on.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 09:54AM - edited Feb 11, 2009 09:56AM by leaf Calcifications means there is some stuff that contains calcium.  Usually these are seen in mammograms. Calcifications are VERY common.  Most of them are benign.  This is a great site about calcifications, probably more than you ever wanted to know. http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 If your docs want you to get more imaging or biopsy because of your calcifications-then I'd strongly encourage you to do it.  Take care of yourself.  Most calcifications are NOT due to cancer, but its good to get them checked out. IF they find something of concern with calcifications, most commonly they are associated with DCIS, which is usually described as a stage 0 cancer, or some people describe it as a pre-cancer.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2013 08:57AM leaf wrote: There is very little that is absolute in breast cancer.  In other words, its certainly possible that breast pain means one has breast cancer; its also possible one will die from a car accident today.   Except possibly for the rare inflammatory breast cancer (which you don't have the normal symptoms for), you can't be diagnosed with breast cancer without  a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. That said, breast pain is quite common.  This is a blurb from Mayo Clinic. www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea... It sounds like often they can't find a cause of breast pain, but its usually not serious. You do have a considerable family history with your mother having breast cancer before the age of 50.  Its important that you report any breast *changes*. I'm not sure what you mean about breast density.  If there are new spots of breast lumps or hardness, then that's good to get  checked out. Any breast changes should be investigated, and you should emphasize your mother's breast cancer. They normally try to avoid mammograms for women at younger ages due to radiation concerns.  Women who get large doses of chest radiation near the time of puberty have an increased risk of breast cancer later in their age: particularly women who have had radiation *treatment* (in other words, radiation for conditions such as lymphoma.)  Ultrasounds or MRIs do not work by radiation and are normally considered safe. If you have a new breast lump, it is common for young women your age to get benign breast lumps called fibroadenomas.  But if these breast densities are new, then get them checked out. There are few 20 year olds who are diagnosed with breast cancer.  I won't tell you 100% what you should do, but these would be some of the things I would consider in your situation.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2008 12:22PM leaf wrote: This means that a lymph node was seen on ultrasound.  Ultrasound works on the basis of echoes when they put sound waves through your tissue.  So 'echogenic' just means what the image actually saw.  It cannot tell you any definite diagnosis. There are MANY reasons for an enlarged lymph node, most commonly a recent infection.  The breast surgeon is being thorough by biopsing it. The only way they can diagnose someone with breast cancer is by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. I know its hard not to worry.  The vast majority of people who get biopsied get a benign result.  A colleague of mine had a lymph node in her axilla biopsied, and it was thought to be from a mild fungal infection from gardening her roses. She is perfectly fine now, some 10 years later. We all want to be ready for whatever is on our path. We all know how worried you can be when you are getting something biopsied.  Let us know what happens, OK?  Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 01:51PM - edited Aug 21, 2009 01:56PM by leaf People's experiences do vary, but most people do well.  I personally had a terrible time, and ended up doing a survey here in 2006.  I had a long wait too.  I was admitted to the surgery day care facility at 09:30am,  had my wire insertion about 11am, my excision didn't start until about 3pm? and I didn't go home until 20:00 (about 8pm.)  (The surgeon had a family emergency.)  Once I got an anesthesiologist involved, all was well, or at least bearable. Before I scare you to death, note that at that time I also had undiagnosed PTSD, or a PTSD-like syndrome.  I'm sure this didn't help my pain score.  I did an unscientific survey here in 2006.  Even though studies are better than anecdotes, at least you get an idea. Injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and pain <=4/10       19 people, 50% Injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and pain >=5/10        7 people   18% No injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and pain <=4/10  3 people    8% No injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and pain >=5/10  9 people   24% Once an anesthesiologist got involved, I was fine. I asked for, and got, an IV injection of fentanyl about 2 hours after my wire insertion, at approximately 2pm.  I was under conscious anesthesia for my excision.  Everytime I tried to speak (even trying to say Ummmm-where am I?) I got another shot of anesthetic.   Post op, for me, a front opening sports bra and tiny ice packs were the treatment of choice.  (I just used the pain meds to try to make me drowsy enough to go to sleep.)  I went to work 24 hours after getting out of the recovery room.  (I work the graveyard shift as a pharmacist.)

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 05:23AM - edited Jul 16, 2008 05:25AM by leaf It is not unusual for one imaging to see something different than another type of imaging. I have not usually seen Birads 4 described as most probable malignancy.   In Dr. Susan Love's book, she describes Birads 4 as 'suspicious abnormality - not characteristic of breast cancer but has a reasonable probability of being malignant.'  and Birads 5 - highly suggestive of malignancy- lesion that has a high probability of being malignant (95%).'  An MRI may be able to tell the extent of suspicious areas.  Then they may be able to tell better what to biopsy. Different facilities differ, but I was told I could not have a mammo for 6 months after my biopsy (I think because it is hard to tell healing tissue from abnormalities.)  I was also told I couldn't have an MRI as screening because I have too much scar tissue. I have had different radiologists rate my imaging - what next. The only gold-standard way of knowing a diagnosis is looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. What a roller coaster you are going through! This must be awful to go through, especially with your sister's experience.   Hang in there.  I have read papers that opined that even in the highest risk women (such as BRCA positive women), overall 80% of biopsies still are benign. We will be here regardless of what happens. Feel free to vent or ask questions.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 08:32AM leaf wrote: I think that would be the way to go, but be prepared: they may not be able to get your records.  I couldn't get a major NCI center to send a copy of my consult to my oncologist.  I tried 5 times in the 2 years after the consult, including 3  tries in person with no results.  They must have lost it.  I was told when having my slide re-read that at my hospital they throw away benign slides after one year.  (They kept my LCIS slides though.)  The recommended time for retaining medical records depends on a number of factors, including: The safest approach is to retain medical records for adult patients at least 10 years; longer if the patient was a minor or incompetent at the time of treatment. State regulations tend to vary widely, and often depend on how the provider is licensed. Physicians are less likely to be subject to state regulations regarding retention of medical records than hospitals and other institutional providers which usually are governed by specific state licensure requirements. State licensing agencies may impose longer retention periods for X-rays and similar documents than for other types of medical records. Under Medicare, the retention periods range from five to seven years, depending on the particular coverage program or type of document. Other third-party payors generally impose similar requirements, although the contractual terms of the agreement may need to be reviewed. The American Hospital Association and American Health Information Management Association both recommend retaining medical records for at least 10 years after a patient's most recent treatment. Longer periods are recommended if the patient received experimental treatment since the records could be needed for future medical research. http://library.findlaw.com/1998/Jan/1/127216.html

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 10:36AM leaf wrote: Nancy-it certainly makes sense to me that cells that are dividing quickly would be more responsive to (traditional) chemo. Traditional chemos prevent quickly dividing cells from dividing. In one way or another, they 'put a wrench' in the process of DNA replication. That's why its the faster growing of the normal cells are most affected by chemo - (depending on the chemo)- hair, gastrointestinal lining, bone marrow are the usual suspects. Traditional (older) chemos act only when the cell is replicating, not when it is in the resting stage. Some of the really new treatments, like the antibodies, don't act this way.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 03:46AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:16AM by leaf I don't know how quickly is 'quickly changing', but most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-10 years before they can be detected by ANY means (including palpation, mammogram, ultrasound, MRI.)   So most breast cancers grow relatively slowly.  Breast cancer cannot be diagnosed without a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope (except sometimes  the unusual inflammatory breast cancer).   Since they have done studies on the impact of breast augmentation on the rate of breast cancer, they had to have some way of getting a tissue sample.   I don't have breast implants, so I can't say from personal experience. They could always do an excisional biopsy, if needed.   I don't think a breast MRI is *definitely* out-of-the-question.  Probably different opinions differ, but, if you had your fallopian tubes clamped a while ago, I would guess they *may* be able to do an MRI.  They don't list fallopian tubes as an 'absolute contraindication' to MRI on this NIH website. www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/en... I'm not a breast surgeon, let alone any kind of physician, so I can't tell you for sure.  Perhaps some things depend on your exact situation. I'm sorry you are going through this scare.  Of course, I hope everything turns out to be totally, boringly benign.  Good for you for getting this checked out!  (Some women would be too scared to get it checked out. )

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 08:01AM - edited Jan 12, 2010 08:02AM by leaf I know this is a big extrapolation, but in this study, A project, designed to locate the population at risk to diethylstilbestrol (DES) exposure in utero in the greater Philadelphia area from 1950-1970, was implemented by contacting area physicians who might have used the drug in their practices on pregnant women. 216 (31.8%) physicians responded to the questionaire; 155 (71.8%) responded that they had used DES.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/463989 I don't know if these 71.8% of physicians used DES on ALL of their patients, but it sounds a lot of people could dave been exposed.   This 1976 paper opined Few drugstores have records today of the prescriptions which they filled 20 years ago. It has been estimated that over the 1950-1970 period more than 200 different companies manufactured or "tabletized" under their own name DES plus a variety of similar synthetic estrogens promoted for the prevention of threatened abortion. A further hurdle caused by the passage of time is that even the records of the physicians are frequently lost. A final problem created by the age of the cases is statute of limitations. If the actual manufacturer of the DES cannot be identified, this is generally the end of the lawyer's interest in the case. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1028312 Since cancer in general, and  breast cancer  in particular, is a very common condition among women, and if many people were exposed to DES, its going to be hard to do the studies and statistics.

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 06:09PM - edited Mar 11, 2009 06:11PM by leaf Well, this site says some people feel the risk of LCIS (and nothing worse) is about 30-40%. How greatly does having LCIS increase breast cancer risk? One estimate is that the lifetime risk of developing an invasive breast cancer is 30-40% for women with LCIS, versus a lifetime risk of 12.5% for the average woman. Another estimate suggests that an LCIS diagnosis increases breast cancer risk to 21% over the next 15 years.http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/types/lcis/cancer_risk.jsp RE: radiation and LCIS: Maybe your onc liked the 2 papers I cited in your other thread. The 'self exam' statement is probably from these findings: Breast self-exam (BSE), or regularly examining your breasts on your own, can be an important way to find a breast cancer early, when it's more likely to be treated successfully. Not every cancer can be found this way, but it is a critical step you can and should take for yourself. Over the years, there has been some debate over just how valuable BSE is in detecting breast cancer early and increasing the likelihood of survival. For example, in summer 2008, one study of nearly 400,000 women in Russia and China reported that breast self-examination does not reduce breast cancer mortality and may even cause harm by prompting unnecessary biopsies (removal and examination of suspicious tissue). Because of the ongoing uncertainty raised by this and other studies, the American Cancer Society has chosen to advise women that BSE is an “optional” screening tool. Breastcancer.org still believes that BSE is a useful and essential screening strategy, especially when used in combination with regular physical exams by a doctor and mammography. About 20% of the time, breast cancers are found by physical examination rather than by mammography. We recommend that all women routinely perform breast self-exams as part of their overall breast cancer screening strategy. Read what Marisa Weiss, M.D., president and founder of Breastcancer.org, has to say about the July 2008 study of breast self-exam.http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/self_exam/index.jsp You are undergoing a lot of stress about many issues in your life.  That's very understandable.  You're also getting widely varying recommendations.  It must be very hard to choose what to do.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 02:59AM - edited Jan 11, 2010 03:24AM by leaf The results of this study were that the results were not stastically significant, but there were excess breast cancers, raising the concern for further investigation.  According to wikipedia, rate ratio is Rate Ratio = Incidence Rate 1/Incidence Rate 2, or in this case the incidence of breast cancer in the DES population / the incidence in the non-exposed population.  Note the huge confidence intervals, which indicate a LOT of uncertainty. The rate ratio for incidence of invasive breast cancer in exposed versus unexposed women was 1.4 (95% confidence interval (CI) = 0.7-2.6). DES exposure was not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer in women under 40 years, but among women aged 40 and older the rate ratio was 2.5 (95% CI = 1.0-6.3). The rate ratio for the association of DES exposure with estrogen receptor-positive tumors was 1.9 (95% CI = 0.8-4.5). INTERPRETATION: While not statistically significant, the overall 40% excess risk, arising exclusively from the subset of estrogen receptor-positive cases, raises a concern calling for continued investigation. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12420954 It must be very hard psychologically going through this.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2013 08:59AM - edited Jan 21, 2013 09:06AM by leaf When I had my core biopsy (for suspicious calcifications) they took additional mammograms afterwards to see if they had removed (or partly removed) my suspicious calcifications.  Since our breasts are soft and floppy, you can imagine how hard it is to fish in a bowl of gelatin that jiggles. I totally agree with what the others have said: try not to read too much into what they are choosing for you.  Its quite unlikely they are hiding any information from you.  Its like looking at a friend from the back:  a person might have the same hair color and style of your friend, wear the same style of clothes and be the same height and physical structure (this would be analogous to what they see in mammograms and/or ultrasounds/imaging), but they won't know for sure until your friend turns around and you see your friend's face (you have your biopsy).  Almost all breast cancer is diagnosed by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope (the only possible exception being the unusual inflammatory breast cancer, which is sometimes a clinical diagnosis, and you almost certainly don't have any symptoms for inflammatory breast cancer).  Imaging/symptoms aside, I think the only people that almost everyone would consider a high risk person (who hasn't personally had breast cancer) are women who have a significant family history (which in general means a greater breast cancer incidence than solely having 1 first degree relative - mother, father, sibling, offspring- with breast or ovarian cancer), have a known deleterious BRCA mutation, and/or radiation treatment to the chest (such as after having some types of lymphoma), or being a nuclear blast/accident survivor.  (Chest Xrays for diagnosis don't count.) If they knew you had breast cancer at this point, then they wouldn't be doing the biopsy. As everyone else said, waiting is the worst.  We all care about your anxiety, and hope this will be something that is 'boringly benign'.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 07:23AM leaf wrote: Be very, very, very careful about statistics. As Mark Twain said, "There are lies, damn lies, and statistics." There is controversy about how much risk a radial scar portrays, but in this paper they get a relative risk of almost 2.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18297395  What is relative risk? www.breastcancer.org/risk/unde... When they say 'double your risk' it does NOT NOT NOT mean 2 x the lifetime risk of the average woman (in the US) = 2 x 12 % = 24%. When they say 'double the risk' they mean double the risk of the woman WITHOUT any particular risk factors.  (The average woman in the US has some risk factors.) The figures I've seen tossed about for this 'base' risk factor is about 3-5%, so double that risk would mean a lifetime risk of about 6-10%. These are estimates, of course.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 10:14AM - edited Oct 12, 2011 10:15AM by leaf Its probably virtually impossible to know the cause(s) of radial scars, because it would be a very difficult thing to know.  It sounds from this paper radiographics.rsna.org/content...  that they are removing radial scars (at least in part) because they may have more risky things going on in the vicinity.   That is also what this paper says. www.sciencedaily.com/releases/...  In the NEJM article cited below, it sounds like often radial scars are NOT detected on mammograms, and are an incidental finding.  So we don't know how many women are walking around with radial scars and don't know it. This paper also opines that radial scars have nothing to do with previous trauma or surgery. This older 1999 paper in NEJM www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/... says that radial scars are a common finding (in this study they had an incidence of about 7%.)  It says most radial scars in their study were incidental findings. Remember that 'about twice the risk of breast cancer' does NOT mean 2x 13%=26% lifetime risk for breast cancer.  Twice the risk means twice the risk of a woman WITHOUT any risk factors, which is something like 3-5%, so because of the radial scar one's lifetime risk for breast cancer might be 6-10%. (We don't know if you have additional risk factors if they would add to this risk.) The 'average' woman in the US has a lifetime risk of breast cancer of about 13%.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 11:55PM leaf wrote: MissJoann, you do not get weepy for no reason. You get weepy because it is a VERY VERY VERY stressful situation. People handle stress in different ways: some cry, some laugh, some get withdrawn, some get angry, etc. Whatever you are feeling is OK. There are several kinds of calcifications that show up in mammos. Calcifications are VERY common. Big calcifications are associated with being benign, and are often associated with age or trauma. Tiny spots (that look like speckles of salt) or branched type calcifications can be a sign of concern. But even these types - ones that look like salt or look like branching - are usually benign. 80% of biopsies, even of calcifications, turn out to be benign. The radiologist is trained to see what patterns are worrisome, and what patterns are not. All of my biopsies (3) have been due to either calcifications or a weird thing on ultrasound, and they ALL have been benign.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 08:05PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:34PM by leaf Of course we can't diagnose you.  But there are many benign causes for lumps.  Perhaps the top two causes of breast lumps in young (under 30) women are the benign fibroadenoma and almost always benign cyst (which is a fluid-filled sac.)  Its probably not a cyst because they usually show up well on ultrasound. Its natural to be worried.  For women in your age group, even if it is suspicious enough to go to biopsy, at least 80%of biopsies turn out to be benign.   You are being referred to a breast surgeon NOT because they are planning to recommend a mastectomy, but because breast surgeons are the experts on breast diagnosis.  They are in the specialty that most often sees the correlation between what the symptoms (and/or imaging) is and what the results of biopsy. Biopsy is the 'gold standard' of diagnosis, but an MRI is less invasive.  On the other hand, MRI can have many false positive (show something worrisome when your breast really is fine) results.  They normally can't diagnose you with breast cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. Anyone in your shoes would be 'in the dark'.  There is little in breast cancer that is 100% accurate.  Your chances are very high that it IS benign.  But, as one author said, if you do feel there is something wrong with your breast, then insist on a biopsy, no matter what the doc says. While there are women here with a lump who have had negative mammograms, ultrasounds, AND MRIs and still ended up having cancer, but this is quite unusual. 2nd opinions are always good.  You can get other opinions.  You may or may not agree with your 2nd opinion.  You can go with the opinion you think is best.  That may be the 1st or 2nd or 3rd, etc. opinion.  I really appreciated getting a 2nd opinion even though I completely disagreed with it.  It spurred me to learn more, and I did. The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's mid-60s.  Of course, women in their 20s CAN get breast cancer, so its good you are getting this checked out.  But your chances are very high this will be nothing.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 12:57PM leaf wrote: Just as far as the 'do I have breast cancer' is concerned (just to give you a glimpse at the larger picture):   I think most/all experts agree that DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ is 'just' preinvasive) or anything worse is cancer, and ADH is not breast cancer. (Bessie is our resident expert here.) When you look at cells under the microscope, there are some cells that plainly look normal, and other cells that can look plainly cancerous.  But there can also be cells that look somewhere inbetween, and their classification can be controversial. You can certainly skip this paragraph, but it is just written to give you a 'bigger picture': In the case of LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) with nothing worse, its still 'stage 0', but most oncologists do not consider LCIS as breast cancer (in spite of its name.) LCIS was named before they knew its natural history.  In this one study, LCIS women actually had more subsequent invasive breast cancers than DCIS women did.  The study was up to 2001, and there are some big gaps in our knowledge about the treatments and risks that each group had. onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10...     Pleomorphic LCIS, a more recently discovered type of LCIS, has some features of both LCIS and DCIS, and is usually considered a more aggressive type than classic LCIS.  So whether something is considered 'cancer' or not may not correlate with their invasive breast cancer risk. (Women who have a known deleterious BRCA mutation usually have a greater lifetime risk of invasive breast cancer than any benign finding under the microscope.)

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 10:11AM leaf wrote: Breast imaging is not 100% perfect. We wish it could be, but it isn't. Its the best what we have to work with. Any breast imaging (including mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs) can have false positives and false negatives. It is quite unusual, but there are some women here who had a lump or thickening, and had negative mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs, and ended up having breast cancer. That's why some women here say things like "the best lump is the lump in the jar' - meaning that biopsies are good. Dr. Susan Love (a prominent breast surgeon) says, if you really think that something is wrong with your breast, then insist on a biopsy, no matter what your doc says. If you are wrong, you will have peace of mind. If you are right, you may have saved your life. They can't diagnose breast cancer on someone without a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 07:11AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 02:53AM by leaf Here's a blurb from the Mayo clinic about breast pain (mastalgia). http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/breast-pain/DS00760. Yes, IDC is the most common type of invasive breast cancer (about 70% of invasive  breast cancers).   The 'runners up' for invasive breast cancer are ILC (invasive lobular carcinoma) at about 15%, IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) at about 5%, and others make up the rest. The most commonly diagnosed noninvasive cancer is DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) at about 85% of noninvasive breast cancers, with LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) roughly 15%.  (Most oncologists do NOT consider LCIS as a true breast cancer, that LCIS was misnamed, and is mainly a risk factor for future DCIS or invasive breast cancer.) This 2005 paper claims Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is mostly diagnosed by mammography. The incidence is between 1% and 5% in countries without widespread use of mammography, but the incidence in mammography screening programs is between 8% and 25%. http://www.springerlink.com/content/q5174604678311n0/ Some doctors define stage 0 breast cancers (DCIS and, to a much lesser extent, LCIS) as cancer, and others do not. (Some define 'cancer' differently.  That's because cancer is 'uncontrolled growth', and you can't see cells growing directly over time on a microscope slide, because the cells you see on a slide are dead cells.  Most breast cancers grow relatively slowly, so even if you could see live cells, it would usually take months to years to see their rate of growth.)  It is usually easy to tell if a breast cancer is invasive or not (if the sample is good), but there can be disagreement in the classification and definition of the noninvasive types and benign breast conditions that put you at higher risk for breast cancer.
Posts.Title: I'm new and need help with constant sharp pain in my left breast Indigal28 leaf

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 03:31AM - edited Dec 28, 2009 03:33AM by leaf Texas is right - statistics are all over the place. You can stick your variables into the NCI breast cancer risk calculator and get a risk score that is 3 decimal places long (the modified Gail model) www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/, but that doesn't give you a clue how much uncertainty there is about that number for making decisions about your treatment. In this study, they took a random woman with breast cancer and a random woman withOUT breast cancer, and compared their modified Gail model score. In other words, for 59% of the randomly se- lected pairs of women, the risk estimated for the woman who was diagnosed with breast cancer was higher than the risk estimated for the woman who was not. Unfortunately, for 41% of the pairs of women, the woman with breast cancer received a lower risk estimate than her cancer-free counterpart. Thus, for any given woman, the two models were better at prediction than a coin toss—but not by much......Current breast cancer risk prediction models perform well for populations but poorly for individuals. jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/re...  (emphasis mine) An additional comment - some people with ADH opt to have their slides re-read elsewhere to get a 2nd opinion on the pathology.  Not everyone does this, of course.  If you didn't have it read at a major institution, some choose to do this because under some circumstances it can be hard to tell the difference between ADH and DCIS, and they are treated differently.  This is completely optional, but some do choose to do it.

Cases of LN with coexisting high-risk lesions (n=9, 10%) were excluded from the study. Patients with associated mass lesions all had benign findings (n=15, 16%) and had no impact on the study results. The remaining 77 core biopsies had no masses or risk lesions and were mammographically Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System 4 (BIRADS) for microcalcifications. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... Best wishes, leaf

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 06:07AM - edited Aug 2, 2008 06:20AM by leaf Of course it is scary.  The unknown is always scary. I had microcalcifications, and was diagnosed with the unusual LCIS and nothing worse.  LCIS is usually considered benign (in spite of the name, no I'm not in denial.) I don't have any personal experience with DCIS.  From what I understand, there are sometimes some situations where mastectomy is recommended for DCIS, such as if you have microcalcifications throughout the breast, or if you have a BRCA or other mutation, or if you have a strong family history with several first degree relatives with breast cancer/ovarian cancer. There may be other situations too, but I'm no expert on DCIS. However, from what I understand, the vast majority of women with DCIS opt for a lumpectomy plus radiation.  In this group of women who had a choice about mastectomy or lumpectomy+rads, about 20% of the group opted for mastectomy.  That means 80% did not.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18...  In every situation, the choice is up to you. Some women have had multiple biopsies and want to  get off the 'roller coaster' of biopsy. No treatment should be forced upon you. From what I understand, there are enough unknowns about DCIS that often the choice is yours. Someone may strongly advise a certain course, but ultimately the choice is yours. To take an extreme example, there are persons with completely treatable invasive breast cancer with multiple node involvement, for which chemotherapy is strongly advised, who refuse chemotherapy. It is their body and their choice. If you are in a certain situation, we would only hope that you make an informed choice.  For some, that means getting involved in every statistic available, and for others it means asking their closest, most trusted doctor, significant other, and/or friend.  Others choose to explore both ways, or a combination of ways, or some other way.  A big unknown, that no one can tell you, is how much your breasts mean to you/significant others, versus a mastectomy that may, in the long term, save your life in some cases.  Only you can know how you feel, and what each choice would mean to you. We all want to be ready on the path ahead of us so we will be prepared.  Because you do not know what you are dealing with, some prefer not to go there until they know more information about their 'suspicious lesion'. Waiting with the unknowns, from what I understand, is one of the hardest things in this journey.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 07:19AM - edited Jan 22, 2011 07:21AM by leaf It sounds like they sent your slides to another institution.  It is usually easy to tell the difference between invasive breast cancer and noninvasive conditions.   It can be hard to tell the difference between the non-invasive types and whether it is DCIS, ADH, ALH, LCIS, or something less risky.  Since they mentioned atypia, it sounds like its likely that you have ADH or ALH.  If I was forced to take a guess, I'd guess that they think you have ADH, but are trying to make sure you don't have DCIS; they are treated differently.  Re-reading the slides took 2-3 months for one person who posted here.  Unfortunately, they didn't tell the patient they had sent them out. When I had my slides sent to a major institution (which was some 20 miles away), sent by Fedex, I thought I had allowed plenty of time giving them 1-3/4 months for a 2nd slide reread by the pathologist.  But either communication was bad or the pathology reread wasn't completed; the results were not available for my 2nd opinion medical appointment 1.75 months later. The wait drives you batty.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 10:36AM leaf wrote: I am so sorry you are going through this. But please realize that NO ONE can say you are 100% certain you have breast cancer before they see a piece of tissue under the microscope. There are women here who were told by their doctors they were 100% certain they had breast cancer (from imaging or whatever), and they turned out to be benign. So, while it may be quite likely you have bc, I think there is some finite chance that you may not. I've never had a lump so I can't help you with that. But I've had 2 core biopsies. For me, they injected a local anesthetic into my breast. I think they used a very fine needle, like a TB syringe. The warned me beforehand that if I had any pain, I was supposed to tell them. I had almost no pain on my first core. There are some strange movements of the table, and most of the time you are supposed to lie still. I had a bad time with a wire insertion before my 2nd biopsy, so when they tried to do the initial injection on my 2nd go around, I pulled out of the mammo machine. It was much more from fear than from pain. But some women get wire insertions with no pain whatsoever. It must depend on the person, and if they get near a nerve. Some people, if they have complaints, complain about not being able to move their head or neck or shoulders through the procedure - particularly if they have neck or back issues beforehand. I never had this problem. I would suggest if you are worried, that you have a conversation with the radiologist before the procedure starts on what (s)he wants you to do IF you have pain, and what they will do about it. For me, sometimes there were loud noises, so it was hard to tell when the doc was saying 'breathe' or 'don't breathe' because I was concerned sometimes the 'don't' would get drowned out. I really liked to have a jogbra or tight fitting bra -especially a front opening one, for afterwards. Also tiny ice packs made it feel better too.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2014 03:44AM - edited Jun 24, 2014 04:01AM by leaf Re: breast density.  I have 'dense, but not extremely dense' breasts (so probably the 50-75% dense category). I get yearly mammograms. This is Beesie's favorite reference about breast density. (Beesie is a member here with a great reputation for her knowledge, even handedness, kindness, and clarity of thought, especially about DCIS.) http://www.breastdensity.info/index.html Quote from that site: ___________ That said, in general, they generally don't do _screening_ mammograms (yearly, every 2 years, or every 3 years screening) on 'average risk' women before the age of 40 or 50. There are several reasons for this, including:  The risk of breast cancer is lower for younger women (as you already know.) Younger women often have denser breasts, so its often difficult to see breast lesions in younger breasts. This is not an 'all or none' statement: some younger women do not have dense breasts, and some older women continue to have dense breasts. From animal studies, there is no 'zero risk' dose of radiation - meaning that even the smallest dose of radiation does have some risk of chromosome damage. However, we all have radiation exposure from our environment.     They do sometimes do  _diagnostic_ mammograms (when there is a known breast sign/symptom) when younger women have breast problems: its a risk -vs - benefit situation.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 01:55AM - edited Sep 8, 2008 02:00AM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this.  Any person in your shoes would be scared too, especially if nothing was explained to them. I do not have this cancer, but this is what I found when I tried to look things up. It sounds like mucinous adenocarcinoma describes only some external features of the cancer.  Adenocarcinoma only means that it starts in glandular tissue - so you can have adenocarcinoma starting in many different organs in your body - that is quite common., Since you are posting on the bc.org site, I assume they found this in your breast. I think that mucinous carcinoma in the breast means that the cancer produces stuff that looks like mucus.  It sounds like its an unusual cancer type, but according to this study, in long-term followup, people didn't do any worse with mucinous cancer than they did with the average type of breast cancer.Your receptors sound good: your cancer is estrogen and progesterone positive.  That means that if you choose, you would be a candidate for anti-hormonal therapy.  This is an addition in your weapons against this disease.    http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17826073 Her2 zero is also good.  Her2 is associated with a more aggressive type of cancer. I think that ki67 is associated with the number of cell divisions they see, thus associating with how quickly the cancer is growing.  It says fav so I assume this means favorable. p53 is a tumor suppressor.   I don't know about the numbers (possibly each lab has different standards for what the number mean ?) but since it says fav after each of the immunochemistry items, I think that is good news. It is good that your cancer is well differentiated.  That means it is your cancer is closer to 'normal' than some other cancers.  Cancer is a continuum, like temperature.  We can heat up water, but at what point do we call water hot?  So the definition of cancer is not a 'line in the sand'.  But your cancer is closer to a 'normal' cell than a cancer that is 'poorly differentiated'. You are in good company here.  About 70% of the women here who have breast cancer have *NO* obvious risk factors, besides being a woman.  Only about 10-20% of all breast cancers are associated with a single, inheritable gene defect, such as being BRCA positive.  The women here are so supportive.  Feel free to ask questions or vent. I hope someone will be along shortly to add or correct anything I wrote. (I do not have invasive breast cancer.)

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2008 11:33AM leaf wrote: As Dukemom and LUVmy2girlZ say, it can be very dangerous to search the internet and not have the FULL picture. Goodness knows, I did that when I was awaiting my first breast biopsy. I had to know the 'worst case scenario', and asked myself if my worst case scenario was that I wouldn't even make it to the tumor board. (A board of doctors that review cancer cases.) Some people have planned their funeral in detail. We all want to be ready for whatever is on our path ahead, no matter what it is. So we search for the worst case scenario. You also have to be VERY wary about statistics. As Mark Twain is reported to have said, "There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies and statistics." But the bigger picture is this: Assuming you do not have a personal history of breast cancer, I am certain that your risk of breast cancer with a Birads 3 mammogram is NOT NOT NOT that you will have a 50% chance of getting breast cancer in the next year. Even the highest risk women, such as have a BRCA mutation, have a 20-60% *LIFETIME* chance of NOT getting breast cancer. All the other risk factors are LESS, and usually MUCH less than this. www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/... *DON'T* hide under the bed and 'forget' to go to your checkups. (There *are* women who do this because they are so frightened). But as the others have said, try not to get ahead of yourself. Some women find relaxation, meditation, exercise, distraction helps.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2016 01:04PM leaf wrote: No, swollen lymph nodes are not alarming. Swollen lymph nodes can be from many different things. Particularly common are viral infections. http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/swol... Viruses cause the common cold, flu, warts. Almost everyone has a herpes virus. Worldwide, ∼90% of people have one or both viruses. HSV-1 is the more prevalent virus, with 65% of persons in the United States having antibodies to HSV-1 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK47447/ Toxoplasma infections (a parasite, not a virus) are also very common. More than 60 million men, women, and children in the U.S. carry the Toxoplasma parasite, but very few have symptoms because the immune system usually keeps the parasite from causing illness. http://www.cdc.gov/parasites/toxoplasmosis/ I don't know about stress causing swollen lymph nodes, but emotional stress is very hard to measure quantitatively, and of course a certain situation will stress one person out and not another.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2016 07:31PM leaf wrote: Different studies give pretty different results for linear calcifications. In this paper they quote for linear calcifications Hofvind reported, in series of 62 cases of fine linear microcalcifications, the presence of high grade DCIS in 84% Burnside reported in his series, in the sub-group of fine linear calcifications, 32% invasive carcinoma, 21% DCIS, 5% lesions at risk Bent et al. reported 70% malignancy, 22% invasive carcinoma and 48% DCIS In 35 cases, Shin et al. reported 23% invasive carcinoma, 69% DCIS, 6% lesions involving a risk In his meta-analysis, Rominger reported a rate of malignancy of 78% (68–86%) https://www.clinicalkey.com/#!/content/playContent/1-s2.0-S2211568413003884?returnurl=http:%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS2211568413003884%3Fshowall%3Dtrue&referrer=http:%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpubmed%2F24525087 Everyone has different experiences with biopsies. Many people rate their biopsy pain as about a 4-7 out of 10. I don't like it when people say a procedure will be painless. We all have different experiences, depending on our personality, background, technique, anatomy, etc. Everyone's experience is VALID. I would highly recommend that IF you have pain, COMPLAIN. If you have a biopsy where they ask you to 'not move a muscle', then either promise yourself you will complain verbally if you have pain, or bring something along that will make noise (like a bell or something) that can communicate you are in pain.

No matter what your outcome, there will be people here who have had something happen like what you are going through.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 10:43AM - edited Jan 18, 2009 10:47AM by leaf Infections can show up in at least 2 ways in the blood (sometimes more).  Infections can cause high white cell counts (called WBC which stands for white blood cell count).  These are one of the infection fighters in the body. This test, to count the white blood cells in a sample of blood, can be done in a few hours or less. They can also take some blood and culture it, to see if they can grow bacteria out of the blood. This takes several days, usually.If you had bacteria in your blood, then this would be called 'sepsis'. But the blood culture would only pick up bacteria that are in the blood stream (or contaminants on the skin.) You can have mastitis without bacteria entering into your bloodstream.  You can almost certainly have mastitis without your WBC count going up. This is the Mayo's site on mastitis. http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/mastitis/DS00678 Are you seeing a breast surgeon?  If you've been on several courses of antibiotics, then either you have a resistant infection, or could have a type of breast cancer.  I would push for a 'punch biopsy' or skin biopsy.  A biopsy of this kind won't rule out inflammatory breast cancer, but it could help with the diagnosis. If you aren't seeing a breast surgeon, I think its high time to get one involved.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 10:25PM leaf wrote: The risk rate does vary from year to year In the 1970s, the lifetime risk of being diagnosed with breast cancer in the United States was just under 10 percent (often expressed as "1 in 10"). The estimated lifetime risk has generally been rising gradually since then; this year, the estimated risk decreased slightly. The last five annual SEER reports show these estimates of lifetime risk: 13.4 percent for 1997 through 1999 ("1 in 7.45," often expressed as "1 in 7") 13.5 percent for 1998 through 2000 ("1 in 7.40," often expressed as "1 in 7") 13.4 percent for 1999 through 2001 ("1 in 7.47," often expressed as "1 in 7") 13.2 percent for 2000 through 2002 ("1 in 7.56," often expressed as "1 in 8") 12.7 percent for 2001 through 2003 ("1 in 7.87," often expressed as "1 in 8") SEER statisticians expect some variability from year to year. Slight changes, such as the one reported this year, may be explained by a variety of factors, including minor changes in risk factor levels in the population, slight changes in screening rates, or just random variability inherent in the data. The estimated probability of being diagnosed with breast cancer for specific age groups and for specific time periods is generally more informative than lifetime probabilities. Estimates by decade of life are less influenced by changes in life expectancy and incidence rates. The SEER report estimates the risk of developing breast cancer in 10-year age intervals (1). These calculations factor in the proportion of women who live to each age. In other words, they take into account that not all women live to older ages, when breast cancer risk becomes the greatest. A woman's chance of being diagnosed with breast cancer is: from age 30 through age 39 . . . . . . 0.43 percent (often expressed as "1 in 233") from age 40 through age 49 . . . . . . 1.44 percent (often expressed as "1 in 69") from age 50 through age 59 . . . . . . 2.63 percent (often expressed as "1 in 38") from age 60 through age 69 . . . . . . 3.65 percent (often expressed as "1 in 27") These probabilities are averages for the whole population. An individual woman's breast cancer risk may be higher or lower, depending on a number of factors, including her family history, reproductive history, race/ethnicity, and other factors that are not yet fully understood. To calculate an individual's estimated risk, see the Breast Cancer Risk Assessment Tool at www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ on the Internet. www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa... But an article written said the chances of the Gail model, and a model that included other factors such as breast density, predicting one's breast cancer risk **FOR AN INDIVIDUAL** was "better than a coin toss-but not by much." jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/re... . They compared one woman with breast cancer to another woman without breast cancer. 41% of the time, the woman without breast cancer had a higher (more risky) value than did the woman with breast cancer.
