Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2014 02:58AM - edited Oct 10, 2014 02:36PM by leaf As others have said, I think it depends on your personality, who you tell, how serious your diagnosis is, how obvious your treatment will be (such as if you will lose your hair or have a mastectomy), and what else is going on with others in their circle. I work at the hospital where I had my excision done, and I felt pretty obligated to tell fellow workers what was going on because I was crying every time someone was admitted who had breast cancer. When I cry, my eyes are red and swollen for hours afterwards.   I felt I had to tell them so they would know I was not crying because of something they did. I had my core biopsy that showed nothing worse than classic LCIS.  I had to wait another 1.5 months for a breast excision to confirm there was nothing worse. Little did I know that the night before my excision, a coworker (who I had not told at all), said that the Xray tech (a male, who I had not known at all, but who was friends with a coworker in my department), said, because he had another co-worker who had had LCIS that had bilateral mastectomies, that I should have BPMs too.  That is not what I needed the night before my excision, by essentially a male  stranger I did not know, who was not my doctor.  (BPM was the routine treatment before roughly the 1990s, but is not the routine treatment now unless one has a significant family history or other huge risk factors.)  I also had a very psychologically traumatic wire insertion before my breast excision, which triggered an anxiety disorder. Similar to proudtospin, I did not tell my family until years later, because my sister had an ultimately fatal cancer, and my diagnoses were minor compared to that.  Probably many in my extended family still don't know, but  classic LCIS is quite a minor situation.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 05:53PM leaf wrote: You may want to see a genetics counselor or see a high risk physician.  They should give you your options, and hopefully not press you for one decision or another. Scientific literature realizes there are probably as-yet undiscovered inherited genes.  This from 2005. Between 9,000 and 18,000 new cases of breast cancer per year in the United States are associated with a genetically defined predisposition. Mutations in BRCA1 and 2 account for greater than 60% of inherited breast cancer. Mutations in additional undiscovered high and low penetrance genes may account for the other 40% of inherited breast cancer cases and possibly a subset of familial breast cancer cases that lacks an autosomal-dominant pattern of inheritance. False-negative rates resulting from gene sequencing of BRCA1 and 2 may be as high as 10%-15%, making the identification of high-risk individuals a complex and often futile process for both patient and physician. As a consequence of technical limitations in BRCA1 and 2, genetic testing and the lack of comprehensive breast cancer prediction models that take into account both genetic and environmental factors, we are unable to quantify future breast cancer risk for many patients. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... (emphasis mine)

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 07:21PM - edited Dec 2, 2007 11:59PM by leaf I'm a lefty (assuming you consider LCIS a cancer. Most oncs consider it benign.) Here's a study. It says that left is about 5% more common than right, except maybe in the upper-outer quadrant, where it was more equal. 1: Cancer Causes Control. 2004 Sep;15(7):637-45. Links Association between breast cancer laterality and tumor location, United States, 1994-1998. Perkins CI, Hotes J, Kohler BA, Howe HL. Minnesota Department of Health, Minnesota Cancer Surveillance System, 717 Delaware Ave., SE, Minneapolis 55414, USA. carin.perkins@state.mn.us OBJECTIVE: Cancer is more likely to be diagnosed in the left breast than the right, but the reasons are undetermined. Left-sided predominance has not been evaluated for some demographic groups or by tumor location. METHODS: Laterality was analyzed among 419,935 incident unilateral breast cancers from 26 population-based cancer registries covering 40% of the US population. Logistic regression assessed the independent contribution of race, ethnicity, age, histology, stage, and location to laterality. RESULTS: Breast cancer was about 5% more likely to be diagnosed in the left breast than the right, a finding that was generally consistent across demographic groups and tumor types. Left-sided predominance was evident among both younger (less than 45 years) and older women, and among men with either in situ or invasive disease. Among women, tumors in the upper-outer quadrant, where one-third of cancers are located, occurred with equal frequency in the left and right breast, while those in the lower quadrants were about 10% more likely to occur in the left breast. CONCLUSION: The observation that the left breast is at greater risk of cancer than the right may not apply to tumors arising in the upper-outer quadrant. The identification of physiologic, pathologic, or immunologic differences between the lower, but not upper, left and right breasts may assist in explaining breast cancer laterality. PMID: 15280621 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 08:13AM leaf wrote: The most *common* symptom of breast cancer is a painless lump.  That said, different women have different symptoms: breast cancer doesn't like to follow the 'rules' we make up for it. Some women here found the very first symptom of their breast cancer was breast pain. But if breast pain was the initial event in all breast cancers, we wouldn't have to do all this other imaging. Of course, we can't diagnose your sister.   Because she is BRCA 1+, she, of course, is at higher risk.  It may be something to worry about, but it may not.  Women with BRCA mutations usually have breast cancer at an earlier age.  If she feels there is something wrong, then I think she should push for a biopsy for peace of mind.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 06:56AM leaf wrote: There is no imaging in breast cancer that is 100% sensitive and 100% accurate.  That means that all imaging can miss some breast cancers (i.e. a breast cancer can be there but the imaging doesn't pick it up - that's sensitivity), and all imaging can detect things that look suspicious but end up NOT being cancer - that's accuracy.)  Mammograms by themselves are touted to be about 80% accurate - in other words it misses about 20% of breast cancers.   All 3 of these imaging modes measure different things.  Mammograms detect how much they show up in a particular energy of Xray.  Ultrasound shows how ultrasounds bounce off different tissues - they are good at detecting the edge between tissue and fluid, like in a cyst.  MRIs measure the magnetic 'bounce' (being very inaccurate.) There are women here who have had lumps that were not detected by mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI, but ended up being cancer.  This is VERY unusual, but can happen.  The more negative imaging you have the more likely it is to be benign.  For some women, the size that they see on imaging does NOT match what they see when they go in and actually surgically remove the lesion. We have to deal with the imaging we have at the moment.  Hopefully better imaging will be developed in the future, but its not here yet.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 07:00AM - edited Aug 9, 2008 05:44AM by leaf Goodness!  You have been through the wringer (and washer, and dryer..)  Welcome to the boards! Oh yes, it is very common to get benign results from calcification clusters.  For the overall population, about 80% of biopsies turn out to be benign.  That's a very big number. I had 'suspicious calcifications', and I got LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ, which in spite of the name is usually considered benign.  It is a marker for a higher risk for breast cancer.) Its uncommon, so don't expect that outcome. I know you do not have a common situation because you have had leukemia and a stem cell transplant.  There are several papers about the risk of leukemia AFTER breast cancer, but its hard to find papers about breast cancer AFTER leukemia.  Even so, most of the studies were from leukemia in CHILDHOOD, so these may or may not be relevant. This one says for people who had CHILDHOOD leukemia, the  30-year risk for non-hematological cancers was <3%, and breast cancer was NOT listed in the top 3 cancers. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17505074 So I can't find any Pubmed papers for your SPECIFIC situation. But there is this article on the bc.org site , which says that the 25 year risk of getting breast cancer after hemotogical stem cell transplant is about 17% with radiation, and about 3% without  These are NOT horrible odds.  I know its only one citation. http://www.breastcancer.org/risk/new_research/20080228.jsp The 'lifetime' risk of breast cancer for the average US woman is about 12%.  Now breast cancer prediction is a can of worms.  At this point, this may be too much detail to worry about.  But we don't know whether your risk because of your leukemia is in *addition* to you other known or unknown risk factors.  This means that if you have a risk of 3% from leukemia, and you have a (just making something up here) 10% risk from something else, then your total risk from these two factors may be 3% or 10% or 13% or8%, or even 1% or 25% *for you as an individual*. We don't know because they haven't studied people in your risk group enough, plus statistically there is not enough risk difference between your risk factors and the average risk factors.  If you don't get this, that's OK. The bottom line is that there are a lot of uncertainties in breast cancer prediction.  Hang in there.  I know this is a very scary time for you.  I don't know of 1 person who wasn't scared during this process of diagnosis. Feel free to ask questions or vent.   If you're going through hell, keep going-Winston Churchill

Posts.Content: May 29, 2014 10:04PM - edited May 29, 2014 10:10PM by leaf Your doctor would know.  Fibroadenomas can vary in size.  The biggest I have read about was about 5 pounds. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12751688, and you wouldn't be able to remove that with a core biopsy.  So it may depend on the fibroadenoma size.  I've also read about some fibroadenomas being frozen instead of removed.  I don't know how common or practical that is. This Mayo clinic blurb says Most fibroadenomas don't affect your risk of breast cancer. However, your breast cancer risk might increase slightly if you have a complex fibroadenoma — which may contain abnormal cysts or dense, opaque tissue called calcifications. A pathologist makes the diagnosis of a complex fibroadenoma after reviewing the tissue from a biopsy of the lump. http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/fibr... One of the things that may go into your decision whether or not to get it removed, is that surgery causes scarring. Even core biopsies can cause some scarring, but generally less than surgery.  Internal scarring can make it harder to read future mammograms and imaging.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 03:52PM leaf wrote: I was scared sh$%less.  I was asking if I'd still be alive by the time the tumor board met every month or two.  I had many anxiety attacks.  I cried at work.  I cried at home. I work in the hospital in which I had my lumpectomy (a core biopsy had showed LCIS and nothing worse), and the night before my lumpectomy, a co-worker came up to me and said that the radiology clerk advised that I have bilateral mastectomies because a co-worker had LCIS and that's what she had.  I had exchanged a total of 15 words with this clerk over 20 years, so it was like having a complete male stranger tell you that you needed to have mastectomies. After having a very traumatic wire insertion, the next day I shared some of my angst with my co-workers.  Wrong move.  One said, "Oh, we're not going to go through this breast cancer stuff again - my neighbor just did."  They didn't understand, and I simply told everyone that the subject was out of bounds.  I now only trust a few select people. My diagnosis opened a whole can of worms I had been avoiding my entire life. I started going to a  family therapist. While worry won't change the outcome, that is NO help in trying to avoid worrying.  Its human nature to want to be prepared for whatever is ahead for us.  We don't know the outcome of our diagnosis, and even if we did know our diagnosis, we wouldn't know how this diagnosis will affect our lives. It ends up that only a small number of breast cancer cases end up being initially diagnosed with advanced breast cancer.  (This is an old website from the early 2000s.)   www.imaginis.com/breast-health...       As you can see, only about 20% of women initially get diagnosed with late stage breast cancer.    Breast cancer is not an automatic death sentence.  Even if you go to the Worst Case Scenario, if you go for conventional treatment, even late stage people live for many years with late stage breast cancer.  I know it was impossible for me not to go to the worst case scenario.  Bad things had happened before in my life, and I wanted to be prepared for what is ahead.  I ended up having (the unusual) classic LCIS and nothing worse. I also learned that there are lots of people out there that can't put themselves in your shoes.  But you know that already.  I stuck with the people who either could put themselves in my shoes, or at least don't tell me I need to be (to exaggerate) neutered.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 11:03AM - edited Mar 8, 2008 06:43PM by leaf I've never had a lump, but from what I've read here, checking on painful/tender lumps constantly is not generally recommended- it can make them bigger and more inflammed. If a woman has pain in her breast, that symptom isn't very helpful to tell whether or not she has breast cancer. Most women with breast cancer do not have painful lumps, but for some women their first symptom was pain. Lots of women with NON-cancerous symptoms have pain too. But, of course, bring the pain symptom up to your doc - so they can try to get your pain under control, no matter what its cause.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 12:51AM leaf wrote: Yes, it is POSSIBLE, though VERY unlikely. You are probably describing something like an infection.  As nancyh said, your daughter is young to have breast cancer.  Anything that can happen on regular skin can happen on the skin of the breast. You and your daughter are probably NOT describing fungating breast lesions.  While some locally advanced breast cancers present this way in developed countries, it more commonly happens in less developed countries. A fungating (malignant) wound is when cancer that is growing under the skin breaks through the skin to create a wound. As the cancer grows, it blocks and damages tiny blood vessels, which can starve the area of oxygen. This causes the skin and underlying tissue to die (necrosis). There may also be infection. The wounds will often look like a fungus or cauliflower. Other areas of the wound may become ulcerated. Fungating wounds are rare, and most people who have cancer will never develop a fungating wound. They can develop in the area where the cancer started (the primary), or when the cancer has spread to another part of the body (the secondary or metastasis). If a fungating wound does develop, it is most likely to happen with breast cancer, head and neck cancer and melanoma. |http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Livingwithandaftercancer/Symptomssideeffects/Othersymptomssideeffects/Fungatingwounds.aspx  This 2009 book opines that most fungating breast lesions present as:    a) A rapidly growing, aggressive breast cancer, usually inflammatory cancer.    b) a recurrance    c) a late presentation where a woman ignored a breast lump for many years. Warning: there are graphic photos in this reference, which some may find highly offensive. books.google.com/books?id=ao1R... As the others have said, regardless, get it checked out; it needs to get at least evaluated, if not treated.  Infections often can cause swollen lymph nodes.

Can you feel the lump in your breast tissue?  Some people do feel their ribs, or their inframammary ridge.  Can you feel it when you press on the side of it?  I have never had any breast lumps (besides after breast procedures), but I've certainly heard of women here who say they can feel a lump, but when they go to their doctor their doctor cannot feel the lump.  I've certainly seen posts here of younger women who have been told 'You're too young to have breast cancer.'  As you know, of course you're not too young to have breast cancer. The surgeon, with the 'scary things are usually painless' remark, was probably referring to the fact that the most common symptom of a breast cancer is a painless lump.  But breast cancer can present in many different ways: a painful lump, a thickening, pulling of the nipple, no symptoms at all, etc, as you probably know. Some doctors, notoriously surgeons, do not have good bedside manners.  (Though I have had several non-breast surgeons who had excellent bedside manners.)  Would you feel better if you got a 2nd opinion?

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 12:19PM leaf wrote: Well, I think its good to get things checked out until YOU are satisfied with the answer. Note I do not and have not had invasive breast cancer of any kind. IBC is a clinical diagnosis.  It is an unusual diagnosis. Most doctors have never seen a case.   Often IBC does NOT form a lump. http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Sites-Types/IBC. Since your symptoms have FADED, they may be less likely to be IBC.  But of course I am not a breast specialist.  This website describes how IBC is diagnosed.  http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCancer/MoreInformation/InflammatoryBreastCancer/inflammatory-breast-cancer-inflammatory-br-ca-diagnosis Risk factors for IBC are poorly understood, and currently it is not possible to estimate a woman’s risk for this type of cancer. IBC tends to occur at a younger age than other types of breast cancer, however, prompting interest in the role of genetic predisposition and early-life exposures.[3]  Rates of IBC increase rapidly up to age 50 and then stabilize. IBC is also more common in African-American women than in White women. http://www.ufscc.ufl.edu/patient/content.aspx?section=ufscc&id=663 Most women who get breast cancer do not have any obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.) IBC is probably one of the 'zebras' of breast cancer.  In other words, its unusual.  If you have a wild animal running around, its more likely a horse than a zebra.   When you have breast symptoms, its easy to go to the 'worst case scenario'.  I am not trying to discount your worry, but its much more likely to be a more common, less aggressive diagnosis. But you need to do whatever you need to do to get peace of mind.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 05:12AM - edited Jun 16, 2009 05:27AM by leaf FYI: the line between normal cells and cancerous cells is sometimes NOT a line in the sand.  Cancer by definition means 'uncontrolled growth'. There can be controversy whether 'uncontrolled' means penetration of the basement membrane (that is beneath the lobules and ducts). There are clearly benign cells, and there are other cells that are clearly cancerous. But there can be controversy over cells that are 'in between'  or  'part of the way there'.  For example, atypical (meaning they are oddly shaped) hyperplastic (meaning there are a lot of cells growing there) cells are thought to be in the middle.  For example, most oncologists consider LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is benign (in spite of the name). There can be controversy whether DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) and LCIS are considered cancer.  Some people feel 'cancer' should be restricted to invasive types.  (Invasive meaning the cancer has extended beyond the basement membranes.) Some people consider DCIS and LCIS 'pre-cancer'.  Other people consider DCIS (in particular) cancer. (I'm not certain how many experts feel that DCIS is cancer or benign.) DCIS definitely needs to be treated. From what I've heard, its usually easy  for the pathologist to tell if cancerous cells have penetrated the basement membrane. So, normally you can't be diagnosed with cancer before they take a biopsy of a piece of tissue and look at it under the microscope.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2008 06:19AM leaf wrote: Hi Melody. This must be a very hard time for you. It would be very hard for anybody. It must be even harder when you've had a first row seat to cancer. Its OK if you don't know all the lingo. ADH is atypical ductal hyperplasia, a mouthful, but a condition that puts you at higher risk for breast cancer, but is considered benign. Wire guided biopsies are biopsies where they insert 1 (or more) wires to locate a spot. This is so a surgeon can go in and remove the suspicious spot. These are done for mammos and MRIs because they can't have your breast in a mammo or MRI machine while they are doing an excision on your breast. I have had only 1 wire guided excision, and they used 2 wires for this excision. I am so glad you were able to deliver a wonderful eulogy for you mother. I'm sure it meant a lot to your family, and your mother would have been very proud of you. It sounds like you are doing the right thing by keeping yourself busy while you wait. Waiting is horrible. Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 09:25AM - edited Aug 10, 2010 09:29AM by leaf If your first doc can't handle a patient wanting a 2nd opinion, then maybe he isn't such a great doc.  I think in cancer, things are not 'written in concrete'.   My onc once said that cancer is like looking in a black room with a flashlight.  You can't see the whole picture. If your doctor's ego isn't strong enough to handle a 2nd opinion, then maybe your doc has some learning to do.  This isn't like solving a mathematical equation. There is usually more than one answer, and different people have different approaches. My onc knew I was getting a 2nd opinion.  I decided he was better than my 2nd opinion.  His attitude towards me didn't change. I am very glad I got a 2nd opinion, even though I completely disagreed with it.  It spurred me to learn more in some areas. Get as many 2nd opinions as you need.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 10:07AM leaf wrote: I'm not a physician either.  But I can give some guesses.   If she is having fluid in her lungs or pleural area, then there probably are cancer cells either in or near the lung, or perhaps in the liver.  The reason I say liver is that it is the liver that produces a protein called albumin (which normally resides in the blood).  The albumin (and other proteins) 'hold'  water in the circulatory system. If there isn't enough protein being produced by the liver, then the water in the circulatory system can get 'sucked' into the peripheral tissues (which would include the lungs, often feet/legs/abdomen/etc.) There are probably other ways this can occur too, but this is one way. If it has metastasized into the lung or liver, they may not be able to remove it surgically. I don't know if these cancer metastasize in spots, or if it can be a general spread. If her IBC has spread to the lungs or pleura (the lining of the lungs), then its still called metastasized IBC, and not lung cancer. If she's not tolerating the chemo because her blood counts are too low, then she's probably not strong enough to tolerate major surgery either.   I hope you can talk to the doc soon and get some firm answers so you know what you are up against, and can make some plans.  My best wishes to you in this time.  I know you care a lot about your mother. My friend is in hospice with metastatic pancreatic cancer, and she has not wanted to go into how she feels.  So some people want to deal with their feelings, and other people don't.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 05:45AM leaf wrote: The uncertainty is awful, isn't it? Of course we can't tell you whether or not you have breast cancer, and I think you understand that. There are some downsides to fine needle biopsy-it may not hit the desired spot or sample the lump properly, and it also may distort the cells in the sample (from friction with the needle), causing it harder to read by a pathologist.  But if the lump can be felt, usually they can hit at least part of it with a needle. There are also downsides to surgical removal of the lump: it can cause scar tissue, making it harder to read mammograms and other imaging in the future, it is possible to get infections, and can be expensive. (My insurance company paid $13.5K in 2006.) Some people here have said 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - meaning its good to biopsy things if in doubt.  But each person is different. All this causes further stress.  It is at least controversial if stress causes or partially causes cancer. About 70% of women who have breast cancer have no known obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.) I'd get all the 2nd opinions you need to feel comfortable with your decision. Check both your brain and your heart and do what you need to do.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2008 11:54AM - edited Oct 1, 2008 01:20PM by leaf The population incidence will vary from study to study. The women who are taking tamoxifen and who have NEVER had breast cancer (however that is defined) may have a different risk than women who have had a history of breast cancer.  Stage may be important too.  (Patients with cancer have an increased incidence of clotting disorders.  There is a saying that 'a dime's worth of cancer can cause a dollar's worth of clots.' (or something to that effect.)) Your risks may vary depending on your age, menopausal status, other clotting risk factors, etc.  This paper found an increased incidence of thromboembolic disease.  This was also definitely affected by the woman's age. www3.interscience.wiley.com/cg...  This paper gave a relative risk of 1.63 for thromboembolic events.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17470740 Interestingly, this paper found NO association between Leiden factor and thromboembolism in tamoxifen users.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16818854 This is an abstract of the STAR trial.  You may be able to get links from the icon in the upper right hand corner.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2017 10:16AM leaf wrote: Size is relative. The largest fibroadenoma (which is a benign finding) I have seen a report of was about 20x20x15 cm (which is about 7"x7"x5"). https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12751688 Masses can also be very tiny (millimeters in size). Chances this is cancer? That's hard to say. Normally they rate mammograms and MRIs with what is called a BIRADS score. You'd have to see your radiology report to see how they rated it. A BIRADS 4 report has about a 5-95% (yes, that's a big range) of it being cancer; a BIRADS 5 report has about a 95% or more chance of being cancer. You should be able to request a copy of your breast MRI report. The other BIRADS numbers (1,2,3) are for other findings. They normally biopsy BIRADS 4 and 5 reports. (Sometimes they split BIRADS 4 into 4A, 4B and 4C, giving you an idea of which end of the spectrum you are in the 5-95% chance of it being cancer. 4C looks more suspicious for cancer than 4A.) Depending on your age, fibroadenomas (which are benign) are the most common breast masses. (Fibroadenomas are quite common in pre-menopausal women, they are more unusual in postmenopausal women.) Fibroadenomas can grow and shrink (degenerate) over time (commonly over years). Since a biopsy is recommended, I would strongly consider following up on this. Hope you get normal results.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2016 12:06PM leaf wrote: There are many 'risk factors' for breast cancer. Its good to know not only how big a risk factor is, but how well we know that information. You may want to read this paper carefully. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.... I am more concerned about MY risk of breast cancer, not the risk of breast cancer of a large group, such as the risk of breast cancer in all women in the USA. In this paper, it points out these are quite different. Most risk factors for breast cancer are quite small. This makes it hard to tell the difference between women with breast cancer and women without breast cancer. With the possible exception of large risk factors, such as being a woman, or a deleterious BRCA mutation, or maybe age or large radiation doses (such as radiation treatment in the chest for people with a cancer like lymphoma), most risk factors are too small to tell the difference between a woman with breast cancer and a woman without breast cancer. The 'science' of breast cancer prediction, especially for individual people, is in its infancy.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2015 03:21AM - edited Jan 5, 2015 03:23AM by leaf I'm sorry you are going through this scare. Most people do not handle potential threats to their health well. Also you have the experience of seeing what happened to your late husband. No one wants to have concerning lesions, or potentially concerning lesions in their breast, but there can be drawbacks to having everything suspicious excised. Excisions can leave scar tissue, which makes it harder for radiologists to read future mammograms. That means they can miss suspicious lesions in future mammograms. You also cannot always excise all suspicious lesions. I have a rather unusual condition called LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ, which is not normally considered cancer in spite of its name), which does not normally show up on imaging. Normally there are many spots of it in a breast, and its often in both breasts. So, since they have no way of knowing where the LCIS spots are without biopsying them, they often don't (which would be a mastectomy), unless you have other stronger risk factors. When LCIS women go on to get breast cancer in the future, it is often in an area that looks normal previously. They don't know how LCIS confers risk, but some of the breast cancers that LCIS women go on to get are not clonally related to their LCIS. So, if they find something suspicious, you may want to talk with your doctor what they find. You may or may not agree with your doctor, and if you are concerned you can certainly get 2nd opinions. But you also may want to wait to find out what the suspicious areas are, and whether or not they have changed. Many things need to be individualized in breast cancer diagnosis, and one approach does not fit all circumstances.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2016 07:27AM leaf wrote: When I look on Pubmed, I don't see any papers that address dimple + microcalcifications. I know you're worried beyond worried. But worrying won't change the outcome. I did find a paper that described the biopsies of mammograms that were designated BIRADS 4c or 5 that proved to be benign.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC348138... I had 'suspicious microcalcifications' and (a few months later) had a breast dimple. My diagnosis ended up being LCIS (which is quite unusual, but, in spite of the name,usually considered benign.) Even IF the chances of you having something invasive was 0.0000000001% (I just took this number out of the air), then you'd probably be going to the 'But what if?' That is perfectly natural to do. Different radiologists can interpret mammograms differently. You want to know the your biopsy results NOW. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. Its so easy to go to the worst case scenario. But humans are notoriously bad about estimating their risk. Its totally impossible for us to tell you what your results will be. Waiting is awful. But whether your results end up being benign, DCIS, or invasive, there will be people here who have been in a similar position. It may be helpful to assure yourself that no matter what the outcome is, that you will handle the results when they come. You can assure yourself you will try your hardest to take care of yourself and keep yourself safe no matter what the outcome. Hang in there and let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 02:34AM - edited Apr 21, 2010 02:40AM by leaf Hi Keiko! Yes, do ask your onc if you should continue to take the bcp.  Note that tamoxifen has different effects on the breast than on the uterus.  Initially, tamoxifen acts like an anti-estrogen on the breast, but acts like an estrogen on the uterus. jjco.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/re...  When people take tamoxifen chronically until it becomes ineffective, for example in the setting of metastatic breast cancer (not what you have, of course), *sometimes* after a while tamoxifen can start to act as an estrogen on the breast. So it is possible for it to 'switch'. You have a more complex case, though, so I would check with your doc about your bcp use.  I had endometritis (maybe a milder case though) and dysfunctional bleeding.  I stopped about a year before my LCIS diagnosis because the bcp wasn't working.  I've been taking tamoxifen the last 4 years. Some places have tried tamoxifen + (estrogen +/- progesterone) in treatment protocols (for established cancer, not for prophylactic use like you are doing) such as this study. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...  I don't know of any studies doing this for*prophylaxis* only (i.e. for ALH/ADH/LCIS and nothing worse.) Ask your doc about your risk of bc - whether he/she sees a red flag we don't see.  You will get estimates again.  (I have classic LCIS, ALH, AH, radial scar, and nothing worse, with a weak family history.) I have gotten estimates from "somewhere between 10 and 60% but probably closer to 10%" to 'about 30%' to 'about 40%', to (from a breast cancer calculator that has NOT been compared to populations, without tamoxifen 85%.  This latter figure, 85%, is undoubtedly wrong.  That's why its important to check the predictions with the specific population that has your conditions.) Note: your pattern of screening may change over time.  I started out with checks every 4 months, and now I'm down to clinical exams every 6 months and yearly mammos. Your screening pattern may depend on your doc or local practice - places do differ. Its good to try to write down all your questions so you won't forget - you'll probably be pretty nervous.  Some people take along a friend/relative/significant other to be another pair of 'ears' in case the doc says something that you don't catch.  Some people ask if they can record the session.  If you  do this, make sure you ask your doc first, and practice with the recorder beforehand.  (Guess how I know?) Let us know how it goes, OK?
Posts.Title: ALH is NOT cancer, right? keiko tgood02

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 11:04AM - edited Nov 8, 2009 11:06AM by leaf I do not think you made a mistake either.  I have ALH and LCIS (which is a more advanced form of ALH.  Together, ALH and LCIS are often called lobular neoplasia. )  They often do excisions in the area of ALH.  But the purpose is NOT to remove all the ALH, but to make sure there isn't something worse in the vicinity.  One reason why they don't have a goal of removing all of the ALH is they have no way of knowing where all of the ALH hides.  LCIS is usually multifocal and bilateral, meaning it often occurs in various spots in the breast.  Unfortunately, it usually is not detectable in mammograms or ultrasounds or clinical exams, so  they don't have a way of knowing where it is to remove it.  To 'remove it all' they would have to do mastectomies. Even if somehow they could magically detect all the ALH and remove it, leaving the 'healthy' portions behind, this would not reduce your breast cancer risk, or at least not by much.  (Since they can't do this experiment, they haven't done it.)  What they have done, is : they have looked at women who started out with a diagnosis of ALH or LCIS , then later got breast cancer.  The places they find breast cancer is often in the places that looked healthy when they did the excision.   Lobular neoplasia is a weird disease. If you are worried about seeding other areas of your breast with surgery, you don't have to worry.  Unlike some other types of cancer, it is thought that breast cancer probably does not seed.  If it does seed, it is quite rare - if you have standard therapy for whatever cancer you have.  Biopsy can dislodge breast cancer cells - but usually the dislodged cancer cells die outside of their 'normal' environment.  Even when they don't, it is thought the stray cells are cleaned up by radiation or chemo or surgery.  So, with standard treatment, seeding in breast cancer is thought to be quite rare. Surgery does have the disadavantage of causing scar tissue,which makes it harder to read mammograms and other imaging in the future.  But roughly 20-30%of the women that have LCIS in a core biopsy have 'something worse'   when they excise the area.  So I think most surgeons do want to excise the area so you can be sure you don't have something else going on in that area. I had LCIS on my core biopsy, and I wanted the area to be excised.  I'm glad I did.
Posts.Title: ALH-did I make a mistake? Milana covertanjou

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 02:37PM - edited Apr 19, 2010 02:54PM by leaf Ginger is right - ALH is not cancer.  It just puts you at somewhat higher risk for breast cancer than the average woman.  About what your numbers mean: I bet you (or your doc) put your numbers into the modified Gail model as seen at www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/  ***** The next part of this post describes how little we know about breast cancer prediction. There is a medical journal editorial here (from 2006) that gives you some clue as to how well the Gail model works for predicting YOUR individual risk of breast cancer. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/98/23/1673.pdf It shows that the Gail model (and an Italian model) worked quite well to predict how many women in a population (of Florence, Italy) got breast cancer.   The models predicted that 180 or 184 women would get breast cancer, and they observed  194.  Very good.  They know how many oncologists they need for breast cancer. But there is another way, also, that cancer prediction models are assessed.  They take one randomly selected person from the group with breast cancer and compare her to one randomly selected person from the group withOUT breast cancer.  So you have 'pairs' of women, and you compare the scores they got from the model. If the model worked perfectly, then in each pair of women, the woman with breast cancer would get a higher score than the woman withOUT breast cancer, and the concordance statistic would be 1.  If the model didn't work at all - half the time the person with breast cancer got a higher score than the person withOUT breast cancer, but half the time the person with breast cancer got a LOWER score than the person withOUT breast cancer, the concordance statistic would be 0.5.   If the model had a concordance statistic of 0, then it would be an excellent model, because it would still predict the outcomes perfectly.  For the Gail and Italian models, the score was about 0.59.  This means that for 59% of the pairs, the woman with breast cancer got a higher score, but in 41% of the pairs, the woman with breast cancer got a LOWER score than the woman withOUT breast cancer.  They described the models as "Thus, for any given woman, the two models were better at prediction than a coin toss—but not by much." Yes, you are at higher risk than the average person to get breast cancer.  You shouldn't miss any screening.  That doesn't mean you are at high risk.  For example, the ACS puts ALH in the category of 'moderate risk'.  www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/con... Before you get too afraid of numbers you see thrown around, you may see numbers like 'ALH carries a 4-5 x normal chance of breast cancer.' (A relative risk of 4-5.)    That is 4-5 x the risk of a woman WITHOUT ANY PARTICULAR RISK FACTORS (besides being a woman).   So the 4-5 x is NOT NOT NOT 4-5x 12% the risk of the average woman = some 50-60%. It is 4-5x the risk of a woman without any particular risk factors which is something like 3-5%.  So 4-5 x 3-5 = about 15-25% lifetime risk of breast cancer.   That's using our Gail model predictors -  which are accurate for a particular woman about 60% of the time.   If you had a severe family history of breast/ovarian cancer, then they might be able to predict more accurately because you'd be more likely to have a known BRCA mutation.  Women with a known deleterious BRCA mutation have about a 55-90% lifetime chance of having breast cancer.  There are probably breast cancer genes out there that have not been identified.  But since you have no family history, that's probably not very relevant. **** One thing you may consider doing, if you have not already had this done, is consider if you want to excise the area.   There is some controversy in that decision.  For example http://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/breastalh.html I agree with Ginger - its good to get the onc's take on what you should do.  You have a more complex situation since you've been told to continue to take estrogenic hormones for your endometriosis.
Posts.Title: ALH is NOT cancer, right? keiko tgood02

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2016 10:07AM leaf wrote: Of course you're scared. Flat epithelial atypia (FEA) means you have some cells that are NOT cancer, but are 'abnormal'. You can have perfectly normal cells, and someone can also have cancer cells (that usually look rather chaotic.) There are lots of cells that look in-between - they have some characteristics of normal cells and some of cancer cells. At your surgical consultation, they will probably evaluate you to see if you need an excision (which means removing the area around the core biopsy - unless you have already had a surgical excision.) They are doing that so they can make sure there isn't anything worse (especially DCIS or invasive cancer) which might be handled differently. Different studies will give different results. There are lots of unknowns, but, for example, in this paper they found that 7% of their group with Flat Epithelial Atypia found either DCIS or invasive cancer. http://www.nature.com/modpathol/journal/v28/n5/ful... . That means that some 93% of their patients did NOT find DCIS or invasive breast cancer. Those are pretty good odds in my book. I had a breast excision after my core biopsy showed LCIS, and they took out about 2 tablespoonfulls of breast tissue. I did have a 'dent', but it filled in over time.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2007 10:00AM leaf wrote: I think that it would be good to discuss your situation with a board certified genetics counselor. There are some families that don't have sibs or have only males in a generation, which may make the genetics story more complex. One generation in my family was only sons, and I didn't know if one relative had pre- or post-menopausal bc, and I was referred for genetics counseling. (I only had 2 relatives with bc in my extended second degree family, out of about 20 second degree members (including males.) (I have LCIS.) Some of the signs that suggest higher risk for BRCA include premenopausal bc, breast cancer in males, ovarian cancer, and/or Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Even though my risk for BRCA was low, and I opted not to get tested, I found the analysis very informative and helpful. You may want to check out the costs and insurance issues though. I paid out of pocket for my counseling session and that cost <$400 (in Mar 2006).

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 08:58PM - edited Apr 27, 2010 08:59PM by leaf I agree with Anne.  Sometimes it can be hard to tell the difference between ADH and DCIS, and, of course they are treated differently.  Perhaps 'severe' meant 'extensive', which doesn't necessarily mean there was a wider area of it - that can mean 'extensive' on a microscopic scale - i.e. most of the ducts or lobules *in the field of view of the microscope* had the condition.  They sometimes use the descriptive 'severe' or 'extensive' when most of the ducts or lobules they see on the slide have a certain condition, but the tissue they look at on the slide may be very,very small (i.e. microscopic) and/or have few ducts or lobules in that tissue sample.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 01:56PM - edited Apr 21, 2012 02:03PM by leaf My paternal grandmother had breast cancer in the late 1940s or early 1950s and had bilateral mastectomies.   I actually got referred to genetics screening  when I was diagnosed with LCIS in 2005 because at the time I didn't know when Grandma had breast cancer, and my grandmother only had sons.  When growing up I was told I was never to mention the words 'breast' or 'cancer' to her.    I think at the time breast cancer was considered a death sentence. So you can imagine how much Grandma's sons knew about her breast cancer.   Grandma's sons were not in the least interested in knowing whether or not Grandma was postmenopausal when she got breast cancer.  Grandma died in the 1970s  of an unrelated illness. It ended up that Grandma was in her early 60s when she got breast cancer, so almost certainly postmenopausal. Of course, I can't be sure, but in reading about breast cancer treatment at the time, I think in the 1950s there weren't routine mammograms, so breast cancer tended to be diagnosed at a later stage.  I think it was pretty much thought to be a death sentence.  While there may have been some chemos in research,- though I don't think there were any for breast cancer -  I think its very unlikely she had  any chemos.  I think they routinely did bilateral radical mastectomies at that time even if they found breast cancer in one breast.  I'm not sure of this of course.  I don't think they did much if any radiation, though I may be wrong about that.  I think the main treatment  in the late 1940s/early 1950s were radical mastectomies.   So I think its pretty unlikely that my Grandma had bilateral breast cancer.   The genetics counselor I saw said my risk for having a BRCA mutation was about the same as an AVERAGE  Ashkenazi Jewish woman - roughly 2%.  She said I could have BRCA testing if I wanted to, but my insurance said it wasn't medically necessary. I chose not to be tested - it would be an out-of-pocket expense for me.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 03:34AM - edited Jun 15, 2008 03:36AM by leaf I'm so sorry you are going through this. Diagnosis of anything, where there is even a remote possibility of something life threatening, is always scary. Unfortunately we cannot diagnose you, as you probably know. I'm not sure if your symptoms match anything about the following. a) It is perfectly normal to have a 'thickening' at the lower edge of your breasts called an inframammary ridge. www.breastnotes.com/anatomy/an... I'm not sure if this matches the location of your ridge. b) I'm not sure what the 'swollen vessels in the breast' are either. I'm not sure if you can feel them or not. Posts.Title: What is this? Anamootoo CarolynTBotell

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 02:20AM leaf wrote: Who wouldn't be scared in your position?   Here's an excellent website on calcifications, courtesy of momzr.  http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 Even *IF* your calcifications turn out to be cancer, they are usually indicative of early breast cancer. Perhaps the reason why your doc said 2 pathologists have to agree is this:     Usually it is fairly easy to tell invasive cancer apart from non-invasive cancer (i.e. in situ cancer.)  It can be harder to diagnose in situ cancer, and to tell that apart from higher risk benign conditions (such as atypical hyperplasia).   On both my pathology reports, they state that the pathologist double checked with another pathologist.  Almost all breast cancer is diagnosed by a pathologist.  (The type that sometimes isn't is inflammatory breast cancer, and you don't have the symptoms for that.)  No one on this big green earth can tell you your diagnosis for sure before someone looks at your slides.  I know its easy to think that they are 'hiding things from me'. Sometimes they tell you your BIRADS score.  They normally do biopsies on BIRADS 4 or 5 conditions.  www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/... But even if you had a BIRADS score of 5, they still wouldn't know for sure whether or not you have cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. I hope you don't beat yourself up about not having a mammogram for some time.   Most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 6-10 years (not a typo) before they are large enough to be detected by any means.  So most breast cancers are relatively slow growing. Holding out my hands to you.  I wish you didn't have to be here.  The waiting is awful, and I wish I could take the awfulness away.   Hang in there.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 12:28AM - edited Oct 7, 2007 12:28AM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this. We all want to know what is on the path ahead of us, so we can be prepared. I was very, very scared, and I bet these other women were too. Anyone in your shoes would be scared because they don't know. For me, it has been very normal to hang on to every word-because we want to make sure that nothing has been missed. But we usually don't have the big picture. Remember that 80% of biopsies are benign. Even **if** you have breast cancer, it is *not* an automatic death sentence. Breast cancer is usually quite treatable. When I was waiting for my biopsy results, I wanted to know the worst case scenario, and was asking if I wouldn't even live to make it through diagnosis. I was reading everything I could about my 'suspicious calcifications'. Some women here have planned their funeral in detail while they wait for their biopsy results. So we all have been very scared. Try to hang in there. Please keep us posted. Feel free to vent if you wish. Waiting is horrible.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 04:08PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:04AM by leaf It sounds like she is going through testing - so she might not end up getting a diagnosis of breast cancer - right? I'm not her, of course, but I would have liked to hear just what you said :-).  So I just let her know that if she ever changed her mind and wanted to talk to me, I'd be here for her. Most people take some time to figure out how they feel.  Most people want a non-judgemental listener. But I would guess that she will only open up to you when/if she feels safe. It can take some time to develop trust. During my diagnosis process, I really regretted telling anyone at my place of work.(I work at the hospital where I get care.)  I initially told people at work ONLY because I was crying at work whenever anyone got admitted with breast cancer, and I wanted my co-workers to know that they had not done anything to cause my red, swollen eyes.  I got unwanted advice (from essentially a male stranger) that I should have bilateral mastectomies, and I had people tell me 'If I was in your shoes I would have done X'  when I had already done Y, which is the opposite of X.   I did NOT find that very supportive, so I told them the subject of my breasts is OFF-LIMITS.  Then later, I had a co-worker (who I had never talked about my medical diagnoses) tell me 'I must be the last one to know about your breast condition but I want to wish you well.'  Gee, I appreciated that too.  Maybe I should wear a sign with my diagnosis. I now am in the process of getting an alias for when I get medical care at my place of work because I'm so angry at many of my co-workers who aren't at all aware about confidentiality.  So I would guess I wouldn't bring up the subject unless she brings it up.  Or, at most, tell her that you are thinking of her, but DON'T pose it as a question that she needs to respond to.  In other words, don't ask "How are you doing?"  But something like "Please know I'm thinking of you." would be better.  That way she doesn't have to respond if she feels angry or that you wouldn't understand or something. I'm not very good at relationships, so I'm sure others will have better ideas.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 05:04PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:04AM by leaf Someone here said, Its IMPOSSIBLE to say the right thing when you first year after you get diagnosed  (or even longer.)  I think there is wisdom in that.  I still REGULARLY put my foot in my mouth. I do see a therapist, and that's the only way I get hints on how to function properly in society :-) Problem is: we're all individuals.  So what one person wants/needs, another person doesn't.  If she does get bc, then I've read a lot of women here that do NOT want pity.  Now, I know I probably have a different psychological makeup, because sometimes I get so infantile that I do want Genuine (not fake) sympathy.   So I don't Really understand what some posters here mean by pity. Another thing that is almost guaranteed: Please don't say, "Be positive".  If you got the worst news you ever had in your life, does it make any sense for you to handle a tragedy by being positive?  But that's part of being non-judgemental I think. There is a whole big thread called The Dumbest things that people have said to you/about you. community.breastcancer.org/for...  - its a huge thread, but maybe you can sample some. You're right- I think people vary a lot in whether or not they want other people to know.  There will almost always be people who will say stupid things to you, and that does hurt, especially at first.   But I think its really good, as you perceived: don't push.  Take the cues from her. She needs to feel whatever she is feeling - sadness, anger, elation, good, bad, whatever.  Let her open up in her own time and own way.  I wish some people at my workplace were as concerned about what they do/say as you are :-).

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 05:31PM - edited May 5, 2008 05:39PM by leaf I didn't have any problem with my first stereotactic mammo-guided core biopsy. I was told 'if you start to have any pain, tell me right away, and I'll stop and inject more anesthetic." I was completely stressed out. I think the hardest thing was hearing when he said 'Breathe' versus 'Don't breathe', because sometimes the table would jerk or make noise. The second time I had a stereotactic mammo-guided core, it was a little rougher because I had been traumatized by a wire insertion for excision a year previous where they had not given adequate anesthesia. I freaked out even before they made the first injection - I pulled out of the mammo. I was silently sobbing the whole time. This was all emotional. I think it would have been fine had it been my first core biopsy. The third time I had a ultrasound-guided core biopsy, just under the nipple. I was freaked out about this one too, because I heard its more sensitive around the nipple. But it actually was more comfortable and went quicker than the mammo-guided. I wasn't offered and didn't have any anti-anxiety meds for any of these - I think I could have used some. The mammo-guided ones took about 3 hours and the ultrasound about 1 hr. I got the results in about 2-3 days. For me, a jogbra 24/7 except showering and tiny ice packs were great. I just used the pain meds to try to make me sleep. (I didn't have pain issues, but I had insomnia from anxiety issues.) If you have pain - COMPLAIN! All of my biopsy radiologists were actually quite responsive to my pain and injected more anesthetic right away.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 01:40AM - edited Mar 5, 2011 01:43AM by leaf I have LCIS and ALH and ductal hyperplasia (not atypical hyperplasia), and I'm finishing up my last year (of 5 years) of tamoxifen.  I had 'warm' flashes the first few months I took it, and have had irregular vaginal bleeding and endometrial polyps (all benign), but I also had all these before I started tamoxifen. Some people have a horrible time with tamoxifen, and some people have no side effects.  You can't tell what category you will be in, or if you will be something inbetween. Remember, on any board, people are much more likely to post about side effects of a medication if they are having bad problems than if they are not. Most people who take a medication and have no side effects do not post about that experience.  There are very few medications, if any, that 100% of patients have a particular side effect.  I'm a hospital pharmacist, and one time someone called and told me never to dispense Dilaudid (an opiate) again because it made her pain worse.  I don't doubt her experience, but that is not the experience of most people. I'm not trying to equate the two, but it is possible in some people with some situations to die of drinking too much water. Luckily,one option is that you can start tamoxifen, and if you don't like it you can stop.   Some people find listing the risks in one column and benefits in another column, and comparing the two can helps with their decision.  Not everyone who takes tamoxifen will have strokes or get endometrial cancer, and not everyone who has ADH will get breast cancer.  You have the power to decide.  Its up to you.  Only you can determine how the possibility of stroke or endometrial cancer would affect you.  Only you can determine how the possibility of breast cancer risk reduction would affect you.   Not everyone who takes tamoxifen gets a stroke or endometrial cancer; from what I've read, the incidence of stroke or endometrial cancer  is something like 1% or less.  And some people do have other side effects; I'm not trying to belittle them. We each need to decide what is best for us on our own journey.  My choice may not be your choice.  And that is how it should be.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 08:42AM - edited Mar 5, 2011 08:53AM by leaf My optometrist is very aware of my tamoxifen use and its possible effect on the eye. But look at the order of magnitude risk in this 2006 study - the incidence was <1%.  Now different populations and studies may give different numbers, since you almost certainly didn't undergo chemotherapy. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16...  In the 1998 NSABP study that compared tamoxifen to placebo for breast cancer prevention (which would be more of your situation), the rate of cataract development was 21.71/1000 women for  the placebo group, and 24.82/1000 for women in the tamoxifen group. (page 1379, bottom).jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten...   So if you simply subtract the two incidences, you get an excess rate of about 3 excess incidences of cataracts per 1000 women for the women who take tamoxifen. That's a pretty low incidence in my book, but it may not be in yours.  We all have different feelings about what kinds of risks we want to take. I don't know how you feel about this; its your body and your choice.  Many people in the US don't go blind from cataracts - many people have cataract surgery if they have significant cataracts.    You may have a different medical situation too.  You may not be like the people in these studies.  But those are the best numbers I can come up with. You would need to compare this risk to the risk of not taking tamoxifen or doing something different.  Its an individual choice.

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 02:54AM leaf wrote: I agree with Elizabeth: In this 2004 study Twenty-two institutions enrolled 2,403 women who underwent imaging-guided fine needle aspiration followed by imaging-guided large-CB of nonpalpable breast abnormalities. All mammograms were reviewed for study eligibility by one of two breast imaging radiologists. The protocol for image-guided biopsy, using either ultrasound (USCB) or stereotactic (SCB) guidance, was standardized at all institutions and all biopsy specimens were over-read by one of three expert pathologists. Patients with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH), atypical lobular hyperplasia, or lobular neoplasia on CB underwent surgical excision. Those with negative CB but suspicious ("discordant") pre-biopsy mammography also underwent surgical excision. Patients having a negative CB that was concordant with the pre-biopsy mammography suspicion were assigned to follow-up mammography at 6, 12, and 24 months following CB. RESULTS: A gold standard diagnosis based on definitive histopathologic diagnosis, mammography follow-up, or an imputed gold standard diagnosis was established for 1,681 patients. Of 310 cases with a gold standard diagnosis of invasive breast carcinoma, 261 (84.2%) were invasive carcinoma, 31 (10%) were ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), four (1.3%) were ADH, one (0.3%) was a non-breast cancer, and 13 (4.2%) were benign on CB ...The sensitivity, predictive value negative, and accuracy of CB for diagnosing masses (.96, .99, and .99, respectively) were significantly greater (P < .001) than for calcifications (.84, .94, and .96, respectively).www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... (emphasis mine) I think this study used a single core biopsy, not multiple core biopsies. Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 03:37AM leaf wrote: To try to answer your statistics question a bit, in Dr. Susan Love's Breast book, it says if you are the average 20 year old, your chances of getting breast cancer in the next 10 years are 1 in 2152.  If you are the average 30 year old, your chances of getting breast cancer in the next 10 years is 1 in 251.  The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's 60s.  As far as I know, cervical cancer is not a risk, but if you have ovarian cancer in your family, then your chances are higher.  If you have breast cancer in your family, particularly premenopausal breast cancer, then your risk is greater.  (Ovarian cancer and premenopausal breast cancer in your family are signs you MAY want to consider BRCA testing.) Cysts (which are almost always benign) and benign fibroadenomas are common in young women.  Some women have lots of them. This doesn't mean you shouldn't get them checked out, as you are doing.

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2013 01:32PM leaf wrote: Waiting is awful. You can try to get on a cancellation list. By the time you get a firm diagnosis on what your lump is, you may be certifiably insane.  Its just plain awful.  I found distraction helped.  Some people get sedatives from their general doc.  In reality, except for some very unusual breast cancers (such as inflammatory breast cancer - you do NOT have the typical symptoms for that) - most breast cancers are slow growing.  The typical breast cancer has been in the breast for some 5-10 years (not a typo) before it can be detected by ANY means (including mammogram, palpation, ultrasound, etc.)  So, even though its hard, this extended waiting time probably won't make any clinical difference. Some people exercise, do meditation or religion, do shop therapy, get drunk, drive too fast, or clean their house compulsively.  I would encourage the more health promoting options rather than the self destructive ones. I am *not* trying to belittle your anxiety.  Many people, including myself, were thinking of the worst case scenario while they were waiting.  But I didn't know at the time that the worst case scenario very rarely happens.  And, as one person said, if the worst case scenario then comes true, then you get to live through it twice.  This probably won't help you going to the dark places, but you are definitely not alone.  Waiting is awful.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 02:19PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:28AM by leaf Well, he's just being thorough.  There is no imaging system for breast cancer that is 100% sensitive and 100% accurate.  This means there is no imaging that picks up 100% of cancers, and only detects cancer and not benign lesions. Ultrasounds are good at detecting cysts, which are a fluid filled sac, and are almost always benign.  Cysts can feel like lumps, especially if they are deep.   MRIs are usually quite sensitive (they pick up most breast cancers), but they also pick up 'junk' that is benign.   Its quite unusual, but there are some posters here who have said they had a lump, but had negative mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs.  When they had it biopsied, it was cancer.  That is very unusual, but can happen.    Depending on your ethnicity, and the medical history of other relatives, you *may* be of increased risk of breast cancer.  Only about 5-15% of breast cancers are thought to be from genetically inherited mutations, and about 70% of women who do have breast cancer have no obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.)  Density is a risk factor for breast cancer, but it must be put into perspective.  Breast cancer prediction for an individual is in its infancy.   For example, the Gail model www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ can give you a number that has 3 significant digits.  It is probably quite accurate in predicting how many women *in a population* will get breast cancer.  However, it is LOUSY at predicting exactly who in that population will get breast cancer.  This older (2006) editorial article in a medical journal says that the Gail model, including other models that add more risk factors - including breast density -  are,for the individuals in this study, "better at prediction than a coin toss, but not by much." jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten...  While breast density is a risk factor, it only improved the concordance score from 0.58 to 0.66.  This means than when they took a random woman who had breast cancer, and compared her test score to a woman who did NOT have breast cancer, the woman with breast cancer had a higher score only 58% of the time (for a regular Gail score model) or 66% of the time (when breast density, and other factors, were added.)  This means that about 35-42% of the time the woman WITHOUT breast cancer had a higher test (Gail, or Gail + breast density and other factors) score. So biopsy is the 'gold standard' of diagnosis (assuming they sample the 'lesion of concern'.) Except perhaps for inflammatory breast cancer, a person is normally diagnosed with breast cancer by a pathologist who looks at your slides.  Imaging can give you an idea, and MRIs can give you a good idea.  But if you are in doubt, go for a biopsy.  An MRI can give them ideas on where they should biopsy.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 05:14PM leaf wrote: At my place, it varies by the situation.  For women doing just mammograms (screening or diagnostic), you never see the radiologist; you just see the radiology assistant, and get a written notice in a week or two.  Once you're higher risk, the radiologist will read your mammogram while you are there, but you'll still never see the radiologist.  The assistant will tell you the results.  If you're having a biopsy done, the radiologist will do that personally, along with a radiology assistant, and you'll be able to ask them questions directly.  If you're having a wire insertion (before breast excision) the radiologist will do that too, with an assistant.  One woman I know had her wires inserted by a radiology assistant, not a radiologist.   I don't know if some places use radiology assistants to do biopsies, but all my biopsies have been done by radiologists.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 07:01AM leaf wrote: If none of your  first or second degree relatives actually had  breast and/or ovarian cancer at an early age (before menopause) and often has multiple, close family members who have been diagnosed with these diseases. Harmful BRCA1 mutations may also increase a woman’s risk of developing cervical, uterine, pancreatic, and colon cancer (1, 2). Harmful BRCA2 mutations may additionally increase the risk of pancreatic cancer, stomach cancer, gallbladder and bile duct cancer, and melanoma (3), then you and/or your relatives are not at high risk for having a BRCA mutation. http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/BRCA The Gail risk model that I find does not list the 10 yr risk of having breast cancer, but a 5 yr or lifetime (to age 95) risk. http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ The Gail model is the most widely used model for breast cancer risk.  But it isn't very good at estimating YOUR risk.  Its very good at estimating how many people in a population will get breast  cancer, but its only 'slightly better than the roll of the dice' for giving you an appropriate score for YOUR chance of having breast cancer.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... the brown button on the right to get a free copy of the article.) This study did NOT find an association with hyperthyroid and breast cancer. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19155436 This study did find an association in certain age groups in those treated with radioactive iodine.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...   But before you panic, note that the relative risk (RR) was about 1.53.  This does NOT NOT NOT mean 1.53 x 13% = about 20%; this means 1.53 x the risk of a woman without any particular risk factors for breast cancer.  There is controversy about  this number, but its about 3-5%.  So if you had RAI and are in the appropriate age group,  then your risk for this factor would be about 3-5 x 1.53 = about  5-8% lifetime risk.  The 'average' woman in the US has something like a 11-13%lifetime risk. Statistics are tricky.  If you have multiple risk factors, then you have to compare that to the risk of people with all of your risk factors.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 12:20PM leaf wrote: I have never had a breast MRI, and I don't have a good intuitive feel for physics, but I can guess part of what might be going on.  I may have part or all of this wrong, but I'm just trying to piece together information from some academic papers.  I'm understanding maybe 10% of what these papers are saying. It sounds like fat in breasts can cause 'ghosts' in the image, which makes it much harder to tell what is going on.  I don't know if larger breasts in general are more fatty or not.  The breast shape can make it harder to get good images too, because the magnetic beam is supposed to be at 90 degrees from the lesion in order to get better images.  If you have metal clips still in place from a core biopsy, it could make it harder to read the MRI.  If the magnetic strength of the MRI is <1.5 Teslas, then it can be harder to get clear images, especially with fat saturation.  If the magnetic field is uneven, then you can get 'bad' images.   There are at least 2 ways to get the 'fat ghosts' out: one is fat saturation, and another is inversion recovery imaging.  They each have their advantages and disadvantages. http://radiographics.rsna.org/content/19/2/373.full I think there are many, many settings that can be made on an MRI machine, and some machines are more adjustable than others.  Since MRIs don't use radiation, it may be safer than a mammogram in respect to radiation.  I think some people rarely can have trouble with the MRI dye (gadolinium), particularly if they have poor kidney function. breastcancer.about.com/od/brea...

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 11:38AM - edited Nov 23, 2007 11:39AM by leaf Having breast biopsies is very stressful. It is normal to be afraid. We are here to listen and support you in this forum. Birads is a rating of how suspicious an image is. I think it was originally developed for mammos, but I think I've heard of these scales being used sometimes for ultrasounds and MRIs too. Birads 1 is routine screening (negative) Birads 2 is definite benign Birads 3 is probably benign (less than 2% incidence of cancer) Birads 4 is suspicious for malignancy, Not typical, but could be. Birads 5 is characteristic of malignancy. Birads 6 is biopsy proven malignancy.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2016 03:27PM leaf wrote: I know you are in panic mode because you just donated a kidney, went through testing, and because you were referred to an urgent care place. No, breast cancer normally does not show up on any testing they would do for kidney donation. But the vast majority of women with lumps, even lumps that enlarge, do NOT have breast cancer. Of course, you do need to be seen and go through the testing, but there is NO WAY they can know whether or not you have breast cancer. You cannot be diagnosed with breast cancer (except the rare inflammatory breast cancer, and you don't have the symptoms for that) until a pathologist looks at a piece of breast tissue under the microscope. The average age to get breast cancer is in one's mid-60s. The vast majority of breast lumps in women your age are either cysts (fluid filled sacs) which are NOT malignant, or a benign breast adenoma (which is a benign growth). So, of course, do get all the screening they recommend. You're actually lucky they want you to get through the system quickly. Most women take months to get through the diagnosis process. It took me 3 months from my abnormal mammogram to my breast excision. For one acquaintance, it took 6 months.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 05:25AM leaf wrote: Its very easy to go to the 'worst case scenario'. We all want to be ready for whatever comes, even if the chances of it are low. Humans are notoriously bad about estimating their risk.  Most people are much more afraid of a shark attack than being hit by lightening.  There have been 106 confirmed unprovoked shark attacks in the USA from 1916 to 2011, of which 13 were fatal www.flmnh.ufl.edu/fish/sharks/... whereas there have been 27 lightening fatalities in the USA just in 2012 www.lightningsafety.noaa.gov/f... Your breast specialist probably sees dozens of mammograms a day, so its probably hard to remember yours.  So even if she cares about your anxiety, doctors are just humans and aren't computers in remembering every detail about each mammogram.   Lots of people try to read a lot into the nonverbal cues in their technician or doctor.  But they really don't know; if they knew they wouldn't have to do the testing. Imaging can be difficult to interpret. I'm sure you wouldn't like it if you were told everything was fine when you did have a problem; you wouldn't like it either if they told you there was a problem when there wasn't.  Some people find distraction helps, other people get antianxiety meds from their doc.  As some wise people have said, worrying won't change the outcome, and if your fears are right and you do get the unusual 'worst case scenario', then you'll be going through the worry scenario twice.  Its hard to stop yourself from worrying, but for me distraction helped.  For me, I couldn't do something I liked to do, but I could do things I hated to do.    Hang in there.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 08:12AM - edited Mar 21, 2014 11:38AM by leaf Breasts are not normal one week and then abnormal the next.   For most breast cancers, breast cancers have been in the breast for some 5-10 years (not a typo) before they can be detected by *any* means (including mammogram, ultrasound, MRI, palpation-lumps, thicknesses, etc.)  You can have diagnoses of 'gray areas' - in other words, breast cells that are not totally normal, but not totally cancerous either. (This has nothing to do with the black, white, and gray areas in a mammogram or ultrasound.) Some places have computer assisted mammogram reading, and others have radiologist read mammogram reading.  (I don't know whether computer assisted mammogram readings are double checked by radiologists. I assume so, but I don't know for sure.)  Its very common to have call backs. Sometimes the breast skin folds over in the mammogram machine.  Different radiologists can interpret a mammogram differently.  If there are different software companies making different programs to interpret mammograms, they probably interpret things differently.   Sometimes they want you to come back to see a specific area more carefully - such as 'spot compression', so they can see more clearly.  To give you some idea of what the radiologist is up against, here is a website that shows different mammograms (look at the mammograms near the bottom of the page.) http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/p4793bfde0ed5...  I have 1 friend who has had at least 10 call backs, and has never had a breast biopsy, and is totally healthy breast-wise.   We all wish breast imaging was 100% accurate (picked up every case of breast cancer) and 100% specific (only picked up breast cancer and nothing else). Unfortunately, its not.  I've seen figures thrown around that mammograms are about 80% accurate (they pick up about 80% of breast cancers), and something on the order of <20% specific (usually you have callbacks before they decide whether or not you need a biopsy, and about 80% of breast biopsies overall turn out to be benign.)  This figure can be different in different situations, so, to take an extreme example, if you a postmenopausal woman and have ulcers on the outside of your breast, you are much more likely to have breast cancer than if you are a 20 year old with a breast lump.  So, as you see, we have a long way to go to get to 100% accurate and 100% specific, even with the very best imaging we have. I think most people here wish there was more money spent into better breast cancer detection, and less money into 'breast cancer awareness'. If you have a suspicious mammogram, they will sometimes do ultrasound or other imaging to see if they see anything different there.  Each type of imaging sees something different.  The more 'negatives' (i.e. nothing suspicious seen on a particular imaging) you pile up, the less your chance of having breast cancer.  But you haven't gotten to that point, let alone to a breast biopsy. Second opinions are always fine, but its first good to know why they called you back.  It could have been an equipment problem or placement of your breast problem or a place that is too blurry (in which case I wouldn't get a 2nd opinion), or it could be the opinion of the radiologist (in which case it might be reasonable to get a 2nd opinion.) The important thing is that someone is looking at your mammogram again. Once I had a mammogram and they forgot to put film in the machine.   Of course, its natural to be anxious/angry when they interpret things as one way one time, and another way the next.  It makes us wonder how careful things are being done.  But from what you say, you don't know why you are getting the call backs.  Interpretation of mammograms can be very difficult, and one radiologist may disagree with another.  The more 'double checks' help prevent errors. I am glad they are being careful and calling you back.

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 08:54AM leaf wrote: This is a gray area. I am at higher risk for bc (I have LCIS.) I had 2 biopsies last Feb (after a core biopsy and excision which found my LCIS a year before). One was because ' they may have mislabeled as scar tissue' a breast lesion they were following on US. This was after the 'all clear' reading had been missed by 3 ultrasounds and 1 mammo over a period of 9 months. I was not a happy camper. I could have had completely obvious ILC for 9 months. (LCIS women are at more risk for the sneaky ILC.) But both biopsies were found to be benign (scar tissue/ ductal hyperplasia, not atypical.) I was most recently advised from a major institution that I should not have MRI screenings in that breast 'because I had too much scar tissue.' As much as I disagree with them, 'Mysterious scar tissue' can look just as mysterious on us as on mammo. US may not make anything clearer. And MRI even more so. (MRI probably has more false positives than mammo or us.) Your choice may be influenced by factors such as a) How comfortable are you with waiting? How well do you tolerate anxiety? b) How high risk are you for breast cancer otherwise?
