Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 12:57PM - edited Jan 18, 2009 12:59PM by leaf Hi Joan!  At my place, my routine mammogram was ordered by my OB/GYN.  It was suspicious.  The radiologist recommended a biopsy, but it had to be ordered by a clinician.  My OB/GYN ordered the biopsy.  When I got the results, I was referred to a breast surgeon, who did the excisional biopsy.  Some people get a breast surgeon involved earlier than this. Then the breast surgeon recommends a biopsy.  At my place, the radiologist can't order a biopsy.  I suspect they want several docs involved in case of law suits. Whether or not you have an MRI may depend on your situation.  MRIs are not as invasive as a biopsy, but they are costly, and some insurance companies will not cover them.  So sometimes in the process of getting diagnosed, some people have MRIs and some don't.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 06:48PM leaf wrote: Breast MRIs can pick up things that other imaging techniques can't (like mammos, ultrasounds.) They aren't 100% (nothing is). As far as I know, its probably the most sensitive we have of the imaging techniques . MRIs have a lot of false positives, which means that you can have your MRI light up like a Christmas tree and you think you must have cancer all over, but, no, it can be something as simple as inflammation. In other words, MRIs can show a lot of things that are NOT cancer. These are the 2007 ACS guidelines for MRIs for *screening*, not diagnosis. caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/c... I think it is common now for women to have an MRI after bc diagnosis to make sure there aren't any other spots to worry about, including in the 'other' breast. I'm not sure if its standard or not though. Probably others who have done this can correct me/give more details.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2013 06:31AM - edited Jun 25, 2013 06:32AM by leaf Good for you for getting this checked out! Different studies differ, but the incidence of breast cancer in recently inverted nipple without a breast mass in this group of women many years ago was 5%. None of the women who had breast cancer were under the age of 50.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7069669 In this old study of 3 women with acute inverted nipple, the incidence of something suspicious was 33% - but this was one out of a total of 3 people (not a big enough sample to say anything) and it doesn't say that this one woman was diagnosed with breast cancer. In the 14 women that had nipple inversion during adulthood, two women (14%) had an underlying malignancy. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9423612 So, if you are like the women in these studies, your liklihood of having breast cancer is quite low. Waiting is awful, but even in the unlikely chance you have breast cancer, most breast cancer is very slow growing.  They estimate that most breast cancers have been in the body for some 5-8 years (not a typo) before they can be detected by ANY means (including mammogram, lump, etc.) Many women take months to get through the diagnosis process. The fastest I have read here is days, and the longest I've read here is over a year, when the person was mis-diagnosed with some other cancer such as lymphoma.  I think most women take at least a month to get through the diagnosis process.  It took me 3.5 months to go from routine mammogram to getting a written report of my diagnosis. Waiting is awful, but many women find distraction helps.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2012 01:22AM leaf wrote: I think many of us go to the  'worst case' scenario.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us.  But the incidence of breast cancer in young women is low.   In this paper, they list several benign causes of nipple retraction. By examining 201 patents by currently available radiation (X-ray, ultrasound, and radionuclide) and pathomorphological techniques, the authors consider that benign diseases (nonspecific mastitis, focal fibrosclerosis, pathological secretion appearing as ductal cysts or papillomas, fibroadenomas, gynecomastia, oleogranulomas) and different histological forms of breast cancer (Paget's disease, infiltrating ductal carcinoma, infiltrating and non-infiltrating lobular carcinoma) result in the retracted nipple syndrome http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17633884 This paper states that Nipple retraction is a common symptom but in the abscence of a mass is rarely due to breast cancer. docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=c... This paper states  Nipple inversion may be bilateral or unilateral and usually results from a benign process that takes place gradually, over a long period (eg, a few years). When nipple inversion occurs more rapidly (eg, within a few months), the cause is more likely to be a malignancy. Additional mammographic work-up is needed in cases in which the history of nipple inversion is not known or in which nipple inversion developed over a short period of time. The additional work-up should include spot compression views with the nipple in profile (to determine whether there is a retroareolar mass) as well as craniocaudal and lateral spot magnification views to assess microcalcifications. If the mammographic views are unrevealing, US should be performed. Reported histopathologic findings in cases of acute nipple inversion with a benign cause include mammary duct ectasia, postsurgical changes (Fig 10), fat necrosis, fibrocystic changes, and Mondor disease (13).http://radiographics.rsna.org/content/27/suppl_1/S65.long I don't know the incidence of many of these benign conditions, but fibrocystic changes are extremely common.   Hang in there.  Its good that you are getting  this checked out (I'm not a physician), but I would guess your chances of having breast cancer are low.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 03:54AM leaf wrote: I agree with WolfsLady re Raynaud's.  You are certainly not alone. This site says Prevalence studies have shown that 3-12.5% of men and 6-20% of women report symptoms of Raynaud's phenomenon. Prevalence is higher in colder climates...One study of about 1,500 people found that 89% of Raynaud's phenomenon was classified as primary and 11% as secondary to an underlying cause http://www.patient.co.uk/doctor/raynauds-phenomeno... So Raynaud's is certainly common, and statistics are certainly overwhelmingly in your favor that there is nothing else going on. Anxiety also can make Raynaud's worse.  That doesn't mean, of course, that I'm telling you to stop worrying. (Of course, I'm not a physician and can't diagnose; anyway telling someone to stop worrying will probably make their worrying worse!)  But, for me, distraction and exercise helps when I'm anxious; some people get antidepressants or anti-anxiety meds or therapy for longer-term conditions. Many people with Raynaud's wear hats, gloves, and socks most of the time (even indoors).  Some people feel a 'loss of control', so for them it can help to consciously and actively select what to do.  Do what makes sense for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 07:32PM leaf wrote: I'm so sorry you have to wait longer.  Further testing could mean a variety of things: perhaps they ran out of a stain (such as stains that help the pathologist classify what kind of cells are in your sample). Perhaps one of the machines broke, or the cells were distorted in the sample.  Perhaps there is a shortage of a stain or a chemical needed to prepare the tissue.  They need to slice the sample very thinly.   Perhaps there is uncertainty or disagreement about the diagnosis between pathlogists.  Sometimes they send the slides to another institution.  Usually it is easy to tell the difference between invasive and non-invasive samples, but it can be difficult to diagnose 'normal' vs higher risk lesions.  Waiting is awful.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2010 10:29AM - edited Sep 3, 2010 10:33AM by leaf Thanks for letting us know.  Unless you have a signficant family history of breast cancer, you are probably not considered to be at high risk. Proliferative lesions without atypia: These conditions show excessive growth of cells in the ducts or lobules of the breast tissue. They seem to raise a woman's risk of breast cancer slightly (1½ to 2 times normal). They include: Proliferative lesions with atypia: In these conditions, there is excessive growth of cells in the ducts or lobules of the breast tissue, and the cells no longer appear normal. They have a stronger effect on breast cancer risk, raising it 4 to 5 times higher than normal. They include: Women with a family history of breast cancer and either hyperplasia or atypical hyperplasia have an even higher risk of developing a breast cancer. For more information on these conditions, see the separate American Cancer Society document, Non-cancerous Breast Conditions.  http://www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCancer/DetailedGuide/breast-cancer-risk-factors Women with some of the breast conditions listed above may be at increased risk for breast cancer. But it is important to keep in mind what this increase in risk really means. For example, a recent study compared breast cancer risk between women with benign breast conditions and those without. The study found that about 5 of 100 women without any benign breast conditions developed breast cancer within the next 15 years. Among women with a benign condition that increases risk 1½ to 2 times, this would mean that about 7 to 10 out of 100 might be expected to develop breast cancer in the next 15 years. Among women with atypical hyperplasia (ductal or lobular), whose risk is 4 to 5 times normal, about 20 to 25 women out of 100 would be expected to develop breast cancer within 15 years. The risk for cancer then declines after 15 years. http://www.cancer.org/Healthy/FindCancerEarly/WomensHealth/Non-CancerousBreastConditions/non-cancerous-breast-conditions-women-at-inc-br-cancer-risk Some of these numbers may be somewhat controversial. In contrast, women with a  deleterious BRCA mutation may have a 60-90% lifetime chance of getting breast cancer.   (I have classic LCIS, ALH, DH (not atypical), radial scar, with a weak family history.   Classic LCIS alone is widely thought to have about a 7-10 times normal risk, and I think the ACS doesn't consider me to be at high risk.  Risk factors are NOT necessarily additive - you may not have higher risk if you have 2 risk factors.  As far as I know, they haven't studied the long term risk of women who have a history of ADH with radial scar, so we probably won't know for some time.) Best wishes to you!

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 06:40AM - edited Apr 8, 2009 06:40AM by leaf We can't diagnose you, of course, but one of the things that a high white cell count can mean is an infection. ANA stands for antinuclear antibody.  Its not very specific, but it can be associated with some auto-immune diseases.  You can't diagnose someone with just a positive ANA. ANAs can be high in everyone from skin conditions like vitilago (where people have irregular skin pigmentation) to thyroid conditions, cancer, some types of arthritis, connective tissue diseases like polymyositis, infections, etc. You have been waiting waaaay too long for answers.  Please know we will all be thinking of you.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 10:48AM - edited Apr 6, 2008 10:49AM by leaf I don't think they know exactly why calcifications occur. They may have something to do with age or trauma. **IF** they end up being associated with cancer, I don't know if they understand exactly why they occur. Plain old arteries that have atherosclerosis can have calcifications all over your body (including your breast). The vast majority of calcifications are benign. Big calcifications are almost always benign. The ones that are more concerning are tiny ones that look like speckles of salt, or ones that look branching. Even if they are suspicious enough to biopsy, remember 80% of biopsies are benign, including biopsies of these 'suspicious' calcifications. They are usually looking for changes in the calcification pattern. So DO get it checked out, worry will not let you miss your biopsy appointment, but know that most of the time these biopsies turn out to be benign. Please feel free to vent or ask questions.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2017 08:45AM leaf wrote: Sclerosing adenosis is when there is some fibrosis involved. Different studies will give you different numbers. In this study Sclerosing adenosis (SA), found in ¼ of benign breast disease (BBD) biopsies, is a histological feature characterized by lobulocentric proliferation of acini and stromal fibrosis and confers a two-fold increase in breast cancer risk compared to women in the general population. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28798985 So LOTS of women have sclerosing adenosis (including me). Now, you do need to understand something about breast cancer prediction. Relative risk is different than absolute risk. Two-fold risk is a relative risk. Relative risk can be a tricky concept, because most people tend to focus on the reported percentage — e.g., 50% higher risk — which sounds alarming. Yes, a 50% higher risk of developing breast cancer (relative to people who don't drink) is significant, but it doesn't tell a woman what her lifetime risk is if she drinks two or more alcoholic drinks per day for the rest of her life. Since women in this group have 1.5 times the risk of developing breast cancer, it's necessary to multiply the absolute risk of breast cancer (12%) for women in the general population by relative risk (1.5): http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/understand_bc... Also, these numbers are for a GROUP of women with this characteristic (in this case drinking 2 or more alcoholic drinks per day). Its not for the INDIVIDUAL woman. We are a LOT less certain about the risk of an individual woman than a group of women (with the same risk factor). https://academic.oup.com/jnci/article-lookup/doi/10.1093/jnci/djj501

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 02:29PM - edited Sep 29, 2008 02:33PM by leaf I'm so sorry you are going through this. It is awful to think that women your age have to be concerned about breast cancer.  It is unusual in your age group, *but it can happen in your age group.* Lobular carcinoma is  casually known as 'the sneaky one' and often does not show up on mammograms or ultrasounds.  It shows up better on MRI.  Lobular often forms a 'thickening' instead of a lump. Breast cancer *usually* does not cause pain, but there are some women here whose first symptom was pain.  That's why this needs to get investigated.  The more negative exams you pile up, the better your chances of it being nothing, but that is NOT a guarantee.   If you REALLY think there is something wrong with your breast, then insist on a biopsy, no matter what the doctor says.  The only way they can diagnose you with breast cancer is by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.   MRIs *can* give false negatives, but it is unusual.  In this study, 1 out of 21 MRIs  missed the lobular breast cancer. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18800196 and in this study MRI missed 1 out of 29 cases.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15...  Here are 75 different possible causes of breast pain.  I'm not saying you are a candidate for all 75 of them...http://www.wrongdiagnosis.com/symptoms/breast_pain/causes.htm but it does say there are other possible causes of breast pain too. Get this checked out until you are completely satisfied with the answers.  I know all this uncertainty is horrible to go through.  Feel free to vent or ask questions.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2011 09:42AM - edited Oct 11, 2011 09:49AM by leaf Its a wire-guided excision. (My description was 'bracketing', because they inserted 2 wires around the lesion.)  Most women have a reasonable time with this, but some do not.  The injectable anesthesia they use is an injection into the breast, not an intravenous injection.  At my place, they weren't able to use intravenous anesthesia because they didn't have an RN present (the wire insertion was done in the radiology department.)  Mine was 5 years ago, so maybe things have changed in that time. But I did a survey here, 5 years ago. 38 people responded to my survey.  People were able to choose only one of the 4 following responses. 1) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)   19 people, 50% 2) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  7 people, 18% 3) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  3 people , 8% 4) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10.) 9 people, 24%. I was told 'not to move a muscle' during the procedure (which might have lasted 1-2 hours?)  For me, I had significant pain, but I was determined not to 'be a baby', and didn't say anything.  I knew if I said something I would cry, thus move.  (I also have other psych issues that I didn't know about at the time.) For me, if I ever have to do it again, I will bring something nonverbal (like a bell or rattle) that I can shake if I am in significant pain.  I will let the doc and assistant know what that bell or rattle means before they start with the procedure. As I said, most women have a tolerable time with the wire insertion.  Once an anesthesiologist got involved (for the actual excision- I had to wait several hours as my surgeon had a family emergency), I had absolutely no problem with pain. I don't know if places have changed their course of action in the last 5 years.  I was told that previously our place did not give intravenous anesthesia or sedation for colonoscopies, and after many complaints, they changed their protocol.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 02:34AM - edited Aug 9, 2011 02:35AM by leaf It sure can be puzzling how radiologists go about the diagnosis process. Looking at a mammogram can be something like looking at a clear balloon with printing on it.  If the printing is on the side of the balloon, then its very hard to read.  If there are folds in the breast, it can be hard to read.   Sometimes the breast tissue doesn't lie flat so it can be harder to read.  Sometimes the breast has not been compressed enough (there are techniques such as spot compression) if they want to look at a certain area. Mammograms catch things like calcifications much better than ultrasounds do.  Different types of imaging can see different things.  One type is not necessarily 'better' overall than another.  Ultrasounds are good at seeing fluid filled sacs, such as cysts.   I am not a mammographer or mammography assistant.  But that's about the extent of what I know.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 02:03AM leaf wrote:  I think most breast masses are considered breast lumps.  I'm not sure if they'd talk about a breast thickening being a breast mass.  The most common symptom of breast cancer is a painless lump, but a variety of scenarios can occur less often. (Painful lump, painful thickening, painless thickening,  painful breast, something seen on a mammogram but not felt, every other possibility, etc.) But the reverse is not necessarily true.  The benign fibroadenoma is a painless lump, and is far more common than breast cancer, especially in the younger age group.  Cysts can feel like lumps especially if they are deep.  (Cysts are almost always benign.).  Just because you have Suspicious Focal Asymetrical Density does NOT mean you are 'doomed' to have breast cancer.  The overall cancer prevalence among women undergoing biopsy was 22.4%. Prevalence in women with mammograms highly suggestive of malignancy (category 5) was 84.6%, with minimal variation in individual cancer probabilities due to age. A total of 24.6% of women with suspicious mammograms (category 4) had cancer, but individual probability estimates ranged from .01 to .86, depending on age, presence of a lump, previous biopsy, menopausal status, and use of postmenopausal hormone therapy. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15968496 Mammograms can be rated by the BIRADS system.  If you had a high BIRADS score ( category 5), then they'd probably be scheduling you for a biopsy, not a diagnostic mammogram. www.cancer.org/docroot/PED/con... (BIRADS is talked about near the middle of this document) www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/con... Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 09:30AM - edited Apr 20, 2011 06:39AM by leaf Since ANA is an antibody test, it is by definition not extremely exact. It can be hard to get pure and specific antibodies.  Antibodies are made out of protein, and they can require very delicate handling.  So different labs can have different values, and probably different batches of antibodies can do different things. The ANA test tests to see if you have antibodies against your  cells' nuclear material.  Your cells' nuclear material means things like the DNA and RNA in your cells. Usually 'average' people don't make antibodies against themselves, but in a small number of 'normal' people, they can.  So it can be a 'normal' condition. But with a variety of conditions, you can have a positive ANA. Crossing my fingers for you for a pain-free rest, and a quick resolution.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2010 04:33AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:23AM by leaf Of course, you are worried and scared. I agree with lisa-e and flash.  You need to look at all the risks and benefits. I have ALH, ductal hyperplasia (not atypical) and LCIS, and a weak family history. Many authors think LCIS confers a risk of breast cancer about twice that of ADH or ALH.  My breast surgeon refused to consider bilateral mastectomies. At the bottom of this page, they list the usual followup for women with ADH (see the chart) http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/screening/understanding-breast-changes/allpages#422252f8-eeaa-4f03-a4d7-d5f6ce4ce39a With mean follow-up of 13.7 years, 66 breast cancers (19.9%) occurred among 331 women with atypia. RR of breast cancer with atypia was 3.88 (95% CI, 3.00 to 4.94). Marked elevations in risk were seen with multifocal atypia (eg, three or more foci with calcifications [RR, 10.35; 95% CI, 6.13 to 16.4]). RR was higher for younger women (< 45; RR, 6.76; 95% CI, 3.24 to 12.4). Risk was similar for atypical ductal and atypical lobular hyperplasia, and family history added no significant risk. Breast cancer risk remained elevated over 20 years, and the cumulative incidence approached 35% at 30 years.  http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/25/19/2671.full Now, different studies give different numbers, and the Gail risk model (a standard breast cancer risk model) predicts breast cancer in populations well, but not individual risk.  Of course you are scared and anxious.  I don't want you to be this scared and anxious.  But you do want to look at all the risks and benefits.
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2011 04:52PM - edited Oct 14, 2011 04:58PM by leaf Well, my answer will be more complicated than I wish. Different doctors classify things differently.  For example, all docs that I know of classify invasive breast cancer as cancer, but some classify DCIS as breast cancer, and some not.  Few oncologists classify LCIS as cancer, though some do.  So there can be controversy over the classification of things. From what I understand you had ALH (and borderline ADH) on your core biopsy.  They are not doing the excisional to remove the ALH; they are doing the excision to see if there is something worse going on  in the area.  (Something worse would be LCIS, DCIS, or invasive breast cancer.) The chances of finding something worse on your excisional is something like 20% (different studies differ, but most are in the range of 10-35% or so.) When someone gets ALH on a needle or core biopsy, its totally usual treatment to get an excision. DCIS (with nothing worse) is about 7 times more common than LCIS (with nothing worse).  ALH is like LCIS except less advanced.  (I have classic LCIS, ALH, sclerosing adenoma, and ductal hyperplasia (not atypical ductal hyperplasia.) ) If you do have DCIS, they normally try to remove all of the DCIS.  That is not the case with LCIS.  That is because if one spot of LCIS is found in a breast, there are often multiple spots of LCIS in that breast, and often more spots of LCIS in the opposite breast.  Almost everything about LCIS is controversial (including the name), partly because its so much less common than LCIS.  In this paper, for the LCIS or DCIS women, if you add the risks of both breasts together, LCIS women had a higher risk of subsequent breast cancer than did DCIS women (both with 'usual treatment'  but not mastectomy.) onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10... I'm not sure what you mean by 'a lot of times I am reading is that most cancers are found before they get to the point I'm at.' After ALH on a needle or core biopsy, its totally common to get an excision so they can double check that you don't have LCIS,DCIS or invasive lurking around.
Posts.Title: Should I Be Worried Lme002 Lme002

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2011 04:49AM - edited Oct 15, 2011 04:54AM by leaf Yes, I'm sure that all 8 samples they found on biopsy were benign.  ALH and/or LCIS are often incidental findings on needle or core biopsy.  This means that the lesion that they find on mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI (i.e. the calcification, distortion, or whatever) is often NOT at the exact postion of the ALH/LCIS.  ALH/LCIS is often found adjacent to the lesion.  In other words, ALH and/or LCIS are usually invisible on imaging.  They just happened to find them when they were trying to target the lesion. ALH and LCIS (also known grouped together as lobular neoplasia) are excised NOT in order to remove the lump or lesion that prompted the needle or core biopsy.  They are NOT excised in order to remove the ALH or LCIS. They are removed because about 20% of the time they find LCIS (which would put you at higher risk of breast cancer in the future), or DCIS (which is usually treated differently than LCIS) or invasive (which, depending on the size, aggressiveness, 'personality'), may be treated differently than LCIS or DCIS.  Again, as in all things concerned with lobular neoplasia, there is controversy. (There is controversy about whether or not to excise ALH/LCIS.)   It was only several years after my excision (I told the breast surgeon to 'get it all out', not knowing the implications at the time), I was told by my 2nd opinion at a NCI certified breast center that I had 'too much scar tissue <from this, my only excision> to get an MRI.'  I have yet to get a breast MRI. Again, I have LCIS, ALH, and ductal hyperplasia (not atypical).  Classic LCIS is usually considered to have about twice the risk of subsequent breast cancer as ALH. Would I choose an excision again under the same circumstances?  Yes, but I may not tell the breast surgeon to 'go all over my breast'.  (I had scar tissue inches away from my incision site, as proved by a subsequent breast biopsy.)  But some people choose NOT to get excised. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21... http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21306860 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19667411 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... I am NOT trying to change your mind.  I am just trying to present some advantages and disadvantages of each choice, and provide more of a balanced picture.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 04:32AM - edited Feb 19, 2010 04:34AM by leaf Extravasation means the leakage of fluid outside the container.  So, during intraveous therapy, your blood can extravasate out of the vein into the tissues, because they don't have the needle in the vein. Here's more about mucin from wikipedia. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mucin Mucin is an unusual condition (in this case 0.51% of biopsies.) This is one author's opinion (2002) Lesions of the breast containing extravasated mucin span a continuum from benign mucoceles to invasive mucinous (colloid) carcinoma. <snip>Mucinous lesions were identified in 22 cases (0.51%), and excisional biopsy material was available for 15 of these. At excision, 0 of 8 benign mucinous lesions showed carcinoma, while 7 of 7 mucinous lesions associated with carcinoma at the time of core needle biopsy showed carcinoma at excision. The vast majority of mucinous lesions of the breast can be diagnosed accurately by core needle biopsy. Whether all such lesions require excision is not known at this time.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12109860 Another author agreed that mucin is associated with a variety of conditions, and it is unusual. They constitute a wide spectrum of lesions ranging from extravasated mucin associated with fibrocystic change to mucinous carcinoma.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... Calcifications are very common, and usually associated with benign conditions.  But some patterns of calcifications can be more worrisome.  Here may be more than you ever wanted  to know about calcifications. http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 I can't find any academic papers that actually look at the group of women with ADH AND extravasated mucin AND calcifications.  The ADH, as Anne said, puts you at somewhat higher risk for bc. Since we don't know why some cells produce mucin (as far as I know), we don't know if the mucin signifies anything.  Since it is associated with everything from perfectly benign conditions to cancerous condtions, it is probably NOT a 'red flag' for anything.  Its just unusual.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2008 12:33PM leaf wrote: There is an unusual type of breast cancer that can involve redness on the breast.  It can be difficult to diagnose.  Many doctors have never seen cases of it.  It can  only  be diagnosed with a breast punch biopsy. Its called inflammatory breast cancer. However,  any skin condition that can happen on other parts of your skin can  also occur on the breast. Most women start out with their general practitioner or Gynecologist.  The experts on breast care are breast surgeon, but most people need a referral to see one.(Most people also need a referral to see a dermatologist.) Its most likely some sort of dermatological condition, but if you do choose to see a dermatologist, I would make sure he/she is aware of  the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer.  Inflammatory breast cancer is often mistaken for a breast infection.  I don't know if it sounds like you have one or not.  Inflammatory breast cancer does not get better or worse over many week's time, unlike most other conditions. It is very likely you have some sort of skin condition that is not cancer, but do get it checked out.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 03:52AM leaf wrote: You may want to check with your doc about this.  My biopsy was in the upper, outer area of my chest, but by day 3, the bottom of my breast was black.  That's because there was a lot of bleeding going on (called a hematoma), and the blood (through gravity) settled in the bottom part of my breast.  For me it took some 3-6 months for all the discoloration to disappear.  It went through stages of purple, green, and yellow.  Those colors are due to the color of the hemoglobin in blood.  (They are autumnal colors - hemoglobin is structurally related to the pigments in leaves.)  Its the pain I'm concerned about.  Its possible to be infected.  I didn't have much pain at all at my incision site. I also had hard spots at my incision/biopsy site.  Once it became pretty much painless, I think it would have been good to massage it, but you don't want to do that if you have an infection going on. I think its good to check with your doc, particularly if its red and hurts.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 08:39PM - edited Apr 10, 2008 08:29AM by leaf They usually give you written instructions so you can read them when you are more alert. Unfortunately, that usually isn't the best time to go shopping. The two items I found really helpful for my excisional biopsy was a) a sportsbra that had a front closing. (I have so much problem getting on one that you have to pull on over your breasts. My breasts hurt when they jiggled or moved.) b) tiny ice packs. I wrapped mine in a cloth, and for me they were better than pain meds to ease the 'zingy' sensations. c) I couldn't take off my dressings for a few days, so it was convenient to have some large plastic bags to tape on my chest to try to keep them dry when I showered. I went to work 24 hours after I came out of the recovery room. Some people needed several days-week. Different people's experience is different, and people have different amounts of tissue removed in their excisional. I didn't jog for about a week. My scar (now 2 years old) is much better than it was at first. Maybe massaging the area helped.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 09:12AM leaf wrote: I'm sorry your regular doctor made you a nervous wreck. Its so hard when someone seems to be telling you that you may have a serious condition. But your regular doctor is just being thorough. The more negative (in other words normal) imaging you pile up, the less likely you have anything to be concerned about. Breast thicknesses can be tricky, so your regular doctor is being through in sending you to a surgeon. That doesn't mean that you have breast cancer; that just means you're going to someone who is more specialized in diagnosing breast conditions. In this one study in the UK, women who were <40 years of age with a breast thickening and, (assuming you would count a breast thickening as no lump size), had a score of 2 thus a probability of breast cancer of less than 5-8%. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC308022... This was a relatively small study, of 802 patients, of which 59 (7%) were diagnosed with breast cancer. Overall, about 80% of women who get breast biopsies have benign results, and your surgeon has not decided whether or not your symptoms are suspicious enough for a breast biopsy. Even if you were at higher risk, it still would be a good plan to try to relax, since worrying won't change the outcome, and just makes it harder on you. Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2008 04:59AM leaf wrote: Its all so maddening when you don't know what they are doing, when this is your first mammo, and they're recommending all these new tests. Its harder with your first mammogram because they don't have anything to compare it to. If this was your 2nd mammo, they could compare it to the first, and they would be looking at changes. I know its maddening, but they tend to interpret breast imaging with very concrete terms. In other words, if there is a density, that means there is a place on the mammo that shows there is more tissue in that place (as opposed to fat) in that place. Younger women (and 41 is considered relatively young in this game) tend to have denser breasts, but some women have dense breasts throughout their lives. Dense breasts means its harder to read mammograms on them - its harder to see through the breast, so its easier to miss things. Ultrasound 'lesions' tend to be described as a 'hypoechoic' place. This means that it looks like the sound waves (the ultrasound waves) didn't bounce back as much in that area. That's all it means. They can't tell, of course, for sure whether or not any of these lesions are any thing to worry about. MRIs tend to give a lot of false positives-they show lots of things including inflammation - things that are NOT cancer. I am sure they do not have the manpower and resources to biopsy every small lesion - even those that seem normal- that is seen on mammogram. Some lesions are more suspicious than others. If it was quite suspicious, then they would be ordering a biopsy right off the bat. My ultrasounds cost on the order of $100-200 each, and my mammo-guided stereotactic biopsy cost my insurance company about $3500. (This was much less than what my insurance company was charged.) My excision (for an excisional biopsy) cost $13.5K (paid by the insurance company, not what the hospital charged the insurance company.) So they aren't cheap.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2011 11:10PM leaf wrote: Hi there mommyalways; I'm so sorry you are going through this. Unfortunately, the only way they can tell for sure is to take a piece of tissue and look at it under the microscope. The report just states objectively what they see on MRI.  (The only 'evaluation' was the BIRADS 0 notation, which means that more imaging is needed for evaluation.)   As Anne says, MRIs show a lot of stuff that ends up being benign.  The location (near your chest wall) does NOT mean that lesion is more likely to be cancer;  it would be difficult/impossible to biopsy by MRI.   When I had my wire insertion for my excision, a friend of a colleague had a wire insertion for excision that was right against her chest wall; it ended up being totally benign (not even high or medium or low risk.)   Some of the things that the MRI is seeing may also be inflammation/scar tissue from your previous biopsy. It took me 3 months to get through the diagnosis process- for some people it takes 4 or 6 months.  Some people ask to be called in case there are cancellations and are able to get in earlier. There are people who have negative mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs (but still have a palpable lump or thickening) but still end up having breast cancer.  That is quite unusual but can happen.  So ultrasound can help clarify whether your lesions are worrisome, but no imaging in the breasts is 100% accurate or 100% sensitive.  I wish we had better imaging, but for now we have to go with what we have. Hope you get news soon and can get this resolved.  Its so hard going through this diagnostic process!

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 12:36AM - edited Mar 8, 2009 12:37AM by leaf Breasts are commonly of un-equal size.  Faces are also not symmetrical.  Since puberty, my left breast has been larger than my right breast.  My left breast is more like a B cup, and my right breast is closer to an A cup. Breast size changes during weight changes.  Breasts commonly get bigger when women take estrogens, or have hormonal changes. I don't know how old you are, but unless you are extremely young, it may be good to get baseline mammos and ultrasounds, so they have something with which to compare. This may be a controversial issue.  Here is one recent study.  www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/ar...  Other studies or doctors may have other opinions.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2009 08:20PM leaf wrote: Risk estimation for breast cancer is very difficult for the general population.  Assuming your risk is no higher than the 'average woman' (in other words, you do not have a mutation in an unknown breast cancer gene), you can use this model. Yes, you can put your values into the modified Gail model, and get a number. http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ There are other breast cancer risk models, but they are not as popular. You may feel very comfortable with your answer- here you have a percentage. But, before you get comfortable with that thought, you may want to carefully read this editorial from a professional journal.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...  Then click on the 'free final text' brown button on the right to access the article. Essentially, it opines that we know quite well the risk of a group  of women with your characteristics.  However,  estimating  your risk, you as an individual,  our ability to estimate your chance of having breast cancer is a different matter.  This editorial opines that our ability to do that is only 'slightly better than the toss of a dice.'  The article describes statistical tests they use to estimate risk. To get a more accurate answer, you would want to see a genetics counselor.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 08:36PM leaf wrote: Some radiologists separate BIRADS 4 into 4A and 4B, 4B being more suspicious than 4A.  From what I understand, implants can make it harder to do mammograms, and may make it harder to see/interpret things.  But anyone with breasts (even people who have had no breast surgery whatsoever) can have a BIRADS 4B rating. BIRADS categories are an estimate of the risk.  They are not the 'last word'.  We have had many women with BIRADS 5 ratings (which are more suspicious than BIRADS 4A or 4B or 4)  here who got benign results after biopsy. The only way they can diagnose breast cancer (except perhaps the unusual inflammatory breast cancer) is by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. Goodness knows, we all would like to reduce the uncertainty and anxiety with 'not knowing'. Holding out my hand to you.

Some people like vigorous exercise, or retail therapy, religion, biofeedback,meditation, whatever. At the bs appt, expect to be asked about your family history, and to get a clinical breast exam. They ordinarily cannot diagnose you with breast cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope (i.e. a biopsy). Most young women with lumps end up having either benign cysts or a benign growth called a fibroadenoma.  Even if you proceed to a biopsy, about 80% of biopsies in the US are benign.  That's a big number.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 07:27AM - edited Apr 8, 2009 07:28AM by leaf 3 months after my excision for LCIS, I noticed a change in direction of my nipple.  It was subtle, but was there. (It turned more outwardly.) It, along with a change in contour, ended up prompting an ultrasound, and because of the ultrasound results, eventually (after 2 more mammos and ultrasounds) yielded a biopsy a year later which showed scar tissue. My breasts have always been of unequal size.  My left breast has been a good B and my right probably an A+.  In my twenties, they were more like an A+ on my left vs a 'barely A' on my right. So having breasts of different sizes are quite common, even if you hadn't had your proceedures. But breast size/shape/contour are very private, individual feelings.   Just because one person might feel one way doesn't mean someone else can't feel something different.  Your feelings are valid, no matter what they are.

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 09:06PM - edited Aug 13, 2010 09:18PM by leaf *If* the doctor recommends a mammogram, you may want to think twice about that and request ultrasound or MRI due to your age.  A mammogram does give you a low amount of radiation, but younger breasts are thought to be more sensitive to radiation.  Chest irradiation **treatment**, particularly when young (used, for example, in some types of lymphoma treatment), are a risk factor for future breast cancer.  The doses used in treating lymphoma are much higher than the doses used in mammograms or chest Xrays, but many people think breast tissue in children and young teenagers may be particularly sensitive to radiation. Ultrasounds are better at picking up cysts (which are almost always benign), and ultrasounds are not known to be associated with causing cancer.  Ultrasounds  of the pelvis are routinely used in pregnancy to look for problems with the baby or placenta.  Breast cancer is extremely uncommon in teenagers, as the other posters have said, but its good to get it checked out.   As the others have said, telling your mom you are concerned is the first step.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 09:36AM - edited Mar 8, 2009 09:37AM by leaf Breast cancer does not read books. Yes, asymmetrical breasts CAN be a symptom of breast cancer, but its not a very specific symptom. This paper opines that breast asymmetry has a relative risk of 1.5/100ml.  That's a risk of now or in the future.  Since 1 in 8 women (approximately) women get breast cancer in the US, that's not a very helpful symptom to separate the women who have or will get breast cancer vs  those who will never get breast cancer. A relative risk of 1.5 means instead of a 3-5% lifetime risk, its more like 4-7% (assuming this is linear and lifetime.  This abstract doesn't say how long they followed the women.) www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... This paper of women undergoing breast augmentation found that 88% of these women had some aspect of breast asymmetry.  Now, that's a select group, to be sure. Overall, 88 percent of the women had some degree of asymmetry, and 65 percent of the women had more than one parameter of asymmetry.http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=18338293 Most women have slightly different-sized - or asymmetrical - breasts. www.cosmetic-aesthetic.com/bre...

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 03:09PM - edited Apr 5, 2011 03:43PM by leaf Each person not only has a different diagnosis, but the risks and benefits of tamoxifen for each group is different.  Tamoxifen is only advised for some, not all, breast cancer patients. I have classic LCIS and nothing worse, and I chose tamoxifen.  My breast surgeon 'refused to do any further surgery on me', and I didn't want to do nothing (only surveillance). If you visit the hormonal forum, you will find lots of people who have had many adverse effects from tamoxifen.  Some people can't tolerate tamoxifen at all, and others have no adverse effects at all.  People are more apt to report problems with something than are apt to report they are happy with a treatment.  That does NOT mean that the people who have problems are not real. I have had mild side effects (some 'warm' flashes, especially at the beginning, an increase in endometrial polyps - all have been benign.)  Different groups of people have different incidences of sides effects of tamoxifen.  Tamoxifen has a different adverse effect incidence in the treatment of advanced breast cancer than it does in women at higher risk for breast cancer. Here's more about tamoxifen from the NIH. www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pd...

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 02:58AM - edited Aug 7, 2010 03:11AM by leaf Although different sources will give you different risks, please know that all of our current models, except perhaps if you also have a BRCA mutation, are pretty poor at predicting YOUR risk of breast cancer. The most used breast cancer risk model is the Gail model.  http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ Different studies will give you different numbers. Know that when they say 'you have risk 5 times higher',this does NOT mean 5x the risk of an AVERAGE woman (i.e. is NOT NOT NOT 5x13%=65%; 13% is the lifetime risk of breast cancer for the 'average' US woman), but 5 times the risk of a woman WITHOUT any particular breast cancer risk factors (besides being a woman).  There are different figures for this,but they usually range a lifetime risk of about 3-5%.  So 3x5=15% lifetime risk, and 5x5=25% max. This study found ALH gave more of a risk than ADH in premenopausal women. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... In this small study that included ADH women, their risk of breast cancer over 5 years was about 5%. These results support current literature showing the synergistic increase in risk for patients with ADH, LCIS, and a positive family history of breast cancer. Obesity was also a strong predictor of breast cancer risk, which suggests that there may be a potentiating effect of obesity on other risk factors. Obesity may represent a modifiable risk factor, providing women with an opportunity to reduce their risk with lifestyle modification. Women with a strong family history of breast cancer or a diagnosis of ADH or LCIS may benefit most from risk-reduction strategies, chemoprevention, and surveillance.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/entrez Our population included 1,412 high-risk women with median follow-up of 4 years. Of 195 women < or =35 years, 3 (1.5%) developed breast cancer. All three had strong FHBC and none had a prior high-risk lesion. Of 82 women > or =70 years, 6 (7.3%) developed breast cancer. Mean Gail score for women > or =70 years was 4.3, as compared with 4.7 in the subset of older women diagnosed with cancer. Fisher's tests demonstrated that ADH (p = 0.15), ALH (p = 1.0), LCIS (p = 1.0), and FHBC (p = 1.0) were not associated with breast cancer development in older women. We conclude that, for women < or =35 years, a significant FHBC may be a stronger predictor for breast cancer development than high-risk lesions. For women > or =70 years, FHBC and history of ADH, ALH, and LCIS were not predictors of breast cancer. This study emphasizes the importance of defining age-appropriate recommendations for breast cancer risk management, including surveillance and chemoprevention.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... The Gail model is quite good at predicting the breast cancer risk for USA  populations (for example, how many women in a group of women will get breast cancer), but it is quite poor at predicting which PARTICULAR women will get breast cancer. In this 2006 medical journal article, they compared the Gail model  to an Italian model (which included other factors like breast density).  They took one randomly selected woman who had been diagnosed with breast cancer and compared her initial model score with a  randomly selected woman who had NOT been diagnosed with breast cancer.  If a model was 100% accurate, her concordance value would be 1:in each pair, each woman with breast cancer would get a higher score than each woman without breast cancer.  If the model was as good as chance, the concordance value would be 0.5, meaning in 50% of the pairs, the woman with breast cancer would get a higher score than the woman without breast cancer,but in 50% of the pairs, the woman WITHOUT breast cancer would get a higher score.  In other words, if you have a model with a concordance value of 0.5, the model isn't a good predictive model. Decarli et al. also assessed each model’s performance at the level of the individual woman. A model that discriminates well at this level should consistently predict a higher risk of breast can- cer for women who will be diagnosed with the disease than for women who will not. Decarli et al. randomly selected pairs of women, one of whom was diagnosed with breast cancer and one of whom was not, to determine the frequency with which each model calculated a higher risk for the woman who developed breast cancer. The resulting calculation produced a concordance statistic, whose value could range from 0.50 (equivalent to a coin toss) to 1.0 (perfect discrimination). The concordance statistics for the Italian and Gail models were essentially the same, ap- proximately 0.59 (with 95% confidence intervals that ranged from 0.54 to 0.63). In other words, for 59% of the randomly se- lected pairs of women, the risk estimated for the woman who was diagnosed with breast cancer was higher than the risk estimated for the woman who was not. Unfortunately, for 41% of the pairs of women, the woman with breast cancer received a lower risk estimate than her cancer-free counterpart. Thus, for any given woman, the two models were better at prediction than a coin toss—but not by much. jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/re...  (emphasis mine). If it is this difficult to predict breast cancer risk for an 'average' woman, think how much we know about women with increased risk. This can make it difficult to decide what to do based on numbers. The server went down, so I can't search for more. There is no rush what to do.  Visit both your brain and your heart, (and your insurance) to see what path you want to take.

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 01:04PM - edited Aug 16, 2009 01:06PM by leaf The worst thing in your pathology report is the atypical ductal hyperplasia.  There is no 'line in the sand' between cancer and normal cells.  Just as one's perspective of how old a person has to be to be older, there are a range of cell growths between normal and cancer.  It is usually fairly easy to classify normal cells, and definitely cancerous cells (the two extremes.) Microcalcifications are small calcifications.  These can sometimes be associated  with cancer cells, but often they are not.  As far as I know, we don't understand why these small calcifications are associated with more/faster cell growth.  Calcifications have nothing to do with how much calcium you eat.  Here is an excellent website, probably more than you ever wanted to know about calcifications. http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 Columnar cells are just part way between normal cells and your atypical cells.   These cells do not put you at a  reliably measurably higher risk of breast cancer. surgpathcriteria.stanford.edu/... The atypical ductal hyperplasia means you have more cells lining your duct (hyperplasia), and the cells have irregular shapes; often the nucleus looks abnormal.  Its the atypia that puts you at somewhat higher risk of breast cancer. surgpathcriteria.stanford.edu/...

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 12:54PM - edited Apr 14, 2009 12:55PM by leaf There are some cancers where it is a legitimate concern that biopsies will spread cancer 'seed the area'. But studies have indicated that the possible incidence of breast cancer seeding is low. In this abstract they report 3 possible cases. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11328321 In this abstract it looks like they got 1 out of 89. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11044522 This abstract reports 3 cases after skin-sparing mastectomy. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... Although there was some contradictory data, this meta-study found no increase in mortality when they were diagnosed by a core needle biopsy. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19167175 This study found NO malignant cells seeded along the needle track. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18365811 In several of these studies, they don't report the 'denominator' in the abstract.  So we don't know the incidence of possible seeding.  Some studies have suggested a LOT of cells can move during the biopsy, but the actual incidence of recurrance is much, much smaller.  This suggests that the treatments we are doing probably kill most of the 'wayward' cells. As others have said, its perfectly natural to fear cutting/biopsies, and whatever you feel is valid.  Its something to think over, and do what is best for you.

Here's more with pictures. http://pathologyoutlines.com/topic/breastmalignantcribriformDCIS.html Comedo necrosis means some of the cells have died in the middle. http://pathologyoutlines.com/topic/breastmalignantcomedoDCIS.html   This, I think, means that the cells are usually faster growing.  Pleomorphism means  there are 2 or more forms in the sample. No stromal invasion I think means the non-normal cells have not been seen past the basement membrane, which means that they didn't find any evidence of invasive cancer. Anybody, please correct me if I'm wrong.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 05:41AM - edited Dec 1, 2007 06:55AM by leaf Any or all of the imaging techniques (mammo, ultrasound, MRI) can miss a cancer, though this is pretty unusual. As always, there are very few things that are 100% in breast cancer. Ultrasounds are cheaper and less invasive than MRIs. MRIs can show a lot of false positives. The only way they can really diagnose breast cancer is through a biopsy. But they can't biopsy every part of everyone's breast. So they need the imaging (or presence of a lesion.) Even with a birads score of 4, about 80% of biopsies are BENIGN. I know its hard not to go to the worst case scenario. But your chances are excellent that things will turn out fine.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 04:30AM - edited Aug 8, 2010 05:24AM by leaf It is very hard to estimate a particular woman's risk of breast cancer, particularly if you have a 'higher risk' lesion (see my post above.) In more simplistic terms, the answer to your question is probably no - if an aunt with breast cancer is all the breast and ovarian cancer in your family history, then that is considered probably a weak family history, and people like you in a group (ADH) may have a lifetime risk of roughly 15-25%.   Remember, some 13% of women in the USA  will get breast cancer some time in their lifetime.  I had a grandmother with breast cancer and an aunt with breast cancer (on opposite sides of the family, both after the age of 50) and my genetic counselor estimated my risk of having a BRCA mutation was about 2-4%. It is thought that no more than about 10-15% of breast cancers are due to a single inherited mutation (such as BRCA).  The other 85-90% of breast cancers are thought to be 'sporatic', due either to multiple gene effects, or environmental or other effects.  It is thought that about 70% of breast cancers in women have no obvious known cause, besides being a woman. Your family pattern probably does not meet  the recommendations made by the US preventative task force for BRCA testing:  These family history patterns apply to about 2 percent of adult women in the general population. Women who have none of these family history patterns have a low probability of having a harmful BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation. www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa... This does not mean it is impossible for you to have a deleterious BRCA gene mutation; it just means it is highly unlikely. There are families with a strong pattern of breast cancer (for example, multiple people in each generation with breast cancer), and they test negative for BRCA.   But one aunt with breast cancer and no ovarian cancer is NOT a strong family history. There are almost certainly unknown breast cancer risk genes out there.  But there are no genetic tests in the general population out for them yet.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 02:50PM - edited Nov 30, 2007 02:55PM by leaf Bessie is right. I had a birads 4 score, and my diagnosis was benign (most oncs think its benign-its an unusual situation.) Dr. Susan Love's book says, with a bit more detail, that Birads 3 is probably benign (high probability of being benign, less than 2 percent were cancerous. Birads 5 highly suggestive of malignancy (Lesion that has a high probability of being malignant (95%). So to make the 80% figure (that 80% of biopsies are benign), then a whole lot of the Birads4 people get benign results. Here is one study I found that came out of Oklahoma. Note this was a study that correlated BIOPSIES with Birads score. So *all* of these people were biopsied. They aren't going to biopsy people who are not suspicious. In it, you see 34% of the biopsies were generated for birads4 score. J Am Coll Surg. 1999 Jul;189(1):34-40. Links Positive predictive value of the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System. Lacquement MA, Mitchell D, Hollingsworth AB. University of Oklahoma Institute for Breast Health, Department of Surgery, Oklahoma City 73104, USA. BACKGROUND: The American College of Radiology has established guidelines for outcomes monitoring known as the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS). These recommendations include calculation of positive predictive values (PPV) and tracking of both benign and malignant histology. We collected this data for 688 radiographically guided biopsies and organized it according to the BIRADS assessment categories. The objective was to evaluate the contribution of the BIRAD System when used to stratify PPV, histology, and biopsy modality data according to the overall assessment rating. STUDY DESIGN: This study included data from 688 image-guided biopsies. Mammographic studies were either assigned a BIRADS rating at the time of examination or, if the image was taken before our use of BIRADS, examined retrospectively and rated. In these retrospective cases, the histologic outcomes of the biopsy remained unknown to the radiologist until ratings were assigned. Positive predictive value was calculated for each BIRADS category. RESULTS: The overall PPV for the sample was 0.23. The PPVs increased with increasing level of suspicion as follows: category 1 (0.0), category 2 (0.04), category 3 (0.03), category 4 (0.23), category 5 (0.92). Category 1 lesions represented 0.1% of the biopsies; category 2, 3.6%; category 3, 46.8%; category 4, 34.0%; and category 5, 15.4%. The most common histologic diagnoses of benign lesions biopsied were fibroadenoma and fibrocystic changes-proliferative and nonproliferative. The most common histologic diagnoses of malignant lesions biopsied were infiltrating ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ. Utilization rates of the biopsy techniques varied by BIRADS category. CONCLUSIONS: Our study revealed that BIRADS does improve the quality of the risk assessment information by making the PPV more specific to a patient's mammogram rather than simply related to an overall PPV. Our histology analysis showed category 3 and category 4 benign biopsies were predominantly because of fibrocystic changes. Category 5 lesions were predominantly invasive ductal carcinoma. Analysis of biopsy modalities indicated the preferred method for management of radiographically detected lesions evolved from stereotactic core biopsy to directional, vacuum-assisted biopsy over the course of the study. PMID: 10401738 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE]

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 01:44PM leaf wrote: Here's a website that was very helpful to me about microcalcifications.  http://www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4793bfde0ed53 Microcalcifications are punctate and do not layer on the mediolateral view.  Punctate means they are small.  Do not layer means they don't line up in different views in the breast.  (Normally they take one 'horizontal' picture and one 'vertical' picture.)   If you can predict the diagnosis by looking at some of these mammograms, then you sure have a better eye than I do.  As itsjustme wisely said, don't be a cancer patient before you have to,  don't jump to conclusions.  Let them run the tests they need to do to accurately diagnose you.   Its hard to not worry.  Some people find distraction helps.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: May 24, 2008 12:43PM - edited May 24, 2008 12:44PM by leaf I agree with Julee. I sure am glad there are people out there like Julz. When I had a very scary surgery last summer, I remembered every comment that the nurses made. It wasn't even so much their words, a lot was their expression, and their tone of voice - if they expressed genuine concern or reassurance. I don't think it has to take a lot of time. It would have taken just as much time to say something like "I'm sorry you are going through this. I'm not allowed to give you the diagnosis, but I'll try to get you the first appointment I can with the doctor so you can discuss it with him/her." Some people might do better if they went through something like this themselves. But for some, I don't know if they're just too self-involved. I know I regularly put my foot in my mouth too. I think sensitivity training should be part of the curriculum for lots of health care people.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 07:44AM leaf wrote: Anybody would be afraid if they were in your shoes. Feelings are often not linear.  They do not need to make sense.  Can one person convince another why they fell in love with their spouse? You don't have to be brave when you show up for your mammogram.  You can be shaking in your shoes.  You don't have to be a 'good patient'.  You just need to show up. I have not been able to overcome fear.  I do not agree with the saying that 'The only thing to fear is fear itself.'  You are right that mammograms do not detect 100% of cancer.  But for now, its probably the best we can do. People have different ways of dealing with fear and anxiety.  Some find distraction helps.  Some can calm themselves with meditation, or biofeedback, or religion, if you are of a religious persuation.  Some people can try to 'postpone' anxiety - like saying 'I will totally fall apart after my mammogram.  But I won't fall apart before.'   Some like it if they can bring along a friend or relative. Some people feel anti-anxiety medications help.   You can promise yourself a big reward after you have your mammogram.  Just for showing up.  Some people would say to themselves something like 'I am giving my body what it needs to be healthy.'  It is your choice what you want to do.  Be healthy, whatever you decide.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 02:44PM leaf wrote: I did a survey here back in 2006, and this is what the poll showed: I separated people into 4 groups: People who had injectable anesthesia before the wire insertion (I assume this is usually lidocaine), and:     a) had pain <=4/10:  19 people (50% of the total people)     b) had pain >4/10: 7 people ( 18% of the total people) People who did NOT have injectable anesthesia before  the wire insertion and:      c) had pain <=4/10: 3 people (8% of the total)      d) had pain >4/10:  9 people (24% of the total). I know this isn't a scientific poll, but its the best I could do. I was told (in MY facility) they couldn't give me any fentanyl (i.e. any opioid) during the wire insertion because they didn't have RNs attending the radiologist; they just had a radiation tech. But you see in this poll that over half of the people (58%) had a pain of <=4/10.  I wasn't one of them, but I didn't have injectable anesthesia beforehand either, like Marin. In addition to Marin's wise words, I would add: if I was going to do it over again, I would also clear with the doc how I was supposed to communicate with him if I had pain.  They tell you 'not to move a muscle'.  For me, personally, I knew if I would have said I'm in pain I would have cried, and if I cried I would have moved. (People are different about this, of course.)  I would have preferred a nonverbal cue, such as ringing a bell or dropping something on his foot. But the MAJORITY of people in this poll taken here did NOT have severe pain.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 03:43AM leaf wrote: People who are at much higher risk than your girlfriend also have this problem.  Women are frightened.  Some women who have had breast cancer don't go to followups to check if they are OK.  Some women have waited until they have breast ulcers, or have one breast twice as big as the other.  Polls have shown that most women are more afraid of breast cancer than they are of heart disease.  More women die of heart disease than breast cancer.  I was told not to talk to my grandmother about breast cancer (this was in the 1960-1970s.)  She had bilateral mastectomies.  This was because at that time, the statistics of surviving breast cancer were not good.  Now, its sooooo much better. Even so, my grandmother, who was diagnosed in the early 1950s, lived over 20 more years - to her 80s, and died of an unrelated cause.  If your girlfriend is in her 20s, then, if she is average, her overall risk for getting breast cancer in the next 10 years is something like 1: 2152. So its probably nothing, but she needs to get it checked out.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2017 04:37PM leaf wrote: In addition to the excellent advice by the mods and MelissaDallas, there are also different types of chemotherapy. (Or to put it another way, different people can define chemotherapy differently.) Some cause a lot of immunosupression, some don't. Some are anti-hormonals, and some are antibodies against certain parts of a cancer. There are and will be new and different treatments for cancer. One condition I'm familiar with says that this condition was a 'total contraindication' for radiation, but I saw one woman on this site with this condition did have radiation. So, depending on your circumstances, you may or may not be able to have chemotherapy or radiation. I agree with everyone else: if you have mammograms, and if they do find cancer, then you can act on that information, and you and your doctors can decide how you could proceed to give you the best chance of a meaningful life.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 06:10PM leaf wrote: Of course you are worried.  Who wouldn't be worried in your shoes? I think that in most places they have radiologists do mammo-guided, ultrasound-guided or MRI-guided biopsies.  Surgeons (breast or general) do surgical excisions. Radiologists normally do the biopsy via the imaging where you see the 'lesions' better.  (In other words, where the abnormality is more prominent.  If they see the abnormality better via ultrasound, then you have an ultrasound-guided biopsy. ) I'm not sure what you are having (biopsy vs surgery/excision) since you say you went to pre-surgery testing, and ask about MRI biopsies.  (I've not had a breast MRI so I don't know if they do pre-proceedure testing for the MRI dye to check your kidney function?  Maybe others know the answer to this.)   I have not had an ultrasound-guided surgical excision, but when I had a mammogram-guided surgical excision, they first put wires in (while having the mammogram) to 'bracket' the area, so the surgeon knew what to excise.  If you have a suspicious lump and are getting a surgical excision, and the surgeon can feel the lump, the surgeon doesn't need an MRI or ultrasound  or wires to know what to excise. Hang in there.  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 04:48AM - edited Jan 25, 2009 04:49AM by leaf Hi there bloomgirl!  All this pathology terminology is confusing, isn't it?  Even if you don't understand any of the terminology, this abstract says its confusing even for the experts! http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19089736 I had a wire-guided (mammo guided wire insertion) and excision when they found LCIS in my core biopsy. I did a survey here after my wire insertion.  Most women do well, but occasionally some do not.  We are all individual people.  I was one of the minority that had a more challenging time, but I had pre-existing issues too.   What I would advise is before the procedure starts, ask the doctor how (s)he would like you to communicate with him/her IF you are having pain.  I was told to 'not move a muscle' for (it seemed like) an hour, but as I was not able to look at the clock, I don't know how long it was. Once I got the wire inserted, everything was much better.  I had an anesthesiologist, and had 'twilight sleep'.  I got big plastic bags to tape over my chest for showers the first many days.  I wore a jog bra 24/7 (except for showers) for several weeks.  I didn't start to jog again for about 2 weeks.  (Jiggling hurt.)  For me, tiny ice packs were better than pain meds.  I was up 24 hours straight (I worked the graveyard shift the night before, and there were delays due to family emergencies.)  I went to work 24 hours after I got out of the recovery room. (I'm a pharmacist.)  If I did it again, I may take an extra day off.  Some people have taken a few days off.  But we are all different. Best wishes for Boringly Benign results!

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 04:24AM leaf wrote: I do not have IBC, nor any invasive bc (that I know of.) IBC is a very unusual cancer.  I have heard it can present in different ways. Many docs have never seen a case, so I hear (though I assume breast surgeons have.) Is Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book, she says the usual first symptoms of IBC are redness and warmth in the skin of the breast, often without a distinct lump. She says what distinguishes it from an infection is that it does not get better with antibiotics.   She says that "Anyone with a breast infection that persists after 10-14 days  of antibiotics should see a breast surgeon, who will probably want to do a biopsy." She says IBC is rare, occurring in about 1-4% of breast cancers.   She says what the tip-off is that after being put on antibiotics, it doesn't get better, and it doesn't get worse.    She says if the symptoms continue after treatment, then ask to have a biopsy done of the breast tissue and the skin itself. In inflammatory breast cancer, you have cancer cells in the lymph vessels of the skin, which is what makes the skin red; the cancer is blocking lymph fluid drainage of the skin.  Maybe you should ask the doc to ask whether or not it was adequate to detect IBC?  I do not know enough about IBC to know if it occurs throughout your entire breast, and whether they can 100% rule out IBC from that biopsy.  Was your surgeon a general surgeon or a breast surgeon?

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 06:38AM leaf wrote: Re-excision means they go in again and take more tissue.  They often do this for DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ) as they want to remove all the DCIS (ductal carcinoma in situ).  If they don't see any DCIS within (the figure varies from place to place) at the tissue margins, they call it 'clean'.  If they find DCIS at the margin, then they call it 'dirty' and need to either go in and re-excise, or, in some cases a mastectomy is recommended. DCIS is usually thought of as a precursor to breast cancer. Here's a paper that supports what traveler said for BIRADS 4. "The prospectively classified BI-RADS 3/4/5 findings revealed a malignant histology in 5.9%/17.6%/90.9% of all lesions, respectively" http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16392601 I had a Birads 4 mammogram too.  I ended up having LCIS and ALH (and nothing worse.)  Don't expect this as it is quite unusual.  I got excised after the biopsy, not in order to remove more LCIS, but to make sure there wasn't anything worse going on. LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) (in spite of the name) is normally considered a benign condition, that puts you at higher risk for breast cancer.  Even if you have 1 spot in 1 breast, it puts both breasts at risk.  Its a weird condition. Most calcifications, and most microcalcifications end up being benign.  I googled microcalcifications when I was waiting for my biopsy, and was very upset.  I didn't know the 'big picture'.  If you just have microcalcifications, then most of the time, as traveler said, it is usually very early stage, often DCIS. We all want to be ready for whatever is on our path. What is the worst case scenario?  You will be killed by a meteorite tonight.  Breast cancer is NOT an automatic death sentence.  Waiting is absolutely horrible.  As they say, its really hard to keep the 'chipmunks' at bay.  Some women feel distraction helps.  Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 12:42PM - edited Jan 13, 2009 01:01PM by leaf Oh of course!  I have at least 4 conditions (I've kind of lost count) that have an incidence of <=1:10,000 (one of which is LCIS).  I been getting a new (or revised) diagnosis/condition every 3-6 months since my LCIS diagnosis in 12-05. One is much more life threatening than my LCIS, and has an incidence of some 5-20:1 million. My best friend, who had no (zero,zip- not even weight or high blood pressure) medical problems whatsoever before her pancreatic cancer diagnosis last February, died last month at the age of 59.  Its the first time I've seen death up close and personal.  She did NOT want to talk about how she felt. I'm agnostic, so prayer or religion isn't for me.  (There is a thread about atheists with BC in the Just diagnosed or the Getting through Treatment forums.) Well, I've been in therapy since my LCIS was verified, and that has helped.  (I was told I have 'something like' PTSD.)  I had some biofeedback training, which has helped.  I've had trauma issues from when I was a very small child.  I didn't even know they were traumatic until my LCIS diagnosis, some 50 years later! But we all have different personalities, so our ways of coping will be different. Sometimes you just have to laugh, because if you don't you would cry. (and I do that too.) There are some people who get diagnosed with dreadful conditions  (like really strange cancers) where there have only been a handful of cases in the literature. They don't know how to treat them or what their prognosis might be.  Just think of how they feel.  I mean, somebody has to be that handful.   Health is not distributed equally or fairly.  There is no "Just World".  It would be a lot less chaotic if the world worked and 'we got what we deserved'.  Sometimes it works that way, but often it does not. For myself, all I can do is to try to be more kind.  Someone here has the signature that goes something like "Be kind to everyone because you do not know what trials they are going through." I can't be kind to everyone (I have some difficult issues), but I can try to improve myself. I know that I spend a lot more time on this board than the average person - I want to 'save the newbies'.  I mean, I never got my Holiday cards written!

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2012 05:59PM - edited Oct 30, 2012 02:11AM by leaf There are links of breast cancer to many, many other conditions.  Remember, the science of breast cancer risk is in its infancy.  There are certain conditions that may significantly increase your risk of breast cancer, such as having a deleterious BRCA mutation, or perhaps a significant family history such as having a 1st degree relative with breast cancer particularly premenopausal, or having radiation *therapy* (not simple diagnostic chest Xrays), such as treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma, or being involved in significant radiation exposure such as Hiroshima atomic bomb blasts.  Remember, about 70% of women who get breast cancer have no obvious risk factors for breast cancer besides being a woman.  Even all the other factors associated with breast cancer risk listed in the Gail model www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/  do NOT give significantly better information on whether *you* as an individual will get breast cancer. In other words, I have classic LCIS, but many places do NOT categorize me as being a 'high risk woman'.  There is a lot unknown about LCIS, but most people estimate my lifetime risk of breast cancer is about 25-40%.  This is more than the 'average' woman's lifetime risk of about 13%. Even known breast cancer risk conditions such as having LCIS or dense breasts do not get the risk curves different enough to be able to separate the people who will or won't get breast cancer. (LCIS is thought to be one of the largest non-cancerous breast cancer risk conditions that can be seen under the microscope.  Certain deleterious BRCA mutations are thought to have up to a 95% lifetime incidence of breast cancer, and I don't know what the rate is for Hodgkin's disease survivors, but its probably higher than the numbers that are usually tossed around for LCIS, about 20-40%; my 2nd opinion said 10-60%, but probably closer to the lower end of that than the upper end.) They can link many factors with increased breast cancer risk - but these are *in populations*.  In other words, they might know that more cases of breast cancer are found in a population with risk factor X.  But predicting WHICH of these individuals in this group with risk factor X will get breast cancer is a whole different ball of wax.  For more complex statistical information, you may want to check out this editorial in a peer-reviewed medical journal.  http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.full.pdf

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2015 05:22PM leaf wrote: I haven't had a false-negative MRI, let alone any breast MRI. But there are MANY different settings on an MRI machine, and different MRI machines have different strengths, so one breast MRI machine or study may or may not be comparable to another. There are things like contrast enhancement, which some MRIs don't have. The physics is beyond me, and its too complicated by my brain. I think the false negative breast MRI rate is quite low, but it is possible. I also don't know if these studies are representative of expert opinion, or how much controversy there is about MRI false negatives. This study showed a zero false-negative rate. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25454098 This study showed a (roughly) 20% underestimation rate http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25148176 This paper cites one false negative MRI (figure 18) when there is a lot of 'background parenchymal enhancement' (which is a high background level). http://pubs.rsna.org/doi/full/10.1148/rg.341135034 There is little in breast cancer that is 100%. There is not a perfect screening tool, as much as we want one. There are always exceptions. But we do the very best we can.
