Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2013 06:56PM leaf wrote: In general, microcalcifications show up best in mammograms.  If you had a blood draw and EKG, they are likely doing a surgical biopsy? Ultrasounds are usually good at picking up cysts (fluid filled pockets that are usually benign). But sometimes they can pick up other things too.  MRIs are usually better at picking up lobular carcinomas, and are sometimes used if you have abnormalities in other imaging and they are planning surgery, or if you are at very high risk such as BRCA positive.   MRIs can pick up a lot of benign 'garbage' such as inflammation.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 12:58PM - edited Feb 9, 2010 01:17PM by leaf Its a very personal, individual decision.  I told some people at work (I work at the hospital I got my excision) because I get really red eyes when I cry, and during the diagnosis process I had been sometimes crying at work (esp.when someone got admitted with a bc diagnosis) and wanted my co-workers to understand they had not done something to upset me. I also heard of several people here who got very warm support from their co-workers and community, so I thought it would be OK. I dropped my mammos off at the radiology dept, and the  clerk, Tommy, said 'Ohhh-LCIS', and I just glared at him.  He knew someone in my dept, but I had only met Tommy once before about 20 years ago and exchanged maybe a total of 5 words with him decades ago. The night before my excision (I work the graveyard shift), a co-worker said to me, "Tommy wishes you the best of luck on your excision, and recommends that you have bilateral mastectomies because he had a co-worker who had LCIS and that's what she did."  I replied, "Well, that takes a lot of audacity.' I did not appreciate essentially having a male stranger tell me I needed to have bilateral mastectomies, in the middle of work, I didn't bring up the subject, and Tommy wasn't a doctor, let alone my doctor. I had a difficult time with needle insertion before my excision, which ended up triggering a previously undiagnosed PTSD-like condition.  I wasn't able to tell the doctor during my needle insertion, because they said I must not move a muscle, and if I had told him I would have cried, and if I cried I would have moved.  It did not help when people in my department told me they would have told the doc.   I even had one co-worker (who I had not told) 'I must be the last person to know, but good luck with your breast problems."  I told everyone the subject was off-limits. When I got a more serious diagnosis, I have told some trusted people at work, but swore them to secrecy, as in 'I will personally boil you in oil if you spread this around.' Perhaps I would have felt differently about things if I did not have an underlying PTSD- like condition, if my medical information was held in confidence, if I had gotten respect for my reaction to my situation, etc.   But once people know, they will not forget it.  At least someone will make stupid comments to you.  You may or may not have tough enough skin for that. There has been at least one person here whose boss did not hire her back after her surgery due to some things she said before her mastectomy.  I'm sure its not supposed to happen, but some people do not act kindly when people have problems with their sexual organs. So lots of things come into play - the seriousness of your condition, your work situation, your boss, your career, your family, etc.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 04:27PM leaf wrote: Bessie knows a LOT more about DCIS than I do, but I wanted to mention my experience with Cowden's. When I had genetic counseling (not testing) in 2007, they suspected I may have Cowden's syndrome.  The genetics counselor at that time said she'd take my case to their peer review board.  They eventually decided it would 'be a stretch' to suspect I had Cowden's.  Cowden's is an unusual condition.  At that time, I found one website that claimed that, although undoubtedly underdiagnosed, they estimated that there had been a total of 200 people - ever, worldwide- who had ever been genetically diagnosed with Cowden's.  These numbers have probably changed, but it still is a very unusual condition. But the genetics counselor gave me a paper that said at that time, there was about a 25% lifetime risk of bc from the Cowden's.  I had already been diagnosed with LCIS. From the little I know of DCIS, I completely agree with Bessie's post.  DCIS needs to get treated.  I highly doubt if we know what the lifetime risk of invasive bc for someone with DCIS (appropriately treated) AND Cowden's really is.  In other words,  you need to get appropriately treated for the DCIS.  Cowden's may or may not give you additional risk (beyond that of appropriately treated DCIS.)  for more DCIS or invasive..  I bet there are no studies.  In other words, to echo Bessie, do make sure you are getting appropriately treated for your DCIS. You may need help from a genetics counselor to help you decide what contribution your Cowden's has to your treatment regimen  (if any).

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 04:33AM leaf wrote: Imaging reports tend to simply factually relate what they see (and not interpret).  So if they were describing a face, they would describe the eye and hair color and texture, presence or absence of moles, freckles, etc. Hypoechoic means the sounds waves of the ultrasound don't bounce off of the tissue as much as the surrounding tissue. Cysts (fluid filled sacs) are normally easily detected by ultrasounds. They didn't describe this as a cyst in the report, so its probably not a cyst. They probably want to wait 2 weeks for another breast exam because if a lump expands *and shrinks* during a woman's menstrual cycle, its almost certainly not cancer - cancer means uncontrolled growth.  If a woman has cancer, its not going to shrink unless its treated. No one on this Earth can tell you 100% whether or not you have breast cancer.  Almost all breast cancer is diagnosed by a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.The more negative imaging you have, the more likely it is that you do not have breast cancer. Most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-8 years before they can be detected by ANY means. There are some women here who have had negative mammograms, ultrasounds, and MRIs, but ended up having breast cancer.  This is unusual, but can happen. Our imaging is not 100% specific or sensitive. Its the best we have.  But, overall, particularly for younger women like you, about 80% of biopsies are benign.  You may see posts from women who had negative imaging results, but, remember, this is a breast cancer support group.  Most women who get negative results do not continue to post here and go on with their lives. I know its hard to make decisions about your health when you have no expertise in making these decisions.  Unfortunately there is little in breast cancer that is 100% anything.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2012 10:40AM - edited Jan 6, 2012 10:41AM by leaf After agreeing 1000% with cycle-path, I think its very normal to go to the 'worst case scenario'.  I think many people do that because they want to be prepared for whatever is ahead for them.   I had calcifications, and was breaking out in tears every time I saw a person came in with breast cancer (I work in a hospital.)  I was worried I was going to die shortly after being diagnosed. I didn't know that breast cancer, even in the late stage, is not an immediate death sentence.  But your chances of having advanced breast cancer are very small.  I had the unusual LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ), which, in spite of the name, is normally not considered to be breast cancer. (Don't expect LCIS; its unusual.)  Your chances are by FAR - that your results will be benign. Here's a website about breast calcifications, so you can see some pictures of what they might be worried about. www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4... No matter what the outcome of your tests, there will be plenty of people here who have been in a situation similar to yours.  But remember, most of the people who keep posting are people who have breast cancer, usually in active treatment, or are caring for people who have breast cancer.  The people who have benign results usually don't continue to post here.  So if you look at the numbers of people who post, you will get a distorted view.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 10:46PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:16AM by leaf Yes, all these forums and posts can be overwhelming!  You are writing just fine: we are not doctors or breast specialists. Its certainly possible to have lymph node lumps/swellings from different causes.  A friend had an armpit lump removed and it ended up being from a fungal infection she probably got when she was tending her roses.   Regular infections can cause lumps in the armpit and clavicle. Here's more on armpit lumps from the NIH. www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/en... including some of the possible 'next steps'.  There is a USA national program that helps with mammograms, but I think you have to have no insurance.  They can cover breast cancer treatment, too, but you have to be diagnosed under their program also, from what I've heard. http://www.cdc.gov/cancer/nbccedp/

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2015 09:05AM leaf wrote: When I was going through the diagnosis process, I was amused through the process - saying to myself 'How can they even suspect that I might have breast cancer?' I thought the only women who got breast cancer were women who ignored their lumps. (I didn't have a lump.) I was wrong about that. I certainly didn't understand the terminology, and the rapid-fire contacts I had made me anxious. That's why I found bc.org so helpful- you can get so much useful information here. I'm not sure what he meant by 'if the biopsy was normal he would continue to look for something else'. There are 4 main kinds of biopsies a) Skin punch - usually for inflammatory breast cancer or other skin related conditions. (You don't have any of the symptoms for this.) b) Fine needle biopsy - can often be done in a doctors office. Can only be done on palpable lesions, and sometimes can miss the desired spot. Can distort the tissue, making the diagnosis more difficult. Easy to do. c) Core needle biopsy - uses a needle with a larger diameter. Done under local anesthesia. Perhaps may be the most common type of breast biopsy?? d) Surgical excision - the 'gold standard' of biopsy - definitely creates internal scarring, making future breast imaging more difficult, but is much less likely to miss the lump or area of concern. Increased risk of infection, and is more expensive than the other biopsy types because its a minor surgical procedure. Maybe be means that if the biopsy you will have next week is normal, then he'll do a little wider excision? (Note: when I had my surgical excision after a core biopsy, my surgical excision removed about 2 tablespoonfuls of tissue. Initially, there was a small dent, but it all filled in, and since about year 2, it healed to a faint pink scar, and I have to really look to see where it was. So 'wider excision', depending of course on your circumstances, does not necessarily mean they will remove a large portion of your breast.) The pathology report is the diagnostic report, so they can't really tell you how they will follow you until you have a diagnosis. Different breast cancer and 'pre-cancers' have different prognoses. Hang in there. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead. We all hope that you do not have cancer. But no matter what happens, there are people here who can share their experiences and help you on your way.

Most breast cancers are not associated with single hereditary gene mutations.  (Only about 10-20% are.)  Lung and liver cancers are not 'flags' for the most common known types of hereditarily caused breast cancer (BRCA1 and BRCA2). I would strongly consider getting a biopsy.  The answer will give you peace of mind. Of course its hard to be positive. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us, no matter how small the chance that something might happen. The vast majority of biopsies turn out to be something benign. Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 04:38PM - edited Oct 21, 2009 04:42PM by leaf BIRADS is a score not of how many calcifications there are on a mammogram.  BIRADS is a rating that gives you some association between the imaging and the likelyhood of cancer. They not only look at the number of dots, they look at the size, distribution, and clustering of the dots. They consider things like shadowing in mammograms.  Calcifications typically show up very well in mammograms. Here is an excellent website about calcifications. www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4...  It includes pictures, so you have some idea what calcifications look like. A BIRADS 5 rating is typical of cancer (about 95%).  However, I have seen several women here with a mammogram BIRADS score of 5 who had benign results. A BIRADS 4 rating is not typical of cancer, but could be cancer. (about 3-95% malignancy).  Yes, that is a big range. Thinking of you as you await your biopsy!  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 08:28AM - edited Dec 1, 2007 08:46AM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this. I have LCIS (which is a more advanced form of atypical cells), and ALH (atypical lobular hyperplasia.) I am assuming you have atypical ductal hyperplasia or atypical lobular hyperplasia. Those are by far the two main types (I don't know if there are any others.) Hyperplasia means that you have more than the ordinary number of cells lining the ducts (or lobules). Most people think this, by itself, does not put you at any higher risk of breast cancer. It is thought the next step in the march towards breast cancer, is getting atypical. This means that features of the cell are not normal: such as the cell shape and nuclei are irregular. If you have atypia, this puts you at SLIGHTLY increased risk of breast cancer. This may be slightly controversial, but you may want the area to be excised, to make sure there isn't something worse going on in that area. It is thought the next step along this line is when the cells in the ducts (or lobules) fill up with these atypical cells, in which case it is called Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), or if in the lobules Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS.) DCIS is considered cancer. LCIS is usually not considered cancer (in spite of the name. No, I am not crazy (smile.)) LCIS is much more uncommon than DCIS. Going one step further, If the cancer cells break through the duct or lobule to the surrounding tissue on the slide, then you have invasive cancer. To get back to atypia, your case. 1) Make sure you get a copy of your pathology report. They should describe the cells. 2) If you have ADH (atypical ductal hyperplasia), then you MAY want to consider getting your slides reread at a major institution. This is because it is possible to confuse ADH and DCIS. They are treated differently. This can cost on the order of $200-550. Atypia, and nothing worse, puts you at slightly higher risk of breast cancer. If you want to find out HOW MUCH your atypia puts you for breast cancer, well, that is another story. It is CERTAINLY not 100%. If you have a bad family history or personal history of breast cancer, then these ideas below MAY NOT apply. If you have a bad family history of breast cancer, then I would strongly suggest you talk to a board certified genetics counselor to give you the facts to decide whether or not you want to be tested for BRCA. BRCA positive women do have a significant lifetime risk of breast and ovarian cancer. If you have a strong family history of breast or ovarian cancer, then you may have a known or unknown genetically inherited risk factor. A genetics counselor is the person to get the best answers in this case. Only about 10% of breast cancers are due to genetically inherited causes. There are models that you can use that estimate one's risk of breast cancer. This includes some questions about family history. www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ This is the modified Gail model. There are other models that can be used if you have a strong family history of breast/ovarian cancer. **However**, the number that you get from this modified Gail model has a lot of uncertainty to it for YOU as an individual person. It should not be used for treatment decisions!!! In one study, the Gail model was excellent for predicting how many women in a population would get breast cancer, but it was really terrible at predicting WHICH individual woman would get breast cancer. The accuracy of this model was "only slightly better than the roll of the dice' in predicting WHICH individual woman will get breast cancer. See my post in the High Risk Section titled Predicting Breast Cancer, dated Sept 17, 2007. I have gotten estimates for my lifetime breast cancer risk that vary from 10% (i.e. no increased risk) to 85% (in a model that has NOT been compared to populations.) (I am at low risk for a BRCA mutation.) If you want numbers in a study, well one of the most recent studies was this one at Sloan Kettering. It looked at women with atypia and women with LCIS. 1: Ann Surg Oncol. 2007 Mar;14(3):1051-7. Epub 2007 Jan 7. Links Results of MRI screening for breast cancer in high-risk patients with LCIS and atypical hyperplasia. Port ER, Park A, Borgen PI, Morris E, Montgomery LL. Breast Service, Department of Surgery, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY 10021, USA. porte@mskcc.org BACKGROUND: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can detect breast cancer in high-risk patients, but is associated with a significant false-positive rate resulting in unnecessary breast biopsies. More data are needed to define the role of MRI screening for specific high-risk groups. We describe our experience with MRI screening in patients with atypical hyperplasia (AH) and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed data from our high-risk screening program prospective database for the period from April 1999 (when screening MRI was first performed at our institution) to July 2005. Patients with AH or LCIS demonstrated on previous surgical biopsy were identified. All patients underwent yearly mammography and twice yearly clinical breast examination. Additional screening MRI was performed at the discretion of the physician and patient. RESULTS: We identified 378 patients; 126 had AH and 252 had LCIS. Of these, 182 (48%) underwent one or more screening MRIs (mean, 2.6 MRIs; range, 1-8) during this period, whereas 196 (52%) did not. Those who had MRIs were younger (P < 0.001) with stronger family histories of breast cancer (P = 0.02). In MRI-screened patients, 55 biopsies were recommended in 46/182 (25%) patients, with 46/55 (84%) biopsies based on MRI findings alone. Cancer was detected in 6/46 (13%) MRI-generated biopsies. None of the six cancers detected on MRI were seen on recent mammogram. All six cancers were detected in five patients (one with bilateral breast cancer) with LCIS; none were detected by MRI in the AH group. Thus, cancer was detected in 5/135 (4%) of patients with LCIS undergoing MRI. The yield of MRI screening overall was cancer detection in 6/46 (13%) biopsies, 5/182 (3%) MRI-screened patients and 5/478 (1%) total MRIs done. In two additional MRI-screened patients, cancer was detected by a palpable mass in one, and on prophylactic surgery in the other and missed by all recent imaging studies. For 196 non-MRI-screened patients, 21 (11%) underwent 22 biopsies during the same period. Eight of 22 (36%) biopsies yielded cancer in seven patients. All MRI-detected cancers were stage 0-I, whereas all non-MRI cancers were stage I-II. CONCLUSION: Patients with AH and LCIS selected to undergo MRI screening were younger with stronger family histories of breast cancer. MRI screening generated more biopsies for a large proportion of patients, and facilitated detection of cancer in only a small highly selected group of patients with LCIS. PMID: 17206485 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] In it, you can see that there were 126 women with atypical hyperplasia. Over the period of 6 years, 3 of these 126 atypia women got breast cancer. Just taking the raw data, and plugging into a computer, this is about 0.4% per year. All 3 of these women with atypia who got breast cancer during the 6 year study were over the age of 56. (During the same time period 11 women with LCIS and nothing worse out of 252 women got breast cancer.) Age is a significant risk factor for breast cancer. (In this study they include DCIS as a breast cancer.) The average age of diagnosis for these things is about in the 40s or 50s. There probably isn't a lot of data for younger women (in their 20s or 30s), but probably the usual screening that they do for atypia without a bad family history is yearly mammos, plus clinical breast exam every 6-12 months. (As you probably know, the recommended screening for women over 50 is a yearly mammo and clinical breast exam.) It is possible you may be offered an antihormonal (like tamoxifen) but it may be somewhat controversial if the risk is worth the benefit. So, no you are not doomed. The VAST MAJORITY of women with atypia will NEVER get breast cancer. Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 03:37AM leaf wrote: I am sorry you are going through this, especially if you are in a foreign country. The first thing I would ask for is a copy of your pathology report, so you know with what you are dealing. While people can throw all sorts of figures around, and predict well how many in a POPULATION will get breast cancer, they have a lot harder time in figuring out WHICH individuals in that population will get breast cancer. That is because most of the risk factors for breast cancer have a low risk factor. I am taking these numbers out of the air, but I am guessing that this is different from, say, close exposure but survival to an atom bomb. Most of those people will get cancer/radiation poisoning because this single factor is such a high risk. But most of the risk factors for breast cancer are much lower than that. So its hard to separate out the people with risk for breast cancer from the general population. (BRCA may be an exception.) So I think that breast cancer statistics are hard, but the figures for Atypical Hyperplasia put you at only slightly higher risk. I have LCIS, which is undoubtedly a higher risk than Atypical Hyperplasia (which I have also). Oh, and I was wrong. Another category of atypia is apparently flat epithelial atypia, although they describe ALH with this term also, so as usual I am confused. www.pathologyoutlines.com/brea... A caution about relative risk: do not be unduly concerned when you see figures like: this pathology puts you at 4 or 5 times the usual risk of breast cancer. These are Relative Risk factors. This does NOT NOT NOT mean that you take 10 or 12.5% of cancer times 4 or 5 giving you 60% chance of breast cancer. What you do is this for relative risk: you take the risk of a woman with NO clear risk factors (no previous cancers, no family history, menarche before 11, menopause before 52, first pregnancy before 30), and this is about 1 in 30 or 3.3%, which is MUCH lower than the 'average' risk of 12%. You multiply this 3.3% by the 4 or 5 and get maybe 13-17%, which is not much different than the 'average' risk. (These are approximate figures, and do vary from year to year.) I just don't want to get too upset when you see relative risk factors of 4 or 5 or something. But again these are POPULATION figures, not figures that are applicable to an individual person.
Posts.Title: What does having atypical cell really mean? Lolly BBJJBB

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 04:40AM - edited Dec 2, 2007 04:44AM by leaf Not a crazy idea at all, Lolly. I am in the US, so I don't know what the regulations are in other countries. I will share with you my experience at getting slides reread. I waited over a year to have my slides reread. That's because my slides were read as ALH and LCIS, and there isn't much difference between the treatment of the two. If I had ADH, I would have been more eager to get them reread. I went to the pathology department about a year after I had my excision, and asked them if I could get my slides resent to a major university. They said they throw them away after 6 months! I was very upset!! (Of course I did not tell them my diagnosis.) So I asked my doc (he's the head of oncology at my local hospital.) He said they always keep those wax cubes that generated your cancer diagnosis. They may misplace them, but they are intended to be kept. (LCIS is technically not a cancer, so I don't know what they do, and I don't know if they handle atypia differently.) I am GUESSING in the US the LCIS samples may get to be part of the SEER database. It ended up they DID have my excision slides that showed LCIS and features of ALH. I know on my excision they did at least 16 pieces. So I was concerned after I had my slides reread to find out the pathologist (who selects the slides to be sent) only sent 2 slides from this biopsy to be reread. (At my local major university it ran $550/biopsy.) I later found out from a person who got a PhD in pathology several decades ago (but has NOT used that info in the last several decades) that they usually squish as much tissue into the little blocks as they can. So one slide can contain tissue from SEVERAL different pieces of tissue. So I don't know whether or not they will give you the wax cubes to keep yourself. I don't know whether you have to protect them from melting (if that is a concern.) I don't know if they will let you keep slides (which of course would be much more fragile.) I don't know if the samples or slides will degrade. I keep my own mammos so they won't get misplaced and because they are from more than one facility. In my humble experience, different specialties handle this info differently. I had some non-breast surgery done, and I had to sign a consent that I would submit all disputes into arbitration before the doc would see me at all, but I HAVE in my possession all of the imaging from that specialty-they gave them to me immediately after they took them, before the images were even read. However, my breast surgeon's attitude seems much more secretive. When I was transporting my mammos from one facility to another, they sealed them up so they would be able to tell if I looked at them. (I didn't have to sign a dispute thing though.) So the last time I had mammos, I just kept them. I bring them with me whenever I have another mammo. Some women here have had their mammos conveniently 'misplaced', whether or not that was intentional. I don't know if that is because they expect women to not want to know about their bodies or what. Obviously your experience may differ. But I think it would be a good idea to ASK. And ask if they will keep the wax cubes and slides, or if they will be thrown away or what. If they are going to throw them away, I'd much rather have them in my possession!

Lymph nodes can be large for many non-cancerous reasons, including bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. The focal asymmetry could indicate a problem, which is probably why they are advising US. In this recent paper, they looked at women with focal asymmetries. After patients with benign results, those considered stable, and those without prior mammograms were excluded, images from 521 studies were reviewed and 202 developing lesions were identified in 201 women.... Conclusion Developing asymmetries were malignant in 15% (95% CI: 11%, 21.1%) of patients. Presence of a US or MR imaging correlate was predictive of malignancy. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26583912 I am not sure if the 15% statistic takes into consideration the patients with benign results, but that means at least 85% of the women in this study with focal asymmetry had benign results. Those are pretty good odds to me. (Of course, I'd hope that no one got breast cancer, but I'd rather have a 85% chance of everything being fine rather than something lower.) Hang in there; chances are good that everything will be fine.

Posts.Content: May 31, 2008 08:45AM - edited May 31, 2008 08:48AM by leaf Hi there Meg. I think one of the worst things you can do to a person is not treat them with respect. I have anxiety issues too. I don't care if you are frightened by pink and purple polkadots- you are anxious for a reason, and whether or not you find out why or if your panic goes away is irrelevant. Your feelings need to be treated with respect. I have gotten a new diagnosis every 3-6 months since I was diagnosed with LCIS in Jan 2006. I got concerned about whether they were 'all in my head' too. You should be treated with respect. Even if your doctor doesn't treat you with respect, please know that I think you should be. Most women here feel 'the best lump is the lump in the jar'-meaning that lumps should get biopsied to get to the bottom of this. This means lumps in the most well adjusted women, and in those that are as crazy as a fruitcake, and everyone inbetween. What person doesn't have some neuroses? By the way, I heard of a person who had strep throat for 5 years, and ended up having some inborn immunologic condition. There are some infectious diseases that can produce prolonged fevers. I, too, get into stress eating when the going is tough. Its hard to find things that are 'soothing' to yourself when you are going through this. I'm sorry you have to deal with a doctor you don't like. It makes it even harder to go through this testing process. Please feel free to vent or ask questions. We're here for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2017 01:15PM - edited Oct 6, 2017 01:22PM by leaf When they found classic LCIS on my core biopsy (2005), the first words my breast surgeon said to me was 'If you want prophylactic bilateral mastectomies, I'll fall down in a chair." This was before she even said Hello, or asked me about my family history. I don't know if I would have had BPMs if I was given the opportunity, but obviously if your surgeon won't do it, its not going to happen. When I had a 2nd opinion at an NCI-certified breast center (in the USA), they said they did NOT recommend BPMs for me at that point. (If you don't know what type of LCIS you have, try to get a copy of your pathology report.) Almost everything concerning LCIS is controversial. Be prepared to get a variety of recommendations. Even if your breast surgeon recommends BPM, do check with your insurance to make sure it is covered. (I don't know how the medical system works in Australia.) Assuming you have the (most common) classic type of LCIS, and no significant family history or single gene mutation, and have not had chest Xray TREATMENT (such as for lymphoma), probably less than half of women with LCIS (and nothing worse like DCIS or invasive breast cancer) will ever get anything worse. If you have an uncommon type of LCIS, then they are normally considered more serious. For a nice report of different types of LCIS, see from 2012 http://www.ucsfcme.com/2012/slides/MAP1201A/18YiCh...). The uncommon types of LCIS were just 'discovered' or 'established' in the last 20-30 years, and indeed are uncommon, so we have less information about them. Unless you have strict concordance between your imaging and the core biopsy, they will probably recommend at least a breast excision. The excision is NOT to remove the LCIS (because LCIS is almost always multifocal and often bilateral, and they can't reliably tell where you have LCIS unless they look at a tissue sample under the microscope). The excision (which removes the area around the core biopsy) is to help ensure there is not something worse (such as DCIS or invasive breast cancer) in the vicinity, which happens ROUGHLY 20% of the time. (Different studies differ.) When classic LCIS women go on in the future to have breast cancer, the breast cancer is often in an area that looks TOTALLY NORMAL on imaging. For more info and experiences, see the LCIS forum, below. Once you have had an excision, there is NO RUSH to make a choice about your treatment, and you can change your treatment choice in the future (except of course for BPMs.) No matter how many women you see that chose one route vs another, that is no guarantee it will be right for YOU. Only you know how you would feel about BPMs or the anxiety of continued surveillance, or side effects of anti-hormonal prevention. There is no BEST option for all women. As Mamabear said, good for you for doing your research; take as much time as you need. Weigh the risks and benefits of each option. Then make the best decision for YOU, which may or may not be like anyone else's decision.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 07:20AM - edited Jan 25, 2010 07:21AM by leaf It is not a stupid question!  There aren't any stupid questions! I think (but I'm just guessing) they can.  If they suspect Paget's disease of the nipple, then I think they often take samples of the areola/nipple.  I had a biopsy for some ultrasound results that were just under my nipple.  I just had another biopsy (with hematoma) a few inches away, so they biopsied from the other side of the nipple, just on the other side of the areola.   I've had hematomas on all my excisions and biopsies.  My breast turns all sorts of beautiful autumnal colors - black, purple,  blue, green, yellow. They can last some time, but they eventually do go away.  It takes some time for the body to re-absorb the hemoglobin in blood, and hemoglobin is structurally related to chlorophyll in leaves.   Evenually, my breast turned to its normal color and softness.  It just took some time.  Maybe gentle massage would have helped to break up the harder areas.  But, for me, my only memento is a pinkish scar.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2009 02:26AM - edited Apr 19, 2009 02:31AM by leaf If a lump expands and shrinks during her monthly cycle, then its extremely unlikely to be cancer.  Cancer, by definition, means uncontrolled growth. Since its growing and shrinking, then it sounds like its hormone sensitive (hormones from her monthly cycle.)   I don't know if the ultrasound being 'clean' means it was a cyst or not.  Cysts are almost always benign.  If it was a cyst, then they may have wanted her to go to a surgeon to get it drained.  Draining cysts (if big enough) is a very simple, in office proceedure. Draining cysts both relieves pain (if any) and makes the diagnosis at the same time. It also makes it easier to tell if there might be something behind the cyst, say in the future.   If the lump is NOT a cyst, she may want to get this evaluated further.  If she is breast feeding, this may be more complicated. The amount of radiation in a mammogram is MUCH less than it was decades ago.  But, as with anything with radiation, it is good to avoid radiation if its unnecessary. But if imaging is needed, it should be done.  If she was, say, 12 years old, then she may be VERY sensitive to radiation to her breasts at this age (12), and this may be associated with breast cancer sometime during her adult life.  (The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's early 60s.) There is a very common kind of benign lump, called fibroadenoma, that often happens in younger women.  They can grow fairly rapidly.  They often degenerate and shrink over time.  They are often hormone responsive. If the ultrasound did clearly show this was a simple cyst, then it is her decision whether or not to get this followed up and/or drained.   No imaging technique used with breast cancer is 100% accurate. This is true for most things in life too.  They can't diagnose someone with usual breast cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. Of course, we cannot diagnose you, or make the choice of what your wife should do.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2011 04:19PM - edited Jan 9, 2011 04:22AM by leaf Well, I would be careful with that breast risk calculator.  While it *is* based on risk factor information from medical journals, it has NOT been compared to the particular groups.  This means, for example, it may not have been compared to relatively small groups, such as those with ALH or ADH.   I have LCIS, ALH, and nothing worse, and (without tamoxifen) at one point it gave me a 90% lifetime chance of breast cancer, which is about 3 TIMES more than I've seen in any other literature.  Even the Major Institution said my risk was somewhere between 10-60%.  (LCIS has about twice the risk of ADH or ALH.)  I have been given figures of somewhere between 30-40%, or about 0.5-1% per year. Note when they say that ADH has '3-4 times the risk of breast cancer', this is NOT 3-4 times the ~13% lifetime risk of the average woman in the USA, but 3-4 times the risk of a woman WITHOUT any particular risk factors, which is somewhere in the area of 3-5%.  So ADH confers a risk of about 3-5 X 3-4 = 9-20% lifetime risk of breast cancer. These risk models also assume that risk factors are additive.  That is an assumption: sometimes they are not. For example, they know the risk factor alcohol is NOT additive with some other risk factors. Even if they knew the risk of a person with ADH and nothing worse, that does NOT mean they know *your* risk.  Even the Gail model, which HAS been compared to populations,  for *individuals* is 'better than the toss of a coin, but not by much.' http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.full.pdf As has been said, "There are 3 kinds of lies: lies, damn lies, and statistics." Be careful with statistics.

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 05:56PM leaf wrote: Hi there whatifitis- I'm so sorry you are going through this, and in addition, dealing with doctors that do not fit well with you. That is so very important. No one on this wide green earth can tell you for sure whether or not you have breast cancer at this point, and I don't think they can tell if your axillary lump is related to your 'vague asymmetric density' and dimple are related. (I assume the dimple is new, not pre-existing.) Dr. Love (a breast surgeon) in her book opines that a breast surgeon can only feel your breasts from the outside; you can feel them from both the inside and the outside. She opines that if you really think there is something wrong with your breast, then insist on a biopsy, no matter what the doctor says. If you are wrong, you will have peace of mind. If you are right, you may have saved your life. For me, its important that I and my doctor can 'relate' to each other. (I have anxiety issues too.) Its quite important to me that I can relate especially to my PCP, because they are the ones that make referrals. Just to warn you- it can be hard to find a surgeon who 'relates' to you. You can't expect that a person who takes you apart and puts you together again can also be warm and fuzzy. The decision is ultimately yours. This is a hard thing to decide. I know if my personality was fitted with your body, I know what I would do, but we are all different.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2011 05:11PM - edited Sep 21, 2011 05:12PM by leaf They are probably doing a prolactin test on you because prolactin is involved with nipple discharge. Here's more from webmd.   http://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/prolactin-15129 It says you should not stimulate the nipple, exercise, or eat before the test.  It doesn't say how long to fast beforehand.   Since its probably too late to call your lab, I get the impression that probably 8-12 hour fast is sufficient. I get the idea there is controversy on whether prolactin causes breast cancer.  This 2008 journal article opines that prolactin does not cause breast cancer www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... , as does this 2009 paper. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19632054 Most experts I've read opine that about 5-15% of breast cancer cases are due to single deleterious genes, and about 70% of women  who get breast cancer have no obvious risk factors for breast cancer (besides being a woman.)

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 07:16AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:24AM by leaf If you are premenopausal, then you may want to monitor your lump for a few weeks to see if it shrinks and grows with your menstrual cycle. (You can use a ruler or tape measure and write down its size horizontally and vertically.)  Untreated cancer does NOT shrink. The vast majority of premenopausal breast lumps are benign. If you are postmenopausal, then I would make an appointment with your GP.  You may want to make an appointment with your GP now, regardless of how your lump behaves, and if your lump shrinks you can cancel it.  It usually takes me at least a week or 2 to get an appointment with my GP. If in doubt, get it checked out with your doctor.  Typically, postmenopausal breast cancer is associated with sporatic cases of breast cancer.   That doesn't mean its impossible that you have a familial mutation, but its less likely. The mean age to get breast cancer in the USA is in one's early 60s.   About 70% of women who get breast cancer have no obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.)  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 06:49AM - edited Sep 23, 2008 06:52AM by leaf Yes, MRIs are good at picking up 'hidden' cancers.  In fact, in women who are newly diagnosed with breast cancer (like from a mammogram or ultrasound-generated core biopsy), they often now do an MRI of the Other breast too, to make sure there isn't something going on in the other breast. MRIs are notorious for picking up lots of 'junk' as well as seeing cancers that are not seen on other imaging.  They aren't usually used for routine screening, except in special cases (like BRCA women), because they would generate LOTS of needless biopsies and they are too expensive.  But they are the least invasive route especially if you have dense breasts. MRIs can pick up things like inflammation, etc, that are benign but show up on MRI.  In scientific language, this is called a 'high false positive rate.'   No imaging technique is 100% correct. But, yes, MRI can pick up a lot of stuff that is not seen in mammograms or ultrasounds.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2014 08:47AM - edited Mar 2, 2014 08:52AM by leaf Unfortunately, in the field of breast cancer, there is almost nothing that is 100%.  So no one can say with 100% accuracy that everything is fine.  (I'm one to 'never say never'.) However, the incidence of breast  cancer in young women about 20 years old is Very Low:  12.1 per 1,000,000 females per year in the 20-24 year age group. There was an increase in the average incidence of breast cancer per million females per year across the adolescent and young adult age groups during the period 1975 to 2000: incidence was 1.3 in 15- to 19-year-olds, 12.1 in 20- to 24-year-olds, rising to 81.1 in 25- to 29-year-olds. http://seer.cancer.gov/archive/publications/aya/ay... (chapter 9, page 112) We're not doctors, and we can't diagnose.  Mammograms would normally not be very helpful in your age group.  Other noninvasive options might include MRI or galactography.  But since the incidence of breast cancer is so low, and your ultrasound turned out negative, if you got a doctor to order this, you may be looking at paying for this out of pocket.  MRIs cost on the order of magnitude of $5000, and I don't know how much galactograms cost, but I imagine it would be about that much.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 11:09AM leaf wrote: No one can give you an absolute answer on this, Heather.  The vast majority of Birads 3 mammograms are benign.  This diagram from Imaginis gives you some of the overall statistics. http://imaginis.com/breasthealth/diagnosis.asp There have been people on this board who have had negative mammos, ultrasounds, and MRIs, but still ended up having cancer.  Its very unusual, but it can happen.  Imaging is not perfect; its the only screening we have.  On the other hand, we just don't have the resources to biopsy every woman every year.  It is estimated that in the USA, we do about 1 million breast biopsies a year. My facility always insists on having a followup with whatever screening was 'suspicious' in 6 months to see if anything changed, no matter what the outcome.   It is thought that most (not all) breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-10 years before they can be detected by ANY means.  That means most breast cancers are relatively slow growing. If you really think something is wrong, then insist on a biopsy, no matter what the docs say.  If not, then get another imaging in 6 months.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 09:03AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:03AM by leaf Well, the subject of LCIS, LN, and ALH are full of controversy. LCIS was first described in the 1940s by prominent pathologists, and from the slides (i.e. dead cells) they thought that LCIS looked very much like DCIS (which had been first described in the ?1890s?).  They thought LCIS had the same kind of risk as DCIS.  But they didn't know the natural history of LCIS. (Natural history means following the course of women with LCIS to see how many of them went on to get breast cancer.)  Since LCIS(and nothing worse) is an unusual condition (one paper proposed the incidence in the normal population might be about 1:10,000 - this is a Rough Approximation),there is not a whole lot of information.  But, on the other hand, we don't know how many women are walking around with ALH or LCIS and don't know it because they haven't had a breast biopsy, let alone a breast biopsy at the appropriate spot in the breast. Since the pathologists were so prominent, the name LCIS 'stuck' (for the most part).  There is NOT complete agreement about the LCIS name.  Most oncologists (not all oncologists) think that the name LCIS is a misnomer, and it is something that is usually a marker for increased risk for future breast cancer.  LN is a description about a continuum of cells in the lobules-it includes both ALH and LCIS. A rough analogy is that the breast ducts and lobules in the breast are like a bunch of dead end streets that intertwine but don't intersect (at least in the ductal part).  The dead ends are the lobules.  The streets are all lined with a sidewalk (the basement membrane).  You have cars parked along the sidewalks (which are like the cells that normally line the ducts and lobules.)  If you have hyperplasia, this means there are more cars parked along the sidewalk - like cars parked in the streets but block the driveways to the houses.  Hyperplasia doesn't put you at additional risk for breast cancer (or if it does, its hardly measurable.)  If the cars are beat up, then you have atypical hyperplasia.  Its the atypia that puts one at increased risk.  So you have more than the normal cells lining the lobules, and they look beat up, making ALH. If you have abnormal cells that cross the sidewalk (basement membrane) and to the garages and houses, then you have invasive breast cancer. DCIS, LCIS, LN, ALH, and ADH, by definition, have *not* crossed the basement membrane, and are restricted to the lobules and/or ducts.  It is usually easy to see if a breast lesion is invasive or non-invasive, but it can be more difficult to classify non-invasive conditions.  So, some people do choose to get a 2nd reading of their slides at a major institution, especially if they are diagnosed with DCIS and/or ADH because they are normally treated differently. LCIS means you have not only cells that line the dead ends, you also have cars filling up the entire dead end (like 'marbles in a bag' and expand the lobules, to mix metaphors.)  This is a rough description, and the analogy is not perfect, of course. Unfortunately, different pathologists sometimes define ALH and LCIS (and ADH and DCIS) differently.  Here are the criteria for ALH as defined by a pathologist at Stanford. surgpathcriteria.stanford.edu/... The 'usual' ways of handling LCIS are 1)'watchful waiting' - minimum yearly mammograms and twice-a-year clinical exams (since you are young, they may be more hesitant of doing mammograms, because in general, younger women tend to have denser breasts (making mammograms harder to read), and younger breasts may be more sensitive to radiation).)  But there is controversy about all aspects. 2) Watchful waiting (see #1) plus anti-hormonals.  Before menopause, your current choice if you do desire antihormonals is tamoxifen. 3) Bilateral prophylactic mastectomies, usually for women with higher family history/risk. www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pd... I have a weak family history, LCIS, ALH, and radial scar, and my breast surgeon said she was not interested in doing any more surgery on me (after my excision).  Thus, we couldn't discuss BPMs. I didn't/don't appreciate this, even though I may have chosen to not have PBMs anyway.  (I have other issues too; don't we all.)  Since I've been on this board (since late 2005), most women with LCIS had more intensive screening than I have.  At a 2nd opinion I had in 2007 at an NCI-certified major institution, they said for LCIS women at that institution, they offer yearly mammograms, and twice-a-year clinical exams, and offer tamoxifen. Here's what the ACS says about ALH (and ADH). http://www.cancer.org/Healthy/FindCancerEarly/WomensHealth/Non-CancerousBreastConditions/non-cancerous-breast-conditions-hyperplasia The subject of breast cancer risk prediction is in its infancy.   The models that we have currently are VERY poor at predicting the breast cancer risk of any one particular individual.  At least in the Gail model (the major breast cancer risk model) say it should NOT be used to guide treatment decisions for any particular woman.  (One paper says the Gail model, or another model that includes other breast cancer risk factors such as breast density as 'better than the toss of a coin, but not by much.')  jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten...    If you do have a deleterious BRCA mutation, then some breast cancer risk models may be better than this.  (That's one of the many issues that would be discussed with you by a genetic counselor.) This is the 2007 paper from ACS that described their recommendations for MRI *screening*, not MRI diagnosis.caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/c... So, except for the facts about the first descriptions about LCIS, everything  about LCIS is controversial. As far as BRCA 'treatment', they include watchful waiting, with or without antihormonals, prophylactic mastectomies, prophylactic oophorectomies (removal of the ovaries).  I'm not an expert on BRCA, so I may not be up to date if there are more options.  Genetic counselors are the 'experts' at keeping up with BRCA.  Different BRCA mutations may put one at different breast cancer and ovarian cancer risks.  Genetic mutation information changes all the time; it is an evolving area of knowledge.   Let us know how it goes, OK?
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications & ALH - HELP!! Rshep9101 Rshep9101

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2008 03:23PM - edited Jul 23, 2008 03:24PM by leaf It is a very stressful time.  You have every right to feel as scared as you are feeling.  If you weren't, we would be worried about you. We all want to be prepared for what is ahead of us. Breast cancer is not an automatic death sentence though.    My grandmother, who got breast cancer in the 1950s, (this is before the age of chemo, and probably before rads) lived for another 23 years and died of something else. So, while anyone with newly diagnosed breast cancer never really knows if they will end up getting mets (unless they are initially diagnosed with them), the majority  (about 60%) of women with breast cancer will die of some other cause.  The mean age to get breast cancer is 64.

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 05:05AM - edited Apr 25, 2009 05:08AM by leaf It is impossible to look at all the breast cells in a mastectomy specimen.  It might take a pathologist a lifetime to do that. (I'm just guessing, of course, but its not practical to do so.) I go to a community cancer center (not a renown first class facility).  My oncologist says they should be keeping the sample that showed your diagnosis indefinitely.  They may misplace it, but the intention should be to keep it.  At my facility, they usually throw away NORMAL samples after, say, 6 months or a year,due to space concerns.  I would guess this would be true for most places, but of course I don't know. Here's a website about handling mastectomy specimens.  (Its just a draft, but just to give you an idea.) www.netautopsy.org/axsop/axsop... WARNING: It is rather graphic. When I had my slides reread at an NCI center, the pathologist selected the slides to be sent.  From what I understand, to make the slide, they normally stuff as much tissue as they can into the little cube, stabilize it (?with parafin or plastic?) and slice it into sections thin enough to see under the microscope.  The NCI lab charged a flat fee for each BIOPSY that was reread.  I had no control over how many slides were read.  It ended up that usually only 1 slide per biopsy was sent and read. (For me, in 2007, the out of pocket  charge was almost $500/biopsy.)  Sometimes insurance will pay for some re-reads.

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 11:16AM - edited Oct 14, 2009 11:33AM by leaf Many medical people do NOT know what they are talking about (especially for unusual conditions).  (I include myself- I'm a hospital pharmacist.) No one on this big green earth, not the brightest Nobel Prize winner in Breast cancer, can tell you for sure if you have something to worry about or not. I have LCIS and nothing worse (this is uncommon), had an excision, and on tamoxifen.  Believe me, I know my choices.  I have looked at all 200+ Pubmed abstracts about LCIS and nothing worse. When I went to my last procedure, unrelated to my LCIS. I work at this hospital.  The nurse who took care of me had invasive bc.  When she saw I had LCIS, she asked if I had radiation or a SNB, and when I said no, she looked at me distainly, then finally said, well its only in-situ, judgementally. My treatment (excision + tamoxifen) is completely standard for LCIS.  They don't normally do radiation for LCIS.   If you have bilateral mastectomies, SNBs are not routinely done - they're usually only done if the patient begs for it. Maybe this nurse knew a lot about invasive breast cancer, but she  did NOT know about LCIS and nothing worse.  Some people don't have the humility and ego strength to admit what they don't know, or maybe they feel out of control for you, or maybe want to prepare you in case you don't know.   I essentially had a male employee at my hospital (he was friends with a co-worker) recommend bilateral mastectomies for me 'since a co-worker of his had that and that's what she had.'  He was completely out of date.  Even if that was routine practice, he had no right to make this judgement.   How would you feel if at work, essentially a stranger comes up to you and tells you that you need your sexual organs removed? They don't  always realize the emotional impact of what they say on vulnerable people. You know more than the tech. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 07:38AM - edited May 6, 2009 07:43AM by leaf I'm so sorry you are going through this worry. Breast cancer in teens has happened, but very unlikely. If you want some numbers,  this may give you an idea.The SEER registry covers about 25% of the US population.  Between 1973 and 2004, they found 75 cases of malignant breast cancer in females under the age of 19.   That is, in 2003,  roughly 8 out of 10 million people (8 out of 10,000,000 female adolescents). www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... In this study of adolescents in Vienna, over 13 years they found 2 cases of breast cancer.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18985359 You may want your mom to take you in to see the doctor so you can be familiar with what is in and around your breasts. Some women naturally have lumpy breasts, and some women don't. If you do have an infected hair follicle, then that can be evaluated. They normally do not like teens or young women to have mammograms because young breasts are more sensitive to radiation.  If you do have a breast lump, that can be evaluated in other ways, such as ultrasound.

Of course, we can't diagnose you, but this article gives you some idea about the range of breast discharge symptoms.This is just one study, so others will have different results. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2696228 It is quite unusual to be diagnosed with breast cancer in both breasts simultaneously, though it is possible. I don't know if this is possible with other cancers. Good you are getting this checked out.  Are your doctors interested in removing a lymph node?

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2008 03:16PM leaf wrote: Of course you are worried.  Anybody would be worried in your shoes.  Going through diagnosis is awful. Well, first they should be doing a clinical exam of your breast and surrounding areas, such as above your clavicle, your armpits, etc. It sounds like you haven't had a mammogram before?  They tend to be more cautious with mammograms in younger women (in this case below about 40 is a younger woman), because many younger women have 'dense breasts'.  This means that its hard to see through the mammograms - it looks like a 'snowstorm', and they can't see anything through the whiteout.  Also, there may be some concern about radiation to younger breasts.  This would be more of a concern if you are, say 22, rather than if you are, say 39. If they do mammograms, then you do feel pressure, but it is for less than, say, 30 seconds.  Whether or not they do a mammogram, they will probably order an ultrasound of your breast.  I found ultrasounds to be quite relaxing at my place.  At my place they used warmed up ultrasound gel, and roll the instrument over your breast.  If they do order these, they are not ordering them because they are convinced you have breast cancer!  They can use these mammograms and ultrasounds to help diagnose even BENIGN conditions. Remember, the most common symptom of breast cancer is a painLESS lump.  The mean age to get breast cancer is 61, which means that half of the people with breast cancer are younger than 61 and half are over 61. Most lumps in younger women are either a benign thing with a big long name called a fibroadenoma, or else cysts, which are a fluid filled sac, which are almost always benign. But for your own peace of mind, keep pursuing this until you are convinced about the answer. They may even be able to do some of the tests there on the spot.  But I had to make an appointment 2-3 weeks hence for each step of the diagnosis. For many women, it can take several months to get fully diagnosed, but some women are diagnosed in a few days. Many women feel distraction helps.  If you are not sleeping, you are not alone.   Feel free to ask questions or vent.  We're here for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 03:16PM - edited Oct 3, 2014 03:17PM by leaf I love this survey that breastcancer.org did. In a Breastcancer.org survey of 2,500 girls ages 8-18, nearly 30% believed they might currently have breast cancer. How is this possible when, in fact, the likelihood of any girl under age 18 having breast cancer is exceedingly rare? Why are so many girls mistaking the normal signs of breast development as symptoms of breast cancer? Over the past 30 years, the breast cancer awareness movement has saved many lives. But as revolutionary as the movement has been, something important has been overlooked. Few, if any, have considered the unintended fallout of surrounding young girls with constant messages about breast cancer.... http://www.breastcancer.org/about_us/press_room/prevention

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 03:09AM - edited Oct 7, 2007 03:09AM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this. There are some women on this website that had breast pain and this was their initial symptom of breast cancer. But for most women, their breast cancer was painless. Pain is not a very accurate way of diagnosing breast cancer overall. But I would encourage you to get it checked out. I also have had a terrible time going through biopsies. I had a very traumatic wire insertion before my excision (pain-wise). This made me so upset that when I had my next stereotactic biopsy, I completely pulled out of the machine when they were trying to insert the anesthetic. They had to physically hold me in the machine the whole time. So you are not alone in having emotional issues. If you are considering having a biopsy, would it be appropriate to consider requesting a medication for anxiety for the procedure? I have eczema of the hands (not of the breasts) but know how the skin splits can cause real pain (I don't know if this is similar to what you are having.) Paget's disease is NOT the same as inflammatory breast cancer. Inflammatory breast cancer is very unusual and often difficult to diagnose. The only real way they can diagnose it is by looking at tissue under the microscope, like every other breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 03:32AM leaf wrote: Breast surgeons are the best people to get diagnoses because they are the people who most often see the clinical picture, then see the diagnostic results. So they get to see the correlation between the two. OBGYNs are NOT breast experts. Just because she goes to a breast surgeon does NOT mean she will have surgery.   At my place, if a breast surgeon (or radiologist or OBGYN) orders a core biopsy, the radiologist does it.  If a surgical excision is required, then the breast surgeon does it.  If a fine needle biopsy is needed, then I think the breast surgeon does it. Different places do things differently.  At my 2nd opinion place, breast surgeons order antihormonals; at my 1st opinion place, my oncologist does. My breast surgeon refuses to do  more surgery on me. (One of my options should be to have bilateral mastectomies.) Breast surgeons should NOT be enthused to do surgery.  Now, to get a diagnosis of breast cancer, the pathologist has to look at a piece of tissue inder the microscope. That requires some sort of tissue movement on some level. It will be YOUR WIFE's choice if she wants to go along with the breast surgeon's proposed path.  Your wife can say 'NO' at any time.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 09:25AM - edited Jun 8, 2013 09:28AM by leaf I bet almost every woman in your condition feels the same way.  I certainly did. I became hyperaware. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. We don't want to be caught unprepared.  When I was getting diagnosed, I asked myself if I had advanced breast cancer, would I live to see the tumor board (a gathering of physicians that get together to discuss difficult cases).  I didn't go this far, but some people here have planned their funeral in detail (down to the flowers, songs, etc.)  Many people have said 'don't borrow trouble', the chances are high that this will not be breast cancer.  But I found its almost impossible for me to not go there.   You've probably seen the figure that overall about 80% of biopsies turn out to be benign.  That's a big number. What I didn't know is that  even if you go to the 'worst case scenario', breast cancer is not an automatic death sentence.The number of people who are initially diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer is small.  Here's a decision pathway that was printed in about 2001.  www.imaginis.com/breast-cancer...        There are about 155,000 women in the USA who are living with metastatic breast cancer. About 10% of the people who have metastatic cancer were diagnosed with metastatic cancer from the initial diagnosis.  http://mbcn.org/developing-awareness/category/13-things-everyone-should-know-about-metastatic-breast-cancer/ Its very easy to go to the 'well, what if I'm one of the 0.00000x% of people who die of breast cancer?  I've had strange things happen to me before.'  Well, if you go that route, I'm not saying its easy, but the worry is awful to deal with, and if you get benign results then you will have gone through that worry for nothing.  If you do get a diagnosis of breast cancer, then you will have to go through that worry twice.  The worry won't make any difference in our chances of getting a worse diagnosis. Humans are notoriously bad about estimating the risk of a bad outcome.  Its much easier to worry about things that are beyond our control rather than things that are in our control. For example, on average, people are much more afraid of dying in a plane crash than dying in a car crash, even though its much more likely we will die in a car crash. I found distraction helped.  Of course, its better if the distraction is not self destructive.  Take a big breath.  For some people, this does not work, and they do other things like get anti-anxiety meds, practice meditation or religion or whatever works for them. Its not easy to get through, but you will eventually know your diagnosis.  Hang in there.  You are not alone.
Posts.Title: I feel like I need a plan nlmlillysmom BrooksideVT

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2013 12:43PM - edited Jun 25, 2013 12:44PM by leaf Of course you're not being silly.  Everyone wants to be prepared for whatever will happen, particularly if its potentially serious.  Humans aren't that good at worrying about the things we should worry about though:  many people are afraid of dying in a plane crash, whereas they are much more likely to die of a car crash.  Perhaps part of our faulty judgement is in a plane, the passenger is not in control, whereas the driver is in control in a car.  Since we usually don't know what causes breast cancer, many women feel a lot more 'out of control'.  Before I got diagnosed, I was laughing at the radiologist 'How can he suspect I have breast cancer?', because I thought 'only women who ignore their breast lumps get breast cancer.'  I thought wrong. On one hand, no one on this big green earth, not even the Nobel laureate of breast cancer diagnosis (if there was one) could tell you 100% if a particular person has breast cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.  The only possible exception is with the unusual inflammatory breast cancer, where sometimes the diagnosis is made by clinical symptoms. But, radiologists can make good guesses. They aren't 100%, but they are much better than 50%-50%. The incidence rate of someone indicating 'its probably nothing' or 'its nothing' when it really is something is called the 'false negative' rate. Unfortunately, there is almost nothing in the field of breast cancer that is '100%'.  Overall, mammograms are thought to catch roughly 80% of breast cancers. In mammograms, and other imaging, they often rank findings according to the BIRADS score. www.cancer.org/treatment/under...  .  As you can see, a category 3 BIRADS score has about a 2% chance of being malignant, and a BIRADS 5 score has about <5% chance of being benign.
Posts.Title: Radiologists/Techs/Doctors Giving Hope ShawtsGirl leaf

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 04:13AM - edited Apr 2, 2014 04:14AM by leaf Of course you were surprised.  When I had my first 'suspicious mammogram' and they tried to do a biopsy, I was laughing throughout the procedure.  I thought, "Why are they suspecting that I would have breast cancer?  Breast cancer only happens to women who ignore their lumps."  (I was wrong. And I'm a pharmacist.)  I'm sorry you had a hard time at the biopsy.   From this Mayo website,it sounds like fibroadenomas can be hard. They are quite common and benign. http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/fib... Remember, overall, about 80% of breast biopsies turn out to be benign.  They are probably planning to remove one of the lumps because it would prevent a good examination of your breasts in the future.  (In other words, if you have a lump in your breast, even if its totally benign, you wouldn't be able to feel any lumps/thicknesses behind that lump in the future.)  If you are younger, many fibroadenomas degrade/disappear on their own over time. We aren't physicians, so I don't know if there are other things that are hard in the breast.

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 12:47PM leaf wrote: You can always get a 2nd opinion on your situation.  The more imaging you get that doesn't show anything, the better your chances that nothing important is there.  However, a negative ultrasound doesn't negate a mammogram.  As one breast surgeon put it, if you're convinced there's something wrong, then insist on a biopsy.  If you're wrong, you will have peace of mind, and if you're right, you will have gotten things earlier.  Your insurance will have a say whether they will cover a biopsy at this point though. Most breast cancers are fairly slow growing.  Most (not all, but most) breast cancers are thought to have been in the breast for some 4-10 years (not a typo) before they are large enough to be detected by *any* means (including mammogram, ultrasound, MRI and palpation.)

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2007 09:57AM leaf wrote: Honey46, I am so sorry you are going through such agony. Going through all the screening tests is so very, very difficult. If you can, take a deep breath. Try that now. Take a big deep breath, hold it, and slowly exhale. Does that feel a little better? Every rational woman is concerned when they get a call back. Most women are petrified about having breast cancer. I know I was crying at home and at work when I was going through the screening process. I have only had 1 callback, and a collegue who has never been diagnosed with any breast cancer has had at least 10 callbacks. So callbacks are common. But do check out your symptom of breast thickening. Show it to the technician and/or radiologist. It is very good that you are getting this checked out and not running away and hiding (some women do that.) They do that because they are so very, very frightened. That said, please know that most women that get call backs for mammograms are fine. You have a thickening which it is important to get checked out. Most women with breast symptoms of one kind or another turn out NOT to have breast cancer. If they are suspicious, they will recommend a biopsy. If you feel at all uncomfortable with what they are saying, then I would insist on a biopsy. A biopsy is the gold-standard way to find out what is going on. If you have a negative mammo and/or negative ultrasound, then make sure this gets investigated until you are comfortable with what they say. It is your body. Biopsies are invasive and can be costly, but if you really think that something is wrong then insist on one. Even if you proceed to the stage of needing a biopsy, remember 80% of breast biopsies in the US are benign. 80% is a big, big number. Hang in there. Please feel free to vent, ask questions, and let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 01:56PM leaf wrote: I am so sorry you are going through this. I hope you don't take this the wrong way, but - if you just consider the breast cancer issue, its actually good that your symptoms are changing.  There is a rare kind of breast cancer that can be mistaken for mastitis.  For this rare cancer, usually after a course of antibiotics things don't get better OR get worse.  Usually for this breast cancer, the symptoms stay the same - they don't get better or worse. Of course you want to get this checked out.  For ordinary, run-of-the-mill breast cancer, they now think it has been in the breast for some 6-10 years before it can be detected by ANY means.  So a delay of a few weeks/months doesn't make any difference clinically.  It SURE makes a difference emotionally though. Sometimes things get delayed for reasons we don't know - maybe the secretary or radiologist is on vacation or had a family emergency come up, maybe it got lost in the shuffle.  Some women here have had their films sent to another facility to get a 2nd opinion.  It sure would be nice if they told you!!

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 06:05AM leaf wrote: Breast pain can be severe.  Many women have breast pain.  Of course, NO one should judge you for having implants.  They probably make you feel better about your self image. That is good. Breast pain is only rarely a symptom of breast cancer.  The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's mid-60s.  Its not likely that you have breast cancer, but if your pain is affecting your quality of life, its good to get it checked out. Here's more on breast pain from the Mayo. www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea...
Posts.Title: Pain and Burning! HelloStarr leaf

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 02:45PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:12AM by leaf Yes, you are allowed to talk.   However, the machine can be quite noisy at times, with pops and jerks and fan sounds, so it can be very hard to carry on a conversation.  I don't think they want you to move your head around, but you can talk if you want.  He certainly heard it when I said 'It hurt' (see below). They will tell you when you need to hold your breath.  For me, on my 2nd biopsy, I asked them to be very clear when they wanted me to breathe vs not breathe, because I wasn't sure I was always following directions on my first stereotactic.  Mine ordered 'Breathe'  then 'Don't breathe' then 'breathe'.  Sometimes the machine jerked and popped so I wasn't sure I was hearing the 'don't' in 'don't breathe'.  The order to 'don't breathe' only lasts something like 5 or 10 seconds.   The table I was on was lifted, so I was about ?4 feet above the floor.  My first stereotactic was just fine.  I was told when I had pain, just tell him, and they would stop and give more anesthetic.  I did, he did, and it was certainly bearable. I had a harder time on my 2nd stereotactic.  This wasn't the radiologist's fault.  Its because I had a traumatic time with a wire insertion, which triggered my PTSD-like syndrome.  So on my 2nd stereotactic, when my breast was in the mammo machine, and they were going to inject the first dose of anesthetic (I'm sure with the smallest gauge needle available), I instinctively pulled out of the mammo machine (which hurt  quite a bit of course). I'm sure I was so sensitized to any potential pain in my breast that it wouldn't have mattered what he did or how skillfully he did it - I was just terrified. He asked why I pulled out of the mammo machine, and I said because the needle hurt.  He puzzled over this, and the technician held me in the machine for the rest of the biopsy, rubbing my back, while I silently cried.  It was because of my past experience in my wire insertion (before an surgical excision).  Your body learns from past experience.  If I hadn't had a traumatic wire insertion, I probably would have been fine. There were towels around my chest and head (to pad the metal table).  They don't want you to move  your breasts, of course. Since you know it is possible you may cry, I would ask them what you should do before the procedure starts.  That way, they are more prepared, and you will know what to do. No, your questions are NOT silly AT ALL.   We all act in accordance to our past experience.  A two year old will pull away from a hot stove after (s)he learns the stove is hot.  We naturally pull away from a traumatic situation, or cry when we are scared or hurt.  That is a completely normal reaction.    We all have different pasts and different personalities.  There is no right or wrong in this.  There is just you and your past and how you feel about things. I don't think anyone should judge how you react.  We are all different and have had different experiences.  I had radically different experiences the two different times I had a stereotactic, at the same facility. Some people have done meditation-like things that help them, or picture a very pleasant, peaceful place.  I think some people *may* have brought in their iPods (but I'm not sure about this - check beforehand if you plan on doing this!!)  Subsequently, I did some biofeedback training, which I'm sure would have helped had I known how to do this. My last stereotactic was in 2007, so others may have more recent experience. Of course we wish you a pain-free procedure and your results are Boringly Benign. You don't have to be brave.  It is in your best interests, though, to show up.
Posts.Title: Somewhat Silly Stereotactic Biopsy Questions JellyShoes JellyShoes

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 04:35AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:12AM by leaf For me, my MRI (of my neck, not my breast) was MUCH more noisy than the stereotactic. The radiologist sat below me, so he could handle everything.  (When I got up after the procedure, I could look through the 'boob hole' to see his chair beneath me.) At my place, if you take a sedative before the procedure, and they know about it, they will insist that you have a ride home and not drive yourself. If you tend to get very emotional during the procedure, if possible, it may be good to have a backup driver if you can.   People can get very emotional during biopsies.  Before my 'suspicious mammogram' days, I saw a lady *run* through the mammogram waiting room, crying.  That is the same waiting room they used for biopsies.  I now understand that woman's anxiety, though I didn't then.  (Before my 'suspicious mammogram' I thought the only women who get breast cancer were women who ignore their breast lumps.  See what I knew. And I'm a pharmacist.) You are not alone. We are all holding out our hands to you.  Hang in there.
