Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 05:33PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:02AM by leaf I'm so sorry you are going through this.  I know I was a wreck. I have ALH, LCIS (which is more advanced stage of ALH) and nothing worse.  Different studies give different numbers, but in this study, about 10% of women with ALH got upgraded to something worse on surgical excision. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...  In this study, it was 16% www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16...  (Upgrade would include LCIS or DCIS in your case.) I had my surgical excision about 6 weeks after my core biopsy.   I did my genetic counseling about 6 weeks after my surgical excision.  It ends up I have a weak family history, and a low risk for BRCA, so my situation was different from yours.  They should already know the location and mutation they are looking for from your sister. There is no rush for ALH women to decide what to do.  After my genetic counseling, it took another 3 months to get an appointment with an oncologist (I chose tamoxifen.) Here is more information about BRCA positive options. Its quite detailed, along with studies, which may be too much information right now?? www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pd...     I bet all these options would  be THOROUGHLY discussed with you should you test positive for BRCA during genetic counseling.  At the place I went, they required genetic counseling both before and after testing. Different places do things differently.  That's just what happened for me.  You have a different situation. Let us know how it goes, OK?
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications & ALH - HELP!! Rshep9101 Rshep9101

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 06:56PM leaf wrote: What a mess to go through, Rebekah!    We are all different, but for me, the best pain relievers post-surgery were keeping the breast immobile (I was given a Valkyrie- looking breast support post surgery), and tiny ice packs (about 1-2 inches in size) that I could pop in my bra.  For me, the pain meds took too long. I have classic LCIS, ALH, and a weak family history.  I had checks (ultrasound, mammos, clinical exams) every 3 months or so for a year.  I had a pair of biopsies 1 year post-excision, which gave ALH and DH (not atypical ductal hyperplasia).  For the last 3.5 years, I have had twice-a-year clinical exams and yearly mammograms.  The NCCN guidelines are to have a medical history every 6-12 months, and a yearly mammogram unless bilateral mastectomies have been done.nccn.com/patient-guidelines.html So my monitoring slowed down after my breasts quieted down.  (I also started tamoxifen.)   I think its more critical for people with DCIS and ADH to have their slides re-read.  I didn't get a whole lot of satisfaction with my 2nd opinion at a major institution. (I had both my slides re-read and a 2nd opinion on treatment.) I got a better idea how little we know.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 09:41PM - edited May 3, 2009 09:57PM by leaf I think that if there is a 'most crucial' part of your hands for hygiene, it is your fingerpads - these are the parts of the hand that are most likely to touch something.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17230387 It sounds like they only measured fingertip  imprints in this study. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15061408 On the other hand (no pun intended), this study suggests that fingertip testing was comparable with whole hand testing. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12008011 I do know that when I went out with my surgical nurse friend, and saw her wash her hands after using the bathroom, she really concentrated on washing her fingertips. Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 10:52AM - edited Dec 1, 2007 11:15AM by leaf I think the main questions I would want to get settled in the near future if I were in your shoes: 1) Should I get the area excised? (If you haven't already had it excised.) There certainly are some papers that support excision. 1: Radiology. 2004 Jun;231(3):813-9. Epub 2004 Apr 22. Links Comment in: Radiology. 2004 Jun;231(3):617-21. Lobular carcinoma in situ or atypical lobular hyperplasia at core-needle biopsy: is excisional biopsy necessary? Foster MC, Helvie MA, Gregory NE, Rebner M, Nees AV, Paramagul C. Department of Radiology, TC 2910N, University of Michigan Health System, 1500 E Medical Center Drive, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-0326, USA. PURPOSE: To retrospectively determine frequency of invasive cancer or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) at excisional biopsy in women with atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) or lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) at percutaneous core-needle biopsy (CNB). MATERIALS AND METHODS: Review of results in 6,081 consecutive patients who underwent CNB at two institutions revealed that in 35 (0.58%), LCIS (n = 15) or ALH (n = 20) was the pathologic finding with highest risk. Patient age range was 41-84 years (mean, 59 years). Of 35 patients, 26 (74%) underwent excisional biopsy and nine (26%) underwent mammographic follow-up for longer than 2 years. Lesions with a pathologic upgrade were noted when invasive cancer or DCIS occurred at the CNB site. CNB results in patients with a diagnosis of atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) (75 of 6,081 [1.2%]) were reviewed; these patients underwent subsequent excisional biopsy. Statistical comparison of frequency of upgrading of lesions in patients with a diagnosis of LCIS or ALH at CNB and in those with a diagnosis of ADH at CNB was performed (Pearson chi(2) test). RESULTS: In six (17%) of 35 (95% CI: 4.7%, 29.6%) patients, lesions were upgraded to DCIS (n = 4) or invasive cancer (n = 2). In 15 patients with LCIS diagnosed at CNB, lesions in four (27%) were upgraded to either DCIS or invasive cancer. In 20 patients with ALH diagnosed at CNB, lesions were upgraded to DCIS in two (10%). Lesions in nine patients who underwent mammographic follow-up were stable. No mammographic or technical findings distinguished patients with upgraded lesions from those whose lesions were not upgraded. In 12 (16%) of 75 (95% CI: 7.7%, 24.3%) patients with ADH, lesions were upgraded. Difference between the upgrade rate in patients with LCIS or ALH and that in those with ADH was not significant (P =.88). CONCLUSION: Lesions in 17% of patients with LCIS or ALH at CNB were upgraded to invasive cancer or DCIS; this rate was similar to the upgrade rate in patients with ADH. Excisional biopsy is supported when LCIS, ALH, or ADH is diagnosed at CNB. Copyright RSNA, 2004 PMID: 15105449 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] 2) Should I get my slides reread? (Your insurance may or may not cover.) If you haven't been excised, and choose to get excised, then you may want to hold off on this depending on what the excision says. 3) *IF* you have a bad family history (such as a first degree relative who had breast or ovarian cancer, or multiple second degree relatives), should you see a board certified genetics counselor to get genetics counseling? (This is usually at a major institution or university.) (Board certified genetics counselors should NOT pressure you one way or another to get tested. They can evaluate your family tree to try to estimate your risk of having a BRCA mutation. Some people can't get their family tree evaluated because they are adopted or other reasons. It was like pulling hen's teeth to get some of the family data for me. ) The reason why this may be important is that if they think you have a strong possibility of genetically linked breast cancer running around in your family, this may affect your treatment choices or options. All of these questions can be answered yes or no depending on your particular circumstances and preferences. There is no blantantly right or wrong choices for any of these questions. I personally am pretty proactive, and if you haven't been excised, then if I were in your shoes, I would strongly consider excision. But it is a personal choice.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 06:38AM leaf wrote: It is awful doing all this waiting before getting finally diagnosed. Most lumps in younger women (and you are definitely younger in breast cancer terms- the mean age to get breast cancer is in one's mid-60s) - are either benign fibroadenomas or cysts - which are almost always benign. It is good you are following this up, but even if they finally proceed to biopsy (they may want to do more imaging first)-  but overall, in the US 80% of biopsies are benign.  That's a big number. Even IF you do have breast cancer, most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 6-10 years (not a typo) before it can be detected by ANY means.  So even if this waiting drives you bonkers, it usually doesn't mean anything as far as treatment goes. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us.  Many women here feel distraction helps with the worrying.
Posts.Title: mamo tommorow proudmama29 leaf

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 10:02AM leaf wrote: Hi there, Kristen!  I'm glad you found this site too.  Good for you for getting your breast lump checked out!  Some women are too frightened to go to the doctor's. Many women find breast lumps by accident.  Almost all of the women on this site have had breast cancer, or are at higher risk for breast cancer, or are going through the diagnostic process.  Most women who have breast lumps end up having BENIGN breast lumps, and not breast cancer.  They usually stop posting here.  So the replies you get here will come from a very skewed population. I've never had any breast lumps, but a big percentage of breast lumps are the almost always benign cysts (which are fluid filled sacs) or benign fibroadenomas. In fact, overall (particularly for women under about 50 years of age) about 80% of breast biopsies end up being benign.  That's a big number.   Anxiety and stress are the norm for women undergoing this diagnostic process. Who wouldn't be worried if they might have a major illness?  Its totally understandable. Can stress cause breast cancer?  Well, that's technically a hard question to answer.  Its hard to objectively measure stress.  For one person, losing members of their family may be no big thing, because they weren't close to them or couldn't form close attachments with them, but for other people, walking across a restaurant to use the restroom is a MAJOR anxiety situation.   About 70% of women who do get breast cancer have no obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.)  We don't know what causes most breast cancers.   Yes, there is controversy about this issue.  For example, these reports claim there is an association between stress and breast cancer: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21875303 This paper suggests stress may alter the immune system. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21600570 However, these authors disagree: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21553982 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19572196 But,  whether or not stress can be a factor in causing breast cancer, that information will NOT be helpful to you.  A person cannot change the past, and it is difficult to change one's coping mechanisms.  Even if you propose, "I got this lump because I ate that artificially flavored candy 10 years ago", all that would do is to make you feel guilty.  Not helpful.  Makes you feel even worse. Breast cancer is NOT caused by 'negative thinking'.  It is totally natural to be frightened by the prospect of breast cancer.  It is NOT helpful to people with cancer to be told their feelings caused their cancer.  It is not helpful to tell someone they should have different feelings than whatever they are feeling.   Isn't it normal for anyone to be distressed if someone gives them bad news? I believe we should all, like all normal people, be free to have good days and bad days.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 01:20PM leaf wrote: I'm sure its possible, but many things are possible.  Its possible,  but VERY unlikely for all the oxygen in the room you sit in will move to the other side of the room.   It sounds like it *can* happen, but is very, very unusual.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20082408 One abstract said they only found 6 reports of an abscess with a particular kind of squamous cell cancer on the breast. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17919353 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16800983 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16800983 I'm glad they're being thorough, but it sounds like its  very unlikely.  Best wishes for a Very Benign outcome!
Posts.Title: Can Cancer cause a breast abscess? shoey1522 JoannCLiddell

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2011 06:37PM - edited Dec 24, 2011 07:11PM by leaf Its totally understandable that you are scared.  When I was going through the diagnosis process, I was so anxious, I was in denial at first.  "How could anyone suspect I might have breast cancer?  Only stupid people who ignore their breast lumps get breast cancer", I thought.  (This is a wrong assumption, by the way.  I am a pharmacist.  See what I knew.) So another poster thought that "Women at age 28 are commonly diagnosed with breast cancer"?  I don't know how that other poster was defining the word 'common', but the government/SEER study (a survey of almost all the people in the US with cancer) says: Breast cancer in adolescents and young adults is rare. From 1975 to 2000, less than 0.1% of all breast cancer occurred in young women under 30 years of age.    http://seer.cancer.gov/publications/aya/ The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's 60s.  That means of course that it is POSSIBLE for a young person to get breast cancer, but, according to these statistics, it is not common. If you have a horrible family history (such as sister, mother, father, and/or brother with breast cancer, especially multiple members in your  IMMEDIATE family), or have a history of chest radiation TREATMENT due to things like Hodgkin's lymphoma - this is NOT a diagnostic chest Xray - , then you are definitely at higher risk, and they may want to be more cautious and thorough about ruling out breast cancer in someone with that history.  The definition of cancer is uncontrolled GROWTH.  There are slow growing cancers where the growth rate may be very slow.  But if your breast lump is shrinking,  then, if your lump is composed of 1 type of tissue, I don't understand how this could be breast cancer.  Many, many breast lumps in young women are hormonally driven (they grow and shrink in response to your menstrual cycle.) These lumps that grow and shrink in response to one's menstrual cycle are benign.  I haven't read here of anyone who had a shrinking breast lump that was diagnosed with breast cancer. I guess it could happen if you had a lump that was shrinking faster than a small cancer was growing.  But that's a real, real long shot. I've not heard about that happening. At your age, it is highly unlikely you would have breast cancer, unless you are in one of the high risk groups such as a rotten family history or history of chest radiation TREATMENT (or were involved in high dose radiation like stuck in Chernobyl or a nuclear bomb or something.) Of course I can't diagnose you, but you could have a swollen lymph node from an infection of some kind, or a cyst, or of course something else I don't know about.  But it sure is not typical to have a cancerous breast lump that shrinks.  **If** it could happen, then I think it would deserve to be an article in a medical journal. This does not mean I am telling you not to be anxious or scared.  Our minds are not rational things all the time.  Some people, including me, can worry about something even if its 0.000X% incidence.  I was diagnosed with a long standing anxiety disorder shortly after my diagnosis. I bet everyone who is mentally healthy here was anxious going through the diagnosis stage, even if their diagnosis ended up being benign.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us.  Its totally understandable you are anxious. But I think the chance that you have breast cancer is very, very low. Feel free to vent or ask questions, OK?
Posts.Title: The Wait for Testing is Agonizing. breadlebane ali68

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 12:54PM - edited May 6, 2013 12:57PM by leaf The first time I had a stereotactic, it really went well; I had some mild-moderate pain, but it was certainly do-able.  I think this was because I had a kind, aware radiologist.  My 2nd stereotactic didn't go so well - that's because inbetween the 2 biopsies (which were about 1.5 years apart) I had a horrible time with a needle insertion (to 'bracket the lesion' with fish-hook like things so the surgeon could know where to excise at a surgical berast excision). But the majority of women consider even this bracketing insertion very do-able.   In a survey I did, most people didn't have a pain score of more than 5/10 during this bracketing needle insertion before a surgical biopsy (this is NOT a core biopsy.)   However,  I have a history of trauma (which I didn't know at the time), so that made my experience different. Everyone is different, so I can't tell you what your pain experience will be.  I would highly encourage you, though, that **IF** you have pain, complain.   I didn't at my bracketing needle insertion because I wanted to be a 'good girl' and not complain.  That was a BIG MISTAKE.   Unlike at a needle insertion to 'bracket the lesion', at the stereotactic biopsy, I was only told to hold still for about 15 seconds at a time, and I could freely express anything I wanted between.   Again, if you have pain, make sure to COMPLAIN.

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2008 04:33PM leaf wrote: Of course you are scared! Anyone in your shoes would be worried. Breast surgeons are the experts at diagnosing *including benign diagnoses*.  They are the ones who most often see the symptoms and get immediate feedback about the diagnosis.   While the majority of women with breast cancer have a painless lump, breast cancer can present itself in different ways, so its good that you are getting it checked out with a specialist.  Only about 15% of women with breast cancer get it from a known genetic link. Cysts are almost always benign.  They usually do not know why cysts occur.  I imagine many of your symptoms could be due to an infection of some kind.  I'm not a physician, so I don't know.  You don't give your age, but the *mean* age to get breast cancer is 64. Since you have a small daughter, I assume you are probably less than 50 years old.  If your current age is 50, then your probability of getting breast cancer in the next 10 years (in the population) is about 1 in 36.  If your current age is 20, then the probability of developing breast cancer in the next 10 years is 1 in 2152. Good for you for getting it checked out!  Chances are very good that you don't have cancer, but you need to go to the doctor to get to the bottom of this.  Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 01:52PM leaf wrote: Here's a link to more about mammos. www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/... I think there is some controversy about mammos for very young women. In very young women, most breasts are very dense and hard to see anything in mammograms, and they may be more sensitive to mammography radiation, although the mammography dose is quite small. However, I think the most common recommendation is, as has been said, to start mammograms at age 40, or 10 years before the age of the relative's breast cancer, whichever is earlier. It is a risk vs benefit situation, and I think most think the benefit outweighs the risk. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/97...

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2007 03:51PM - edited Oct 30, 2007 03:56PM by leaf I have had 2 stereotactics, which they described as core biopsies, and they only made 1 incision each time, each about 1/4 inch wide. On the first one, they followed up with a surgical excision, which increased the width to about 3/4 or 1 inch. I later found they went in inches in both directions in my breast during the surgical excision. Maybe I'm remembering the terminology wrong, or they have used the terms loosely. For me, the scars have improved over time. (My first core was 12-05.) For me, they have been much more attentive to my discomfort during stereotactics than they have during my one wire insertion. Women's experiences vary, but I think most find the breast pain tolerable. Some women with neck or back issues find it difficult as you have to be still for long periods. Great idea to call to see if there are cancellations. You are **NOT** a wuss. I was not brave and was shaking in my boots. Wishing you normal results!
Posts.Title: what is the next step? juliamiller Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2011 04:06PM leaf wrote: Oh yes, we all hate to wait! Unfortunately, it is rarely possible to tell 100% if something is a breast cancer.  The 'gold standard' of diagnosis for breast cancer is a biopsy - in other words, for almost all breast cancers  (except inflammatory breast cancer - you don't have the symptoms for that) - they can't diagnose you with breast cancer before a pathologist looks at a piece of tissue under the microscope.  Even when you have a biopsy, it can be possible to miss the spot they want to sample, or something like that. Its a judgement call to decide whether or not something is suspicious enough to biopsy.    They normally look for changes in a mammogram.  Mammograms do not detect all breast cancers; they pick up about 80% of them.   If your first mammogram was not overly suspicious, they are probably looking at changes. The more 'negative' imaging you have (the more times they do not find anything suspicious), the more confident you can be that the area is not cancer. Most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-10 years before they can be detected by ANY means, including feel, mammogram, ultrasound, or MRI.  So most breast cancers are relatively slow growing. At my place, they have everyone who has a biopsy get a followup mammogram in 6 months to see if anything suspicious has happened, and to get a new 'baseline' for future mammograms. You can look at the BIRADS score.  You probably had a BIRADS 3 score since they are recommending a short followup. http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/mammograms/results.jsp My colleague has had at least 10 call backs over the years, and has never had anything suspicious enough to biopsy, let alone have any other breast problems.  Hang in there.  Feel free to ask questions or vent, OK?

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 01:19PM leaf wrote: Yes, it is possible.  I think they call this an 'Unknown primary'. (To me it sounds like a murder mystery.) But I think its very, very unusual.  Its MUCH more likely that you have lymph node swelling or some other swelling due to another cause (such as an infection).  I've always had big fat pads under my arms: I always had to cut down arm holes.  (Even when I was a VERY skinny child.)   A friend had a swollen lymph node in her arm pit because she got a fungal infection from caring for her roses. Of course I'm encouraging you to get it checked out by a doctor or health care professional.  However, its so easy to go to the 'worst case scenario'.   A distant relative had an unknown primary, and they never found the primary.  But he was a man, so its very, very unlikely that it was a breast cancer, he was quite elderly in his 80s, etc. You are probably feeling guilty about being 6months overdue for a yearly mammo.  But remember, most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 6-10 years (not a typo) before they can be detected by ANY means.  In England, they only do mammograms every 2 or 3 years.  So, yes its possible, so get it checked out, but its not likely to be breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 07:33PM - edited Jan 25, 2008 07:35PM by leaf Yes, it does elevate risk, but the amount of risk may be difficult to assess. I have LCIS, ALH, and DH ( the DH being without atypia), and a weak family history. Grandmom had postmenopausal bc, aunt (other side) had postmenopausal bc. The ACS recommendations for MRI are in this article. caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/c... This is their recommendations Insufficient Evidence to Recommend for or Against MRI Screening Lifetime risk 15–20%, as defined by BRCAPRO or other models that are largely dependent on family history Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) or atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) Heterogeneously or extremely dense breast on mammography Women with a personal history of breast cancer, including ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) This is probably why your insurance company is refusing.If you want to find some information about the risk of bc in a study, you may find this interesting. community.breastcancer.org/top... It is the SOLE reference given in the ACS paper about MRI screening. Note that at Sloan Kettering, even for women with LCIS, which almost certainly imposes a higher risk for bc than women with atypia only, the monitoring is yearly mammos and biannual clinical exams. BTW, I went for genetic COUNSELING (not testing), and she opined that my risk for BRCA was about 2%, which is about the risk of an average Ashkenazi Jewish woman. As you see from the conversation, I was told I shouldn't have MRI even as a baseline from a major university due to too much scar tissue.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2010 10:15PM leaf wrote: *If* you have LCIS and nothing worse, LCIS is normally multifocal (meaning there are spots of it all over your breast), and is often bilateral (in both breasts.)  It usually doesn't show up in imaging.  They don't normally try to remove all the LCIS (unless you choose prophylactic bilateral mastectomies, usually reserved for persons with the unusual pleomorphic LCIS or persons with a bad family history plus LCIS. When people choose prophylactic bilateral mastectomies for LCIS, they normally do this only after at least a few months of waiting.) (I have classic LCIS.)  LCIS is not considered cancer by most oncologists (in spite of its name.)  DCIS is about 7 times more common than LCIS. If they find something worse than LCIS (i.e. DCIS or invasive),  then they often do MRIs to plan their surgery.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 03:55PM - edited Oct 21, 2009 04:14AM by leaf Well, I think at least part of the theory (in other words, why there are no studies) goes: Bras mostly constrict the lower part/under the breasts, due to gravity. From what I understand, most of the lymphatic vessels around the breast do NOT drain through the bottom of the breast. Most of them drain through the axilla (around the arm/armpit), or maybe the middle of the chest. That's not where I feel most of the pressure in a bra. http://www.breastcancer.org/pictures/types/vascular_lymphatic_invasion.jsp www.springerlink.com/content/e...  I also believe that the upper, outer quadrant has a somewhat higher incidence of breast cancer.  That's not where I feel pressure in my bra.  In this abstract, looking at IDC and ILC only, they found 19% of the tumors in the lower quadrants, and ~80% in the upper quadrants. I'm not sure if the bra theory mandates location of the tumor in the breast, but the upper quadrants are not where most breast constriction occurs (due to gravity). www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... So I think that's why they think there is NO association between wearing a bra and getting breast cancer - almost all of the lymph node drainage in a breast is to the arms and beneath the middle of the sternum - there is no/very little lymph node drainage at the bottom of one's breast where bras constrict. I'm not an anatomist, or a structural engineer.

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 06:41PM - edited Apr 22, 2009 06:44PM by leaf There aren't 3 breast cancer genes.  The two most common single genes that increase your risk of getting breast cancer are BRCA1 and BRCA2.  There are others, though.  Many of them are quite uncommon.  Some of them have multiple names.  One of them is PTEN (Cowden's syndrome).  When I was genetically counselled in 2006, they said there had only been 200 people worldwide, ever , who had been completely diagnosed with Cowden's.  Cowden's gives an approximate 25% lifetime risk for breast cancer, much less than the risk of BRCA1 or BRCA2.  There are other gene abnormalities in other genes that put you at higher risk for breast cancer.   Only about 15% of breast cancer is thought to be due to single mutations in genes that are passed on by heredity. Some families have very strong family histories (such as EVERY female in the family has gotten breast cancer), yet when tested, they are negative.  This means there are probably breast cancer gene(s), or combinations of genes, that infer a strong family risk.We don't know what genes these are, or if we do, they have not yet developed a commercial test. This is a field that is changing. A board certified genetics counselor in cancer prevention is the person who knows the most about this.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2012 08:44PM - edited Oct 27, 2012 08:45PM by leaf Hmm... well, certainly if one pathology report was ADH, and another pathology report was DCIS, I'd personally want a 2nd opinion on pathology, because they treat / can treat ADH differently than DCIS. I think its really important to get a 2nd pathology opinion if they were going to treat you differently depending on their results.  (Some breast surgeons/oncologists offer patients with ADH  tamoxifen treatment.)   Your treatment options may change if genetic testing shows you have a deleterious BRCA mutation.   Your genetic counselor should be able to advise you about your potential risk for a deleterious BRCA mutation. Part of your decision may be whether or not your insurance will pay for 2nd pathology opinion and/or genetic counseling/testing.   FYI: I have LCIS and ALH, and I ended up getting a 2nd opinion on the pathology.  I paid for the 2nd opinion out of pocket, but it ended up that my insurance paid for the 2nd opinion.  (My diagnosis only changed from classic LCIS with cells with characteristics of ALH to (on the 2nd opinion) classic LCIS with ALH.)  So my 2nd pathology opinion didn't change my treatment course.

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2014 11:30PM leaf wrote: I'm sorry you are at higher risk.  Since you've already had your excisional biopsy, there's no huge rush to make a decision what to do next.   I had 2 breast biopsies 1 year after my initial excisional biopsy showing LCIS, which showed some ALH and DH (not ADH - its the 'A' (atypical adjective)  that puts you at measurable increased risk. Since Since PBMs were taken out of the equation (my breast surgeon refused to do them), I chose tamoxifen and took 5 years.   I am not saying that is the right choice for anyone else.   I know of no solid evidence that multiple diagnoses (LCIS, ALH and ADH) put you at higher risk than LCIS alone.  So I don't think its a valid assumption to add up the individual risks for your situation.  At least when some data came out several years ago, they thought alcoholism was a risk factor.  But when a group had both alcoholism and other risk factors, alcoholism was not an increased risk. I don't know the current state of that evidence, but I'm just trying to give an example. The science of breast cancer risk prediction is in its infancy. I've had no other further breast issues since 2007.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2013 07:06PM leaf wrote: In addition to Beesie's wise observations of incredibly small sample size, there is another way of looking at breast cancer risk models.  The Gail model predicts the chance of breast cancer in a group of women with those specific characteristics.  In other words, it does not predict the risk of breast cancer of any one specific woman.  In this opinion article, this paper looks at the application of the modified Gail model, and compares it to the modified Gail model with many other risk factors not included in the modified Gail model such as breast density, etc. Note the modified Gail model was peer reviewed and compared to populations in the USA.  So the modified Gail model  was evaluated against probably something close to a good portion of the USA female population. I'm not that super at statistics, but one way of judging how good a model is for an individual is the concordance value.  'Judging a model for an individual' means answering the question 'What is my risk of breast cancer over my lifetime', as opposed to the modified Gail model that can answer  'How many people in a population of X (say, 100,000) that have risk factors like me will get breast cancer?'  This opinion article said that the modified Gail model, and the modified Gail model that includes other risk factors such as breast density, will quite accurately predict how many women in a population will get breast cancer.  However, both models are 'better than a roll of the dice, but not by much' in predicting how well the model works for an individual.  (To be specific, the best model they tested, the modified Gail model + other risk factors including breast density correctly predicted about 59% of the population, as opposed to 50% of the population if the model was as good as chance.  The best model imaginable would give a value of 0% or 100%.) jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.full.pdf If the modified Gail model works this bad for individuals with 'average' risk factors in the 'general population' , just think how well it works for a much smaller population, such as those with ADH (even if the study had a much larger sample size). The article says that those who have a strong family history, such as a deleterious BRCA mutation, may be in a different category, and some risk models may work better for them as individuals. I do not have ADH; I do have DH, ALH and LCIS.  I've gotten lifetime risk factor estimates from '30 or 40%' to 'somewhere between 10% and 60%, but probably closer to 10% than 60%.  If you want anything more accurate, go to the literature.'  I haven't seen any academic papers that say that women with ALH, ADH, DCIS, or LCIS have a risk lower than that of the general population. So I think that the subject of breast cancer prediction for individuals (even in the general population) is in its infancy.  Its probably in the fetal stages for individuals with higher risk conditions.
Posts.Title: ADH Club Chickenpants SarBar22

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2014 12:52PM leaf wrote: Hi Renee!  I have LCIS and ALH.  They don't try to get clear margins on ALH or LCIS.  That's because normally there are multiple spots of LCIS (and presumably ALH) in a breast, and it is often bilateral (in both breasts).   Since they can't reliably see ALH or LCIS on any imaging, and is only diagnosed by a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope, the only way they can positively 'remove all the ALH/LCIS' is do do bilateral mastectomies, and even then they have to leave some breast cells in place. (My breast surgeon refused to consider doing bilateral mastectomies on me with LCIS and ALH.)   Even if, magically, they could remove all your ALH, that wouldn't necessarily remove your risk.  For LCIS (which is usually considered a more advanced case of ALH), when these people go on to get breast cancer in the future, they often get breast cancer not _at_ the site of the previously known ALH or LCIS, but in a different spot in the breast (or in the other breast).  So that's why ALH and LCIS are known as being a risk factor for breast cancer.  In a minority of cases, they think that LCIS can itself become breast cancer, but in a majority of cases LCIS patients never get breast cancer.  Unless you have other significant risk factors (such as 1st or 2nd degree relatives with breast cancer or ovarian cancer), or a history of radiation treatment (such as treatment for lymphoma) you aren't at anywhere in the category of 'high risk' in my opinion.  Some papers classify LCIS as 'moderate risk'. Its totally fine to ask your oncologist 'What is my risk for getting breast cancer?', but don't expect the answer to be an answer they know well.  I was shocked years after my diagnosis to find this academic opinion paper. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.... A synopsis of this paper is that, for the modified Gail model (which you are eligible to take since you don't have DCIS, LCIS or invasive) http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/, even when they add risk factors such as breast density (in the Decarli model), they don't get better than a 59% concordance rate.  I know statistics are awful, but what this means is they compared the group of women who got breast cancer and the group of women who didn't get breast cancer.  They took one random person from each group and compared their scores on the two models.  In other words, for 59% of the randomly selected pairs of women, the risk estimated for the woman who was diagnosed with breast cancer was higher than the risk estimated for the woman who was not. Unfortunately, for 41% of the pairs of women, the woman with breast cancer received a lower risk estimate than her cancer-free counterpart. Thus, for any given woman, the two models were better at prediction than a coin toss—but not by much. (A coin toss would be a 50% chance of heads and a 50% chance of tails.) This does NOT mean your risk of breast cancer is 50% or 59%.  This means that the modified Gail model, even when you added risk factors such as breast density, was 'right' 59% of the time, and was 'wrong' 41% of the time. The modified Gail model *is* accurate for groups of women.  If they have this much trouble in predicting which women will get breast cancer in the general population, just imagine what the database is for a woman with ALH or LCIS. Some people get 'Your lifetime risk for breast cancer is 58.3%'.  I got 'your lifetime risk is about 30% without tamoxifen'.  Another place said 'Your lifetime risk is somewhere between 10% and 60% but probably closer to 10% than 60%.' Unless you have a significant family history or had radiation treatment (not routine diagnostic chest Xrays), the state of breast cancer prediction is in its infancy.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 12:15AM - edited May 14, 2011 12:35AM by leaf I think it depends on the personality and needs of the woman, the personality and support of her friends and family, and their circumstances.  I don't think there's a single answer to this question for everyone. Some people have an excellent support system, and they tell everyone, and all goes well. Usually the woman will eventually encounter some people who can't handle her diagnosis, or her potential diagnosis.  They may or may not be the immediate friends or relatives of the patient. Sometimes there are other circumstances going on, such as a relative currently having a different but more severe crisis, or a person in ill health.  Some don't want to worry others. I do want you to think twice about telling people at work.  There are 2 stories I would like to share about work, one of a poster here, and one about myself. One poster here said when she had a mastectomy, her breast surgeon told her boss that she was suicidal.  (Don't ask me how this happened.  Its obviously against HIPAA regulations for a doctor to share the diagnosis with an employer.)  When she recovered from her surgery, she was not hired back.  She was single and thus lost her health insurance.  She was in the middle of treatment for invasive breast cancer. Yes, I think its illegal to discriminate against people for getting cancer, but I highly suspect that it does happen, with the reason that 'business is bad, we had to let her go.' In my own situation, I was diagnosed with classic LCIS and nothing worse (which is unusual).  In spite of the name (lobular carcinoma in situ) it is NOT normally considered cancer.   I work at the hospital where I had my breast excision.  The radiology clerk saw my diagnosis on my surgery sheet.  I work the graveyard shift, and late on the night before my surgery, interrupted in the middle of a very busy night, I was told by a co-worker that this radiology clerk (who was essentially a male stranger to me) 'recommended that I have bilateral mastectomies because he had a co-worker who had LCIS and that's what she did.'  I did not appreciate being told my private parts needed removal by essentially a male stranger in the middle of work. Some people do not have the capacity to hold information confidentially.  Some people cannot handle the fact that sometimes some friends or relatives have things go wrong with their private parts.  I have certainly said the wrong thing to other people, and have not held information confidentially.  Saying the wrong thing does hurt.   It can be really, really tough to find the right thing to say to a person.  Even if you just reply, "I'm sorry you are going through this." or "How awful" or "Yuck", maybe you wouldn't feel supported with these words.  You might think 'I'm sorry' was making light of your situation, that 'How awful' or 'Yuck' was presuming how you felt about the situation - maybe you were feeling something else at the moment. To see other examples of things that are said to breast cancer patients, see threads such as 'the Worst thing people have said to you' community.breastcancer.org/for...   or the 'Dumbest thing people have said to you' community.breastcancer.org/for... I'm not saying these things happen to everyone; some people have absolutely excellent support systems.  I think most people don't know how good or bad their support system is until it happens to them.  For me, I have not told some relatives about my LCIS because it is a relatively minor threat and other family members are going through much more turmoil. Some women with a late stage diagnosis have not told their frail elderly parent because of the shock it may cause. So its an individual choice.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2012 12:02PM - edited Mar 4, 2012 12:06PM by leaf No, you are not insane. My first stereotactic was tolerable.  The radiologist said to stop and tell him if I was having pain, and he'd give more local anesthetic.  When it hurt, I did, and he gave me more anesthetic and it was fine.  Then I had a horrible wire insertion (prior to a breast excision.)  MOST WOMEN DON'T HAVE THIS BAD OF AN EXPERIENCE WITH WIRE INSERTION. My next stereotactic I had, about a year later, I had a much worse time.  Not surprisingly, I 'learned' from my bad wire insertion.  I did make it through, but they had to hold me in.   I would very much recommend , as the mods said, that you tell the radiologist and tech beforehand that you are very frightened of having pain, and to ask you if you are having pain.  They should try to make you more comfortable. If worse comes to worse, you can warn them that if your pain is not being controlled, then you are going to stop the procedure.  That's what I should have done during my bad wire insertion.  Instead, I didn't say anything  (they didn't ask either), which made me feel very much a victim. (I have a trauma history so that didn't help at all.) P.S. The post-stereotactic mammogram I had immediately after the stereotactic was the most comfortable mammogram I had ever had.  (They did the mammogram to see if they got the 'worrisome calcifications' they were trying to biopsy.)

Posts.Content: May 14, 2011 05:42PM - edited May 14, 2011 05:43PM by leaf About getting informed: different places and different docs do things differently.  I was called about my core biopsy by my sweet radiologist.  For my breast excision, I had to wait until the postop appointment, which was 1-2 weeks after the excision.   I personally think it would be best if each patient could choose which way would be best for them.  I haven't heard of anyone that was given this choice. Some people don't want to be phoned so they won't be 'blindsighted' - called for example when they are driving.  They want to have some control over the surroundings in which they find out. Others want to be called right away no matter what.   Initially, all they can tell you is the state of the cells in the sample.  So they can usually tell you if its IDC, ILC, DCIS, LCIS, ADH, and/or ALH.  Sometimes it can take longer to do the hormonal/Her2 stains, and sometimes the outcome of these stains can change their pathology interpretation.  Staging can be a complex process.  They usually can't stage someone until after surgery. www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...  Some people, particularly with large/advanced tumors get chemotherapy before surgery.   I am *no* expert on this, but I think if you get chemotherapy before surgery, then its a lot more difficult/impossible to stage you, because you don't have direct information about your tumor size or node status.  (Others know a lot more about this than I do.  Hopefully you won't have to know any of this.) We're all sure hoping all is benign for you!

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 05:34PM - edited Feb 9, 2009 05:35PM by leaf 1) It is certainly reasonable to get a 2nd opinion even if you just had plain ordinary ADH.  So I think it would be very reasonable to get a 2nd opinion in your situation.  This abstract opines there can be diagnostic challenges. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...  (It also does not imply that mucus type changes are invariably associated with LCIS.) It is important to make sure you have ADH and not DCIS.  They are treated differently, and they can be confused. 2) I would think it may be prudent to wait for the results of your 2nd opinion slide reread before trying to conceive.  IF you happen to have DCIS, then the usual treatments are (lumpectomy + radiation) or mastectomy.Radiation is not normally recommended in pregnancy. From what I understand, chemo is more 'doable' in pregnancy than radiation. 3)  I think it is certainly reasonable to get 2nd (or more) opinions.  If you have nothing worse than ADH,  then normally for ADH and nothing worse close monitoring is definitely an option.  (I assume you do not have a significant family history such as breast cancer in a first degree relative like mother, sister, father, brother, or ovarian cancer in a first degree relative.) If you are in Boston, John Hopkins is a renown breast center.    Is your surgeon a breast surgeon?   If your surgeon gives you trouble about wanting a 2nd opinion, then I would seriously consider 'firing' your surgeon.  You may be able to get a referral through your OB since you desire to get pregnant.  (I was able to get a 2nd opinion without a referral.)   If you get a 2nd opinion, they normally want ALL your records, and it can be expensive.  When I had a 2nd opinion at a major university (2007) it cost (out of pocket) about $500 for the 2nd opinion, and $550/biopsy to get the slides reread.  In my case, insurance did pay, the slide reread was $350/biopsy. I know this is very upsetting and confusing.  But I would recommend at LEAST that you get in the hands of someone with whom you feel comfortable. You may also want to check with the opinions on the young women with breast cancer forum, below.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 10:53PM leaf wrote: I tried to look on the net as far as tissue coloration.  I know some cancers can be colored differently than normal tissue - some cancers are white or black or yellow.  But I don't know if other lesions can also be those colors.  I suspect they can.  For example, if you have some kinds of necrosis (dead tissue - often due to lack of blood supply), I'm almost sure necrotic tissue can be black.  So I do not think that the tissue color is very diagnostic.  I am pretty confident that some cancers do not have any special characteristics by the naked eye- which is why DCIS often needs re-excision.  My breast surgeon said she was looking for tissue that was pulling - I think this happens in ILC.   I'm not sure what a 'pink or cloudy film from a Fine Needle aspiration' means.  Are they referring to a film on the needle?  I know when they do core biopies on an invasive lesion, often the needle shows cancer cells on the core needle washings (about 50% of the time).  This does NOT mean the cancer cells are going to grow out of the needle track.  If seeding happens in breast cancer after 'standard treatment', it is quite unusual. You normally can't be diagnosed with breast cancer without a report from a pathologist who has looked at a piece of tissue under the microscope. (The unusual inflammatory breast cancer may be an exception, and is sometimes diagnosed on clinical grounds.)  If we could reliably diagnose breast cancer from the color, or other characteristics, then they wouldn't need a pathology report. So, unfortunately, we must wait for an answer from the pathologist.  We don't want the pathologist to be rushed and make a mistake.  But there's no arguing that waiting is awful.

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 01:04PM leaf wrote: I'm so sorry your sister was recently diagnosed.  This must be quite hard on you.   To give you a real number, I'm sure that your family would have to be examined by a genetics counselor.  If your family has a BRCA gene (the far-and-away most common single breast cancer gene) - then your risk is going to be higher than if you don't.  Some families have a LOT of breast cancer, yet test negative for the KNOWN BRCA genes.  This means there are probably breast cancer genes we don't know about. These BRCA genes are thought to be responsible for only about 15% of breast cancers - the rest are sporatic.  Whether they are caused by environmental factors, or by multiple gene mutations - is unknown.  Your twin probably shared a lot of environmental factors, as well as sharing many/all genetics traits. Genetics counselors are normally found at major institutions.  I can't give you a number, but the risk of breast cancer  when one twin gets breast cancer and the other does not) in a monozygotic twin  is higher than in the general population.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18972750 The incidence in a prospective study of monozygotic twins of patients was approximately constant at 1.3% per year (77 cases), again about 0.7% per breast. At ages older than a patient's age at diagnosis, her mother and sisters have an incidence of 0.3-0.4% per year.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11... In this paper, monozygomatic twins traded tissue for breast reconstruction !http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18827632 This study found support for a gene that may be associated with breast density,which in itself is thought to be a risk factor for breast cancer.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2014 01:44PM leaf wrote: Its natural for you to want anything questionable out. You want to reduce your risk as much as you can. But there are very good reasons why its not good to remove everything that is questionable. Its all 'risk vs benefit'. Most of these 'thingies' turn out benign. Even if they decide on a biopsy, overall, about 80% of biopsies are benign, and at age ~40 that 80% figure is probably even higher. Some removal can cause scar tissue. Scar tissue makes future imaging harder to read. More extensive surgery generally creates more scar tissue, so a fine needle biopsy would rarely cause scar tissue, core biopsies can sometimes cause scar tissue, whereas surgical removal will almost assuredly cause some scar tissue. Another thing is that for some types of conditions, it doesn't really reduce your risk by removing it, as non-intuitive as it might sound. For example, don't expect to get what I have, which is LCIS, which is unusual. But they don't try to get clean margins for LCIS or atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH). That's because LCIS and ALH are thought to usually give you a higher risk for breast cancer, but are usually incidental findings found on biopsy, are usually multifocal (meaning there are usually multiple spots of it) and bilateral (meaning in both breasts.) LCIS and ALH are relatively unusual, so I wouldn't expect these conditions. They usually don't biopsy things that are rated as BIRADS 3. These lesions have about a 3% chance of being breast cancer. BIRADS 4 lesions are considered for biopsy, and have something like a 3-95% chance of being malignant. Different radiologists can rate imaging differently, but, also, we don't have the resources to biopsy everything that is BIRADS 3,4, or 5. We aren't doctors, and we don't know anything about how to evaluate your imaging. You probably aren't BIRADS 5, because the doc said *if* biopsy is necessary. Your previous imaging showed BIRADS 4. I don't know if the subsequent imaging changed your BIRADS score. But there are risks and benefits to everything. Its good to listen to your doc and see what (s)he says. Hang in there.
Posts.Title: Waiting to have another mammo and US Ozzy74 barb1319

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2007 08:15AM leaf wrote: Good for you that you are getting this checked out. No, you are not a hypochondriac. Most lumps in women your age are benign fibroadenomas (Isn't that a big scary name? but its common and benign.) Young women are at low risk of breast cancer, but it is important to get this checked out. Lymph node swellings can be due to benign things like infection, or something they never discover. If you feel uncertain about how you are treated, then consider going to a breast surgeon. They are the breast specialists. This does NOT mean they are planning breast surgery on you. Breast surgeons are the breast specialists because they see and diagnose breast problems the most. They see the symptoms and results more than any other specialty. I know its tough going through this diagnosis process. Pursue this until you get a complete answer. Some women here think that every lump should be biopsied or aspirated to be sure. (Some lumps end up being cysts, which means something fluid filled.) Even cysts can feel like hard lumps even if they are deep. (Cysts are almost always benign.) Dr. Susan Love, a breast surgeon, believes that if you really feel that there is something wrong with your breast, insist on a biopsy, no matter what the doctor says. If you are wrong, you have peace of mind.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2010 03:42PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:55AM by leaf My first core biopsy went well.  The radiologist told me before the procedure to tell him if I was in pain, and he'd stop and give more anesthetic.  I did and he did. The wire insertion (bracketing) radiologist never asked if I was in pain.  He never checked if his lidocaine injection worked.  He went in and out the door at least a dozen times, and never announced who he was.  The room opened on to the waiting room.  Any family member of any patient could have walked in the door.  I work there.  I felt like I was 'on display'.  About 15 pairs of feet came in, none of them identified themselves.  I'm sure that if he would have asked if I was in pain that my pain score would have been lower. My next core biopsy, about a year later, was much rougher than the first core biopsy, even though the radiologist was much more open to the possibility of pain.  When they tried to inject the anesthetic, I pulled out of the mammo machine and had to be held in it for the rest of the procedure.  My body learned that this was a dangerous situation, like a 2 year old learns that it can be painful to put your hand on top of a hot burner on the stove. In my  2006 survey here about wire insertion,                                      Local Number of people    Injectable anesthesia before?    Pain score      % of total responders 19                                Yes                                           1-4                     50% 7                                  Yes                                            5-10                  18% 3                                   No                                           1-4                      8% 9                                   No                                           5-10                    24%

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2008 09:42AM - edited Jun 18, 2008 09:44AM by leaf It makes me SOOO angry when I find out people have pain during procedures. I have a friend, a surgical nurse, who said "No procedure should be a painful procedure." My first core biopsy was OK. They used plenty of local anesthetic. My wire insertion (mammo-guided) before excision was AWFUL. I felt I could not tell them how it hurt because if I did, I would have cried, and if I cried I would have moved. If I moved, it would wreck the entire procedure. I did a survey here, and wrote 2 letters to the doctor (I work at the hospital where I had it done.) The doc left a message on my answering machine that they would try to use anesthesia beforehand. Other women who wrote (about their bad experience) got no reply. It traumatized me so badly, that at my next core (a year later), I was jumping when they were trying to even inject the anesthetic. In fact, I pulled out of the entire mammo machine. The radiologist was not pleased. They had to hold me in the mammo (while I was silently crying of course.) I think *FOR ME** most of it was because I had been traumatized by my earlier experience. Women really do have a variety of experiences. Women can have one experience one time, and another experience the next. EACH EXPERIENCE IS VALID. I'm so sorry. You don't forget these experiences. Even if it was only you who had that experience, it would be valid. No procedure should be a painful one.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 07:46PM - edited Feb 10, 2009 07:50PM by leaf If they excised the area, then that's all they need to do for LCIS, ALH, or ADH.  It is sometimes called a lumpectomy (even if there isn't a lump). In these cases they are not trying to excise all of the LCIS/ALH/ADH, but to make sure there isn't any DCIS or invasive in the area. In the case of LCIS, they are not aiming to remove all of the LCIS because of several reasons: a) LCIS is usually not detectable except by looking at the tissue under the microscope.  The breast surgeon normally doesn't know where LCIS is growing when they are excising.  So they wouldn't know where to excise.  LCIS is also usually multifocal (which means there are usually several  different spots of LCIS in a breast) and is often bilateral (meaning you have spots of LCIS in both breasts.) To 'get rid of all the LCIS' for sure, they'd have to do bilateral mastectomies, and even then they can't get 100% of the breast cells in a mastectomy. b) Even if your case of LCIS is NOT bilateral or multifocal, that makes little difference clinically, because even if you have one spot of LCIS in one breast, LCIS puts both breasts at risk. In some small (but no one will commit to a number) of cases LCIS may be a nonobligate precursor for cancer.  (DCIS is thought to be a cancer precursor.) http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/new_research/111005.jsp For DCIS, they want you to have clean margins (i.e. no DCIS at the edges of the tissue they remove.)  If they don't have clean margins, then they normally go back and do more surgery until they do, or they recommend mastectomy. They don't normally do chemo for DCIS, though I think with some very aggressive DCIS they can. Hi,Desdemona.  In your reference, I don't see the words 'very small' in reference to LCIS.They do say the majority of women with LCIS won't get breast cancer.  That means it is <50%.  I guess its a judgement call if you call anything <50% 'very small'.    I have been quoted incidences of 30-40%, which is<50%. These numbers are supported by the writing on this site, though another figure is 21% over the next 15 years. www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/...  I have seen estimates for ALH and ADH that their risk may be about half that of LCIS. Here's more info about atypia and subsequent risk for breast cancer in YOUNG women. http://www.breastcancer.org/risk/new_research/20081215.jsp

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2009 11:43AM - edited Feb 11, 2009 11:47AM by leaf Yes, if you feel uncomfortable with anything, it is good to have a 2nd opinion. As far as the 'danger' of DCIS - yes, DCIS does need to be treated much more thoroughly than LCIS.  However, in the Li et al SEER study, (1988-2001) they found the LCIS patients had a very slightly higher incidence of invasive breast cancer than DCIS patients. Among DCIS patients, incidence rates of ipsilateral and contralateral invasive breast cancer were 5.4/1000 person-years and 4.5/1000 person-years, respectively; and among LCIS patients, incidence rates were 7.3/1000 person-years and 5.2/1000 person-years, respectively. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... From what I understand, pathologists can follow whatever classification they choose.  Different pathologists can use different terminology, classifications can change over time,etc.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 08:12AM - edited Feb 10, 2009 08:15AM by leaf I don't have DCIS, so I'm not an expert on that.  I DO have LCIS, ALH, and DH (ductal hyperplasia, not atypical).  Its the atypical in ADH or ALH that puts you at higher risk.I also have radial scar, etc. If you 'only' have ADH, then your usual option is close monitoring and nothing else. If you have DCIS, then they usually do (lumpectomy + radiation) or mastectomy.  Sometimes they follow this with tamoxifen.  Tamoxifen is contraindicated in pregnancy.  If you have invasive, then it depends on the characteristics ('personality' of your cancer), but for early stage breast cancer, they usually do (lumpectomy + radiation) or mastectomy, with or without chemo, with or without tamoxifen or other antihormonals. DCIS covers a wide range of 'personalties': from very mild to quite aggressive.  But DCIS alone is not invasive. Tamoxifen is normally taken x 5 years. You should not be pregnant while on tamoxifen.  I'm on tamoxifen (for LCIS.)  The usual  LCIS treatment options are: close monitoring, close monitoring + tamoxifen/antihormonals, or prophylactic bilateral mastectomies.  The latter is usually reserved for women with a horrible family history of breast/ovarian cancer. From what I've been reading, it sounds like mucous type benign lesions are at most low risk. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...  Its hard to put numbers on anything, and even if they did statistics can be really misleading.  For example, with my LCIS (which is considered more advanced than ADH or ALH), I have gotten numbers from various sources that my lifetime  risk of breast cancer is 10-80%.  That's a big range. My oncologist and genetics counselor gave me a lifetime risk of about 30-40% which is probably more accurate. Statistics programs can be really tricky. Statistically, they know fairly well in a population about how many women will get breast cancer.  For example, in a city the size of Florence, Italy, they were able to closely predict how many women in that town would get breast cancer.  However,  they are VERY POOR  at predicting WHICH PARTICULAR INDIVIDUALS  in the town would get breast cancer.  How bad?  If you predict with a coin toss, it should be 50% (which is something like the concordance value)(if the coin is fair.)  If you had a model that predicted correctly 100% of the time the  concordance value would be 100%.  The Gail model, or other models that try to improve on the Gail model including breast density, etc, are used, the concordance value is about 59%.  This is better than 50%, but not by much. If you only have ADH, then the numbers I have seen usually suggest people who only have ADH as a group have a much lower lifetime  risk for breast cancer- maybe about half of people with LCIS. (You can put your numbers into the Gail model.) www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/  But again, note that this is for the population AS A GROUP with your characteristics, not you individually.  But its probably the best we can do. Here's some info about breast cancer and pregnancy.  I know you don't have a personal history of breast cancer, but I can't find articles that specifically address your situation.  In any event, you would want a consult to weigh in on this anyway. From this site: http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fert_preg_adopt/bc_pregnancy/risks.jsp http://www.breastcancer.org/tips/fert_preg_adopt/bc_pregnancy/screening.jsp and from other sites: http://www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/artemis/200108/feature6.html http://www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/artemis/200601/16.html www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/ar...

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2013 11:13PM - edited Apr 27, 2013 11:15PM by leaf They know the statistics for GROUPS of breast cancer patients, as melissadallas and kayb quoted, but for the INDIVIDUAL PATIENT, that's a totally different story. nci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.full.pdf  estimates the accuracy of the Gail model (the most commonly used model) for an INDIVIDUAL patient as 'better than a coin toss, but not by much'.  (This may not apply if you have a deleterious BRCA mutation or radiation treatment for lymphoma.)  Even when they added factors such as breast density to the Gail model, they found the accuracty was around 60% accuracy (vs 50%-50% for a coin toss).  The modified Gail model is for GROUPS of fairly normal people - you can imagine the situation for the much smaller population of people with a somewhat higher risk such as people with ADH or ALH - the accuracy must be much closer to 50-50 than 60-40. (In other words, the maximum times they can predict an 'average' individual will or will not get breast cancer correctly is <60% versus 50% of the time for a random coin toss.) The point being is that though it would be very helpful to make your decision based on 'numbers' - e.g. 'What is my risk for getting breast cancer?', we really do not know that number for YOU.  We know the risk well for groups of fairly normal women (probably including women with ADH and ALH), but not individual women in those groups. Here's more info about a large study comparing tamoxifen and raloxifene for breast cancer prevention.  As others have said, its about a 50% reduction in risk. This information of course is for groups of women, not individual women. http://www.nsabp.pitt.edu/STAR/Index.asp

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 05:18AM - edited Dec 29, 2009 05:22AM by leaf BRCA genes can be passed along from either parent to children of either gender.  So a father can pass a BRCA gene mutation on to his son as well as his daughter. Breast cancer is much more uncommon in males than in females, of course. A BRCA mutation often carries a higher risk of ovarian cancer. The BRCA genes can also pass along a  lower tendency for other, non-gynecological cancers.  Most (not all) BRCA-related breast cancers occur before menopause. The person most qualified to evaluate your daughter about a possible hereditary breast cancer gene would be a genetics counselor, usually found at major institutions. Overall, only about 10-20% of breast cancers are thought to be due to a gene mutation, the most common being BRCA.  About 70% of breast cancers are thought to be from unknown/non-obvious risk factors (besides being a woman), at least in the United States.

I don't know if women with large breasts and deep tumors would have the same results as women with small breasts and surface tumors. Of course, I am not an expert.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 06:44PM leaf wrote: There are 2 kinds of stage 0s - DCIS and LCIS.  There are about 5x more women diagnosed with DCIS (and nothing worse) than LCIS (and nothing worse) (per the SEER survey).   I have LCIS and nothing worse. The treatments for LCIS and DCIS can be quite different.  Often they recommend excision for  classic LCIS - this is not to remove the LCIS, but to see if there is something worse in the area. For pleomorphic LCIS, they sometimes recommend more aggressive therapy.  One plausible option for classic LCIS (and nothing worse) patients is watchful waiting and nothing more.  For DCIS, they usually recommend more (minimum complete excision with clear margins - from what I understand).

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 05:16PM leaf wrote: The initial symptom of the *majority* of breast cancers is NOT pain. Most breast cancers are painless when diagnosed. However, this is not a hard and fast rule. Some women here have had breast cancers that are painful. Good for you for getting them checked out! While there are faster growing breast cancers, most breast cancers have been in the breast for 4-8 years before they are big enough to be detected by *any* means. There are some breast cancers that grow faster than this, though. I've had pain in my ribcage that the doc said was from irritation from the soft tissue next to the ribs. It went away on its own. (This was 20 years before I had any breast issues.) But, of course, point it out to the doc. Most women probably take 1-4 months to get through the entire diagnosis process if you get to the point of them wanting to do a biopsy. It took me 3 months. I sure wish it was faster! Let us know how it goes!

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2008 07:42PM leaf wrote: Both are important.  Different imaging techniques show different things.  The more normal imaging you have,  the larger your chances of having a benign lesion.  But having a normal ultrasound does not negate the presence of your lump.Ultrasound is best at telling if your lump is a cyst, which means a fluid filled sac.  Cysts are almost always benign. I haven't read your history - has the lump grown and shrunk with your menstrual period?  If it has shrunk, then its highly unlikely to be cancer - cancer by definition means 'uncontrolled growth'.  Many women here feel 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - meaning that the most definitive answer is to have a lump biopsied.  They will decide by your next appointment whether it is suspicious enough to be biopsied, or if they want to do another type of imaging. If you think that  something is really wrong, then no matter what the docs say, insist on a biopsy.  As Dr. Susan Love says in her book, if you are wrong, you will have peace of mind.  If you are right, then you could be saving your life.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 01:01PM - edited Mar 14, 2009 01:03PM by leaf Density, as applied to breasts, usually means how it looks in a mammogram.  This site is a good site for looking at many examples of dense breasts.  http://www.halls.md/breast/density.htm (His breast risk calculator may be WAAAY off for unusual conditions like LCIS.  He states that this breast calculator has NOT been compared to populations - so don't faint if you calculate your risk is unusually high.) A dense breast mammogram has more 'white' in it, so its harder to see anything against this white background.  I guess its like trying to see a snowman in a snowstorm.  A dense breast may have more lobules and ducts than a less dense breast.  More 'fatty' breasts are usually less dense.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 10:57AM leaf wrote: Yes, my wire insertion was before excision. I have previous several traumas (before the wire insertion), which made me more susceptible to my PTSD-like condition.  I was told before my procedure that 'You must promise with all your heart that you will not move a muscle during the procedure.'  Well, when the first needle went in, he did see my facial expression, and gave me a shot of local lidocaine, but that hurt as much as the wire and didn't do a thing.  People have told me, "Well, I would have told the doctor about the pain during the procedure."  That isn't helpful to me. My pain was at least a 8-9/10 pain score (I know it would have been worse if they ripped off my arm), and if I told him about the pain I would cry, and if I cried I would move, making the excision useless, so I was just following instructions.  You don't tell people who lost relatives in the Oaklahoma City bombing because they let go of their relative's hand that they 'should have held on longer'. That isn't helpful. A friend of a collegue had the same procedure about the same time, and she called it 'barbaric'.  I agree with that adjective.  I did a survey here, and, while many people had only mild discomfort, I don't care if this degree of distress happens 1 in 1 million times, or if I certifiably insane, or whatever.  No one should have to go through that experience. Another consequence- if a person has a bad experience with a procedure, people will stop getting screened, because they know if they 'find something', they are at risk for a repeat of this procedure.When I wrote my 2 letters to the radiologist, he replied that 'He'd have to inject some sodium bicarbonate each time.'  Whatever that means. I know he's under immense pressure to handle as many patients as possible.  But we also do not normally do surgery without anesthesia. I'm embarrassed I didn't go back and read your history that you *are* a member of the club.   You will be an excellent volunteer!

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 07:26AM leaf wrote: This is what the Mayo says about breast pain. www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea...  Breast pain is rarely a sign of breast cancer. As the Mayo says, if this lasts through one menstrual cycle (if you are menstruating), or if you're post menopausal, then its good to get it checked out. Usually breast cancer diagnosed before the age of 50 is more of a 'red flag' for single inheritable gene mutations.   But about 70% of the women who do end up getting breast cancer have no obvious risk factors (besides being a woman). Only about 10-15% of breast cancer cases are thought to be due to single inheritable deleterious genes. Two different breast cancers in the same family do not have to present in the same way.  Remember, about 1 in 8 women in the USA will get breast cancer sometime in their lifetime.   I am *not* saying that you don't have breast cancer.  I'm encouraging you to get it checked out.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 10:50AM - edited Aug 9, 2009 10:51AM by leaf I have had 2 stereotactics, both at about 11am, and I went to work at 22:00 that night  both times (I work the night shift as a pharmacist.)  For me, I didn't resume jogging for a few days to a week.  You can play it by ear.  For me, things that made my breasts jiggle hurt.  I had hematomas each time (which I knew about each time I before I left the facility.) I wore a sports bra 24-7 (except for showering) for several days.  For me, as with Juliecc, tiny ice packs were the best pain reliever.  I mainly used my pain pills to try to get to sleep (due to anxiety, not pain).   My breasts  eventually turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal colors, but after a few months they were fine.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 07:50AM leaf wrote: I think its because there is little in breast cancer that is 100%; meaning that no imaging or procedure is 100%. Breast cancer doesn't always follow the 'rules' we make for it.  It is routine at my breast place to get a followup ultrasound and/or mammogram 3-6 months after any biopsy, even if it is benign.  This also helps produce a new 'baseline', so they can compare future mammograms to post-surgery ones.  Open surgeries definitely cause scar tissue, and even sometimes core biopsies can cause scar tissue, which can make it harder to read future mammograms.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 12:25PM leaf wrote: They had me lie face down on a metal table, with 2 holes for your breasts.  They raise the table and the radiologist is underneath you. They gave me an injection of anesthetic into the breast, then inserted a needle.  Your breast is compressed in a mammogram-type machine.  My radiologist asked me several times if I was in pain, and if it hurt, he used more anesthetic.   Sometimes the machine made these popping noises.  When they advanced the needle, they told me to hold my breast for about 10 or 15 seconds or so.  The radiologist made it clear when I could breathe and when I should hold my breath.  I only had to hold my breath about 4 times.   The entire process, including dressing and undressing and getting prepared and putting on the bandage afterwards, took about 2-3 hours.  (I tend to bleed more, so they had to spend some time compressing my breast.)  I was not able to look at the machine underneath me. Stereotactic just means they use a computer to guide the needle so it will hit the area they want to reach.  They 'triangulate' (use coordinates) to find the area they want to biopsy.  (Its sort of like treasure hunting and using a compass to find the area they want to biopsy, except they don't use magnets.)  I think they normally use stereotactic mammogram-guided core biopsy when your lesion shows up best in a mammogram. For me, tiny ice packs were better than the pain pills they gave me.  I had it done in the morning, drove myself home, and went to work that evening (I work the graveyard shift.)

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2013 01:53PM leaf wrote: There are many causes of rib pain, and it is natural to go to the worst case scenario. But in this blurp from the NIH, they don't even mention cancer as a cause of rib pain. http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/003109.htm I've had rib pain decades before my breast condition  (no known trauma) , and the doctor recommended some Ibuprofen.  I'm not saying you have what I had, but ibuprofen didn't work for me.  But the rib pain gradually went away.  Its natural to be anxious before a biopsy.  Golly knows I went to the worst case scenario, and was asking if I'd be alive before the next tumor board.  I didn't get the big picture.  Of course, its possible for you to have metastatic breast cancer, but it sure doesn't happen frequently.  Yes, there was a meteor that caused damage in that Russian town last week, but how often does that happen?  We don't go around worrying about getting hit by a meteorite, or being run down by a car as we cross the street.  But its perfectly natural to go to the worst case scenario: we all want to be ready for whatever happens to us. Do tell the radiologist when you get your biopsy about your rib pain: that way they can try to give you reassurance.  Nothing in life is 100% certain.  But you are going to show up for your biopsy. That is a brave act. As they say, you are not required to be brave: it is in your best interests, however, to show up.

Women with fibrocystic breast disease have lumpy, painful breasts. Although once considered a disease, the condition is so common — especially in premenopausal women — that most experts now prefer the term "fibrocystic breast changes."" www.mayoclinic.com/health/fibr...

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2008 01:33PM - edited Jul 5, 2008 02:23PM by leaf MRIs are *not* Xrays.  What they do is put you in a *strong* magnet. This magnet is so strong, that 100 kg people have been dragged towards the magnet because they forgot to remove their belt buckle.  Except for the hazard of magnetic metals, MRIs are thought to be quite benign (except for the noise, or having to lie still or the feeling of being enclosed.) Well, as always, its a risk vs benefit situation if you're pregnant.  For me, the noise was like being right next to a jackhammer.  Some people also have problems with it being enclosed.  I didn't-they put a damp towel over my eyes.  You also have to lie still.  Any Xray is radiation.  Mammograms are Xrays of the breast, but the dose is very small for modern mammograms.  One radiologist said the dose of Xray you get from a mammogram is about that of going nude on a beach for 10 minutes or until caught, or being a passenger in a plane that flies over Denver, Colorado (about 1 mile up).  Chest Xrays have much more radiation than modern mammograms.
