Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 08:57AM - edited Jul 27, 2008 08:59AM by leaf E-cadherin is a protein that acts like glue, or maybe Velcro, making cells stick together. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadherin Classically, invasive ductal carcinoma is associated with being E-cadherin positive.  It is thought that this is why most ductal carcinomas are lumps. Classically, invasive lobular carcinomas are associated with being E-Caderin negative, so the cells don't stick together.  Lobular carcinoma is associated with forming in sheets, not lumps. The association of the tumor type with E-cadherin positive or negative is pretty strong.  Something like >90% of IDCs are positive and something like >90% of lLCs are negative.  (If I remember right, one article said they were more like 95 or 98% accurate.)

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 12:37PM - edited Jan 9, 2012 12:59PM by leaf Farmerlucydaisy wrote: My initial path from a ductal excision was -  one doc said LCIS/DCIS and the other said ADH and ALH, the specimen was then sent to Vanderbilt for a tie breaker and that pathologist said ADH/ALH. I'm thinking if there is a progression of the cells, I must be closer to the LCIS/DCIS than the "typical hyperplasia" end of things. Does that ring true for you or is there a flaw in my logic? I don't know about the 'progression' part, because we don't really know the natural history of ALH/LCIS.  That means we don't know the 'pathway' (if there is one) between ALH, LCIS, and invasive breast cancer.  We don't know if 'everyone' who has invasive breast cancer started with ALH and/or ADH.  This is controversial, as in all  things LCIS. This paper opines there is NOT a low grade pathway between LCIS/DCIS and invasive, but that is only one paper. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21935747 This is a hard subject to study, because we don't know who is out there walking around with ALH, ADH, LCIS and don't know it, because these are all usually incidental findings found on breast biopsy.    But with LCIS, the minority of women who do later go on to get breast cancer usually (not always) get breast cancer in areas that look NORMAL (by mammogram or ultrasound).  This is a very old paper (1993)  Among patients with LCIS, invasive carcinoma happens anywhere in the breast parenchyma.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/82...  In addition, LCIS is normally multifocal (meaning there are lots of spots of it in a breast) and usually bilateral (in both breasts.) (Classic) LCIS used to be routinely treated with bilateral mastectomy (before, say, the 1990s or so.)  When they found that early stage invasive breast cancer could (usually) be treated with lumpectomy and radiation, many surgeons thought that routine mastectomies for  LCIS was overkill (in the absence of a strong family history.) They think that LCIS can, in a small number of cases, directly become invasive.  As in all things LCIS, there is controversy. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... LCIS, ALH, and (I'm guessing ADH) are normally found as an incidental finding on a biopsy.  LCIS is often  (not always) found not at the lesion of concern (i.e. what prompted the biopsy), but adjacent to the lesion. You weren't diagnosed with this, but besides the classic LCIS (which I have), there is the much more unusual PLCIS (pleomorphic LCIS) which has some features of both LCIS and DCIS. PLCIS wasn't described until the late 1990s or so, so we don't know much about it.  Classic LCIS was first described in the early 1940s. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... The genetic couselor said 50% lifetime risk, since my mom was diagnosed at 27, died at 29, and her sister died at 47 (i.e. both premenopausal.) I am very glad you got a 2nd opinion at a prominent medical center (Vanderbilt).  I have heard it is usually simple to tell invasive bc from non-invasive bc, but it can be tricky to tell ADH from DCIS. I would say you definitely have a strong family history, and that your genetics counselor's estimation is on track.  (Your genetics counselor, at least if board certified, is certainly a better expert than I.)  In my own genetics counseling, I was not given an idea how little we know about risk assessment.  You have a strong family history.  I don't know if you have been tested for a BRCA mutation, but if you haven't then you could be at risk for one.  That strong family history risk 'trumps' any risk you might have from ALH/ADH, or if you had DCIS or LCIS.  (Some BRCA mutations confer up to a 84% lifetime risk of breast cancer up to age 70.)www.uspreventiveservicestaskfo... Also the genetics guys said the ALH would not show up on an MRI, but it should at the point it is LCIS. MRI shows a lot of 'junk' (stuff that looks suspicious but is NOT breast cancer, such as inflammation), and MRIs can see LCIS, but I doubt if it always does.  If you do have LCIS, though, that isn't all that important, because they treat ALH about the same was as LCIS.  I think your risk of getting breast cancer due to your strong family history is much more important. I'm not really sure I understand the LE risk with PBMx. In my case I don't think they would need to check the lymph nodes, but can they "happen" to damage them thus causing the LE?  I watched a mastectomy operation on utube and it looks like they are really close to the lymph nodes near the pectoral muscles. I've never watched a mastectomy operation.  I had bilateral carpal tunnel surgery, which can mess up the lymph vessels in the hands, as well as other medical issues I'd rather not go into.   I'm no expert on lymphedema.  This article says Published incidence rates for BCRL <breast cancer related lymphedema> vary substantially with a range of 2-65% based on surgical technique, axillary sampling method, radiation therapy fields treated, and the use of chemotherapy. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21945108 This abstract doesn't describe the breast surgery and breast cancer treatment well, but found significant problems in returning to recreational activities. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21735276 Binney4 is our resident expert on lymphedema  (I know there are others, but Binney has received awards for her work), and this is what she says about lymphedema risk on a prophylactic mastectomy.  It sounds like the risk is low but NOT zero.  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/64/topic/777425?page=1#post_2690657 I started out with an every 6-12 month check, but after 2 or 3 years, I'm now down to yearly mammograms and twice-a-year clinical exam.  I think that's because I'm now 6 years away from LCIS diagnosis, and if I had any missed invasive cancer at diagnosis, it would have shown up by now. (I.e. I have a VERY low risk now of having an invasive cancer that was not detected when I was diagnosed with LCIS.) Farmerlucydaisy: you are in a different category since you have a strong family history, and I think it certainly makes sense to strongly consider mastectomies when you have a strong family history. But only you can judge what your treatment choice or surveillance should be.  Some women with a known deleterious BRCA mutation choose watchful waiting, and that is a perfectly valid choice for them.  Others choose prophylactic mastectomies for a known  deleterious BRCA mutation, and that, too, is a perfectly valid choice.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2007 10:00PM leaf wrote: Lobulated in your path report describes the shape of the area of concern. Lobule: small segment or lobe, especially one of the smaller divisions making up a lobe. lob´ular. The liver has several lobes, and the alveoli in the lungs are described as lobes. The breast, too, has lobules, where the milk is made. They are like 2 or more rounded lumps that are attached to each other, usually at one side. I usually imagine the picture as an elongated shape, and they are attached at one elongated end. Liver lobules are less enlongated.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 08:11PM leaf wrote: I'm not a radiologist, but here's a photo of architectural distortion in a paper. www.ajronline.org/content/181/...  Apparently it can be quite subtle.  Its like seeing a pattern in the background.  This paper says its the 3rd most common sign in a nonpalpable breast cancer. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3046672/ This paper opines This may be because architectural distortion on mammography is most commonly due to benign conditions, causing the surgeon to excise with minimal margins.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1422421/ I know this is a small sample, but to me it sounds like in this group about 10% of mammograms with architectural distortion ended up being cancer. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...   I don't know how much variation is in those numbers, but those aren't horrible odds to me.  I know you're worried, as anyone would be.  Of course, I'm hoping it will be just a call back for you.  I have a friend who has at least 10 callbacks, and has never even had a breast biopsy, let alone any breast problems. Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2012 09:44AM - edited Oct 14, 2012 09:49AM by leaf I have classic LCIS, ALH, and ductal hyperplasia.  I took tamoxifen for 5 years.  I had some 'warm flashes' the first few months (but I was perimenopausal so I don't know if those would have happened anyways).  During  the 5 years on tamoxifen, I had endometrial polyps removed about every 18 months.  All were benign.  (I also had pre-tamoxifen endometrial polyps so its also difficult to tell if the endometrial polyps were from the tamoxifen.)   I did not have routine transvaginal ultrasounds, but only had transvaginal ultrasounds when I had irregular bleeding. I kind of 'landed' into tamoxifen because the only breast surgeon in my insurance said she did not want to do any surgery on me, I didn't want to pay the huge out-of-network fees, and I wanted to do something. If I had the choice to make again,  given the same circumstances, I'd still choose tamoxifen.  But everyone is different. As far as breast issues, I had 2 breast biopsies (2 different spots in the same breast biopsied a week apart in 2007) 6 months after starting tamoxifen.  Both were  nothing worse than what I had.  I've been followed by yearly mammograms and twice-a-year clinical exams, and I haven't had any breast issues since my 2 biopsies in 2007.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 08:45PM leaf wrote: Scientific literature knows there are probably as-yet undiscovered inherited breast cancer genes. This is from 2005 Between 9,000 and 18,000 new cases of breast cancer per year in the United States are associated with a genetically defined predisposition. Mutations in BRCA1 and 2 account for greater than 60% of inherited breast cancer. Mutations in additional undiscovered high and low penetrance genes may account for the other 40% of inherited breast cancer cases and possibly a subset of familial breast cancer cases that lacks an autosomal-dominant pattern of inheritance.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... (emphasis mine) BRCA 1 and 2 are autosomal dominant, higher penetrance genes.  (Penetrance means how many people have the gene mutation and the affected genotype. A high penetrance gene in breast cancer risk means many of the people with the deleterious gene mutation will eventually get breast cancer.)  You can have low penetrance genes, where most people with the deleterious gene will NOT get breast cancer.  You can have deleterious gene mutations on the X chromosome (such as in some types of hemophilia.)  There are different patterns of gene inheritance.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 04:27PM leaf wrote: It probably depends on the radioactive tracer and its chemical formulation. and the organ into which it is injected. The half life (time it takes for half of the isotope to decay), varies with each isotope, and the chemical formulation can affect how long it takes the tracer to get excreted. It sounds like technicium is often used.  If that is true for you, then this site says the half life of technicium is about 6 hours, so after 24 hours, the patient is almost radioactiviy-free - that would be regardless of how the body handles the tracer .http://www.southernhealth.org.au/nm_patient_information.htm The decay curves show more of the radioactivity is lost in the first half of this period than in the last half.  It would be good to check with your facility though, to see what they will be using for you and any precautions you may need to take.

Posts.Content: leaf wrote: This will probably not be very helpful for most people with an increased risk of breast cancer, but I was just reading the breast cancer prevention section in the recent Annals of Internal Medicine (a peer reviewed medical journal), and it mentioned this BRCAPRO model is more accurate than the Gail model www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ for women with a markedly positive family history. NOTE: This claim of being 'more accurate than the Gail model for women with a markedly positive family history' is NOT a  breathtaking feat.  In real life applications, the Gail model (in women who do NOT have a personal history of breast cancer) has a less-than-breathtaking concordance statistic of about 0.6. For those unfamiliar with the concordance statistic, it takes a random person from the group (in this case) who never had breast cancer, and compares the model prediction with a person who DID end up having breast cancer.   If the model worked as well as a coin toss, it would have a concordance statistic of 0.5.  If the model worked perfectly, it would have a concordance statistic of 1.  So, for the Gail model with a concordance value of  about 0.6, about 60% of the time, the person with breast cancer would get a higher score than the person without breast cancer.  However, about 40% of the time the woman withOUT breast cancer would have a higher score than the person who ended up having breast cancer. It may not be very useful for most patients due to several caveats (see below).  NOTE: I have NOT attempted to download the program. It is free, but it is 'not convenient'. a)  It requires registration with the website. It does provide spaces for institutional affiliation.  I don't know if they would allow downloads for patients, or those without an institutional affiliation.  It does have categories for 'student' and 'other'. b) It has software requirements. It was designed for persons running Windows 2000, NT, or XP.  There is a separate link for those who run Unix.  There is no Mac version, though they claim some users have used it on a Mac with PC emulation. astor.som.jhmi.edu/brcapro/  I have not downloaded it because a) I do not have a strong family history and b) I do not have a PC, nor do I intend to put PC emulation software on my computer. (I have a Mac.) In addition, there is a link to other conditions on this UT Southwestern website, but at least some of them seem to link to abstracts. www8.utsouthwestern.edu/utsw/c... More than 50% of all breast cancer occurs in women without known familial or reproductive risk factors. Classic LCIS.If knowledge can create problems, it is not through ignorance that we can solve them- Isaac Asimov Dx 12/8/2005, LCIS, ER+/PR- Surgery 1/24/2006 Lumpectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 7/15/2006 Tamoxifen pills (Nolvadex, Apo-Tamox, Tamofen, Tamone) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 10:09AM - edited Jul 16, 2008 10:10AM by leaf I don't know of an association between breast and cervical cancer. There is a strong connection between ovarian cancer (which some families are too embarrassed to call ovarian cancer.  Sometimes they call it 'stomach cancer' or something) and breast cancer.  There may be other, much weaker associations with other cancers, such as pancreatic. (?) Some women are understandably too frightened to get anything checked out.  The mother of one of my friends had a breast lump for years, and waited until it ulcerated to go to the doctor because she was too frightened. By then, of course, it was far advanced. Some women are just too frightened to get anything checked out. In my grandmother's day (1950s) breast cancer was not talked about.  That's because at that time, breast cancer *was* (nearly) an automatic death sentence.  It is *NOT* now.

Its perfectly fine to be concerned about how you will look cosmetically.  This is YOUR one and only body, and YOU will be living with the outcome.  It sounds like you'd be glad to get an answer from your surgeon. It sounds like its an important question to ask your surgeon.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2007 03:42PM - edited Nov 11, 2007 03:43PM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this. Anyone who was in your shoes would be frightened. I've never had a ductal excision, so I'm really guessing here. I know that ducts as they go back into the breast can be very convoluted, and look like a sagebrush, except the ducts almost never interconnect. Since the ducts are usually convoluted, but the incisions are straight, could part of the blood be from the incisions crossing more than one duct? I think it would be very prudent to call up your breast surgeon so they can share with you what they think is going on. I hemhorraged from my biopsy. They had to compress me for 2 hours to stop the bleeding. My breast was all purple and swollen. It was so swollen, they had to approach my 2nd biopsy (a week later) from the opposite side.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 10:03AM leaf wrote: I had a hard area - it was quite a distance away from the excision scar.   I had a dent, too, plus a hematoma: my breast turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal colors-purple, black, green, yellow.  I had all sorts of weird sensations-itching, zinging pain, numbness - these are probably from nerves being cut.  I started massaging the area after a month or two.  Different people have different amounts removed - I have a B cup and had maybe 2-4 tablespoonfulls of tissue removed.  By 6 months or a year, all I had was a faint pink scar, and the dent 'filled in'.  But, I had always had unequally sized breasts, and the surgery was on my larger breast. I had an appointment with the BS about 2 weeks after my excision, when she took out the stitches.    If you have one, you might want to ask about the bloody nipple discharge, and when its OK to squeeze the nipple and if you can massage it.  I never had blood coming out of my nipple, but my incision was halfway up my breast.  When I had another biopsy inches away from the incision a year later, it came back as scar tissue - they can go all over the breast to check for abnormal looking tissue.     If you get a red area that spreads, especially if you have a fever, then make sure you get it checked out to see if an infection might be going on. Of course you want to feel normal again.  It took me several months, but mine does look quite normal except for a faint pink scar.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 06:35PM - edited May 4, 2009 06:37PM by leaf Apparently, according to a person (not me) who got a PhD in pathology, they take the tissue cores  (I don't know if they select 'suspicious parts') and stuff them into a cube as tightly as they can.   So they can put multiple cores into one cube.  From this one cube, they make thin slices which they make into a slide. So you can have multiple cores on one slide. I had my mammos taped closed too, including when I took them to get 2nd opinions.  When I had spine issues, there was none of this 'hide the images from the patient' thing. My old mammos are now in my living room.  The docs don't need them anymore because they need to compare last year's, not the ones 4 years ago.

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2008 03:22AM - edited Aug 3, 2008 03:23AM by leaf Good for you for getting it looked at.  I don't want to scare you, but some 40 years ago, a woman I knew (then in her 20s) cut her finger with a knife while she was washing dishes.  By that night she saw red streaks going up her arm.  She waited another day or two.  It ended up that she lost all of her teeth from the infection!  (She was in her 50s when I knew her.) I work in a hospital, and can assure you that infections can very much happen right after surgery.  They monitor people's temperature for that reason.  Many times at night (I work the graveyard shift) they start people on antibiotics for temperature spikes.  Its good you got it evaluated. I'd tell your surgeon about it, unashamedly.  It should have been evaluated, at least.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 05:42PM leaf wrote: I agree with others-it depends on your personality, your situation, and your support system. I told co-workers about my situation because I work in a hospital, and every time I saw a person who had breast cancer in their diagnosis I burst out in tears.  So my eyes were swollen and red (I look awful when I cry and it lasts for hours), and I wanted them to know they hadn't done anything to make me upset.  I had LCIS on my core biopsy. I had my subsequent excision at the place I work, and the night before my excision, I had a co-worker tell me that the radiology clerk (friends with another co-worker) said "Good luck with your surgery, and I recommend bilateral mastectomies because a co-worker had LCIS and that's what she had." No, that's not what I needed to hear from a male stranger. A few years ago, someone posted here a massive HIPPA violation.  They were diagnosed with breast cancer quickly (within a week) and had bilateral mastectomies.  As you might imagine, this was quite a shock to the patient.  Don't ask me how this scenario happened, but the poster said her breast surgeon told her boss that she (the patient) was suicidal.  Even if she was suicidal, I don't think most breast surgeons are authorities on suicide.  Anyway, after she recovered from surgery, her boss would not let her return to work, and she lost her job. She was single (a ?geologist) and her own provider, so that meant she had no health insurance, and still had chemotherapy to go through.  I know this is illegal, but it probably does happen.  After my experiences, and seeing how co-workers  spread things around, I got an alias for my health information (of course with help from the HIPAA compliance officer).   Some people get a lot of support from other people, but I wanted control of my health information.  Once people know, they don't forget. We are all different, and our situations are different.  But you need to do what is best for you.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2017 11:16AM leaf wrote: I'm sorry you are going through this. Some fibroadenomas can grow. This is the largest fibroadenoma I have read about, and it happened in a 43 year old. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12751688 (If you're in the USA, 2800 grams is about 6 pounds, and you know the size of a 5 pound bag of sugar or flour.) These large fibroadenomas most commonly happen in younger women: sometimes they are called juvenile giant fibroadenomas. But obviously, they can occur in middle aged and older women too. This recent report is of an 84 year old with a breast fibroadenoma, and she did have a history of breast cancer. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27096476 But, as you were told, it is unusual for older women to get fibroadenomas. As far as why, there are lots of things we don't know, but since fibroadenomas are pretty common in younger women, it is thought one factor may be hormonal changes. Presumably you are past menopause, so, unless you are taking estrogen or progesterone, that wouldn't be a big factor for you. Some people just don't fit into strict categories. I have one condition (not breast related) where the doctor said it looked like the pathologist made up the diagnosis because it didn't fit cleanly into any category. There are lots of academic papers that are looking at different tissue factors that may affect breast tissue growth. There is a lot we don't know about breast cancer and why we get what we do. Since it is causing you anxiety, you may want to get a 2nd opinion, or at least talk to the doc who ordered your mammogram and sonogram. If you do have it removed, one down side is that removal will cause scarring, which will make future mammograms/imaging harder to interpret. But some fibroadenomas can 'hide' lesions beneath them. Best wishes, leaf

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 11:48PM - edited Oct 22, 2009 12:48AM by leaf I can't think of any time where 100% of the people who do/have the risk factor get the disease.  There may be some, but if so, its very, very uncommon. There are people who smoke that don't get lung cancer.  There are people who are exposed to the HIV virus but don't get HIV disease.   But there is certainly much more of an association between smoking and lung cancer. They know the carcinogens that are in smoke, and they know the presence of HIV virus in the bloodstream is highly associated with HIV disease. For example, as far as I know, in Japan, when women bound their breasts, the incidence of breast cancer wasn't higher than what it is now.  As far as I know, in Victorian England, when women wore corsets, the incidence of breast cancer wasn't higher than it is now.  The death rate was certainly higher, but I don't know of evidence of even an association between breast constriction and breast cancer.  Women who breastfeed (and get their breast chewed, etc. during breastfeeding) don't have a higher association with breast cancer - in fact breastfeeding is associated with a lower incidence of breast cancer.  When women want to stop breastfeeding, sometimes they bind their breasts. So manipulation/constriction of the breast is not associated with breast cancer, as far as I know. Bras don't constrict lymph flow of the breast in any significant way.   You might as well associate breast cancer with wearing something over one's torso. I don't think that cultures where women go topless have a lower incidence of breast cancer.   Many English speaking women  in English speaking countries circle F for their gender when required to do so.  That doesn't mean that  the act of circling F causes breast cancer.  Being a woman IS a strong risk factor for breast cancer. Association is not causation.  But you need to have an association to even propose a causation. Many women wear bras. I don't know of an association between bra-wearing and breast cancer. How would bras cause breast cancer?  They don't constrict lymph flow in the breast to any significant degree.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 11:03AM - edited Aug 26, 2008 11:06AM by leaf No, it doesn't sound horrible.   We all want to live in a world that makes sense.  We want to know the CAUSE of why we feel bad.  (At least I do.)  We all want to have something specific to fight back against.    Because of your family history, you are probably at higher risk for having breast cancer.  After this episode is over, you may want to consider seeing a board certified genetics counselor (usually found at major universities) to learn more about genetic testing.  They should *not* be pushing you one way or another about testing.  The major gene involved when there is family breast cancer is BRCA1 or BRCA2.  They cause about 10-20% of all breast cancers.  The American Cancer Society now says that BRCA women should be screened by MRI.  caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/c...   Hang in there.  Feel free to ask questions or vent. You may also want to check out the FORCE website.  This is for women who are at increased risk for hereditary breast cancer. www.facingourrisk.org/

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 04:57PM - edited Jan 8, 2012 05:07PM by leaf Hi there!  As I usually say about LCIS, there is little about LCIS that is NOT controversial, including the name.  That creates uncertainty, but that also means its hard to choose wrong (providing you are given choices.) I have classic LCIS, ALH, and DH (ductal hyperplasia, not atypical).  The LCIS + 'features of ALH' were found at my first biopsy after a routine mammogram showed 'suspicious calcifications'.  I was 51 at diagnosis, as you. A 2nd opinion upgraded the 'features of ALH' to 'ALH'.  The DH was found at a subsequent biopsy a year later. I have a 'weak' family history, with only 2nd degree female relatives who all had postmenopausal bc. My breast surgeon from the get-go refused to do any further surgery beyond the excision after the LCIS/ALH core biopsy.  There weren't any other breast surgeons in my network.  At the time, I was also having carpal tunnel issues and ended up having bilateral carpal tunnel surgery.  This might put me at higher risk of lymphedema if I had PBMX.  I now have other medical issues that make any decision even more complex if I go on to have something worse than what I have now. Some papers combine LCIS and ALH and put them both in the category of LN (lobular neoplasia).  LCIS is at one end of the spectrum of LN, and ALH is at the other.  They usually think that LCIS has about twice the risk as ALH.  I wanted to do something, so I went on tamoxifen.  I just completed my 5 years of tamoxifen.  I had 4 endometrial polyps (roughly every 1-2 years), one starting before I went on tamoxifen, all were benign.  According to the NCI site regarding LCIS and the choice of tamoxifen:  In women older than 50 years, this benefit was accompanied by an annual incidence of 1 to 2 per 1,000 women of endometrial cancer and thrombotic events. (Refer to the PDQ summary on Breast Cancer Prevention <www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pd... for more information.) Bilateral prophylactic mastectomy is sometimes considered an alternative approach for women at high risk for breast cancer. Many breast surgeons, however, now consider this to be an overly aggressive approach. Axillary lymph node dissection is not necessary in the management of LCIS. http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/pdq/treatment/breast/healthprofessional/page5 Obviously, there are many women here with LCIS (classic or pleomorphic), or ALH or ADH who do not agree with this notion and choose PBMX.  Not ALL of these women have a dreadful family history.   Yes, ALH puts both breasts at risk.  I assume you have had a surgical excision?  Some, but not all, docs recommend that in order to help reassure there isn't something worse there (i.e. LCIS, DCIS, or invasive.) www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... But 'high' is a relative term.  Some academic papers categorize LCIS and ALH as 'high risk' whereas others categorize LCIS as not high risk (at least LCIS/ALH without a strong family history, usually described as a first degree relative, especially if pre-menopausal.) Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) and atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH), together described as lobular neoplasia, are associated with substantially increased risk of subsequent breast cancer, with lifetime risk estimates ranging from 10% to 20%.45 This equates to a continuous risk of about 0.5% to 1.0% per year. The invasive cancers may be ipsilateral or contralateral, are usually invasive lobular cancers, and more than 50% of these diagnoses occur more than 15 years after the original diagnosis of LCIS. Similar findings have been reported by Fisher et al,46 describing a 12-year update of 180 women with LCIS who were treated with local excision alone and followed by the National Surgical Adjuvant Breast Project (NSABP), as well as Li et al, who described the risk of invasive breast cancer among 4,490 LCIS patients using Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) data between 1988 to 2001.47onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10... This '10-20% lifetime risk' is lower than my onc and genetics counselor stated. (Remember, I have a 'weak' family history.)  They stated a 30-40% lifetime chance.  However, I took 5 years of tamoxifen, which may cut that risk by about half. So family history may play a role in your decision.  Get your family information (if available), particularly first degree premenopausal breast cancer, ovarian cancer, or male breast cancer.  Here is more about BRCA screening. www.uspreventiveservicestaskfo... The 'science' of breast cancer prediction is in its infancy.  Seriously.  They do know fairly well how many women in an 'average' population will get breast cancer, but they barely have a clue which of those individuals will get breast cancer.  So they have only have very poor answers to the question 'What is my risk for breast cancer?'  If they have this little idea for an 'average' woman, you can imagine how well they know for a woman with ALH and/or LCIS. jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten... Do your research carefully, get all the consults you need, check in with both your head and heart.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 10:21PM leaf wrote: Agree in total with the above. Just also wanted to note that 80% of biopsies are benign. Most women here think that the Best Lump is the Lump in the Jar (ie to get them biopsied.) The only way someone can diagnose a person with breast cancer is to look at a piece of tissue under the microscope. So I would push for a biopsy. There are 3 major kinds of biopsies. One is a fine needle biopsy, which can be done in the office, one is a core biopsy that takes larger samples (they use plenty of anesthetic), and the last is an excisional biopsy that is a surgical procedure. Waiting is the tough part. Some women find distraction, meditatiion, etc, a help. Let us know how it goes for you, OK?

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2007 06:57PM - edited Dec 10, 2007 07:02PM by leaf Hi Peaches. I know you've really been through the works this year. These are the US Preventative Services Task Force Recommendations for family histories that warrant consideration of testing for BRCA1 and BRCA 2. (From Annals of Internal Medicine, 2005: 143: 355.) Ashkenazi Jewish Women: a. Any first degree relative with breast or ovarian cancer. b. Two second degree relatives on the same side of the family with breast or ovarian cancer. Non Ashkenazi Women: a. Two first degree relatives with breast cancer (including one diagnosed <=age 50) b. Three or more first or 2nd degree relatives with breast cancer. c. Both breast cancer and ovarian cancer among first and 2nd degree relatives. d. First degree relative with bilateral breast cancer. e. Two or more first or 2nd degree relatives with ovarian cancer. f. A male relative with breast cancer. An article opines that a recent meta-analysis showed women who test positive for the BRCA1 mutation have a 57% of developing breast cancer and a 40% risk of developing ovarian cancer before age 70. Those that test positive for BRCA2 have a 49% risk of developing breast cancer and an 18% risk of developing ovarian cancer. It says that clinically important BRCA mutations have been found in about 2% of Ashkenazi Jewish women, and are estimated to occur in about 1 in 300 to 500 women in the general non-Jewish US population. I have a weak family history with postmenopausal bc in grandmother on one side and aunt on the other side. The genetics counselor said my risk of having a BRCA mutation was probably about 2%, about the same as the average Ashkenazi Jewish woman. I think the reason I was referred was because on one side my grandmother (who had bc) had only sons, so it would be masked if there was bc in that generation. This article opines that *in general* women with no family history of bc or ovarian cancer should not be tested. It also points out that the onset of cancer in BRCA mutation carriers occurs at an earlier age than in the general population. I read on these boards one woman who had NO family history of breast cancer and DID test positive for a BRCA mutation. So it is possible to have a BRCA mutation with no family history. Its just very unlikely. Thinking of you.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 04:22PM leaf wrote: Benign means not cancerous. "benign (bēnīn´), adj a condition that, untreated or with symptomatic therapy, will not become life threatening. It is used particularly in relation to tumors, which may be benign or malignant. They do not invade surrounding tissues and do not metastasize to other parts of the body. The word is slightly imprecise, as some can, due to mass effect, cause life-threatening complications." medical-dictionary.thefreedict... One example of where a benign tumor might be life threatening is in the brain. There isn't much extra room in the skull. If something takes up space, it means something may be in danger of getting squished out. The only sizable hole in the skull is at the bottom, so you can have increased pressure on the brain. The brainstem lies there, which controls essential things like breathing. So 'benign' brain tumors can be deadly because of their location. Some breast conditions can be pretty ambiguous. I have LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ). Even though it has the word 'carcinoma' in the name, most, but not all, oncologists consider it a benign condition. But there is little about LCIS that is NOT controversial. Does that help?

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 08:32AM - edited Mar 2, 2012 08:46AM by leaf Of course you're frightened and worried.  Who wouldn't be?   Here's a case of a breast fibroadenoma that weighed about 5.5 pounds in a 43 year old of short stature. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12... Just think of having a 5 pound sack of flour in one breast. Just to play devil's advocate, surgical excision  can cause scarring which can make it more difficult to monitor your breasts in the future.  When I had my breast excision after a core biopsy that showed LCIS, I told my breast surgeon to go 'all over' my breast to make sure there wasn't anything worse in the vicinity.  (LCIS patients are more at risk for ILC, which is also know as 'the sneaky one' - in other words its hard to detect since is often doesn't form a lump.  I, with a weak family history, was given about a 30-40% lifetime risk of invasive breast cancer; but there is a LOT of uncertainty about this figure; my 2nd opinion said it was 10-60%, but probably closer to the 10% side  rather than the 60% side especially since I opted for tamoxifen.) I didn't realize until about 2 years later that the surgery left so much scar tissue that a 2nd NCI certified 2nd opinion said that in my case I should not have an MRI, not even a baseline one, because I had so much scar tissue.  I have 'dense, but not extremely dense' breasts per the radiologist.  I had a 2nd core biopsy 1 year after my excision that was inches away from  my surgical excision and it 'was consistent with scar tissue'.   I'm not saying you should or should not have a surgical excision; I'm just pointing out that there are consequences for each decision you make.  You will make the right decision for you; I just want you to be aware of potential consequences. P.S. You will probably have a LOT LESS scarring than I had on my surgical excision, because they will be able to feel your lump and locate it. In LCIS patients they are probably more on the look out for pulling of different areas, which may be an ILC, which is something they have to see and not feel, so they probably have to disturb more breast tissue. But you probably will have *some* scarring, to some degree, which could make it more difficult to see things in that area in the future.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 12:10AM - edited Dec 29, 2008 12:18AM by leaf Fibroadenomas are more common in the young, but they can be found at any age.  In this abstract from Nepal, about 50% of the fine needle biopsies done on women >30 years old were classified as fibroadenomas. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19079396 Apparently older women who do have fibroadenomas tend to have more complex fibroadenomas, and it is more common  for these women to have cancer near the fibroadenoma.  However, this was a rare incidence: in this study 40 cases out of 1715 patients. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11345838 In the big picture, 42 is considered young for breast cancer.  The average age to get breast cancer is in one's mid-60s. Besides female gender, age, BRCA positivity (a breast cancer gene - affects about 15% of people who get breast cancer), and therapeutic  chest radiation (such as treatment for Hodgkin's disease) are probably among the biggest known risk factors for breast cancer. (Screening chest Xrays are not one of these huge risk factors.  Of course, you want to avoid any unnecessary  chest radiation, particularly for girls.)

Of course, one can have bacterial breast infections too.   Some breast fungi can form lumps under the skin. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6505915 I don't know why some bacteria and fungi form lumps under the breast, and why others don't.  Most breast cancer is very slow growing - most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-8 years (not a typo) before they can be detected by *any* means including mammogram, palpation, etc.  Bacterial and fungal infections can occur much more rapidly, so that may be one reason why they might want to try anti-infective agents first.  Please make sure to finish the entire course of anti-infective unless your prescriber says otherwise - you don't want to develop resistant organisms.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 02:23PM - edited Sep 23, 2008 02:41PM by leaf Well, breast cancer doesn't read our textbooks.   I sure wish it did.  There are few things in breast cancer that are 100%. I have read figures like mammograms pick up about 70% of breast cancers.   You may not want to read the following (it is scientific):  ********  There are 2 words that might be helpful: sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity (in statistics) is (in this case) the number women who do have breast cancer  and their mammogram detects the cancer. If we just consider mammograms:  Specificity (in statistics) is (in this case) the number of women who do NOT have breast cancer and them mammogram does NOT detect the cancer (because there isn't any cancer to detect). If you have a 100% figure in both instances, then you have a perfect (or at least near-perfect) test in this regard. The people that DO have breast cancer and the mammogram (in this instance) says they are normal are 'false negatives.' The people that do NOT have breast cancer and the mammogram (in this instance) says they DO have breast cancer are 'false positives'. In reality, mammograms are rated on a scale called BIRADS.  A BIRADS score of 5 means that the mammogram is typical of cancer (in other words, about 95% of the women whose mammogram looks like this have cancer.)  A BIRADS of 4 means not typical of cancer, but has a reasonable chance of being cancer.   So in reality mammograms don't give you an 'absolute' yes or no answer.  Imaging is NOT perfect.  Different studies differ, but just to post the first ones I could find:  In this study, the sensitivity and specificity of mammograms varied between about 60-95%.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11002452 In this study on ultrasound, you can see the numbers of positive people under various conditions. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18...  ********  The more imaging  that is rated as 'negative' that you get, the higher your chances of having a benign condition.  While there are some women here who were diagnosed with breast cancer after having a negative mammogram, ultrasound, and MRI, that is unusual. There are 4 major ways that breast cancer is detected (before a biopsy): clinical exam (whether or not prompted by symptoms reported by the patient) mammogram ultrasound MRI There are women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer with 3 out of these 4 being negative (in other words, only 1 out of the 4 is positive), but that is  quite unusual.  The person who has the final say in diagnosing breast cancer is the pathologist.  (In other words, you can't be diagnosed with breast cancer before a pathologist says you have breast cancer.) Anyone in your shoes would be scared.  If you weren't scared or anxious or angry or disturbed at some level, then you would be in denial, or have some sort of mental illness, or something.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 11:31PM - edited Mar 5, 2013 11:32PM by leaf If it is not a cyst, it could be a fibroadenoma.  Fibroadenomas, in spite of the long complex name, are benign.  They are most common in younger women, but older women can have them too.  Some fibroadenomas can disentegrate over time (usually years).  If you have an fibroadenoma and you are a middle aged or older woman, then they may want to ultimately remove it, or freeze it, so that they would be able to feel other future potential lumps in that area. Fibroadenomas don't make it significantly more likely you will get breast cancer. You shouldn't have to ask for more tests.  Likely the surgeon will either do a fine needle biopsy right there in the office or order an MRI or order a core or excisional biopsy.  If the lump is readily accessible, and large enough, then its probable they will do a fine needle biopsy right then and there in the office.  I've never had one, but I've heard that generally they are painless. If the doctor doesn't order a biopsy or MRI, then you can insist on one.  Dr. Love in her breast book says that if you are convinced that something is wrong, then insist on a biopsy.

I actually got some at a hospital pharmacy that they used for packing frozen medications. I just got lucky, I don't know where else you can get them.) Wrap them in some sort of cloth so it doesn't freeze the skin. If she's having a wire insertion before the surgery, then women can have a variety of experiences. If she is concerned about pain, then make sure she has a conversation with the radiologist BEFORE (s)he starts the procedure, so your mom knows what to do during the procedure**if** she has any discomfort. If she's an active lady, then she may not feel like doing things like jogging for a while. Jiggling of the breasts can hurt. Her breast may be all sorts of strange colors, and be swollen. Mine was blue, purple, and eventually got to green and bronze. This eventually goes away. For me, it looked horrible, but for me it really didn't feel bad at all. If your mother is in the mood for talking, I think one of the most helpful things you can do is to listen, without judgement. I went to work 24 hours after getting out of the recovery room. That probably wasn't the wisest thing to do, and it would probably have gone better if I took another night off.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 09:58AM - edited Sep 16, 2012 10:08AM by leaf Remember, I'm not a pathologist or a physician.  It does NOT sound to me like you have any profilerative changes.  Ectasia means duct dilation.  The important issue is how the cells that line the duct or lobules look - whether or not they are small or if they look irregular, beat-up, large, etc.  Sclerosis means fibrosis - meaning an increase in connective tissue in the breast. There is a lot we don't understand about the development of breast cancer.  But breast fibrosis is common, and has not been linked to the development of breast cancer. breast-cancer.ca/miscellaneous... Different women have different breast textures; some women have lumpy breasts, some have smooth breasts.   These are all normal. If you have extremely lumpy breasts, then it can be harder to do a breast exam, but besides this, I don't think there's any big correlation between lumpy breasts and breast cancer.  I have never had a breast lump (except scar formation after breast surgery), but have LCIS. However, if you develop a breast lump, make sure to get it checked out, at least if it doesn't change after a menstrual cycle. Breast density is a risk factor for breast cancer, but breast density is *not* how your breasts feel when you have a breast exam.www.breastcancer.org/risk/fact... The inked margins mean the sample of tissue that they removed.  When they remove a piece of tissue, it is inked on each side with a different colored ink to designate the front, back, right side, left side, up or down direction.  They said the sample was rubbery.  Normal breasts come in a wide variety of textures and sizes.  If you have any breast *changes*, then get them checked out.

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2009 05:32PM leaf wrote: It depends on the doctor whether or not they are willing to give results over the phone.  Some do, and some don't.  Some patients want to know over the phone, and others don't. I would guess that 5 days would mean 5 business days.  Remember, they have to solidify the sample in wax or plastic or some other material, and let it dry.  Then they have to slice thin slices to make into slides.  Then the pathologist has to read them.  Then the results have to be typed up.  Sometimes one or more of the people involved are on vacation or there is a staffing shortage.  You don't want to rush the pathologist - you want an accurate report. Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 07:55AM leaf wrote: I agree with LISAMG, from the little I understand. Here's a blurb from Science daily about 3T  breast MRIs.http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2009/05/090505162448.htm T stands for Tesla, a measure of magnetic energy. Tesla was a  brilliant but strange scientist in the late 1800s who was into magnetism and electricity.  It is a measure of the strength of the magnetic field of MRIs.   Here is a brief description of how MRIs work people.ee.duke.edu/~jshorey/MR... The biggest and most important component in an MRI system is the magnet. The magnet in an MRI system is rated using a unit of measure known as a Tesla. Another unit of measure commonly used with magnets is the gauss (1 Tesla = 10,000 gauss). The magnets in use today in MRI are in the 0.5-Tesla to 3.0-Tesla range, or 5,000 to 30,000 gauss. Extremely powerful magnets -- up to 60 Tesla -- are used in research. Compared with the Earth's 0.5-gauss magnetic field, you can see how incredibly powerful these magnets are.  http://science.howstuffworks.com/question698.htm

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2016 10:50AM leaf wrote: I think its very important to understand not only when a doc gives you a certain risk, but how well they know it. In the case of breast cancer, its NOT MUCH. But the Gail model has some limitations. It has predictive value only for women over age 35 who have not previously been diagnosed with breast cancer,67 and it does not incorporate specific genetic risk factors. Although it is highly accurate at predicting the aggregate number of women within various age or other risk groups who will develop breast cancer within 5 years, its ability to predict which individual women will develop breast cancer is only slightly better than chance.60 It is, nonetheless, used to assist in determining whether individual women should engage in cancer prevention measures, because there are no better models that have been validated for individual risk prediction. (emphasis mine). http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK22312/ Even different breast cancer risk model differ. In this paper, of 3 breast cancer risk models, Our analyses found that of the 5,894 women in this study, 342 (5.8%) were eligible for MRI by at least one of the models. There were large differences in the number of eligible women by each model. Most notably, the Tyrer-Cuzick model identified 330 (5.6%) of the study population to be eligible, whereas the BRCAPRO and Claus models identified many fewer eligible women (25, 0.4% and 54, 0.9%, respectively; Fig. 1). Surprisingly, only 13 women (0.2%) were identified to be eligible by all 3 risk models. When the BRCAPRO model results were adjusted to approximate the additional risk of DCIS, we found that these results changed slightly (Fig. 2). This adjustment identified more than twice as many women (61 women, 1% of the study population). Yet, the overlap between the models changed very little with only 18 individuals (0.3%) identified by all 3 models. (emphasis mine) http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content/22/1/146.lo If they have this much trouble predicting the risk of women in the general population, just imagine the trouble they have in ONE woman who have some type/risk factor not included in the model. Even if you define 'high risk' as >X%, they sure don't know the value of X very much at all for any individual person. So if someone gives you figures about your risk of breast cancer, they sure don't know that number very well AT ALL.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2008 08:53AM - edited May 20, 2008 08:55AM by leaf I'm sure there are MANY causes of enlarged lymph nodes, but I think it is possible to have bc in nodes without a mass/lump. In Dr. Susan Love's book (p. 320) she describes 'The Unknown Primary'. This is a cancer that has spread to a lymph node in the armpit without an obvious primary tumor. In women, this type of tumor is almost always in the breast. She says this is a rare type of breast cancer, accounting for less than 5% of cases. She says the patient typically shows up with an enlarged lymph node, usually in the armpit. Its biopsied and we find breast cancer cells but there are no breast lumps. Usually the woman is first sent for a mammo and ultrasound. If that doesn't show anything, they try an MRI. In situations where no breast lesion can be found, she says the treatment can be more controversial. She says that contrary to what you might expect, survival rate in cancers that show up in the nodes but not in the breast is actually a bit better than for cancers that show up both as a breast lump and an enlarged node. In this age of antibiotic resistance, it is certainly possible to have an infection that doesn't respond to the antibiotic you are taking. Hang in there. The waiting is horrible.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2014 08:22AM - edited Apr 12, 2014 12:05PM by leaf How high is 'high risk'? Weight is not a factor in the modified Gail model. www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/  . Now, probably they didn't know about obesity as a risk factor when the Gail model was formulated. Breast cancer risk was 55% greater in obese women older than 60 compared to younger women. http://www.breastcancer.org/research-news/20111206 Now, in the general population, breast cancer is diagnosed in about 1 out of 8 women during their lifetime (about 12%).  Do all obese women get breast cancer?  No, of course not.  Roughly, roughly, even if you take this 13% and multiply it by 1.55 you get about 20%, or about 1 in 5.  This is an overestimate because about half of breast cancers occur in women younger than 60.  I don't know what the numbers are for women younger than 60, but it sounds like its not 55%. But, about 1/3 of the US population is considered obese. http://www.cdc.gov/obesity/data/adult.html Has the breast cancer incidence gone up? Breast cancer incidence rates in the U.S. began decreasing in the year 2000, after increasing for the previous two decades. They dropped by 7% from 2002 to 2003 alone.   http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/understand_bc... Now, of course, breast cancer incidence might increase in the obese population, and some other factor might decrease the incidence even more.  But you'd think if 1/3 of the population has a risk factor for something that was significantly high, then that might increase, not decrease, the breast cancer incidence. I'm not a statistician, and these numbers are quite rough anyways.  Maybe my logic and methods aren't very good.  But if you are in your 20s, then obesity alone may not be as big a risk factor as you think it is.  Its so easy to go to the 'worst case scenario', and its easy to be angry when you have all this uncertainty.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2014 10:43PM - edited Dec 23, 2014 10:50PM by leaf I have both LCIS and ALH, which was found on a core biopsy. (LCIS is normally regarded as higher risk than ALH, roughly almost twice the risk. Histologically, LCIS is a more 'extreme' case of ALH; some places group LCIS and ALH together and call the group 'lobular neoplasia'. This is partly because it is sometimes hard to draw the line between ALH and LCIS because its a continuum.) I had a subsequent excision of the area, which removed about 2 tablespoonfuls of tissue, and showed nothing worse than what I already have. I have a weak family history, with several aunts and a grandmother on the other side of the family having postmenopausal breast cancer. My breast surgeon refused to do any further breast surgery on me. I was given a lifetime risk of breast cancer of about 30-40%, though that is a very soft figure (in other words, they don't know that number well at all.) It took a few months for the swelling and bruising to go away. After about year 2, I have to really, really search to find the faint pink scar, which is less than 1 inch long. (I have a B cup.) I had every 3-6 month screenings for the first 2 years or so (because I had 2 additional breast biopsies, and at my place after a biopsy they do more imaging 3-6 months after each biopsy.) I haven't had any more breast biopsies or imaging call backs after year 2. After about year 3, I'm down to twice-a-year clinical exams and yearly mammograms. (That's what the NCCN recommends for LCIS.) I took 5 years of tamoxifen. Last year my oncologist said she doesn't want to see me anymore. Most LCIS is multifocal (meaning it occurs in multiple spots in one breast) and is often bilateral (meaning it occurs in both breasts.) They know this because before about 1990, they used to routinely treat LCIS with prophylactic bilateral mastectomies, and they could look at the mastectomy specimens. So, even though they removed my one spot of LCIS and a spot of ALH, it is highly likely that I have other spots of ALH and LCIS in my breasts. We don't know what causes ALH or LCIS, or how it confers increased breast cancer risk. But just because you had 3 spots of ALH does not necessarily mean you are at higher risk than a person who only had 1 known spot of ALH. I probably have 3 spots of ALH and/or LCIS, but the only way they could tell is if they biopsied all of both breasts, which essentially means a mastectomy. I took tamoxifen for 5 years. It really wasn't bad for me. I had benign endometrial polyps every 18 months while on tamoxifen, but I also had benign endometrial polyps before I took tamoxifen. At first I had some mild 'warm' flashes, but I was peri-menopausal anyway. Tamoxifen experiences differ; some have no adverse effects whatsoever, and some have horrible adverse effects. If you have little to no adverse effects on a medication, you are much less likely to post about them. So you can't take the number of posts on this board and say they represent the population of people who take tamoxifen. So, depending on your particular risk factors, you may not need to be screened with imaging every 6 months for the rest of your life. In the study cited by the moderators above, roughly 16% of the study group (both ALH and ADH) ended up getting invasive breast cancer. Yes, since this study covered women diagnosed from 1967-2001, the 16% is probably an slight underestimation of the risk, since it is likely that many of the women diagnosed in the latter portion of this period are still alive, so they didn't measure their lifetime risk. (The average age to diagnose LCIS is in one's 40s or 50s.) But still, it gives you an idea. Remember, the lifetime risk for 'average, run-of-the-mill' women in the USA to get breast cancer is about 13%. Remember, most women who get invasive breast cancer will not die of breast cancer, but will die of something else. Of course, no one wants to get breast cancer. But depending on your other risk factors (mainly family history of breast/ovarian cancer, particularly pre-menopausal in 1st degree or 2nd degree relatives), you may have a lower risk than you think.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 06:18PM - edited Nov 1, 2010 06:21PM by leaf From what I understand (and I am NOT an expert on this), atypia includes ADH (atypical ductal hyperplasia) and ALH (atypical lobular hyperplasia).  Some studies lump both of them together and call them atypia.  I don't have any ADH that I know of: just ALH, LCIS, and DH.  I'm sure Bessie would know more, but I'm pretty sure that  ADH,ALH and LCIS don't RELIABLY show up on MRI.  So I'm SUSPECTING that there's no way your surgeon could know that (s)he has taken out all of the ADH during biopsy (before its seen by the pathologist).  That is certainly the case with ALH and LCIS: both ALH and LCIS are often multifocal (occur in several different spots) and often bilateral (occurs in both breasts.)   They certainly don't have to take out all the ALH or all the LCIS: they'd have to do bilateral mastectomies to do that. I'm not certain what the situation is with ADH, but I'd be surprised if the 'standard of care' for ADH was they needed to remove it all.  But I may be wrong, and will be happy for someone else to correct me.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 01:47PM - edited Jun 6, 2008 01:49PM by leaf Sometimes docs can use lorazepam (Ativan) for nausea. Sometimes metoclopramide (Reglan) helps, or dronabinol (Marinol). Some like other antiemetics that are related to Compazine (for example perphenazine.) (Besides the family of Zofran (ondansetron), Anzemet (dolasetron), and Kytril (granisetron).) Its rather curious about Compazine - it was first developed in hopes of curing intestinal worms (in about the 1950s.) They tried it out on people in mental institutions (since they can be more prone to worms), and found it helped with psychoses. (So the general family is known as anti-psychotics.) Then they found in psychotic patients who also had nausea, it helped with their nausea. By the late 1990s, it was used almost exclusively for nausea and vomiting, and was only rarely used for other uses in the general hospital. Until they stopped making the injectable form, so they couldn't use it in the hospital after operations for several years. Now its back, but usually other drugs are used first in the general hospital. One drug can sometimes have many uses. Ativan can be used for sedation, anxiety, seizures, nausea, muscle spasms (not a complete list I'm sure.)

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 05:46PM leaf wrote: Yes, markers can move.  This woman had a 4cm movement in 10 months.  Since this is a case report, that would make me think that this is a large movement. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11...  It looks like a more common movement is about 4mm over several months. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19137493 That doesn't mean that's what your breast lumps and/or pain are due to breast clips. Breast pain is quite common.  They often can't find a cause. www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea... This one woman appeared to have an allergic reaction to her titanium clip, but she had an extensive history of allergies, and had atorpic dermatitis shortly after breast clip placement. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11... So while it is possible your pain is due to the breast clip,  I find no Pubmed references to any association between breast clips and breast pain.   Of course, your breast pain is distressing.  It must really affect your quality of life.  But I wouldn't jump to the assumption that your breast clip is definitely causing the pain.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2015 11:25AM leaf wrote: I have no doubt you had intense pain during your biopsy. When I had brackets placed before my excision, I had pain of at least 9/10, although this is quite uncommon per a survey I did here. No one should have to go through that kind of pain. I think it is much more likely that you are having pain from your biopsy than pain from your breast marker. Obviously, they use a needle that cuts breast tissue when you have a biopsy. It is common to have pain at the site of most surgeries. It is common to have 'electrical shocks' after a breast biopsy/surgery. I had a marker inserted after my core biopsy, and the marker was removed at my excision. I certainly had plenty of 'electrical' sensations after my excision, and there was no marker present. Most people think its because nerves in the breast can be cut when you have a biopsy or excision. The 'electrical' sensations gradually decreased over time (several months-years) for me. If a breast marker can help prevent putting in a bracket (like a pin so the surgeon can locate the 'area of concern'), personally, I'd rather have a breast marker put in. Before my excision, I had 2 brackets (pins) inserted. This was more painful than my previous core biopsy (partly I'm sure because of the attitude of the radiologist). You may want to talk with your radiologist whether they'd need to put brackets in if they end up needing to excise this area. Every person is different, so your situation, choices and preferences may be different than mine. I just want you to have less pain.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 09:04AM - edited Dec 13, 2011 09:36AM by leaf Yes, I have.  I was completely freaked out, because I had had a difficult wire incision (prior to an excision) the year before.  In addition, the ultrasound-guided biopsy was just under my nipple, which is the most sensitive part.  I was also freaked out because there was evidence of this weird thing some 1.5 years prior.  So I was afraid I had this for many years undiagnosed.  (Note that most people think that most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-10 years before they can be detected by ANY means.) My one ultrasound guided biopsy for me was way easier than my two stereotactic mammo-guided biopsies.  On all of my biopsies, I drove myself home, and went to sleep and went to work that night (because I had my appointments in the late morning, and I work the graveyard shift.)  At my place, it was darkened (so they could see the screen better), and they used warm ultrasound gel.  It was actually somewhat relaxing (at least before the needle insertion.) Personally, I found tiny ice packs and a jog bra were more effective for post-biopsy pain than pain meds.  But your experience may be different.  We are all different people. I wore a jog-bra for a few days. At the time, I was still jogging, and I avoided doing that for a week or so.  Your nurse or doc will give you specific instructions at your biopsy how long you need to keep your bandages on, and when to shower.  (They tend to vary from doc to doc.) Nevertheless, you will have your own experience  and your experience will be valid.  Your emotional history, and previous history with breast biopsies (if any) can really play a part in your experience.  (I had a perfectly tolerable stereotactic the first time, but my second time was much worse due to the intervening awful needle insertion.)  Most people have at least a tolerable time after biopsy.  (I have additional emotional issues.) What you might do, before they start the biopsy, is to tell them that you are concerned about possible pain, and that you want a lot of anesthetic.  Hopefully, they will take more concern in this area.  I know you are concerned about spreading by the biopsy.  This is understandable considering what your mom went through. The last time I looked (about a year or so ago), they thought that while in many cases, if a woman does have invasive breast cancer, these cells are often moved along the needle track line,  they think that most of the time that these cancer cells do NOT survive their new location. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21...  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19... This paper claims to have a 0.7% incidence of seeding. **IF** you end up having invasive results, then it may be good to a) at subsequent surgery have the needle track excised - at least if the surgery is close to the time of biopsy or - b) have radiation or mastectomy or other systemic or 'standard' therapy. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20...  If you do end up having cancer, it is a good question to ask your breast surgeon and oncologist. Now, in some unusual conditions, puzzlingly, it probably doesn't matter - such as in my relatively unusual case.  I was diagnosed with LCIS and nothing worse.  LCIS is normally multifocal (meaning it is normally found in several spots in the same breast) and often bilateral (occurring in both breasts).  But also, LCIS is not normally considered cancer (in spite of its name.)  LCIS usually 'just' puts you at higher risk for breast cancer. I also want to play 'devil's advocate' for a moment.  When I had my excision, I also wanted it ALL out!!! I'm not trying to tell you what you should do, or what decision you should make, but  do know that apparently my breast surgeon did go 'all over my breast', including inches away from the incision.  In subsequent biopsies, there was scar tissue.  I was told by one 2nd opinion that I was not a candidate for a breast MRI (to monitor for further breast screening) because I had too much scar tissue.  So there are consequences for every decision you make.  I just want you to know some of both the risks and benefits of your choices.  Its YOUR and YOUR SURGEON'S call, not my call.  Of course you are terrified.  Anyone would be terrified in your shoes.  We're here with you every step of the way!

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2015 04:24PM leaf wrote: HIgh risk for invasive cancer? High risk for death from breast cancer? I think that the words 'high risk' are in the eyes of the beholder. Even assuming that you can accurately evaluate your risk (which I don't think you can very well- at least for you as an individual), how high is high? I've quoted this paper many time before. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.... Its about the modified Gail model, which automatically excludes both you and me. Its meant to predict the average breast cancer risk of a group of women (without breast cancer) with certain risk factors. Unfortunately, its a really poor model for predicting the risk of any certain individual. I figure that if they know this little about predicting risk for an 'average' group of women without breast cancer, just think how well they know the risk of a person who has some risk factors? I know they know practically zip about LCIS, but I have seen or gotten lifetime risk predictions for breast cancer that range from 10% to 90% (the 90% in a non-peer reviewed calculator.) That's a pretty wide range. In ONE paper, in different places they described LCIS as a 'high risk' and a 'moderate risk' condition. I would imagine that having a mastectomy greatly reduces your risk, but there are always some breast cells left. Some doctors say things in notes in order to get insurance to pay for them. I have LCIS and sometimes my gyn described me as having breast cancer, even though almost no oncologists would (or should). (I was having a D+C for uterine polyps when I was taking tamoxifen.) Sometimes the people who are reviewing surgeries and treatments do not know all that much. I certainly remember an infectious disease specialist (MD of course), and he was challenged by the insurance company about an antibiotic treatment he recommended. The insurance company suggested a cheaper antibiotic. He pointed out that the antibiotic the insurance company was suggesting did not cover that particular bacteria! All this is very anxiety provoking, especially when you are newly diagnosed. But as you learn more, eventually most people come more to terms with their situation.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 04:16PM leaf wrote: Well, this isn't spiculated mass with calcifications, but in this ancient (1991) study Cancer was identified in 29 per cent of the biopsies done for calcifications, 20 per cent of those done for a mass with calcifications, 6 per cent of those done for an asymmetric distortion and 38 per cent of those done for an asymmetric distortion with calcifications. Forty-nine per cent of the mammographically suspicious calcifications were cancer, while 100 per cent of the indeterminate calcifications were benign. Forty-five per cent of the spiculated masses were cancerous, while only 3 per cent of the circumscribed masses were malignant.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1847244 Although microcalcifications are often associated with breast carcinoma, not all spiculated lesions with microcalcifications are malignant. Sclerosing adenosis occurs with punctate microcalcifications, but the lesion often has a radiolucent center, compared with the opaque center generally found in malignant spiculated lesions. Radial scar may occasionally occur with microcalcifications and usually has a radiolucent center, but the latter is not a reliable criterion for differentiation from carcinoma.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8356272 I know I'm getting ahead of the horse, but this study found Mammographic spiculation (the presence of either a spiculated mass or distortion) was associated with more prolonged breast-cancer-specific survival. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17056932 Hang in there!  We're all hoping the best for you!

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 05:27AM - edited Feb 13, 2011 05:31AM by leaf My single experience with a wire insertion was different, but my wire insertion was 5 years ago. Maybe things are different at your place.   I got the total of the equivalent of 3 seconds with an ice cube for anesthesia (a cold spray on my skin), then the wire was inserted.  When the doc saw my face, he injected the area with lidocaine, which hurt as much as the wire insertion.  He never checked if my pain was reduced, which I'm sure contributed to my pain score.  I always do much better if there is some 'human connection' with the person; they somehow acknowledge that I may have some discomfort. I did a survey here in 2006, and this is what people said: 38 people responded to my survey.  People were able to choose only one of the 4 following responses. 1) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)   19 people, 50% 2) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  7 people, 18% 3) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  3 people , 8% 4) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10.) 9 people, 24%. Before the procedure, I had to promise I 'would not move a muscle' during the procedure.  I couldn't tell the radiologist how I was feeling during the procedure because I was would cry, and if I cried I would have moved my breast. We all have different personalities and handle this differently.  For me, if I have to ever have another one, I will make some arrangements with the radiologist before the procedure, and bring something like a bell or a rattle to shake if I am in significant pain. Probably most women are able to tell the radiologist if they are in pain, but I was not.  (Plainly the majority of women in my poll had a pain score of <=4/10.) Of course I wish you a pain-free procedure.    (I have prior trauma issues, so I am probably NOT the norm.) Once a real anesthesiologist got involved, it was totally fine.  I had conscious sedation during the surgical excision.  I used tiny cold packs at home after the excision. I went to work 24 hours after my procedure.  I probably would have felt better if I was out an additional day, but it was 'do-able'.  (I don't usually have to lift anything more than 5 pounds at work.) As Bessie said, Hoping for nice clear definitive benign results this time!

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 05:21AM leaf wrote: To look at a breast tissue sample under the microscope, they have to slice it very thinly. In order to diagnose you with breast cancer, they normally have to look *microscopically* at a piece of tissue under the microscope.  (IBC (inflammatory breast cancer) is an exception -its a clinical diagnosis, but I think even with IBC they ordinarily try to look at a sample nevertheless.) I am not a pathologist, but I think it is usunual for surgeons to make *guesses* whether a sample looks like cancer or not *looking at the sample with the naked eye*.   This wikipedia article describes the process of preparation. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Histology After they slice it, the  pathologist has to look at it, and someone has to type up the results. For most people who have posted on this site, it ordinarily takes at least several days before they have the results available.  For one unfortunate woman, they sent the slides to another institution for a 2nd opinion (without telling the patient), and it took about a month.  I had a routine breast biopsy, and it took me 3 full days. Yes, it is possible to have cancer cells in a fibroadenoma, but in this one study in Tunisia, the incidence was quite low. The incidence of a carcinoma within adenofibromas is estimated at 0.1 to 0.3%  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18...  That means that about 1 to 3 people out of 1000 people had an adenocarcinoma in their fibroadenoma.  Another study reported 6 cases.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10...  I can assure you that if they write a report saying they found 6 cases of something, that means it is quite unusual. Best wishes for a Boringly Benign outcome!  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 10:49PM - edited Mar 21, 2008 10:52PM by leaf As AnneW said, High risk pre-cancerous, as far as I know, would usually include at least atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH), atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH), and lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), and I agree that removal of the area is often done just to make sure there isn't something worse in the area. I know high risk precancerous may scare the dickens out of you, but the risk is usually thought to be much LESS than the risk for BRCA women. I have LCIS and ALH, and they have estimated my lifetime risk as between 10 and 60%. My onc estimated my risk without tamoxifen as about 30%, or about 0.5-1%/year. There are studies that support the 0.5-1%/yr figure for LCIS. I think it is usually thought that the risk for ALH and ADH women (with nothing worse and a weak family history) is much less than LCIS, maybe half this or less. I have read papers that LCIS confers the biggest risk of breast cancer of any benign condition that you can see under the microscope, so your risk will almost assuredly be not more than that of LCIS (unless perhaps you have a bad family history of bc.) However, due to statistical stuff which is not easy to understand, these numbers (like 0.5% per year) are for the POPULATION that might be similar to yours, but is NOT valid for the individual. In other words, these risk numbers might be valid for a population that has your risk factors, but in the case of breast cancer, they are VERY POOR for estimating the risk that YOU as an individual will get cancer. In other words, they are NOT of very much value to make clinical decisions about YOU. Make sure you get a copy of your pathology report so you know what you are dealing with. Please feel free to ask questions.
