Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 02:40PM leaf wrote: Of course you are scared. Anyone in your shoes would be scared. Hormones can DEFINITELY change the size of some lumps, at least premenopausally. I've had 2 mammo- guided core biopsies, and 1 ultrasound guided core biopsies. I actually found the ultrasound guided ones were easier-it was faster and you could move around more. But they numbed me up well for both. The biggest problem I had with the mammo-guided ones-they put you face down on a table with your breasts hanging down and your head to your side - was hearing the directions of the radiologist to 'breathe' or 'don't breathe' because sometimes the machines made noises or slightly jerked, so it was hard for me to hear. If you have pain-complain. They should stop and give you more anesthetic. Get a sports bra-I found the front zip type very helpful, and wore them almost 24/7 for several days after biopsy (except showering). Tiny ice packs were also helpful for me. I know this is a very frightening time. I think everyone is frightened. But many women here think 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - that means getting biopsied- because that's the sure fire way of telling what is going on. Good for you for getting it checked out! Sending you cyber-hugs as you go through this.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2014 03:00PM - edited Mar 31, 2014 09:41AM by leaf Hi V8grrl: " Do you know.... Is Atypical lobular hyperplasia a higher risk also?....i was just told I have Focal atypical lobular hyperplasia, sclerosing adenosis and ductal calcifications. this came back after the stereo biopsy. I go to see a breast specialist next week. darn these boobs. Yes, atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) is higher risk too.  Most studies I've seen combine both ADH and ALH together in the same risk group.  Even though you see ADH and ALH described as 'high risk', IMHO, there is a BIG difference in people's definition of 'high risk'. Some particular BRCA mutations put women at an 80% lifetime chance of breast cancer.  Yes, I'd call that 'high risk'. Some papers also call ADH and ALH as 'high risk'.  This recent study (different studies differ) A total of 698 women with atypical hyperplasia were followed a mean of 12.5 years; 143 developed breast cancer..http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24480577 143/698 = ~21% over a mean of 12.5 years. (This 21% figure includes DCIS) Remember, the  lifetime overall average for breast cancer in the USA population of women is about 13%.  Most women are diagnosed in their 40s-60s. In another study  ,Estimated 10-year cancer risks were 17.3 % with ADH, 20.7 % with ALH, 23.7 % with LCIS, and 26.0 % with severe ADH   http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23117858 There is almost no information about the long term (>15 yr) risk of ALH or ADH.  In this study of LCIS (which generally is considered to be more at risk (not less risk) for breast cancer than ALH or ADH), was found to be at least 7% after 10 years. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=LCIS+Chu...   LCIS and DCIS are certainly considered to be closer to invasive cancer than ALH and ADH on a microscopic level. I guess this shows how little we know about probabilities. Your prescriber may give you different numbers; studies are different; women are in different situations, some women have different risk factors such as family history or history of chest radiation treatment (such as for lymphoma).

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2016 04:15PM leaf wrote: Yes, its so easy to go to the 'worst case scenario'. We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. Everyone's situation is different. If you have an extensive family history of breast/ovarian cancer, you may want to be evaluated for that. I know you don't want to go through this anxiety every year. But there are downsides to having bilateral mastectomies, besides the obvious. Some people do really fine after surgery, but some definitely do not. So it ranges from A-OK (except of course without breasts, at least initially, and drastically reduced sensation) to continual infection, continual ongoing pain, difficult reconstruction (f you want reconstruction), etc. I have classic LCIS (which is thought to confer a higher risk than any of your listed conditions), and my breast surgeon refused to do PBMs. Normally they reserve PBMs to persons who have an extensive family history. You may have problems finding a) a surgeon who would do this and b) get insurance coverage to do this, even if your heart is set on this. Many LCIS women on this website have had PBMs. Of course, you can ask your doctor whether there is anything you can do about your condition. I would be VERY surprised if (s)he recommends PBMs unless you have an extensive family history. But everyone's circumstances are different. There's no harm in asking your doc if there is anything you can do.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 01:33AM - edited Apr 23, 2009 01:35AM by leaf Its perfectly appropriate for you to feel anxious.  People are telling you to relax because they can't handle their anxiety.  If you were not anxious or concerned on some level, then I would be concerned there might be something wrong.  Some women here feel distraction helps.  Some of the things I've heard that helps for different people : Things they liked to do Things they hated to do Shopping, meditation, religion, washing the floor, volunteering, vigorous exercise, watching comedy movies, reading a book, knitting, going out to lunch with a friend, doing group activities, etc. Even though it might be distracting, I wouldn't recommend doing things that are self destructive. I know I was imagining the worst when I was going through waiting.  I didn't go this far, but some people are planning their funerals in detail.  We all want to be prepared no matter what is ahead.  It is not a sign of weakness of going to your GP and asking for a prescription of anti-anxiety meds, if that is something you feel you need. Hang in there!  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 03:01PM leaf wrote:  Well, I can't answer all your questions, but I can maybe give you some helpful information. They can see all sorts of stuff in mammograms.  But they can't really know what it is until they do a biopsy. Dr. Susan Love, in her book, describes it like this.  You have a close friend named Mary.  If you see a woman from the back, she may look like Mary - she may be the same height and weight, and wear clothes like Mary usually wears.  She may carry a purse like Mary does. She may have the same hair color and style.  But you won't know if its Mary for sure until she turns around and looks at you in the face. Densities just mean that its hard to see through them.  So if you have something going on in dense breasts, it can be hard to see - its like trying to see in a snowstorm. Here is a website that shows a bunch of different mammogram densities. http://www.halls.md/breast/density.htm From this article, it sounds like 'indeterminate nodules' means it looks somewhere inbetween frankly benign and frankly malignant. I don't know if they misspelled nodular as modular.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 12:38PM leaf wrote: Cheryl - I am a hospital pharmacist.  Your dose is low.  Our standard IV  dilaudid cartridge is 15 mg. This is what we give to many postsurgical patients.   We have many oncology patients using many of these dilaudid cartridges per day. To give you some idea, the most pain medication I have ever dispensed, and this was to a person who was not intubated (she was breathing on her own) was 1000mg dilaudid IV per hour,  plus 250-500mg midazolam (Versed) IV per hour. I don't know if they have different dilaudid formulations in Canada - we don't have any timed release dilaudid that I'm aware of in the USA.  I know different people can react very differently to pain meds.  But feeling weak is NOT a usual reaction to Dilaudid.   Maybe you could be having an electrolyte or food or some other problem?  Normally, dilaudid would just make you feel more sleepy, and may cause nausea/vomiting/constipation.  I'm sure that lack of food could make you feel weak. You are NOT getting a high dose of Dilaudid.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 03:10AM leaf wrote: I'm so sorry you are going through this.  The uncertainty is awful, isn't it? I'm sure different studies differ, but this study showed The aim of this study was to make a thorough inventory of the histologic features of epithelium and stroma within and adjacent to breast fibroadenomas in 396 cases. Breast fibroadenomas seemed to display a wide spectrum of proliferative and nonproliferative histologic changes. Hyperplasia (excluding mild hyperplasia) within the fibroadenoma was found in 32.3% of cases. Carcinoma in situ (CIS; 5 ductal, 3 lobular) was found in 8 fibroadenomas (2.0%) removed from 6 patients, the youngest of whom was 40 years of age. In 3 cases CIS was not confined to the fibroadenoma, but also involved the adjacent parenchyma. No invasive carcinoma was present within this series. Complex histologic features were seen in 40.4% of cases, mostly in relatively older patients (mean age, 35.4 years). Hyperplasia in adjacent tissue was found in 8.8% of cases, usually in older patients (mean age, 45.5 years). Known risk-elevating lesions in and around breast fibroadenomas occur frequently and mostly in patients older than 35 years. These findings may have consequences for the clinical management of a subgroup of patients with fibroadenoma. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11345838 I assume you don't have something very unusual going on, such as a history of radiation TREATMENT (such as for Hodgkin's disease) in the chest, or Cowden's syndrome which has an estimated incidence of 1:200,000 but is probably somewhat higher emedicine.medscape.com/article... or taking cyclosporin (usually used for organ transplants) . This is what the ACS says about fibroadenomas: "Fibroadenomas can be diagnosed by fine needle aspiration or core needle biopsy. Most fibroadenomas are simple fibroadenomas. They look the same all over (uniform) when seen under a microscope. They do not increase breast cancer risk. But some fibroadenomas contain other components (macrocysts, sclerosing adenosis, calcifications, or apocrine changes). Women with these complex fibroadenomas have a slightly increased risk of breast cancer (about 1½ to 2 times the risk of women with no breast changes).  <snip> Sometimes (especially in middle-aged or elderly women) these tumors stop growing or even shrink on their own, without any treatment. In this case, as long as the doctors are certain the masses are really fibroadenomas and not breast cancer, they may be left in place and watched to be sure they don't grow. This approach is useful for women with many fibroadenomas that are not growing. In such cases, removing them all might mean removing a lot of nearby normal breast tissue, causing scarring that would change the shape and texture of the breast. This could also make future physical exams and mammograms harder to interpret. It is important for women who have fibroadenomas that have not been removed to have breast exams regularly to make sure the mass is not growing. Sometimes one or more new fibroadenomas grow after one is removed. This means that another fibroadenoma has formed -- it does not mean that the old one has come back."http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_6X_Non_Cancerous_Breast_Conditions_59.asp  Even *IF* you have some of these higher risk lesions, when they say 'increases your breast cancer risk 1.5-2 times', they are NOT NOT NOT saying that risk is 13% x 1.5 or 2 = up to 25%.  The breast cancer risk of a woman with 1.5-2 times average risk is the risk of a woman WITHOUT any particular breast cancer risk factors, which is about  3-5%.  So the lifetime risk of a woman with a lifetime risk of 1.5-2 times is about up to 10%.  The average woman in the USA has a lifetime breast cancer risk of about 12-13%. Of course, you should and are getting your new symptom checked out. Anxiety is awful, isn't it?  Some people find distraction helps.  Some people get a prescription for anti-anxiety meds from their GP. Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 06:09PM - edited Mar 20, 2010 06:11PM by leaf People do vary a lot with their pain.  People also learn from their past experiences.  My first biopsy (stereotactic mammo guided) was OK; the doc used a lot of lidocaine.  But when I had a mammo-guided wire insertion prior to my breast excision (they use a thin wire with a hook on the end, so its analogous to a biopsy), I had a very difficult time.  I'm sure my pain score was at least a 8-9/10 for at least 1-2 hours. I'm sure it would have been worse if they ripped out my arm, so I'm not calling it a 10.  I'm sure part of the problem was because I was informed strictly to 'not move a muscle during the procedure', and I knew if I told them it hurt I would cry and if I cried I would move.  He saw my face, and injected lidocaine, but that hurt as much as the wire insertion, and didn't ease any pain.  This went on for another hour or so (held in a mammo machine.) I was traumatized.  A few months later I was diagnosed with a PTSD-like syndrome.  (I had previous traumas growing up, but I'm sure this breast experience didn't help.) My next biopsy was stereotactic mammo-guided again. I actually pulled out of the mammo when he tried to inject my breast with lidocaine in a tiny TB syringe.  I did that instinctively because last time I had been traumatized. He asked himself what to do.  They had to hold me into the machine as I silently cried. With my next biopsy (ultrasound) I warned the doc I wanted LOTS of lidocaine, and it wasn't painless, but it was better. I wrote 2 letters.  I did a survey here on needle insertion.  Some women  (about half) have a pain score <=5/10. Others do not. As bcincolorado says, some people do pass out.  One poster here had such a bad time with a breast biopsy/needle insertion that she didn't go for a mammo again for 10 years, because she was so afraid of the pain that would be involved if she needed another biopsy. (As you probably know, they commonly have a 6 month followup when you have a benign outcome, and even with the most lenient schedules, she would have a followup mammo much before 10 years.)  When she did go get another mammo in 10 years, she had invasive bc.   Everyone is an individual.  Everyone brings their own past experience with into the biopsy room.  As my recovery room RN friend said, "There should be no painful procedures."  I'm sorry this happened to you. Wishing you Boringly Benign.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2010 05:12AM - edited Jan 9, 2010 05:23AM by leaf Its so hard holding it together before you get diagnosed.  Overall, about 80% of biopsies in the US turn out to be benign.   That's a BIG number.  Most women who get breast cancer have no obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.)  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us on our path. MRI is quite sensitive, so they are probably doing one to help select where to biopsy.  There is no way they can be 100% sure what is going on at this point. Many women here find distraction helps, preferably healthier choices.  That includes exercise,  meditation, religion (if you are into those things), reading, retail therapy (if you can afford that), etc. While some women are able to be diagnosed in a week or two, for some people this process can take months. Here's a link to a diagram about diagnosis (with percentages) imaginis.com/breasthealth/diag... Almost all cysts are benign.  As you implied, its the non-cysts they are worried about.  Here's more on calcifcations. www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/4... The non-cysts could be a variety of benign things - the most common thing being a fibroadenoma, or fat necrosis.  The mean age to get breast cancer is in one's early 60s, but we have had a thread about a 10year old (this is VERY uncommon.)   Best wishes to you for boringly normal results! Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 05:39PM - edited Jan 11, 2009 05:45PM by leaf The digital and regular mammo proceedures aren't different.  The digital machine will probably be newer because it is a newer technology.  One brand  (in the US) of baby teething medication  (over-the-counter) is 'Orajel' or, better yet, the generic. (See what they have in the 'teething baby' section. Its probably benzocaine.)  Benzocaine, or any of the -caines itself shouldn't cause any problems with clouding  the Xrays. Make sure whatever you use does not contain with talc (magnesium), calcium, aluminum, or iron. These metals probably are not put into baby teething medication. It may be messy (bring wipes or towels) and your bra will get medication on it. Wipe it all off before you have your mammogram. Its easier if you wear a 2 piece outfit (like pants or skirt with top.  They let you wear your skirt or pants while getting the mammogram.)   And let the technician know you have breast pain.  If they have any sense, they will treat you as gently as possible. They can use mammograms to help diagnose BENIGN breast diseases, as well as breast cancer. If this was a routine,normal mammogram, it might take a month or so to get your results.  The technician will not be able to give you your results.  At my place, only the clinician (the doctor that ordered the mammogram) could give you your results.  I'm high risk, so often I can get a verbal from the radiologist (him/herself) or (radiologist via the technician) if everything looks OK.  So if you're lucky, you may get a reading on the spot, but sometimes you will have to wait and get the information from your clinician.  It may depend on the radiologist's workload that day. Waiting is awful!  Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 07:58PM - edited Jul 25, 2011 08:12PM by leaf Well, both thyroid disorders and breast cancer are relatively common disorders.  So it would not be uncommon to have both, just by chance (if they are independent diseases). This study found an association, but it may be just chance. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20...  This1997 paper opined the association has long been a matter of debate. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/92... This study speculated a possible hypothetical mechanism. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... Since they don't even know if the association is real, the association, if real, is quite weak. Breast cancer prediction models for individual patients are in their infancy.   When you look at breast cancer risk models, the most popular (for women withOUT a personal history of breast cancer, DCIS, or LCIS) is the Gail model. www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ However, you must look at the caveats about that model.  The Gail model specifically says it should NOT be used for medical decisions.(All other models I have seen, with the possible exception of BRCA  models - are just as rotten as the Gail model for prediction of breast cancer for an individual woman.) For example, this medical journal opines that, even for the 'average' women, the Gail model, and other models that include significant risk factors are, for any individual woman, "better than the toss of a coin, but not by much".  jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/re... That's because when they compared any randomly selected woman WITH breast cancer, and compared her score to any randomly selected woman WITHOUT breast cancer, roughly 55-60% of the time, the woman WITH breast cancer got a higher score than the woman WITHOUT breast cancer.  However, this means that about 40-45% of the time, the woman WITHOUT breast cancer got a higher score than the randomly selected woman WITH breast cancer.  This is even when they threw in known, established risk factors such as breast density. So, yes, there may be an association between thyroid disorders and breast cancer. I have both a thyroid disorder and LCIS, which is usually considered a risk factor for breast cancer. I certainly wouldn't worry that your thyroid disease means you are destined you will get breast cancer.  There are many risk factors for breast cancer that are a lot stronger than thyroid disease (in populations), yet they still are not powerful enough to separate out individual women who will get breast cancer from those that won't.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 03:10PM leaf wrote: I am not a physician or a pathologist.  But I may be able to give you an idea what they mean. In researching this, I gather that these two items are just markers that help the pathologist identify that the cells are breast cells, and, perhaps what type they may be.  Sometimes when they see cancerous cells, it can be hard to tell what type of cells they really are.  Cancer cells are named from their organ of origin.  So when breast cancer cells travel, say, to lymph nodes, they still stay breast cancer cells, not lymph node cancer cells.  If you have colon cancer and it travels to the brain, the cells in the brain are still colon cancer cells, not breast cancer cells.  Cytokeratins are a type of protein found in some cells. They are found in epithelial cells.  Epithelial cells are the cells that line the cavities and surfaces of many organs. Skin cells are epithelial cells. Epithelial cells rest on a basement membrane. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epithelial_tissue It sounds like cytokeratins are now called keratins. They provide structure to the inside of some cells.  These cytokeratins tend not to change when a cell becomes cancerous.   So they help the pathologist decide what type of cell may be cancerous. Apparently, in one report, cytokeratin 5/6 (which apparently is the same as cytokeratin CK5/6) can distinguish between usual ductal hyperplasia (UDH, which is NOT atypical) from atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH)/ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), or lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).  The latter 3 conditions (ADH, DCIS, and LCIS) puts one at increased risk of invasive breast cancer, while UDH does NOT put one at higher risk (or by any significant amount.)  ADH, DCIS, and LCIS in this study showed no or low staining with anti-CK 5/6. www.springerlink.com/content/0...  Nothing is absolute though - these stains just help make it more probable the cell is one certain type and not another. I'm not a pathologist or cell biologist, so I'm not sure exactly what all they are testing for or against, but it certainly just seems to be a confirmation that they are breast cells and not another type, or a confirmation of the diagnosis, as CandDsMomsaid.  It will be good to ask your mom's onc when she sees him next. Please know we are thinking of you and your Mom.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 04:55PM - edited Apr 17, 2008 05:00PM by leaf Oh my, IL. I am so sorry you and your mom are going through this. Of course you are scared-anyone would be scared in your shoes, especially with what you have gone through. I don't know hardly anything about Paget's disease, so I don't know about prognosis. I do know that many doctors are wrong about predicting how much time a person has left. I do know that many women with stage IV breast cancer can live many productive years. I am trying to help a friend who has a cancer with a very grim prognosis (Its not breast cancer or ovarian cancer.) Less than 5% of patients live 1 year after diagnosis. There was one website that I think was helpful in dealing with my friend. cancerguide.org/median_not_msg... She knows it will take a miracle for her to survive. She doesn't want to talk about her emotions, but I am hoping eventually to get her to the place where she feels safe enough to accept my care and concern about her. When she was first diagnosed I was going to make her tell me how 'angry, or afraid, or whatever' she was feeling. I didn't know it was OK for people to be in denial. I think most people want people to listen to them. For me, I think its been helpful for my friend to let her know that her treatment decisions are HER choice, because it is HER life. Even if I disagree with the course she is taking - because I am not in her shoes. If she asks for information or help, I try to give her that. There are forums below for metastatic disease, for African Americans with breast cancer, and another for caregivers, below. You may be interested in checking them out. I'm sure others with more experience, support, and information than I will be along shortly. You and your mother are in my thoughts.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 03:36PM leaf wrote: Of course you don't want to loose your mum. You are right that it is ultimately her decision. I know everyone is different, and you know your mum better than anybody here. But I will share what has worked better for me. But it probably won't work for anyone. I have a friend that was diagnosed with a very serious cancer ( its not breast cancer or ovarian cancer) Feb 1. She knows what the statistics are - it will, indeed, 'take a miracle' for her to survive this. At first, she was wavering back and forth if she wanted to be treated at all. Some studies showed even if rads and chemo for this cancer don't help with survival, they may help with quality of life. She's having lots of pain, etc. She has simply refused to discuss how she is feeling. At first she shut up even more. But I have spent hours with her, just listening non-judgmentally to her, whatever she wants to talk about. Sometimes she's silent. Sometimes she has been pretty critical of me, like saying I wear watches that are too big, or that I'm going to grow mushrooms under my hats (I often walk around with wet hair.) But now I'm just glad when she can express anger at me or anyone. I have not had a pain score of above 5 continuously for over 2.5 months, nor am I in her shoes dealing with an almost certainly terminal illness. Very gradually, she's gotten closer to telling me about how she feels. I brought up the 'Be Positive....(shuuut up!) thread in the Just Diagnosed forum. She agreed said she just ignores those people. But that's closer to expressing how she feels than what I've gotten before. I know she has issues about 'feeling trapped'. I'm hoping at some time in the future, that she will feel safe enough to talk more about her feelings, so at least at some point, I'm hoping she will be able to listen to me telling her how much her friendship has meant to me. We might never get there. And maybe its bad for me to try to make her go in that direction. Now maybe pushing works for some people, and 'not pushing' works for others. And probably something entirely different works for still others. But maybe its something to think about.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2007 01:28PM - edited Oct 3, 2007 01:41PM by leaf I am no pathologist, nor am I a physician. I think it would be good to ask the doctor what (s)he means. I can find very little information about the phrase 'fibrotic infiltration'. But I thought that fibrosis, with no other diagnoses, was a benign condition. Fibrosis can happen in many tissues in the body. It can be a reaction of the body against something. I do not know if fibrocystic conditions are the similar to fibrotic infiltration, but I would suspect they are similar. I would guess that fibrotic infiltration would just mean there is a lot of fibrosis going on. While we don't know what causes fibrocystic conditions in the breast, they are very common, and is definitely not cancer. The most common signs of fibrocystic breasts include lumpiness, tenderness, cysts (packets of fluid), areas of thickening, fibrosis (scar-like connective tissue), and breast pain. www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/... Here is a website that describes many conditions of the breast, but does not include 'fibrotic infiltration'. http://www.pathologyoutlines.com/breast.html If that doctor has made you frightened you have cancer without explaining anything to you, then I think (s)he has failed with communication. From what I understand, it is good to get nipple changes checked out, as it sounds like you were doing. But the doc needs to explain to you what he means. From what I understand, fibrosis does *not* mean cancer. If you haven't done this already, you may want to consider seeing a breast specialist.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 09:38AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:14AM by leaf I had absolutely no problem with the actual excision, but I did have problems with the wire insertion.  This was in early 2006, so I am hoping that radiologists are doing a better job now. At that time (2006) I did a survey about mammogram-guided wire insertion here.  This is what I found. 38 people responded to my survey.  People were able to choose only of the 4 following responses. 1) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)   19 people, 50% 2) I had injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  7 people, 18% 3) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was tolerable (<=4/10 on a scale of 1-10)  3 people , 8% 4) I did NOT have injectable anesthesia before wire insertion and my pain was NOT tolerable (>4/10 on a scale of 1-10.) 9 people, 24%. So we are all different and come to this with a different personality and history.   At my place, IV anesthesia during the wire insertion was out of the realm of possibility because an RN was not in attendence.  The injectable anesthesia (which I got after the first wire insertion) was an injection of a local anesthetic (lidocaine) into the breast. We all have our own, unique experience, which is valid for each of us. Of course, we all hope you have a painless proceedure, and as good an outcome as possible.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 03:16PM - edited Jul 16, 2008 03:20PM by leaf Taking tamoxifen (whether or not you are premenopausal) or Evista (if you were postmenopausal) is an option, not a requirement, for ADH and ALH.   There are risks as well as benefits with tamoxifen and Evista.  It is a choice only you can make.  For example, some women are going to be more concerned about breast cancer than they are about stroke or uterine cancer, and for another woman, they may be more concerned about stroke and/or uterine cancer than breast cancer.   There is no right choice for everyone.  That's why there are choices.  These are the screening guidelines for BRCA, which is the main gene mutation associated with breast cancer.  Remember, only about 5-15% of all breast cancer is thought to be due to a single genetic mutation. Basically, these are the general recommendations by the US Preventative Task force for genetic screening.  It does depend on your actual family tree: for example if there are no females in one or more generations, then there may be no info about some patterns of inheritance:  Both maternal and paternal family  histories are important. For non–Ashkenazi Jewish women,  these patterns include 2 first-degree relatives with breast  cancer, 1 of whom received the diagnosis at age 50 years or  younger; a combination of 3 or more first- or second-  degree relatives with breast cancer regardless of age at di-  agnosis; a combination of both breast and ovarian cancer  among first- and second- degree relatives; a first-degree rel-  ative with bilateral breast cancer; a combination of 2 or  more first- or second-degree relatives with ovarian cancer  regardless of age at diagnosis; a first- or second-degree rel-  ative with both breast and ovarian cancer at any age; and a  history of breast cancer in a male relative.    For women of Ashkenazi Jewish heritage, an in-  creased-risk family history includes any first-degree relative  (or 2 second-degree relatives on the same side of the fam-  ily) with breast or ovarian cancer.  http://www.ahrq.gov/clinic/uspstf05/brcagen/brcagenrs.pdf   (A first degree relative would be a daughter, mother, or sister.  A second degree relative would include a grandmother or aunt.)

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2013 05:57AM leaf wrote: I'm so sorry you are going through this.  I know you are scared.  Anyone would be scared with all the unknowns. This paper looks at the time between diagnosis and the start of treatment in young women.  Note you have NOT been diagosed yet.  It says that there was a worse outcome in patients that had a delay over six weeks. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23...  Your clock  to start the '6 weeks' has not started clicking yet because you haven't been diagnosed yet. There was a reference in another paper : Love and colleagues evaluated the relationship among age, delay, and outcome in 550 premenopausal women participating in adjuvant hormonal therapy in Vietnam and China. They found that women with a >6-month delay in diagnosis had larger tumors clinically and pathologically (p = .0006 and p = .004, respectively), more frequent axillary node involvement (p = .008), and shorter, but not statistically different, disease-free and overall survival intervals from the time of diagnosis (p = .09 and .35, respectively).  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/artic...  This was a 6 month delay, again *from the time of diagnosis*.  Note even with the 6 month delay, there was no significant disease-free and overall survival difference. Of course you are crying and can't sleep.  Who wouldn't?  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2013 09:57PM leaf wrote: I have classic LCIS, ALH, and a weak family history. (Paternal grandmother, 2 maternal aunts (all post-menopausal), 2 maternal cousins, one pre- and one post-menopausal.)  I have gotten estimates of my lifetime chance of bc as anywhere between 10 and 40%.  I think in the long run, they really, really don't know how to estimate one's future risk of bc. nci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.full.pdf Since my breast surgeon refused to do PBMs on me (Her first words to me were 'If you want PBMs, I will fall over in a chair')and I had no other breast surgeons that took my insurance, I chose tamoxifen and took it for 5 years.  I had benign endometrial polyps every 1.5 years, but I also had endometrial polyps (all benign) before starting tamoxifen.  It caused some warm flashes at first and these calmed down.    I had 2 more breast biopsies a year after my breast excision for LCIS, but they showed nothing worse than what I had already.  Since then, I have only had annual mammograms and twice-a-year clinical breast exams.   No breast issues since 2007 when I had my 2 benign breast biopsies. Everyone is different and screening is controversial (at least for LCIS).  Many (not all) people estimate that LCIS confers about twice the lifetime risk as ADH, it is certainly possible  (not certain) that after a period of time your screening intensity will decrease.  LCIS is a different animal than DCIS. No matter what you choose, you will have friends here that support your choice.

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 06:52AM leaf wrote: The needle for a fine needle biopsy is very fine. I have not had one, but I don't recall complaints from women about the pain. If needles upset you, make sure you tell your doc beforehand. You won't have to look, I'm sure. If you are having apprehension about pain, then I think its best to have a conversation with the radiologist before the procedure starts. Ask him or her what you should do if you have pain, so you know what to do, and (s)he will be alert for that. On some procedures (like stereotactic core biopsies), they don't want you to move. So, for one procedure (this is NOT a fine needle or core biopsy), I wish I would have set up some nonverbal signal to show if I was in pain, even if it was ringing a bell or something. One woman here posted that she thought all biopsies should come with an offer of a sedative. I agree with her. My core biopsies took like 1-2 hours, but a lot of that time was in setting up the mammo machine (I had stereotactic core biopsies). For my core biopsies, you had to be still maybe 30 min to 1 hr. They injected so much lidocaine, I didn't even *feel* the post-procedure mammograms. My ultrasound biopsy was much shorter. It took maybe 15 minutes. A lot of the time involved is in the set up, and afterwards, they want to make sure any possible bleeding has stopped. In all cases, I went to work about 8 hours later. (I work the graveyard shift.) Please know we are thinking of you, and wishing you a normal, healthy outcome. If you have a core biopsy, then I think that a tight fitting bra (like a zip front sports bra) is ideal.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 11:04AM - edited Jul 14, 2009 11:11AM by leaf No, I don't think your breast has to heal from a biopsy in order to do an excision/biopsy. If a biopsy is positive, they may have to go in again.  It depends on what they find, and what is in the cut edges of the sample they remove. For example, if they found invasive bc or DCIS, and they found invasive or DCIS at the cut edges (called 'at the margins'), then they normally want to go back in and get clean margins.  However, some women, especially those with more extensive invasive disease, get chemotherapy before surgery.  So their surgery can be many months after their biopsy. The chemotherapy can shrink the tumor, and they can preserve more of the breast. If you have LCIS or atypia and nothing worse (an unusual case, to be sure) after excisional/lumpectomy biopsy, they normally don't go in again.  That's because the purpose of the excision (in the case of LCIS and nothing worse) is to make sure there isn't something worse in the area, not to remove the LCIS/atypia.  The reason for this is that you can have multiple lesions of these in one's breast, and they usually can't detect where it is except by looking at a sample in the microscope. They would not know what areas of the breast to remove.  Also, it doesn't matter much because, at least in the case of LCIS and ALH, those conditions put BOTH breasts, even the normal-appearing tissues, at increased risk. If they get clean margins, then they normally don't have to go in again.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 11:22AM - edited Mar 25, 2014 11:33AM by leaf I don't have ADH, but I have both ALH and LCIS, plus ductal hyperplasia (not atypical ductal hyperplasi; its the 'atypical' adjective that puts you at measurably higher risk).  The NCCN guidelines do *not* recommend more than annual mammograms and clinical exams every 6-12 months for LCIS women. http://www.nccn.org/patients/guidelines/breast/ind...   (pg. 60).  Since LCIS women are usually considered to be more at risk (roughly twice the risk?) for bc than ADH women, and LCIS women are more likely to have the 'sneaky ILC' than the general population, you probably can understand why some docs would not recommend more than what LCIS women get.  Currently, that's all I get (annual mammogram and twice-a-year clinical exam).   I think I'm  one of the few LCIS women who isn't followed with screening MRI, or hasn't gotten PBMs.  Other risk factors, such as family history or prior radiation treatment (such as for lymphoma) may play a role in this decision too. I'm *not* trying to dictate what the right screening is for you.  That's for you, your doctor, and perhaps your insurance company to decide.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 11:04AM - edited Mar 23, 2010 11:24AM by leaf I doubt if there is anyone in their right mind who doesn't remember the anxiety.  Personally, in order to try to contain the anxiety, I was thinking "What is the worst case scenario? -that  I wouldn't live to the tumor board?"  (Many hospitals review complex or interesting cases every few weeks.) Some people have planned their funeral in detail.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. But that is NOT an accurate picture.  Here is a decision tree from Imaginis.  The exact numbers change from region to region, and patient demographics.  www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/...    Even *IF* you are diagnosed with breast cancer, it is not an immediate death sentence.   Most radiologists rate mammos and ultrasounds with a 'BIRADS' score.  www.imaginis.com/breasthealth/... From 2002-2006, the median age at diagnosis for cancer of the breast was 61 years of age. <snip>The stage distribution based on Summary Stage 2000 shows that 60% of breast cancer cases are diagnosed while the cancer is still confined to the primary site (localized stage); 33% are diagnosed after the cancer has spread to regional lymph nodes or directly beyond the primary site; 5% are diagnosed after the cancer has already metastasized (distant stage) and for the remaining 2% the staging information was unknown. The corresponding 5-year relative survival rates were: 98.3% for localized; 83.5% for regional; 23.3% for distant; and 57.7% for unstaged.  http://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/breast.html I know your mind will come up with the 'what ifs' - 'What if I'm the X in 100 that has XXX'... It is  NOT helpful to say 'don't worry' - it denies your feelings.  But worrying won't change the outcome.  Worrying is the very natural response to anyone who is threatened, no matter how unlikely the chance. Many people find distraction helps (preferably something good for you in some way, but whatever way you need to handle this.)  Vigorous exercise helps some people too (if you are physically able.)  Hang in there.  Let us know how it goes.  Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2011 07:52AM - edited Jul 10, 2011 07:55AM by leaf I also have LCIS, also ALH and DH (though not ADH - its the atypical adjective that really adds to the risk).  The science of breast cancer prediction is definitely in its infancy.  Even for women who *don't* have a higher risk lesion, models such as the modified Gail model *for any particular individual woman* are 'better than the toss of a coin, but not by much'. jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten...   If that's what they say about women withOUT higher risk lesions, you can imagine our state of knowledge about women who HAVE higher risk lesions. So there is a LOT of uncertainty. Also, different studies differ.  Many studies group ALH and ADH together, because the numbers of subjects are so small. In this Mayo study, which grouped ALH and ADH women together, The 331 women with atypia were followed for a total of 4,543 person-years (mean 13.7 years), with 66 (19.9%) observed breast cancer events to date.jco.ascopubs.org/content/25/19... In this study in 2007,  In keeping with the results from our prior study and from other previous studies,1–15 the current results continue to indicate that women with AH are at a substantially increased risk of breast cancer (approximately 4-fold compared with women who have nonproliferative lesions). http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cncr.22408/full Note this '4 fold' is NOT NOT NOT 4 x 13% of a lifetime chance of breast cancer, but 4 x the risk of women WITHOUT any particular risk factor, which may be ??about 3-5% so 4x 3-5%= 12-20% approximately. I am NOT NOT a statistics guru, there are a lot of statistics I do NOT understand.  One of these papers describes OR (odds ratio) and I do NOT have an intuitive feel for what that means.

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2009 09:50PM - edited Feb 9, 2009 10:55PM by leaf Well, yes, I would think a nodule is a lump.  If they are worried about a calcification, they usually say so. But many breast lumps, particularly in younger women, are benign. As far a lumps being either cancerous or non-cancerous, well, that can be a little of a gray area. In general, yes, lumps are usually categorized as either cancerous or non-cancerous.  However, cancer is NOT a 'line in the sand'.  Cancer is 'uncontrolled cell growth'.  In the middle of the spectrum, it can be difficult to categorize tissues as cancerous or non-cancerous.  That's one reason why they like to characterize a cancer's 'personality'.  I have an unusual condition that has 'carcinoma' in its name, but most oncologists do not consider it a cancer.  (Lobular carcinoma in situ - don't expect that as its unusual.) For older women, they often like to remove lumps, whether or not benign, because they can mask things underneath it. They cannot diagnose you without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.   Without knowing your symptoms, age, and background, I would really hesitate at labeling you 'sunk'.  If you have an ulcerous lesion that is growing on the surface of your breast, bulging lumps in your armpit that stick out from the surface, then it is likely you have advanced cancer. If you had chest Xray treatment for things like Hodgkin's disease, then that puts you at higher risk. They can, and often do, 'score' mammograms and imaging.  If you have a BIRADS score of 5 (probably (>95% chance cancerous), you have a higher chance of having breast cancer than if you have a BIRADS score of 4 (about 5-95% chance of being cancerous.)  Even so,we have had people with a BIRADS score of 5 come back with benign results.  Even if it is news you don't want to hear,  breast cancer is not an automatic death sentence. You mother had breast cancer at a relatively early age (I assume pre-menopausal.)  That does put you at higher risk.  But it is not inevitable. On the other hand, if you are young (< say 50 years old), and have no symptoms, then it is less likely.  Overall, for the entire population, 80% of breast biopsies in the US turn out to be benign.  This groups together the people who have more suspicious signs and less suspicious signs, but it gives you some idea.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 04:14AM - edited Jan 11, 2009 04:17AM by leaf I would definitely get some topical anesthetic, considering the pain you are having now.  Maybe the only kind you will be able to find is something like benzocaine (or other '-caines') used for teething babies. (Make sure it doesn't have any heavy metals in it - it shouldn't if it is for babies.)  It may be messy. Wipe it off before you get into the mammography room.  You shouldn't use any antiperspirants or deodarants or powders before the Xray because they can cause artifacts that can look like calcium deposits. You first get into absolutely lovely hospital gowns.  (They let you wear the garments on your lower body. )   You usually sit in a room with other women dressed the same way, looking nervously at each other.  Sometimes a nice comraderie develops. They have you stand in a certain position, support your arms against grips on the machine.  The techinian puts your breast onto a plate, tells you not to move, steps away to take the picture.  You are normally not compressed for more than 10-30 seconds. I heard there was one study where the patients were allowed to control the amount of compression they had during mammograms.  (The flatter your breast, the better the picture.)  The patients selected a pressure that was not significantly different than what the technician would have chosen. The technician is not allowed to give you any results - preliminary or otherwise.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2015 11:32AM leaf wrote: I think that some radiologists/breast surgeons do not get pain relief for breast biopsies. I do not have a lidocaine, or any local anesthetic allergy. When I had my breast excision, they first injected needles in my breast to 'bracket' the 'area of concern'. They gave me 1 spray of ethyl chloride (which is about the equivalent of 3 seconds of the application of an ice cube), then did the insertion. Unfortunately, beforehand, they told me I was not to move a muscle under any circumstances. I knew if they had to do it over again, they would be mashing up the tissue even more. I tried to be brave, but I'm sure my pain score was at least 9/10. (I have a history of trauma, so that's probably why I reacted so badly.) Most people handle this fairly well (I did a survey here, and most people probably had a pain score of around 5/10), but I did not, nor did another friend of a friend who had the same procedure. This was 10 years ago, so maybe things have changed. I was told that they couldn't give me opiods because they didn't have an RN present. (This was done by the radiology staff, so there was a radiology tech present, who of course does not have an RN.) I wrote 2 letters complete with Pubmed references, and got a reply from the radiologist 'then I'd have to add some sodium bicarbonate to the mix'. I have no understanding how adding sodium bicarbonate would have helped with my pain relief. (I'm a pharmacist.) This paper says sodium bicarbonate doesn't even work. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11... They never even asked me if I was in pain - and I'm sure the procedure lasted for at least 30-90 minutes. Agreeing with what aunt paula already said, here's a website about people with different local anesthetic allergies. If you are in the 'worst case scenario' and cannot handle any amide or ester-type anesthetics, they can use opiods, diphenhydramine, or general anesthetics. www.uic.edu/pharmacy/centers/d... I'm sure they'd have to go through extra insurance company loops to get an OK for an anesthesiologist (MD or RN) to get involved to use a general anesthetic, because that would be more costly. But, I don't care if I was 1 in 1 million people. No one should have a pain score of 9/10 during a procedure, even if its 'all in their head' or whatever.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 07:51PM leaf wrote: Most people find going through this process is stressful - that's one big reason for having this website. When you are told there may be something wrong with an area of your body, it is natural to feel every twinge that happens.  That does NOT mean that you are 'imagining things', its something that most people do. Many women here have reported that when they are diagnosed with cancer, they can get 'canceritis' - every symptom they have feels like it is connected to their breast cancer.  Women can worry that they have metastatic cancer to the back, or the knees, or when they stub their toe they have mets to their toe, or their hair feels funny so they must have cancer of the hair, etc.etc. It can be impossible to say the right thing to people with cancer.    I have said the wrong thing to people with cancer both before and after my diagnosis with a condition that puts me at higher risk for breast cancer.  Many people with cancer feel more vulnerable, at least some of the time.  But we all have our own personalities, and ways that we handle things. This is a great site for support.  Chances are that everything will turn out fine, and you will not have breast cancer.  If you have questions or want to vent, feel free.  Let us know how it goes, OK?
Posts.Title: Hi Everybody... minx minx

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2013 07:01AM leaf wrote: Once you've had your call-back mammograms, they probably won't do any more mammograms on you (unless they are doing a biopsy where any lesion shows up best in mammograms, or there is a problem with the machine or if there is a fold in your skin making it hard to see your entire breast.)  While your chances of having breast cancer are quite low, if it is breast cancer, then one type they may be thinking about is lobular carcinoma.  Lobular carcinoma often does not show up on mammograms or ultrasounds.  Its nickname is 'The Sneaky One' because it can be hard to diagnose.  For almost all breast cancers, they can't diagnose you without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. I wouldn't want to worry your family about this either.  Even if you get a diagnosis you don't want, I find it helpful to be in control of what information the people in my life get.  I only tell the people in my life when I'm good and ready to tell them.  Once you tell them, you can't 'untell' them. But your chances that this is a 'nothing' are very high.  Keep us informed.  Waiting is awful, but some people find distraction helps.

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 01:04PM - edited Dec 1, 2008 01:07PM by leaf More breast lumps are found in the upper, outer quadrant of the breast.  There are slightly more lumps found in the left than the right breast,but this statistic may not apply to tumors in the upper, outer quadrant. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15... If lumps are found near the collar bone,then they can be lymph nodes.  (That is one of the first places I have been examined during a breast exam.) I don't think there is an association between location of breast cancer (in the breast) and family history. Many women here feel 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - in other words, biopsy is the way to get the most definitive answers about a breast lump. I know this is a very stressful time for you. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 01:00PM leaf wrote: One nice thing about oral meds is that you can stop them if you don't like it after you start it. Here is a website from the NCI that describes plusses and minuses of tamoxifen.  It states that the increased incidence of stroke in tamoxifen users is about that of women taking hormone replacement.   www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/fa... **If **this is of concern to you, and since you are postmenopausal, you may also consider taking another SERM. There is little that is cut and dry in breast cancer, including with conditions that put you at higher risk such as with ALH.   Almost all findings/opinions concerning ALH (and LCIS) are controversial. 'Extensive' may have an ambiguous meaning here.  Extensive may mean 'extensively throughout the field of the microscope - in other words, the TINY (microscopic) sample that the pathologist looked at has ALH all over it', or extensive, as in each sample that was looked at had ALH.   Even so, this may depend on the size of tissue they LOOKED at (not took) during your excision.  LN (lobular neoplasia) is often multifocal (in other words you have multiple spots of it) and bilateral (both breasts-although this is less common.)  They know this because about 20 years ago, they routinely did bilateral mastectomies on LCIS patients. Over 50% of patients diagnosed with LN contain multiple foci in the ipsilateral breast and about 30% of cases will have further LCIS in the contralateral breast [12-14]. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC314428/ Since LN is usually an incidental finding, it is not possible to know exactly how much ALH you have without a mastectomy. A higher risk of progression is attributed to LIN 3 (pleomorphic LN, extensive LN, and signet ring cell LN) compared to LIN 1 or LIN 2 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... but this is just one paper's opinion. Since you have no family history of BC (and I assume of ovarian cancer), then I would assume you would be at low risk for a BRCA mutation.  It is usually thought that BRCA puts one at higher risk of breast cancer  (about 60-90% lifetime risk) than any of the atypias (including ALH and LCIS). I have LCIS and ALH (and sclerosing adenoma) and a weak family history, and I have read papers that describe LCIS (which is more advanced than ALH) as moderate risk. caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/c... This Stanford site describes ALH risk as 'moderate'

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2010 05:48AM - edited Apr 16, 2010 05:49AM by leaf Here's an abstract. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19105706 and the article article.  There was no difference for invasive, and a *nonsignificant* difference for noninvasive. There was no difference between the effect of tamoxifen and the effect of raloxifene on the incidence of invasive breast cancer; these results are shown in TABLES 1 and 2. There were 163 cases of invasive breast cancer in the women assigned to tamoxifen and 168 cases in those assigned to raloxifene [25]. The rate per 1000 was 4.30 in the tamoxifen group and 4.41 in the raloxifene group (RR: 1.02; 95% CI: 0.82–1.28)....<snip> In contrast to the findings for invasive breast cancer, there were fewer noninvasive breast cancers in the tamoxifen group than in the raloxifene group, although this difference did not reach statistical significance (TABLES 3&4). There were 57 incident cases of noninvasive breast cancer among the women who took tamoxifen and 80 among the women who took raloxifene (rate for noninvasive breast cancer, 1.51 per 1000 women assigned to tamoxifen and 2.11 per 1000 women assigned to raloxifene [RR: 1.40; 95% CI: 0.98–2.02]). http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2785111/?tool=pubmed

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 05:46PM - edited Mar 20, 2010 05:48PM by leaf Here's more on cell phone use and cancer from  the National Cancer Institute.  They're talking about cellphone use and cancers in the head/neck. Studies suggest that the amount of RF energy produced by cellular telephones is too low to produce significant tissue heating or an increase in body temperature. However, more research is needed to determine what effects, if any, low-level non-ionizing RF energy has on the body and whether it poses a health danger (2)<snip> How is a cellular telephone user exposed to RF energy? A cellular telephone's main source of RF energy is produced through its antenna. The antenna of a hand-held cellular telephone is in the handset, which is typically held against the side of the head when the telephone is in use. The closer the antenna is to the head, the greater a person's expected exposure to RF energy. The amount of RF energy absorbed by a person decreases significantly with increasing distance between the antenna and the user. The intensity of RF energy emitted by a cellular telephone depends on the level of the signal sent to or from the nearest base station (1). [To me, this implies that RF is not produced, or at least produced at a much lower level, when the cell phone is off.  However, this is a guess.  I am not a RF expert.] <snip>?What parts of the body may be affected during cellular telephone use?There is concern that RF energy produced by cellular phones may affect the brain and nervous system tissue in the head because hand-held cellular telephones are usually held close to the head. Researchers have focused on whether RF energy can cause malignant (cancerous) brain tumors such as gliomas (cancers of the brain that begin in glial cells, which surround and support the nerve cells), as well as benign (noncancerous) tumors, such as acoustic neuromas (tumors that arise in the cells of the nerve that supplies the ear) and meningiomas (tumors that occur in the meninges, which are the membranes that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord) (1). The salivary glands also may be exposed to RF energy from cellular telephones held close to the head.Ihttp://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/cellphones

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 04:43PM leaf wrote: I'm not an immunologist, but I think you are correct - there is no invasion; it sounds like if that's the worst you have (atypical papilloma), its benign.  The CK34, P632 and SMA are immunochemicals that help the pathologist characterize the cells.  They help the pathologist diagnose if the cells are ductal or lobular, etc.This is an academic paper.  www.researchgate.net/publicati...   Sometimes breast cells don't have their typical appearance, and these immunochemical markers help the pathologist diagnose the cells.  These immunochemical markers, by themselves, don't mean you are in any further risk.  Its like saying a person wears long hair and lipstick, so its more likely, but not certain, that this person is a woman.(Sorry about the imperfect analogy.) If your excision doesn't show anything worse than atypical papilloma, then your chance of having a future breast cancer is higher than the average woman, but still low.  www.breast-cancer.ca/type/papi...  Most studies I've seen give women with ALH or ADH (and nothing worse) a lifetime chance of breast cancer of something like 15-25%.  If you have a significant family history of breast cancer (such as a mother or daughter with breast cancer), then your chances of breast cancer are probably higher than 10-20%.  (Note the average woman has a lifetime risk of breast cancer of roughly 13%.)  For comparasion, I have classic LCIS, which is more advanced than ALH or ADH, and may have a lifetime risk of DCIS or invasive breast cancer of something like 20-40%.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 08:43AM - edited Oct 6, 2012 08:50AM by leaf This website says one chest CT has a radiation dose of about 7 mSv, which is about = 2 years of background radiation.  www.radiologyinfo.org/en/safet... and rates this as about 1:10,000 to 1:1000 risk of cancer.    If you use the 'more worse case scenario' (because it says this varies alot with machinery and patient weight - I don't know what the 'worst case scenario' is), and assuming this is a additive and linear relationship, since you've had 3 CT scans, that's about 3:1000, or about 0.3%.  I would think this is pretty small since the 'baseline' overall lifetime risk for cancer in the normal population is about 1 in 5 or about 20%.  In other words, 0.3% is fairly small compared to about 20%.  I know there's a lot of variation in these numbers, and I may not have done the math correctly, but this paper lists the risk for 1 chest cat scan as 'low'.  But 3 cat scans would be about 6 years worth of background radiation.  There is a lot more variation than that in the average lifespan of women. This paper suggests that some women in their mid-20s who received radiation treatment for Hodgkin's disease had about a 25-35% risk of breast cancer in the next 30 years. jnci.oxfordjournals.org/conten... I think most experts feel there is no threshold for radiation risk.  In other words, every radiation exposure will increase one's risk of cancer. But the 'average' background radiation dosage is about 3 mSv per year.  It sounds like this is chiefly from radon (which varies geographically) and cosmic rays (which we can't control). I know these numbers may be really rough, and I may not understand the statistics or  done the math correctly or don't understand the assumptions involved but I hope this gives you some order-of-magnitude idea about the involved risk.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2010 05:59PM - edited May 29, 2010 06:06PM by leaf IV sedation means they give the sedation through an intravenous line.  That's what I had when I had a colonoscopy.  I got the same drugs as a colonoscopy (fentanyl and versed), but in addition a short acting sedative called propofol. (Other anesthesiologists may use different medications.) They can sedate you to one of two endpoints: so that you're completely unconscious, or until you have conscious sedation.  When I had my excision, I had conscious sedation.  I didn't have any pain, but sometimes I could feel some patting sensation on my breast (presumably the surgeon blotting away extra blood.)   I could not open my eyes or see a thing until it was all over and they were transferring me to another table.  Everytime I tried to speak (even just trying to say Ummmmm - I wasn't feeling any pain at all; I was only expressing surprise at being in this state of consciousness) - I got another slug of anesthetic.  I didn't have any masks (that I was aware of) for my excision.  I could not say anything more meaningful than 'ummmm' or 'uhhhh.' Usually IV medication is usually included in the mix, even if they use masks and gases in addition. When they've used masks on me (for other operations), often the masks had a very 'plasticy' smell.  But I wasn't conscious long, and when I woke up I was not wearing a mask. Different anesthesiologists do things differently.  Some people have had a choice whether they want to be totally unconscious or whether they want conscious sedation.  It also probably depends on how large or long the surgery will be, and what other medical conditions you have.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 07:45PM - edited Dec 7, 2009 07:47PM by leaf Yes, it is possible for ultrasound to be wrong.  Mammos can be wrong, and MRIs can be wrong.  Even biopsies can be wrong - you can sample the wrong place, or (for example if you have a fine needle biopsy) your tissue can be distorted, making it harder to read.  If you have a sizable piece of tissue biopsied, they can't look at all the cells under the microscope; they have to take a sampling.  On the other hand, larger pieces of tissue taken out mean more scar tissue, which can make it harder to read subsequent imaging. There are a very few women here who have had a negative mammogram, ultrasound, and negative MRI, but still ended up having breast cancer.   This is quite, quite unusual, but it CAN happen. Conversely, there are women who have had a worrisome mammogram, ultrasound, AND worrisome MRI,but a biopsy turned out negative for anything worrisome. There is little that is 100%in breast cancer.

Although the most common symptom of breast cancer is a painless lump, there are people here who have been diagnosed with  breast cancer and had every possible permutation-painful lump, painful but lumpless, painless and lumpless, etc. Remember, this board is mainly populated by women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer, or are at high risk for breast cancer, or are a SO of someone who has breast cancer.  The people who don't have breast cancer usually quit posting after they get a benign result. Good for you for getting it checked out .  You are right-better safe than sorry. If you really think that something is wrong, insist on a biopsy. Best wishes for a Boringly Benign result!

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 06:48AM leaf wrote: I haven't had an experience like this.  Of course you're worried.  The more imaging negatives (mammogram and ultrasound) that you have, the less likely you have breast cancer.  If you are premenopausal, then your lump could be due to hormonal issues.  If you have a lump that gets larger and smaller during your monthly menstrual cycle, then its almost certainly not breast cancer. There is almost nothing in breast cancer that is 100%.  If we could diagnose breast cancer from symptoms only, then they wouldn't need to do imaging or biopsy.   For almost all breast cancer, they can't diagnose you until someone looks at a piece of tissue under the microscope.   Since it sounds like you are very worried (as would be natural), then you may want to push to see the breast surgeon.  If your lump is big enough, and perhaps in the right location (?) then they may be able to do a fine needle biopsy right in the office.  (I've never had a fine needle biopsy.)
Posts.Title: negative mammogram and sonogram, but still have lump amysunflower amysunflower

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 07:31AM - edited Jul 11, 2008 07:39AM by leaf I'm so sorry you are going through this, falco.  I'm so glad you found a job with insurance so now can get your doctor's visits covered.   I'm sure this is extra frightening for you because you are seeing a relative die of breast cancer.   There are women who really have lumpy breasts.  Some women have many, many cysts.  If these are cysts, then the cyst itself is not the concern, but they like to aspirate them so they won't interfere with detecting other lumps. Some women get a lot of cysts.  If all of these lumps are solid,  I think some women here have had something like 8 - 14 biopsies, and only 1 of them turned out to be cancer. Ultrasound is good at detecting if a lump is sold or if it is fluid-filled (a cyst.)  Cysts are almost always benign. I haven't had any lumps, but I'm sure its physically possible to biopsy lumps in both breasts at the same time.  I had 2 'areas of concern' in the same breast, one seen by mammo and one by ultrasound, and they did the biopsies a week apart. I'm sure they would have done them together if they had been able to detect them with the same imaging. Most breast cancer is *not* genetically linked to a single mutation.  About 70% of women with breast cancer have no obvious risk factors for getting breast cancer (besides being a woman.)   Age is a big risk factor for breast cancer. (You are considered young for breast cancer.  The median age to get breast cancer is 64, per Dr. Love's Breast Book.) *Some* 'red flags' for having a genetic breast cancer (BRCA1 or BRCA2)  from a single gene would be things like having several first degree relatives (mother, sister, daughter)  with breast cancer or ovarian cancer, or several second degree relatives (aunt, grandmother) with breast or ovarian cancer, or male breast cancer. There are other genetic mutations in other genes, but they are much more uncommon.  I went to genetic counseling, and though I have more than the average amount of cancer in my family, I was at low risk for having a BRCA or any other breast cancer-related mutation.  The most common symptom of breast cancer is a painless lump.  But some women do have painful lumps.  Most often, these are benign.  Remember, overall, 80% of biopsies are benign. That's a big number. In the 'worst case scenario', if you have breast cancer, most breast cancer has been in the body for 6-10 years before it can be detected by *ANY* means.  So a delay of several months usually won't make a difference.  It is good you are getting them checked out.  Many women here feel that 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - in other words, feel best in getting things biopsied (at least if they aren't cysts.)  Cysts can feel hard if they are deep. If your lumps shrink and swell with your menstrual period - well, cancer doesn't shrink like that - cancer is 'uncontrolled growth'.  Feel free to ask questions or vent. We are here for you!
Posts.Title: Life sentence, even with no cancer? theonlyfalco AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 04:15PM - edited Jul 25, 2008 04:18PM by leaf Cysts are almost always benign, and are often drained.  Not because they are a worry, but because they can mask feeling any tissue that is under them. Cysts can also be painful, and draining them relieves the pressure. No change in the lump sign is probably a bit on the side of good, but it doesn't give you much information.  Its good that it isn't growing at a rate you can detect.
Posts.Title: Life sentence, even with no cancer? theonlyfalco AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2008 11:13AM - edited Sep 30, 2008 11:14AM by leaf There is probably no recommendation.  I think the person must be able to give legal consent though.  It is a very individual decision. Some people who have a bad family history choose not to get tested for BRCA,and some who are BRCA positive choose not to have bilateral mastectomies.   Usually if a person has a bad family history of breast/ovarian cancer, they prefer to first test a person who has had the breast cancer - and it may be the first person in the family who got breast cancer (if that is possible - if they are still alive - for some families they have documented breast cancer going back for many, many generations.) Some people with a horrible family history get negative BRCA results.  The purpose of the first genetic counseling meeting is to inform you of the possible consequences of genetic testing, and what they may mean to you emotionally.  They usually indicate that genetic testing may want to be done if it would change treatment decisions. The genetics counselor should not be pressuring you for or against genetic testing.  They usually  recommend to start screening daughters when they are about 10 years younger than their mother got breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2009 05:53AM - edited Sep 9, 2009 05:55AM by leaf The path towards diagnosis is not exactly the same for everyone.  Of course you are scared.  We all want to be prepared for whatever is ahead for us, no matter how small the risk. No one can tell you for sure whether you have a cancer or not.  The doc who normally diagnoses a person with breast cancer is a pathologist after looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.  I wouldn't be surprised if you had,  at some point, an ultrasound.  Ultrasounds are good at telling the border between tissue and fluid , such as a cyst (a fluid filled sac.) Cysts can be aspirated in the office. Here is an overview of the breast cancer diagnosis tree.   http://imaginis.com/breasthealth/diagnosis.asp As you can see, the vast majority of women, particularly young women (and you would be considered young - the mean age to get breast cancer in the US is in one's early 60s)  have a benign outcome.  Here's more from the NCI about breast papillomas. www.cancer.gov/templates/db_al... Studies do differ, but in this study, they didn't find an association between breast symptoms (breast pain, lumps, and nipple discharge) and breast cancer. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12... http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12000140 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 06:42AM - edited Jun 14, 2008 06:58AM by leaf The diagnostic process is HORRIBLE! Some women have had to wait 4 or 6 months or more going through this process. There probably aren't enough trained radiologists to handle all the diagnostic process to have it go faster. But that doesn't make it less stressful. It would be very helpful if they gave the patient some info to put their results into context. That is one of the very nice things about this BB. This website has a lot of information. It is common to have your mind run wild while you are getting things checked out. We all want to be ready for whatever is on the path ahead of us. I'm sure it is common for people to imagine the worst case scenario. I said to myself, "What is the worst case scenario? That I not live to make it to the tumor board? (The tumor board is the hospital committee that processes that handle cancer diagnoses.) Some women have pictured their funeral in detail. I didn't get the big picture. Overall, for all age groups, 80% of biopsies are benign. They haven't even talked about biopsies for you yet. I will tell you how worried I was. I ended up having a biopsy. I got the call about diagnosis on a Friday night at 6pm (so I'm sure the radiologist stayed late to tell me), and he said "You have LCIS. Do you know what that means?" I replied, "Yippeee! " I was so happy I didn't have invasive breast cancer. (LCIS (lobular cancer in situ), in spite of the name, just puts you at higher risk for breast cancer. Its quite unusual.) Now, I wouldn't wish this on anyone, but I am grateful I didn't have invasive cancer. After that, even **IF** you have breast cancer, breast cancer is NOT an automatic death sentence. About 65% of those who get breast cancer die of some OTHER condition. My grandmother had breast cancer in the 1950s, before the age of chemos, or probably rads. I think all they had was mastectomies. She lived for another 23 years and died of an unrelated cause. At that time, breast cancer was an unspoken word (because most women died of it), and I was told to never talk to her about it. Treatment is light years better now.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2010 03:56PM leaf wrote: About 15 years before my classic LCIS, I had (what ended up being) a solitary benign T3 (that's the 'wimpy' hormone, in comparasion to T4)-secreting adenoma (i.e. Plummer's disease), with Hashimoto's (autoimmune destruction of the thyroid).  My symptoms were simply a large lump on my thyroid about 3cm wide.  I first had an ultrasound, which showed it was not a cyst, then a nuclear scan.  Solitary nodules are rather uncommon, as are T3 secreting ones.  I had a half of my thyroid removed.  I'm on thyroid replacement (T4, levothyroxine).  I've had few problems over the last 15 years, besides gradually increasing my thyroid dosage. (I rarely have trouble swallowing, due to minor damage to the pharyngeal nerve.  Usually I can take all ~15 tablets - this includes BIG calcium and thiamine tablets- at once.)  I tend to specialize medically in getting the uncommon.  I had it removed because they were afraid it would take too high a dose of radioactive iodine to kill it medically, and eventually it might affect breathing. A co-worker had Grave's disease at the same time, and it went undiagnosed for about a year.  The doc kept on giving her anti-anxiety meds.  After she was diagnosed, she had radioactive iodine treatment.   Thyroid cancer is uncommon.  There is one nurse at my hospital who had it about 25 years ago, and is doing absolutely fine.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 04:10PM leaf wrote: I am so sorry you are going through this.  You have had a hard life, and its natural to think that because you have had rotten things happen to you in the past that you are tied to that pattern. Its easy to go to the worst case scenario.  I certainly did. But I didn't get the 'big picture' when I was getting diagnosed.   Here is a diagram that shows roughly the percentage of people that get certain results.  As you can see, on a biopsy, about 80% get benign results and 20% get a cancer diagnosis.   Of those 20% that do get a cancer diagnosis, about 80% get an early cancer diagnosis, and 20% get a late stage diagnosis.  www.imaginis.com/breast-cancer...  Those are pretty good odds for me.   I'd certainly rather have a 20% chance of something being bad, than an 80% chance, and even if you're in that 20% group, only 20% of that  cancer group has a late stage diagnosis. If you wear yourself out worrying about the outcome now, then if you do get a bad outcome, you'll have to go through that process twice.  i know its very hard to do, but for some people, distraction helps, or some people get anti-anxiety meds or do spiritual exercises or exercise or whatever works for you. Let us know how it goes: we all know how awful this process is.
