Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 05:36PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 11:52AM by leaf I am no expert on this, of course, but I did find 1) In this reference, the terrified woman with suspected endometrial cancer who found SAA as her diagnosis found out it meant "Same as above". www.hystersisters.com/vb2/show...   2) I am sure that SOME normal uteri could have high SAA.  If there were none, they would be abandoning traditional screening for this SAA test.   It sounds like SAA may be a marker for several different things - including inflammation (which of course is not cancer.) Elevated levels are also found in a variety of cancers.  They have investigated MANY 'biomarkers' for endometrial cancer over the last decade (at least).  I have had several endometrial biopsies, and to my knowledge they have not done any of  these biomarker tests on them. I would doubt that your gyn requested this test for a 'routine' endometrial test, unless you are in an endometrial cancer trial or study of some sort.  It sounds like SAA is being tested in endometrial cancer in a RESEARCH setting, and has not reached routine clinical use. In addition, because they wrote:  Final Diagnosis: SAA, even IF you did have high SAA levels, that is NOT a diagnosis- that is a laboratory test.  They didn't even write diagnosis: Elevated SAA. So I highly suspect it means: Same as above. Please let us know what you find out.
Posts.Title: BC survivor w/ concerning endometrial biopsy result KorynH leaf

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 08:26AM - edited Dec 13, 2007 08:31AM by leaf Your lump can DEFINITELY be benign. 80% of biopsies are benign. People here have had breast cancer surgeons who told them they were sure it was cancer, and when they went in and biopsied it it was benign. Its so hard going through the waiting. When I had my first appt with the breast surgeon, it took another 3 weeks to get an appointment for an excision. There are 3 main ways they biopsy. 1) Fine needle biopsy. This can be done in the office. It is the least invasive, but it can distort the cells in the sample, making it harder to read. 2) Core biopsy. I think these are usually done by radiologists. They use a slightly larger needle. They use local anesthesia. I've had 3 of these. 3) Excisional biopsy. This is when they remove the 'area of suspicion', and is a surgical procedure, done by a surgeon. This is the most invasive, but the 'gold standard' way of looking what is going on. I have had one of these. Waiting is definitely the hardest. We all want to be prepared for what is ahead. Remember, even for the most high risk woman, 80% of biopsies are BENIGN in the United States. Hang in there, We are all rooting for you to get benign results!!

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 02:31PM - edited Jul 22, 2008 02:33PM by leaf Of course this could be something else.  Yes, she needs to be seen by a doctor to find out if they can find a cause. Swelling is a common sign of infection, as could be changes in the shape of the breast.  If she has a breast infection, the breast lymph often drains into the armpit/underarm.  The lymph nodes act as a 'trap' for infections. They will probably do a breast exam on your mom, and likely order a mammogram.  Mammograms can be used to diagnose other things besides breast cancer.  There is little in breast cancer that is 100%, but the most common first sign of breast cancer is a painless lump, or a mammogram abnormality.  But some women can have other symptoms. It is good to get this checked out.  But do not diagnose her with breast cancer before her doctor does.  She does not have breast cancer until she is diagnosed with it. It is a very frightening time, so your mom is lucky she has such a concerned and resourceful daughter like you! Many women like to have a person who will listen well to them at a time like this.  And many women feel distraction helps.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 02:42PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 10:57AM by leaf Echoing all the above.  (At my place, the radiologist who did the core biopsy was the one who first called me with the result.) Diagnosis does take a long time. I've seen some posters here who said it was >6months.  (They sent slides to another institution, and didn't tell the patient.) Before I was diagnosed, I thought the only women who got breast cancer were women who ignored  their lumps.  See what I knew! This site has been sooo helpful. The importance of confidentiality.  (I work at the hospital where I got diagnosed.) I learned NOT (for ME) to tell my colleagues about my potential health problems. (I was crying periodically at work, and I wanted them to know it Wasn't anything they had done.)  It ended up some very inappropriate things happened, such as  (essentially) a male stranger (who was not a doctor, but knew someone with my diagnosis) tell me he recommended bilateral mastectomies, and people recommending how I should have handled my feelings.  That was not helpful. While it is inevitable that some people will say dumb things, I was also probably much more vulnerable around the time of diagnosis and getting a treatment plan in place. That when I tell someone else about my diagnosis, their first gut reaction will likely be something self protective, that involves the feeling "That's awful and won't happen to me." I learned that saying, "I'm sorry this happened to you" is generally more helpful than 'You will be OK', or 'Be positive'. I found out about how often mothers with young children are struck with  breast cancer.  That the women who chose tough treatments are not doing this to 'maime' themselves, but to save their lives.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2013 05:38PM leaf wrote: Breast cancer is extremely unusual in teens, but it can happen.  In this study, there were about 30 /100,000  teens who got breast cancer in 2003-2005.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3411830/ We are not physicians so we can't diagnose you, but your chances of having breast cancer, particularly if you have no family history, are very, very small.  Anything that can happen on regular skin can happen on the skin of the breast.  Its good that you are aware of the possibility of breast cancer.  In the 1950s, when my grandmother was alive, the words 'breast cancer' were a taboo subject in my family because so many women died of breast cancer.  (This was before they had treatments for breast cancer like chemotherapy let alone antihormonals.) You might want to check with your mom to have her look at it.  If you are uncomfortable doing this, it may provide some comfort to have a health care professional look at it. There are many things that can happen to breasts including infections or acne which can happen in areas where there isn't much air circulation.  Many young women can have benign breast lumps called fibroadenomas in their teen years.  I like to never say never, but the chances of this being breast cancer are very, very small.  But as with anything, its good to get it checked out.

Posts.Content: May 10, 2013 03:02PM - edited May 10, 2013 03:04PM by leaf Maybe they ordered an MRI to see if that can tell them better where to biopsy. It *is* awful to wait.  No one here can tell you for sure the news you want to hear - whether or not you have breast cancer.  But know in the literature that they use the words 'high risk' in a very inconsistent manner.  They use the word 'high risk' for people with a deleterious BRCA mutation,which can mean a 90% lifetime risk of having breast cancer.  (I would consider this high risk too!) They can also use the words 'high risk' for people with atypical hyperplasia or LCIS or DCIS with a weak family history.  The science of breast cancer prediction in these women with atypical hyperplasia, LCIS, or DCIS is in its infancy, but some places put the risk of  some of these women as low as 10%.  (I, with  classic LCIS and a weak family history, was told I have a risk somewhere between 10% and 60% but probably closer to 10% than 60%.) Now, personally, for me, I choose something different for things that are a 10% risk than if I had a 60% risk or 90% risk. If they were really worried, they would have given you a BIRADS 5 rating.http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/mammograms/results

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 06:46AM leaf wrote: Just about anything is possible.  There have been women here who have only had their cancer show up on MRI.  Historically, MRIs are notorious for a lot of false positives (the MRI shows something and they biopsy it and it is nothing.) It can pick up a lot of things like inflammation.  There probably is a factor of the particular MRI settings that are used and the skill of the radiologist in interpreting the imaging. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18953825 In this study from the Netherlands of BRCA women, MRI had a false positive rate of 83%. When combined with mammography, the false positive rate was lower. RESULTS: In all, 41% (81 of 196) of the women had at least one positive MRI or mammography. Malignancy was detected in 17 women: 11 at surveillance, 4 at an intended prophylactic mastectomy and 2 had an interval cancer. Imaging by mammography and MRI had a sensitivity of 71% and a specificity of 90%. The probability that a positive MRI result is false positive was 83% www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18...    (That does leave 17% that were truely positive.) The ACS does recommend annual MRI screening for BRCA women   (2007 article) http://caonline.amcancersoc.org/cgi/content/full/57/2/75

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2012 10:47PM - edited Jan 9, 2012 10:53PM by leaf Yes, in general radiologists specialize in reading images.  A general practitioner can legally do brain surgery, even though you'd never want one to, nor probably could they get hospital privileges to do brain surgery.  Some docs, though they have one specialty after their name, have also done residencies in other specialties.  I've heard of dermatologists who also have done residencies and have written academic papers in rheumatology and immunology. So, its not good to generalize.  There are 'Renaissance doctors' who know multiple areas well.  I read of one surgeon (who did ?trauma surgery) who also did a residency in psychiatry. Some people do have knowledge outside of their specialty.  Once, a hospital pharmacist, after looking at  some imaging of a patient, very very gently led the doctor to a diagnosis of endocarditis (infection of the heart valves).  Pharmacists are normally NOT trained in imaging.  She made the doc  feel like he made the diagnosis, but it was really the pharmacist that caught the missed diagnosis. (Legally, pharmacists cannot diagnose.) However, one nutty relative said 'First I got lung cancer, then breast cancer, then terminal brain cancer diagnosed by a dermatologist', had never had an MRI, seen an oncologist, neurologist, or neurosurgeon. We were really confused.  She was a chronic liar, and we knew something was amiss with her choices.  We didn't know how unstable she was until later.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2007 09:24PM - edited Nov 30, 2007 09:25PM by leaf When they do ultrasounds, they bounce sound waves off of tissue, and they measure the signal that comes back. That is the 'echo'. If its hypoechoic, then the sound waves didn't bounce back strongly. If its mixed echoic, some parts bounced back strongly and some did not. They are simply describing in very concrete terms what the ultrasound looks like. It would be like looking at a photo of a house and saying "It has a black asphalt roof, with green stucco, and windows trimmed with brown." They cannot tell what the diagnosis will be before a biopsy. No one can diagnose breast cancer from an image (Mammo, MRI, ultrasound.) Remember, Birads 4 is suspicious, but not characteristic of breast cancer. Notice the *not characteristic* part of this sentence. 80% of biopsies are benign. Hang in there.

Five of 20 patients (25%) with measurable metastatic disease (visceral and/or soft tissue metastases) had objective antitumor responses defined as either a partial response (PR) or a complete response (CR). Four additional patients (20%) had prolonged stable disease (SD) for > or =6 months. Three of 6 patients (50%) with nonmeasurable metastatic disease (bone-only) had prolonged SD for > or =6 months. Clinical benefit rate (defined as CR + PR + SD > or =6 months) for all patients was 46% (12/26), with a median duration of 10 months. Overall median progression-free survival for the 26 subjects was 5 months. Median survival from the start of HDE was 17 months (range, 3-54 months)http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20110046 Clinical benefit rates were 9 of 32 (28%; 95% CI, 18%-41%) in the 30-mg group and 10 of 34 (29%; 95% CI, 19%-42%) in the 6-mg group. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19690310 They had ethinylestradiol as 3rd to 7th line endocrine therapy. One patient (8%) came off treatment early due to hepato-renal syndrome. Clinical benefit (objective response or durable stable disease for > or = 6 months) was seen in 4 patients (33.3%) with a median duration of response of 10+ (7-36) months. The time to treatment failure was 4 (0.5-36) months.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16834778

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 12:37PM - edited Dec 29, 2008 12:39PM by leaf Well, IBC can be a very difficult diagnosis - is often a clinical diagnosis, and you can have negative biopsies, mammos, etc.  You had a skin (punch) biopsy? (I think they usually look like a tiny cookie cutter vs a needle biopsy where they use a needle.) In IBC usually lymphatics in the dermis (that's a skin layer) are involved (but not always).  I guess you can bump this up to a more 'expert expert' (breast surgeon). For another rare medical condition (not bc) I was first referred to the local specialist.  I knew he was umm, shall I say, wasn't well versed in the disease (he said to come back when I had more symptoms) and I ended up going to the nearest Major Institution, to a person who specialized in this medical condition. If you are not happy with the way you have been handled,  you really need to get someone 'on your team' in which you have confidence.  Major Institutions can have excellent people, and some not so excellent people.  (I was not happy with my breast consult at this Major Institution, but I'm very happy with my care for this other rare medical condition - different physician and department.)  You need to have confidence in 'your team'!!

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 07:43AM leaf wrote: Breast pain is quite common, and they often can't find the cause. www.mayoclinic.com/health/brea...  Most women with breast cancer do NOT have breast pain, but for some women it was their first symptom.   However, dimpling is not a normal symptom.  I would bring this up with my doc and get it checked out until you are satisfied with their diagnosis.  That doesn't mean you have breast cancer.  There is no 'perfect imaging' in breast cancer, unfortunately. I can't find any studies with your specific symptoms, but in this >10 year old study, about 1% of the women with a breast symptom and normal mammogram had cancer. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14...   I know you had a normal ultrasound and not normal mammogram, but its the closest I could find. If your doc says "You're too young to have breast cancer", then I'd get suspicious and get another opinion.  Because of your age, your chances of having breast cancer are low, but, on the other hand, breast dimpling is a potential symptom.  Even in the women who have a suspicious enough situation for a biopsy -  they haven't recommended a biopsy for you yet - overall about 80% of biopsies are benign, particularly for your age group.  That's a big number, but I'd bring  your symptom up with your doc.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 11:01AM leaf wrote: They will target the lesion they saw on the mammogram (if they best see the lesion by mammogram).  If they best see the lesion by mammogram, they often do a 'stereotactic core mammogram guided biopsy' - they put your breast in a special mammogram machine (you lie prone and your breasts hang down), and they give you a local anesthetic in the breast, and the computer/machine helps locate the lesion. There are several kinds of lesions.  These things are described like they look on the mammogram, even though we might not understand what they mean.  So if they were looking at a picture of a woman, we might describe her as having dark hair, with widely spaced dark eyes and a broad chin; the radiologist might describe a mammogram as having microcalcifications, or breast asymmetry, architectural distortion, masses, etc.    Here's a presentation that gives some photos of some suspicious mammograms. http://eradiology.bidmc.harvard.edu/LearningLab/r... They often put a metal marker (often titanium) at the suspected area, because core biopsies often cause some internal scarring, so they can tell in future mammograms where the suspicious area was.  The marker is very tiny, but bigger than a blood vessel.  If you do end up having a surgical excision of the area, they often remove the marker.  For me, they said it would be obvious where my excision was.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 05:50AM - edited Jun 14, 2008 05:57AM by leaf It is so scary going through this diagnostic process. It sounds like this is the ultrasound report, and the ultrasound report apparently cannot entirely exclude the mass (density) seen in mammo. It is a good ultrasound report. Ultrasounds do *not* 'trump' mammograms, and mammos do not 'trump' ultrasounds. They all give more information. No breast imaging is 100% accurate or sensitive. This means that there is no breast imaging technique that can detect all breast cancers, and/or exclude all benign lesions. They saw a density on mammogram, and didn't see it on ultrasound. That's all your ultrasound report means. This is not uncommon. They are proceeding to investigate this further with MRI. Lesions often show up in one imaging and not in another. When multiple imaging (for example mammo + ultrasound + MRI) all are taken, then it improves the sensitivity. They aren't saying that your density under mammogram didn't happen, or changing their minds that the density *under mammogram* wasn't seen. Hang in there. Feel free to ask questions or vent.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 04:38PM - edited Mar 25, 2012 04:44PM by leaf It is so very, very hard going through the diagnosis process. When I was going through diagnosis, I always went to the 'worst case scenario'.  I think most women go through this during diagnosis.  I thought that for me the worst case scenario would be that I would die before I got through the diagnosis process.  Some people have planned their funeral in detail.  I didn't do that, but some people do. I work at a hospital and every time a person with breast cancer was admitted I burst into tears.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us. Here's a chart that's over 10 years old on the overall percentages that falls into each group.    http://www.imaginis.com/breast-cancer-diagnosis/overview-of-breast-cancer-diagnosis-decision-process Now this shows that its POSSIBLE that your worst case scenario could come true, but its not at all likely.  Humans are notoriously terrible about estimating how likely an event will happen to them.  One wise person here said something like ' If you worry and your worst case scenario doesn't come true, then you would have worried for nothing.  If your worst case *does* come through, then you will have gone through the worry process *twice*.'  We're human so we worry.  Your feelings are perfectly valid. We aren't machines that think 'Well, my chances are only 0.0000000005% for that so I'm not going to worry.'  We sometimes think in non-linear ways.  But sometimes some people can find distraction helps.   We're here listening and supporting you.    You don't sound like you have any obvious risk factors (besides being a woman.)     Good for you that you are following up and getting this lesion explored!  Some people are too scared to do that.  Please feel free to vent here or ask questions.  We're here for you!

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 05:54AM - edited Oct 5, 2007 05:54AM by leaf I am so sorry you are going through this. This means that at 6 o'clock, you have a solid mass, and next to this you have a cyst. At 2 o'clock, you have an area that shows up 'light' (hypoechoic means in the ultrasound, the ultrasound waves don't bounce back as well as in ordinary tissue) echoes in 2 places, and you also have a cyst. Cysts are almost always benign. Masses may or may not be. Hypoechoic does not mean that you have definite cancer. Smooth margins in a mass suggest benign, but this is not an absolute rule. Unfortunately there are few rules in breast cancer. The only way they can definitely diagnose cancer (or benign-ness) is with a biopsy. Did they recommend biopsy? People are different, but you need to have your doctors keep testing until you are comfortable that this is benign. They may also be able to drain the cysts if they can locate them (I do not have any personal experience with cysts.) Remember, 80% of biopsies in the US are benign. This figure holds even in women with a horrible family history of breast cancer. So statistics are in your favor, even if they did recommend a biopsy.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 05:46AM - edited Sep 29, 2014 08:18AM by Moderators No, it doesn't have to be cancer.  No one can diagnose you with breast cancer without looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.    Almost all breast cancer is diagnosed by a pathologist. They often rate breast imaging with a BIRADS score. http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types... We don't have any breast imaging that is 100% sensitive (it picks up all breast cancers) or 100% specific (it only picks up breast cancer and nothing else).  There are people who have gotten a BIRADS 5 rating and after biopsy it turns out to be benign.  It sounds like you don't know your BIRADS score.  It sounds like they haven't made the decision to do a biopsy yet.  (For me, that took several weeks because they had to get an OK from my insurance company.) One thing you might ask is what is the BIRADS score of your imaging.  Most women have calcifications.  Even most suspicious calcifications end up being benign.  Overall, about 80% of breast biopsies end up being benign. When calcifications do turn out to be breast cancer, it is usually an earlier breast cancer (as opposed to an advanced breast cancer). http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/types/mammograms/mamm_show Its very scary going through the diagnostic process.  We all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2010 06:24PM - edited May 20, 2010 06:29PM by leaf The majority of breast cancers do not cause pain (as the initial symptom).  But for some women, breast pain was a symptom, and for some breast pain was their first symptom. About 10 percent of women have moderate to severe breast pain more than five days a month. In some cases, severe breast pain lasts throughout the menstrual cycles...Breast pain alone rarely signifies breast cancer.  http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/breast-pain/DS00760 In this very old study (1980) of mastectomy breast cancer patients describing their initial symptom (remember, this was before lumpectomies became an option for some early breast cancers).   An unexpected finding was that pain was the first symptom noted by 13 percent of the women. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7454159 As some people say, breast cancer does not read books (it can present in a variety of ways). Fingers crossed for you for Boringly Benign!  Let us know how it goes, OK?

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 02:16AM - edited Feb 25, 2009 02:20AM by leaf I went to work (I'm a pharmacist) 24 hours after I got out of the recovery room.  They used fentanyl and propofol during surgery, so by definition you're not allowed to drive for 24 hours. (I was up for 24 hours straight because I also worked the night before.) I would have been better if I had been able to be out another day, but it was do-able. I echo the recommendation to have full front-opening garments so you don't have to have a slip over top. For me, tiny ice packs, a zip-front jog bra 24/7 (except showering) were great for me.  I also bought some tape and plastic bags to cover the incision area during showering.  I waited a two weeks to do jogging.  They put a breast contraption (support) so I looked like I should be in a Wagnerian opera.  Jiggling hurt, so the breast support was good.  I got a bunch of pain pills, but I didn't need more than a dose or two.  I mainly used them to try to relax me to get to sleep, but they didn't do that very well either as I was very anxious. Over the next week or two, my breast looked a lot worse (it turned all sorts of autumnal colors - purple, green, yellow, etc) due to hematomas, but eventually everything went away.   (Don't be shocked if that happens.  It looked MUCH worse than it felt.) Best wishes for a speedy recovery!

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 12:26PM - edited Oct 2, 2009 12:38PM by leaf There have been women here who have waited MONTHS after their excision for their pathology report.  In one case, they sent the slides to a 2nd hospital for confirmation (without telling the patient).    You do not want the pathologist to make a mistake.  I have read that its usually fairly straightforward to tell the difference between benign and invasive, but other important features can be more subjective.  You don't want to rush the pathologist. In this paper, they opine in their sample 8% of the time made a difference in mastectomy vs lumpectomy plans. www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrh... There can be problems with standardizing immunological staining. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...   Some studies do better than others. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19346635 There can be disagreement between pathologists.  This can have impact on which treatment to select. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18... They may have pathologists, secretaries, etc on vacation or ill, they may need to standardize or obtain different immunological stains to help with classification, they may have specialized instruments break or need repair, etc. Some patients (with some diagnoses) have their slides re-read. (The costs involved can be non-trivial, but sometimes/often insurance eventually covers it.) They usually come back the same, but sometimes they come back different.   Some women who are diagnosed with ADH  (a benign pre-cancerous condition) have their slides reread at a major institution, because it can be difficult to tell the difference between DCIS and ADH, and they are treated differently. Not knowing can drive you BONKERS.  Many people find distraction helps.  If not, then some people request anti-anxiety meds.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2017 06:37PM leaf wrote: There is actually a nation-wide shortage of SOME concentrations of lidocaine + epinephrine currently. (I work at a hospital pharmacy.) We don't have problems getting plain lidocaine injectable (so far.) Depending on your particular situation, there are some medications that some physicians use to lower their risk of bleeding, such as aminocaproic acid or tranexemic acid (both intravenous.) They sometimes use these, for example, when a woman is at high risk of hemorrhage after delivery. These may or may not be appropriate for you. However, they are normally given by IV, and I've never had an IV for any of the breast biopsies I've had. I bleed a lot after my 2nd core biopsy; I had a big hematoma. They had to compress my breast for an hour or two, and said if I continue to bleed in the evening to come back to the ER. After a few days, my breast turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal shades (yellow, blue, purple, green), but eventually the blood hemoglobin resorbed, after months. Luckily, I am not employed as a stripper, and probably most women here aren't either. It only looked horrible, it didn't feel horrible.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 09:39PM leaf wrote: Of course you are concerned. Anyone would be concerned. No one can tell you for sure what your lump is at this point. The only way they can really tell is to look at a piece of tissue under the microscope. I'm not sure what your doctor means by implanting medicine right into the breast - maybe this is the anesthetic that is injected into the breast before they do a core biopsy.   They are doing the mammogram and ultrasound to see if there is something suspicious showing there. Ultrasounds can usually see if something is a cyst- a fluid filled sac.  These are almost always benign.  They can feel hard if they are deep. Many people choose to have cysts aspirated, not because they are dangerous, but because in the future they can hide the tissue beneath, and cysts can sometimes cause pain. If they aren't a cyst, then many women here feel 'the best lump is the lump in the jar'.  (This means to err on the side of biopsy.) Remember, overall, 80% of biopsies are benign. That's a big number.  Get your lump checked out. You want to have peace of mind.
Posts.Title: Worriesome or not? MamaLaiste MamaLaiste

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2015 06:54PM leaf wrote: I am __NOT__ a statistician. I would think they may be very helpful in this situation. I am a postmenopausal woman with both LCIS and ALH, and a weak family history. In order to make decisions for ourselves, we really want to know 'What is MY risk for breast cancer?' Since my risk for breast cancer may be different than any other group I am thrown in with (e.g. women with LCIS, women with ALH, women who started their menstrual period at age X, women who didn't breastfeed, etc.) Since I can only make decisions about myself, my aim is to estimate risk for ME, not risk for a group I may belong to. I can point you to this article. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.... It points out the vast difference between estimating breast cancer risk in a large group of women, and the risk of an individual woman. It looked at the Gail model, which is probably the most used breast cancer risk model, at least for women without a significant family history of breast/ovarian cancer. The Gail model automatically excludes anyone with LCIS. It found the accuracy of the Gail model, with or without additional risk factors such as breast density, etc, was very poor FOR INDIVIDUAL WOMEN. It separated the population into two groups: a) the women who ended up getting breast cancer, and b) those that ended up not getting breast cancer. They selected one random woman from each group, forming a pair. It looked at the risk of each pair of women. 'In other words, for 59% of the randomly selected pairs of women, the risk estimated for the woman who was diagnosed with breast cancer was higher than the risk estimated for the woman who was not. Unfortunately, for 41% of the pairs of women, the woman with breast cancer received a lower risk estimate than her cancer-free counterpart. Thus, for any given woman, the two models were better at prediction than a coin toss—but not by much.' (emphasis mine). So if they have this much trouble calculating the risk of an average woman in the USA, just think of how many problems they have for calculating the risk of an individual woman with ALH, which a member of a much smaller group of women with ALH, versus the risk of an individual average woman in the USA, a member of a much larger group. My clinicians tossed my lifetime breast cancer risk numbers at me. (I got various figures such as 30%, 40%, and from one clinician, 'somewhere between 10% and 60%, but probably closer to 10% than 60%. If you want a better answer, go to the journals.') Those numbers may or may not be true. But to estimate MY risk, they may throw out numbers, but, I imagine even in the best case scenario, those numbers will be correct for you a MAXIMUM of 60% of the time; since we know so much less about ALH than the average woman, I imagine those numbers will be correct for you closer to 50% of the time, which is pure chance (i.e. the model does not predict any better than by chance.) This last paragraph is pure speculation on my part, again I am not a statistician, but I can't imagine they know numbers for ALH with or without LCIS, even as a group very well.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2010 04:16PM leaf wrote: Hi CameoBarbie - I'm having trouble understanding - could you help me understand?  I'm not sure if you're saying that work caused your thyroid condition?  Hashimoto's is an auto-immune disease.  About a decade ago, I found a paper that looked at serial autopsies, and found about 25% of the autopsies had *microscopic* evidence of Hashimoto's disease (not clinical Hashimoto's disease.)  Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in the United States after age 6 years, with the incidence estimated to be 1.3% in a series of 5000 children aged 11-18 years. In adults, incidence is estimated to be 3.5 per 1000 per year in women and 0.8 per 1000 per year in men. Incidence may be as high as 6% in the Appalachian region. In the Colorado Thyroid Disease Prevalence Study, involving 25,862 adults, the prevalence of elevated TSH in symptomatic and asymptomatic adults was 9.5%, with a greater percentage of those involved being women. The prevalence of hypothyroidism and of thyroid disease in general increases with age. http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/120937-overview I also have other autoimmune diseases.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 04:52PM - edited Mar 22, 2014 04:54PM by leaf If I had a lump, I'd much, much, much rather have a lump with a mammogram and ultrasound that showed nothing, than a mammogram and ultrasound that showed something suspicious.   The more 'negatives' (nothings) you get on imaging, the less likely it is that it is breast cancer.  Breast imaging is not 100% accurate (meaning it only detects breast cancer) nor is it 100% sensitive (meaning it picks up every case of breast cancer.)  I've seen figures thrown around that mammograms are about 80% sensitive and they are something like <20% accurate.  Since your ultrasound came out negative, that means the lump is unlikely to be a cyst, since ultrasounds are usually good at picking up cysts.  That means the next most likely thing is probably the benign fibroadenomas.  I don't know how old you are, but fibroadenomas are very,very common in younger women, but still do occur in older women.   Since you can feel the lump, probably the next step might either be an MRI, or a fine needle biopsy (which often can be done in a quick office procedure.)  If you are quite young, they may or may not recommend biopsy.  Breast cancer is quite unusual in younger women.  If you are concerned, which it sounds like you are, then you can push for either more imaging or a biopsy of some kind. If they don't want to do a fine needle biopsy or MRI, then there are also core needle biopsies, which use a needle of a larger diameter.  But I'd much, much rather face a biopsy with a negative mammogram and negative ultrasound than a biopsy with a positive mammogram and/or positive ultrasound.  That means your chances of it being benign are much larger. Remember, overall, about 80% of biopsies are benign.  That's a big number.

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 10:38AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:28AM by leaf Well, I have LCIS and ALH, but I don't have any DCIS.  (I had an excision, and ALH was found at a subsequent biopsy a year after my LCIS.) LCIS and ALH, at least alone, do put one at increased risk of bilateral breast cancer.   I don't think there is any concensus about DCIS with ALH,but I could find these Pubmed articles. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20727142 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16... The NCCN guidelines for LCIS (which most people think have maybe double the risk of ALH) are yearly mammograms and exams every 6-12 months, unless you are at higher risk, such as have a significant family history. nccn.com/images/patient-guidel...

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 02:49AM - edited May 4, 2008 02:57AM by leaf Once you are through the excisional biopsy and it is benign, statistically, your chances of breast cancer go down. There is less information about atypia at a younger age. In one recent paper, it looked at MRI screening for women with LCIS and atypical hyperplasia. In a 6 year study, of 125 women with atypia (ADH or ALH) and 252 with LCIS, 3 of the atypia patients and 11 of the LCIS patients got DCIS or worse. If you just stick these numbers in a calculator, this ends up being about 0.4% per year for atypia, and about 0.7% per year for LCIS. (Port et all, Ann Surg Oncol 14(3) 1051-1057 (2007) www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... The age of the women in this study was 25-74. The youngest woman with atypia who got 'anything worse' was 56, and the youngest woman with LCIS who got 'anything worse' was 39. If you take these numbers and multiply them by your lifespan, if you expect to live until age 80, then (obviously making a whole lot of assumptions), (80-24) x 0.4 = about a 22% lifetime risk for breast cancer, which is about 1 in 5. (This is making lots of assumptions.) You can also stick your numbers into the Gail model. www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ But do be aware how much uncertainty there is about the Gail model. The Gail model pretty accurately predicts how many women in a population will get breast cancer. But it is really lousy at predicting which INDIVIDUAL women will get breast cancer - to make clinical decisions about any particular patient. If you look in hindsight and compare the Gail model scores of individual women who ended up having breast cancer, and individual women who ended up NOT having breast cancer, their Gail model scores were usually only slightly different- the breast cancer woman had a higher score less than 60% of the time. So it isn't good at predicting if YOU will get breast cancer. ***** Then the question of getting BRCA testing. It will depend on your family history, and what your family tree looks like. If you have fewer people in your family tree, and fewer women, then it may be valuable to get your family tree evaluated by a board certified genetics counselor. Here are some recommendations about genetic testing, from a different thread in this forum. This study says that families with a truncated family tree need to incorporate this uncertainty in the decision. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... These are the guidelines for BRCA testing by the US Preventative Task Force. www.guideline.gov/summary/summ...

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 05:12PM leaf wrote: When they see a 'lesion' (don't you love the term?), they often try more than one method of looking at it (usually mammo, ultrasound and/or MRI).  If they see something suspicious, they use the imaging technique that will give the best view of the lesion.  For example, most  microcalcifications show up well in mammography.  So if you have a suspicious set of microcalcifications, they probably  will use stereotactic mammogram-guided biopsy.  If it shows up better on ultrasound, they will use an ultrasound guided biopsy. So one is not more accurate than another.  They use the one where the lesion shows up best.  That is often different for each individual lesion. Don't assume you need treatment until you get the biopsy results.  One person I know gets a written copy of her pathology report (eventually) , even if everything is just fine.  I think that's a good strategy.

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 11:11AM - edited Oct 13, 2009 11:47AM by leaf After my breast excision (I was diagnosed with LCIS, which in spite of the name just puts me at higher risk for breast cancer), I thought I found a shadow on my breast.  I wasn't sure. The only thing the nurse practitioner could see was my nipples seemed to be pointing in different directions.  I got a sonogram.  LCIS puts you at higher risk for ILC (sometimes known as the sneaky one).  Eventually, I had a biopsy, which showed scar tissue. If you have not had surgery, its pretty unlikely you have scar tissue.  I had scar tissue inches from my excision - my surgeon must have gone all over my breast. She later said that when she went in for my excision, she would have been looking at any 'pulling' in the tissue. Wrongdiagnosis.com lists 7 potential causes of breast dimpling. www.wrongdiagnosis.com/symptom...  (and I'm sure there could be others). I know we all want to be ready for whatever is ahead for us, so we tend to think about the worst case scenario.   I can't tell you what the doctor will recommend, of course.  No imaging is 100% accurate or sensitive; as you probably know, they have to look at a piece of tissue before you get diagnosed with breast cancer.  I'm not certain what you've had done, but if your mammo is negative, they might order an ultrasound (sonogram).   If that is negative, they may order an MRI or biopsy.   Biopsies can be expensive, but can give you the most accurate picture (if they get the right area.)  Pursue this until YOU are satisfied with your answers.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 08:05PM - edited Oct 5, 2012 08:15PM by leaf I had a paternal grandmother who only had 4 sons, no daughters, and she had breast cancer with bilateral mastectomies.  I ended up getting referred to a board certified genetics counselor.  It took a lot of work to get the information from one of her sons, but it ended up my paternal grandmother's cancer was when she was over 50. This was in the early 1950s, so this was probably before the age of chemotherapy (hence the bilateral mastectomies).  A maternal aunt also had postmenopausal breast cancer. I am not Ashkenazi Jewish, nor is there any male breast cancer history in my family.  I had a sister who never had breast cancer. I was told that my chance of having a BRCA mutation was low, about 2% of the people like me.  My family has more than the usual amount of cancer, but probably not BRCA.   On my genetics family tree information, they didn't ask for any information about cousins; only grandparents, parents, uncles and aunts, sibs, children, neices and nephews.  This was in 2006, so perhaps things may be different now and other places might do it differently, but I'd be surprised.    (I had my genetics consult at an NCI-certified center by a  board-certified genetics counselor.  That's what places like FORCE recommend:  www.facingourrisk.org/info_res...   Subsequently, I've had 2 female cousins and another aunt who got postmenopausal breast cancer. But remember, overall, about 13% of women will get breast cancer some time in their lifetime, my cousins were over 50, and I have a lot of female cousins. Here's what the USPTF recommended for BRCA testing;  this assumes you have a 'usual' family tree. www.uspreventiveservicestaskfo... Of course, the only people really qualified to evaluate your family tree are board-certified genetics counselors, and I'm definitely not qualified. I chose to not be BRCA tested; I'd have to pay out of pocket and my risk was low. Bessie is totally right.  Only about 15% of women who get breast cancer are thought to get breast cancer because of a single deleterious mutation.  About 70% of women who get breast cancer have no obvious causes for breast cancer (besides being a woman.)

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 08:22AM - edited Jul 27, 2008 10:42AM by leaf This is the best website I have found about understanding MRIs (though I certainly don't understand all of it.)  health.howstuffworks.com/mri.htm  It doesn't mention what T2 is, but it sounds like it can be the 'relaxation time'.** I'm totally guessing**, but I think T1 and T2 are MRI  adjustments or ways of looking at the tissue with MRI. I think usually when they write reports like this, they say exactly what they see.  For example, in plain English, they might say of a mammo that there are white spots here and a shadow there.  They can't say whether or not it is cancerous or benign, because they don't have that information. The only way they can for sure diagnose breast cancer is by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. Dr. Susan Love, in her book, describes  breast imaging like this: Its like seeing your friend Mary from the back.  You know that its probably Mary because she is about the same height as Mary, has the same hair color as Mary, is wearing the kind of clothes that Mary usually wears, but you won't really know that its Mary until she turns around and you can see her face. If you see a person that is a foot taller than Mary, then you know its almost certainly not Mary. We can't biopsy everyone because we simply don't have the resources. You won't know for sure what a diagnosis is unless you look at a piece of tissue under the microscope.  Going through all this diagnostic stuff is awful.  We're here for you.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 09:56AM - edited Nov 19, 2008 10:03AM by leaf Oh Kimber - I'm so sorry this had to happen to you!  I know you are very scared.   I wouldn't worry too much about the article.  It isn't exactly accurate.  For one, the article says that women with BRCA 1 or 2 have an 80% chance of getting breast cancer.   That just isn't true. This is a direct quote from the NCI website.  They didn't even quote the website THEY were citing correctly. "According to estimates of lifetime risk, about 13.2 percent (132 out of 1,000 individuals) of women in the general population will develop breast cancer, compared with estimates of 36 to 85 percent (360-850 out of 1,000) of women with an altered BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene. " http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/factsheet/Risk/BRCA They should have said UP TO 85%.   Some of the people with BRCA have a 36% lifetime risk of breast cancer.  That's different than 85%. The article you cited said that BRCA women had "And in women younger than age 40 without the BRCA mutations, but with a very strong family history, the risk is about 15 times higher than the general population, according to the Canadian researchers." but we ALREADY know that BRCA women have breast cancer at an earlier age, and the risk of breast cancer in the normal population before the age of 40 is quite low- the AVERAGE age to get breast cancer is in one's early 60s.   You have to beVERY CAREFUL with statistics.  When somebody says they have 15 times the general population- well, you know that CAN'T be right because the NCI says the risk for an average woman is 13%, and 13x15 is MORE THAN 100%, which of course isn't possible.  When they say 15 times, the researcher probably means 13 times 3-5% which might be 45-65%. I can't remember  what your family history is like, but if you have a significant family history, I would really encourage you to talk to a board certified genetics counselor. I had a horrible experience with wire insertion too.  People shouldn't have experiences like this!!!!!! Holding you in the light, Kimber.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2015 04:15PM leaf wrote: I am definitely not a genetics counselor or physician. I totally agree with Ddw79: discuss your situation with your GC. I think an excellent question is not only what is your lifetime risk, but also how well do they know that number (in your case 26.3% I assume.) I was diagnosed with classic LCIS about 10 years ago. When I saw an oncologist, he said my lifetime risk was about 30-40%. That's about what my genetics counselor said (~ 10 years ago.) I was told I have a BRCA risk about the same as an average Ashkenazi Jewish woman. My family history is somewhat better than yours: Postmenopausal (after the age of 50): paternal grandmother, several maternal aunts; post genetic counseling I have also had 1 postmenopausal cousin and one premenopausal cousin diagnosed with dc. I found one paper that described LCIS as 'high risk' and in another part of the same paper 'medium risk'. They still have not decided whether or not LCIS women should get MRI screening, even though of course 30% and 40% are more than 20%. (LCIS is an unusual condition.) I have not had any further breast diagnoses worse than classic LCIS. If the GC determines your risk of a BRCA mutation is relatively low, then do know that the science of breast cancer risk prediction is in its infancy. See this paper for comparing how well the modified Gail model did, which is not very good for individuals. The modified Gail model does really well for seeing how many women in a GROUP will get bc, but it does LOUSY for predicting whether ONE PARTICULAR woman (for example, you) will get bc. http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/98/23/1673.... . (Lousy is my adjective - the modified Gail model is right about 60% of the time and wrong about 40% of the time for the general population. Notice that the toss of an honest coin would be 50% heads and 50% tails.) In the paper they say perhaps an exception may be for women with a single inherited mutation, such as BRCA.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 12:03PM - edited Jul 11, 2011 12:05PM by leaf I had 'suspicious calcificatios', and on my core biopsy, they found LCIS and ALH.  This is unusual.  (There are about 7 times more cases of DCIS than LCIS.) Unfortunately, pathology terminology can change over time, and one pathologist can have a different opinion than another about criteria especially for non-invasive conditions. Here's a 2003 article on columnar cell atypia with and without hyperplasia. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/artic... Its just one pathologist's view.  Here's a Stanford pathologist's view. http://surgpathcriteria.stanford.edu/breast/flat_epithelial_atypia/ This website claims that there is no significant increased risk of breast cancer  - I assume after lumpectomy (citing a 2008 paper). http://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/breastcolumnarcelllesion.html I don't know exactly what the size of my lumpectomy was (it took out maybe 2 tablespoonfulls), but while I was at the hospital for about 12 hours (because my surgeon had a family emergency), I went to work 24 hours after I left the hospital.  They had given me conscious sedation during the lumpectomy; if I was to do this again, I'd probably feel better  if I had taken that day off. I had hematomas, so my breast turned all sorts of beautiful autumnal colors (black,purple, green, yellow) which faded over time.  I wore 'breast supports' (thin wire breast plates that looked like I was in a Wagnerian opera) for about a week.  I resumed jogging about 1 week later.  Jogbras were very helpful to me. Jiggling hurt. Tiny ice packs were better for me than pain meds.   I found the wire insertion (mammo-guided wire insertion) very difficult, but l have a history of trauma and anxiety issues.  I did a survey here, and more than 1/2 of the people found the wire insertion tolerable (pain score <=4/10).  Since everyone has a different history, personality, and anatomy, I would only advise that *****IF****** you have pain, complain.  I did not, and I'm sure that would have improved my situation immensely.  During the wire insertion, I was told 'I was not to move a muscle during the procedure', and it lasted ?1.5 hours.  At my place, they did not allow IV anesthesia during the procedure since they don't have an RN present. You are right: they are mainly doing the lumpectomy to make sure there isn't 'something worse' going on in the area. I didn't have an MRI before my lumpectomy, but it was almost 6 years ago.  I think it is much more common for women to have an MRI before lumpectomy so they can plan their surgery better if there are things that light up on MRI.  MRIs are not cheap, so if you do decide to ask for one, you may want to inquire if your insurance would pay for them.  Some women pay some $3-7K out of pocket for them when their insurance does not cover, and I want you to at least be prepared if that's the route you want to go.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 11:51PM leaf wrote: Different studies do differ.  In this study,they found no displaced cells. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18365811 In this study, they found about 65% had displaced cells.  www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17...  Some studies found possible seeding, and some found none.  http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16684314 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16502019 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15135480 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12...  The big question is whether these cells live after displacement and treatment.  All of the studies I've seen document possible cases of seeding in terms of case reports or a few cases; they are not recorded in terms of %, so the risk is not high. If you are concerned, then I think its reasonable, if the biopsy does turn out to be positive for cancer, to either opt for mastectomy, get the needle track excised, and/or get definitive therapy such as radiation.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2014 12:43PM leaf wrote: Overall, only about 15% of breast cancers are found to be due to inherited single gene mutations.  That means that about 85% of breast cancers are 'sporatic'. Unless you have had chest irradiation (such as for Lymphoma, which can't be a huge group of women), most women with breast cancer do not know why they (as individuals) got breast cancer.   The main risk factors you hear about, such as dense breasts or higher alcohol intake, aren't big enough factors to separate a woman with breast cancer from a woman without breast cancer.  Most breast cancers have been in the breast for some 4-10 years (not a typo) before they can be detected by _any_ means.  There are breast cancers that grow faster, but they are usually unusual breast cancers like inflammatory breast cancer (and you don't have the symptoms for that.) At my first biopsy, for suspicious calcifications, I was laughing at the techs and doctors, because I thought it was silly they were suspecting that _I_ had breast cancer.  I thought that the only women who got breast cancer were women who ignore their breast lumps.  Needless to say, that's not true.   I won't give you any advice because most who post here are who were in the unlucky 20% who did get breast cancer at their biopsy.   So, for them, it was important to get biopsied.    Another way of looking at your choice is: if your doctors are giving you the option of whether to biopsy or not, then there's no strict right answer, and whatever you do (whether its an 'informed decision' or not) will be the right choice for you.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2010 02:18PM - edited Apr 2, 2010 02:44PM by leaf The only Pubmed article I could find addressed dentists. It said Dentist cancer mortality and incidence generally showed a favourable risk pattern for lung cancer and overall cancer occurrence. Nevertheless, several studies reported an increased risk for certain cancers, such as those of the skin and, to a lesser extent, the brain and female breast. These elevated risks may be related to social status or education level, or may alternatively represent the impact of hazards in the workplace. The evidence for an increased mortality or cancer incidence risk among dentists must be interpreted in light of methodological limitations of published studies. Future studies of dentists would benefit from the assessment of specific occupational exposures rather than relying on job title alone. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17... This about occupational exposures: Despite weaknesses in certain individual studies, we consider the evidence linking the increased risk of several types of cancer with specific exposures somewhat strengthened by recent publications, among them brain cancer from exposure to non-ionizing radiation, particularly radiofrequency fields emitted by mobile telephones; breast cancer from exposure to the pesticide dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) before puberty; leukemia from exposure to 1,3-butadiene; lung cancer from exposure to air pollution; non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) from exposure to pesticides and solvents; and prostate cancer from exposure to pesticides, polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), and metal working fluids or mineral oils. In addition to NHL and prostate cancer, early findings from the National Institutes of Health Agricultural Health Study suggest that several additional cancers may be linked to a variety of pesticides. Our report also briefly describes the toxicological evidence related to the carcinogenic effect of specific chemicals and mechanisms that are difficult to study in humans, namely exposures to bis-phenol A and epigenetic, trans-generational effects. To underscore the multi-factorial, multi-stage nature of cancer, we also present a technical description of cancer causation summarizing current knowledge in molecular biology. We argue for a new cancer prevention paradigm, one based on an understanding that cancer is ultimately caused by multiple interacting factors rather than a paradigm based on dubious attributable fractions. www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18...

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 03:51PM leaf wrote: I think its fairly routine.  They are probably starting the MRI-process a bit 'ahead of time' because they are (hopefully) checking with your insurance to see if it will be covered.  Mammogram, ultrasound, and MRI are usually the 3 imaging types that are done for most breast cancers.  They are doing all these non-invasive imaging in hopes to avoid doing a biopsy, which is invasive. Of course you're scared.  Anybody would be scared.  They will review all the imaging, then decide whether or not your imaging is worrisome enough to have a biopsy. You normally can't be diagnosed with breast cancer without a pathologist looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope.   I felt 'this is crazy' too, when I was going through being diagnosed.  At the first attempt at an ultrasound biopsy, I was laughing all the way through because I thought it was ridiculous they should suspect that *I* might get breast cancer.   I thought the only women who get breast cancer are women who ignore their lumps.  I  learned I was wrong.  And I'm a hospital pharmacist. (And I don't have 'real' breast cancer either, but that's a long and irrelevant story.)  I had 'suspicious calcifications' and no lump. I have a colleague, who is near 60, who has had at least 10 'callbacks' for mammograms, and has NEVER had a breast biopsy, and is A-OK. Here's a diagram of the diagnostic process.  Its a little old (2001), but the numbers are still roughly the same. www.imaginis.com/breast-health...  Hang in there.   We're here for you.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 12:23PM - edited Jun 18, 2008 09:51AM by leaf Many women here feel 'the best lump is the lump in the jar' - in other words go for biopsy. There are plusses and minuses to ANYthing. For needle biopsy: Some of the minuses: a) There will be a charge for this procedure and for the pathologist to prepare and read it. b) There is a VERY SMALL chance it may cause some sort of scarring internally. I think the chances are VERY SMALL, but possible. c) It may not be totally painless, but most women don't feel it is too bad. d) It is possible to miss the lump, or not get a good sample. e) You will have to wait a few days for the results. f) There is a very small risk of infection. Some of the positives: a) You will have a much better chance to know exactly what you are dealing with. You won't have to wait in agony for 3 or 6 or 9 months wondering what this is. Biopsy is much more reliable than breast imaging. There are MANY fewer risks to ultrasound. Minuses: a) It will take about 1 hour of your time, and may cost a few hundred dollars. b) It is not 100% accurate - it is simply ' more info'. Plusses: a) I found it very comfortable-at my place they use warm ultrasound gel, and the slowly press a wand across your breast. b) It is good at detecting fluid-filled things, like cysts, which are usually benign. I have had an ultrasound-guided core biopsy, and a mammogram-guided core biopsy. I bled after my 2nd mammo-guided core biopsy, but it wasn't distressing. They gave me plenty of local anesthetic. My breast looked black and blue after the 2nd one, but it went away after several weeks. It returned to its normal color in a few weeks/months. It is YOUR choice what you want to do. Because your mom has breast cancer, and because it is a lump, I would vear towards getting it ultrasounded and/or biopsied. But I'm a Nervous Nellie, and am at higher risk. It is YOUR choice. If you definitely do NOT want to have these procedures, you don't have to have them. But I'd have to have a REALLY GOOD reason for not doing these.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 05:44AM leaf wrote: Could it have turned into cancer?  Could is a very big word.  Could a meteorite fall on your head while you read this?  Could all the oxygen move to the other side of the room, suffocating you?  Yes, to all.  I'm *NOT* trying to make fun of your anxiety. The chances of fcc turning into cancer are probably larger than a meteorite landing on your head, but the increased incidence of breast cancer is women with fcc is small- its hard to measure. There is a lot we don't understand about the development of breast cancer.  There is a lot we don't understand about who will get breast cancer. There is a lot we don't know about the statistics of breast cancer. Since about 60% of women have fibrocystic breasts, and in the USA roughly 13% of the general population will get breast cancer sometime in their lives,  many women with fibrocystic breasts will be part of this 13%.  But many people who *don't* have fcc on a biopsy will get breast cancer, and, of course, many women get breast cancer who have never had a breast biopsy so we don't know what is in their breast. If you have atypical cells in a breast biopsy, this is an adjective that will put you at a measurable increase in breast cancer risk. Even *if* you have atypical cells, then numbers get thrown around that your lifetime risk of breast cancer is about 15-20%, which is an increase from the average 13% of the normal population.   Even if a surgeon recommends a biopsy (which hasn't happened yet), overall about 80% of biopsies are benign.  That's a pretty large number.  So the chances of this being breast cancer are quite small.  If you are postmenopausal and have a new lump, then you might have a somewhat higher chance of having breast cancer than if you are premenopausal.  But still, the chances are very large this is nothing to be concerned about. The only connection that I know of between cervical dysplasia and breast cancer is that both can be influenced by hormones, specifically estrogen.  But, of course, all women have some estrogen running around in their bodies.  Having certain viruses (such as HPV) are a risk factor to have cervical cancer, but since women's estrogen levels vary all over the place, and cervical cancer grows very, very slowly, this is very difficult to measure. So, to sum up, from what you have said, *if* you have any increased risk of breast cancer, its probably so small its not measurable.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 03:37PM leaf wrote: There are unfortunately a lot of unknowns about breast cancer.  There is hardly anything about breast cancer that is 100%.   I have read posts here of women who were diagnosed with breast cancer within a month of having clean imaging.  It is unusual, but possible.  There are people who have had negative mammo, ultrasound, and MRI, that had a thickening, that had breast cancer.   But that is very uncommon.   I have LCIS, which is usually considered a more 'advanced' stage than atypical hyperplasia.  They certainly don't know for sure, because they don't know how many women are walking around that have atypical hyperplasia, or LCIS, and don't know it.  Atypical hyperplasia or LCIS are usually not detectable on mammogram, ultrasound, MRI, or palpation (though it can be.) It is usually just found on biopsy. My risk for breast cancer has been estimated at everything between 10% and (with a breast cancer calculator that has NOT been compared to populations) 85%.  But probably a good ballpark figure would be a lifetime risk about 30% or around 0.5-1%/year. Most women with BRCA are estimated to have a lifetime risk between 40-90%.   Most figures I've seen for atypical hyperplasia are roughly half that of LCIS, maybe 15-25%? Its not known if a bad family history increases that risk, as far as I know. Some risk factors are additive, and some are not.  This means, for example, if your risk from factor A was 10% and your risk from factor B was 20%, your overall risk might be 30%, or 20%, or 10%, or some other number.  If your risk factors were additive, they'd be 30%, but that is NOT always the case. The 'average' woman in the US has a lifetime chance of getting breast cancer of about 10-12%.  Risk factor calculators, such as that published by the NCI , are good for calculating the risk in a POPULATION, but are 'only slightly better than the roll of a dice' for calculating *YOUR* risk as an individual. http://www.cancer.gov/bcrisktool/ http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/98/23/1673.pdf Its because we really don't know the characteristics that clearly separate women who have had breast cancer from those that have not.   About 70% of women who are diagnosed with breast cancer have *no* obvious risk factors for getting breast  cancer, other than being a woman.

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 12:00PM - edited Sep 16, 2009 12:01PM by leaf According to your note 'such active breasts usually lead to cancer'.  That does not mean 100%. The women who are highest risk of a new primary breast cancer (who have no history of breast cancer) are women who have a BRCA mutation.  These women have about a 60-85% lifetime chance of getting breast cancer.  I would consider getting a 2nd opinion, and seeing what other breast surgeons feel about your situation.   Surgeons are known for having horrible bedside manners.  As one onco-psychiatrist said, you can't expect the person that takes you apart and puts you together again to be touchy-feely.  You may have to go to someone else for that.  But no one can know for sure what will happen  -no one has a crystal ball.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 12:24PM - edited Feb 19, 2012 12:33PM by leaf I haven't had fibroadenomas, but *if* you do choose to get it removed surgically, that doesn't *automatically* mean that your breast pain will resolve.  It may, but it may not. Pain is a really complicated subject. I think a lot is unknown about breast pain.   http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/breast-pain/DS00760/DSECTION=causes If they surgically remove the fibroadenoma, then your surgery will probably not be as extensive as those who undergo breast cancer surgery (certainly they won't look for any lymph nodes), but, for example in this paper of chronic pain after breast *cancer* surgery, a significant number of patients had chronic pain (presumably from surgery and/or breast cancer treatment). www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...  Your chances of breast pain after breast surgery are almost certainly not this high since fibroadenoma removal would not involve any further treatments or lymph node removal.  I don't quickly see if they provided information about how many women had breast pain *before* their breast surgery. Other options for fibroadenoma removal include cryoablation (freezing the adenoma) ww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12433600 and vacuum assisted biopsy.www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19...  I can't dig up much information about breast pain after these procedures other  than what the abstract says.  There also may not be anyone in your area doing these procedures. I didn't know this before my breast surgery, but breast scarring does not only include how your breast looks on the outside.  Internal breast scarring makes it harder to see(mammograms, etc)  what is going on (for routine breast cancer surveillance) in the future. So there are *many* factors involved in whether or not to have surgery.  You will make the right decision for you after consultation with your doctor.

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 09:22AM - edited Jul 16, 2008 09:24AM by leaf Probably the 1:00 and 11:00 are how the radiologist is describing the location of the 'suspicious lesions'.  (Don't you love their terminology?) If you look at the breast like the doctor would be looking at yours, with your nipple at the center of a clock, then 12 o'clock would be straight up from your nipple, towards your face.  This is not describing how deep (how far between your skin surface and your chest wall.) Your surgeon should discuss things with you.  (Some surgeons are better at this than others...) You don't talk about lumps, so I assume it may be calcifications.   There are 3 main types of biopsies: a) fine needle biopsy: they take a fine needle and sample the 'area of concern'. b) core biopsy: they take a larger needle, and take samples about the diameter of a cooked spaghetti noodle.  c) excisional biopsy: they usually only do this if there is a big lump to be removed, or you already have some cancer diagnosed. Cosmetically, it will also depend on how big your breast is, and how much they remove.  I have a B cup, and I've had 3 core biopsies and  1 excisional biopsy.  I had a slight dent from my excisional (had about 6 cores the size of a spaghetti noodle removed), but it filled in over time.  I went back to work 24 hours after having my excisional biopsy.  For my core biopsies, I had them done in the late morning, and went to work on the graveyard shift that night. Unless your lesion is on the chest wall, they won't be touching any chest muscles.   If I were you, I'd like to see my lesion on the ultrasound. Remember, overall 80% of biopsies turn out benign.  The mean age to get breast cancer is 64. Its good that you are getting it checked out!
Posts.Title: Biopsy question... Journey Journey

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 09:02AM - edited Jul 22, 2008 09:03AM by leaf These imaging reports usually say exactly what they see, spots that are dark and spots that are light.  So if they were making a report about your avatar, they might say something like 'See woman in blue and white top with dark hair, 2 eyes, and arms held slightly out from sides." The ultrasound sends sound waves off tissue, and sees how well these waves bounce back.Its just saying it sees some internal, irregular echos- not smooth tissue.  (NOTE: I do NOT know what is 'normal'.)  In many ultrasounds they say they see hypoechoic areas, which just means whatever is there, the ultrasound waves didn't bounce off the lesion as much as regularly (hypo meaning less). They do NOT know if this is cancer. The only sure way they have of diagnosing breast cancer is by looking at a piece of tissue under the microscope. I have not read your previous posts, so hopefully they will be contacting you whether they think you should be biopsied, or have an MRI.  The Birads scoring system  (at least for mammos) is Birads3: probably benign (<2% cancer) Birads 4: suspicious abnormality: not characteristic of breast cancer, but a reasonable probability of being malignant. Birads 5: lesion that has a high probability of being malignant (95%).  Remember, even if you get to the biopsy stage, 80% of biopsies are benign.  That's a big number. Good for you for getting the US report!
