Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 09:44AM - edited Nov 4, 2008 09:51AM by leaf For the wire insertion, they use the imaging where the 'area of concern' shows up best.  So if they found your breast mass by ultrasound, they will use ultrasound for the wire insertion.  Mine showed up on mammogram, so I had a mammogram-guided wire insertion. They may or may not give you an injectable local anesthetic before the wire insertion. At my place, the radiologists insert the wire.  At my place, they can't give you IV sedation for the wire insertion because they don't have RNs in attendance. They only had the radiologist and the radiology tech. I had to be on NPO (nothing by mouth) status as of midnight the night before, so even if I had been very anxious, any oral seditative I would have taken at midnight would have worn off by the time I had the wire insertion at about noon. If you have pain, complain. People vary widely as far as their experiences with wire insertion.  Most (the majority) find it tolerable, but some have a more difficult time.You may want to ask the radiologist beforehand what (s)he wants you to do in the unlikely event you do have pain.They had to run in and out of the room a lot, because they had to develop the mammograms.  They shouldn't have to do that for ultrasound - it should be a lot faster and more comfortable with ultrasound. Then a while later (for me it was about 3 hours because my surgeon had a family emergency), you will go in to surgery.  They started an IV then because they would have doctors and nurses in attendance. I had conscious sedation.  That means I was semi-aware while it was going on.  Every time I tried to say anything at all, the anesthesiologist gave me more sedative. It was an outpatient procedure.  I went in at about 9am, and I got out of the recovery room about 8pm.   Under normal circumstances, you could cut at least 6 hours out of that time period, because there were numerous delays (emergencies, etc.). Bring an old book or whatever to entertain yourself as you wait.  If you want to bring an iPod, ask first.  You will be not functioning during surgery, so there may be a risk of losing it during that time.... Beforehand, make sure you have a tight bra (like a jogbra). The type that opens in the front is particularly handy, because you don't have to contort to get it on. I also liked TINY ice packs.  You will be swollen after surgery.   I wore my jogbra 24/7 for about 2 weeks (except for doing the laundry and showers.)  I went back to work 24 hours after release from the recovery room.  (I work the graveyard shift.)  If I did it again, I might want to take an additional day off.  I found tiny ice packs controlled the weird sensations a lot better than pain meds did....but everyone is different. I didn't have any armpit surgery, so you may want some extra leeway for that.  There are women who have had outpatient mastectomies.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 10:32AM - edited Jun 26, 2013 12:41PM by leaf Unfortunately, they can't reliably remove all ALH.  Why?  Because ALH (and LCIS) are normally found on biopsy incidentally when they are looking at something else.  Often (not always), a mammogram will show suspicious microcalcifications.  Often (not always) in the people that get diagnosed with ALH or LCIS, the ALH or LCIS are found not precisely at the site of the microcalcifications (or other abnormality they find), but adjacent to it. They know that LCIS is often multifocal (in other words, there are usually multiple spots of it in a breast), and is often (not always) bilateral, meaning it occurs in both breasts.  I assume this is the case with ALH too.  (I have both LCIS and ALH.)  So, if they were going to try to 'remove all the LCIS and ALH', they would have to sample every part of both breasts (to find the parts that were normal and which had ALH or LCIS), which, in effect, is a mastectomy. In addition, they don't know if the ALH and/or LCIS is the 'bad thing' that is happening in the breast.  What does that mean?  It means that of the women that, after a diagnosis of LCIS, go on in future years to get invasive breast cancer, the invasive breast cancer is often (not always)  in an area that looked totally normal on imaging, *not* at the areas that have known LCIS.  So that's why they think that *some* LCIS is not actually a precursor to breast cancer, but is a marker for something else that puts you at an increased risk of breast cancer.  If you were magically able to remove all the LCIS spots and leave the normal spots in the breast, we may have decreased the breast cancer risk, but maybe not so much.  They can't do this experiment, of course, because we have no way of knowing what areas in the breast have ALH or LCIS without biopsying them.  They have done experiments to see when invasive breast cancer is diagnosed at the same time as LCIS, if the two are genetically related.  Sometimes they are, but sometimes they are not. BTW, if you choose to do 'watchful waiting' (i.e. followed closely), you may, or may not, just do mammos.  For LCIS, which is normally thought to be of higher risk than ALH, the NCCN recommends once yearly mammograms, and twice-a-year clinical exams, and that's it.  That's what I get, and I have classic LCIS and ALH.http://www.nccn.com/files/cancer-guidelines/breast/index.html#/60/ There is a wide variety of opinion as to the increased risk of ALH.  If you have a weak family history (in other words, don't meet the usual guidelines for BRCA testing www.uspreventiveservicestaskfo... then the usual opinions are that the lifetime risk of breast cancer for a woman with ALH is *roughly* say 20% (as opposed to 13% lifetime risk for the 'average' US woman.)  I have seen estimates of anywhere between '10% and 60%' for me, with my ALH and LCIS.  (My weak family history includes bc in one paternal grandmother, 3 maternal aunts, all postmenopausal, 2 maternal cousins, one premenopausal.) No one can make a decision for you.  It is your body, and it not only depends on your specific circumstances, it also includes how much anxiety each of the choices entail for you.  Each choice entails upsides and downsides.  There is no rush to make your  choice.  There is no one good choice that fits everyone's circumstances.
Posts.Title: Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia-minute focus what's the relevance Scaredandworried concernmom

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 02:29PM - edited Jul 11, 2009 02:37PM by leaf I was concerned about metal allergies before my core biopsy.  Even surgical steel earrings make my earlobes swell, turn red, and give off this lovely serous fluid. Gold and silver earrings are OK for me.  I hadn't tried titanium. They said my first core biopsy was too obvious to put in a titanium marker, but I had one in for my 2nd and 3rd biopsies. I've had no trouble with them. Titanium allergies supposedly can occur http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18992567 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17873538 but they are exceedingly rare.
